HEADLINE: Facts Of Life;
More Than Inspiration Is Needed to Fight AIDS

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM

 BODY:
IN the 10 days since Magic Johnson announced that he is infected with the virus that causes AIDS, he has been courted by hundreds of health groups, invited by the President to serve on a commission and even asked to lend his name to a brand of condoms. Perfectly cast as an AIDS educator for the 1990's, he can hardly fail to do good. Yet those working frantically against the epidemic say it will take more than Magic to curb the insidious spread of HIV.
As AIDS becomes more deeply entrenched in the culture of poverty, inspiration alone can only help so much. Already, those answering Johnson's call to get tested for the virus may face months of waiting. Those who test positive and lack health insurance may find themselves in a three-month line just to see a doctor, let alone gain access to costly life-prolonging therapy. 
 Compared with the frenzy triggered by Rock Hudson's stunning disclosure of AIDS back in 1985, Johnson's announcement suggested just how far the country has come. Hudson hid his disease in shame almost to the end, speaking out only after reporters learned of his pitiful pilgrimage to Paris for an untested cure.
Johnson's open discussion of his infection with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, while he still stands healthy has been received with sadness, but also with a kind of national warmth, stoked by that wonderful smile. Within days Johnson's corporate sponsors, echoing President Bush, said they wanted a piece of Magic's new act. As a symbol, Johnson is easy to adopt. Attributing his infection to careless heterosexual promiscuity, he does not evoke the more uncomfortable but more pervasive faces of AIDS: homosexuality and drug use, poverty, homelessness and the spreading lack of access to health care.
As a black man and sports hero, Johnson will obviously be more credible with inner city youth than, say, Nancy Reagan with a message of "Just Say No" to drugs and unprotected sex. But a decade's experience shows that coaxing major behavior changes among those now most vulnerable to AIDS is devilishly hard. It depends not only on greater awareness but also on sustained, labor-intensive programs of education, counseling, HIV testing and medical care, not to mention costly, prolonged treatment for drug addicts.
"If because of Magic Johnson there is increased awareness and more people get tested, then we'll need more testing sites and we'll need more counselors," said Ronald Johnson, director of the Minority Task Force on AIDS in New York. "And then we have to provide a medical care delivery system."
Bound by the budget cap and an urgent need to increase funds for treatment of the sick, Congress expects, in the 1992 fiscal year, to reduce the $400 million Federal budget for AIDS education, testing and counseling by some $14 million. "We're being forced to choose between helping those with HIV and preventing new infections," said Jeffrey Levi, director of government affairs at the AIDS Action Council in Washington. "We shouldn't be making that choice."
Near-bankrupt state and city governments are in no shape to expand AIDS programs to keep up with the soaring needs. At the same time the White House, under pressure from conservatives, has killed two planned surveys of sexual behavior that would help tactical planning against the disease.
America's AIDS epidemic has entered what scientists call the "mature" phase, an agonizing long-term presence with a slowly shifting profile. The virus is no longer spreading explosively among gay men and drug users as it did in the late 1970's and early 1980's, infecting huge numbers before most realized what was happening. Largely because of that early sweep, Federal experts believe, perhaps one million living Americans carry HIV, an awesome personal and social tragedy that will play itself out over two decades or more. So far, 200,000 people have developed outright AIDS, according to the current definition of the disease, and more than 125,000 of them have died.
Now, perhaps 50,000 more people become infected with the virus each year, according to very rough estimates by the Centers for Disease Control. To describe who these people are is to describe the prevention challenge. Compared with the population as a whole, "the newly infected are much more likely to be people of color, much more likely to be residents of inner cities, much more likely to be economically disadvantaged," said Dr. James Allen, director of the National Aids Program at the Public Health Service.
They include teen-age boys discovering their homosexuality, not believing that even a single unprotected encounter may hold deadly risk. They include new recruits to the underworld of intravenous drug addicts, too desperate or self-destructive to faithfully use sterile needles. They include female crack addicts who trade their bodies for drugs. Increasingly they include homeless men and women, who may shoot drugs, prostitute themselves or both.
To a very minor degree they include men who, as Johnson says he did, receive the virus from one of a multitude of heterosexual partners. Far more they include women, mainly black or Hispanic, who are infected sexually by a husband, boyfriend or casual sex partner; women who, even when they suspect the danger, are often powerless to persuade their men to use condoms. And they include babies: some 1,500 to 2,000 born with the virus each year.
Fighting heterosexual spread, even knowing how to talk about it credibly, has posed special problems. Early on, some experts dismissed the risk as negligible. As more women came down with AIDS who were sex partners of drug addicts but insisted that they had never used needles themselves, and as evidence poured in from Africa, the threat began to seem less remote. On the other side, some who were out to gain attention and funds exaggerated the risk, evoking the improbable specter of a runaway national plague.
Actually, the Federal scientists who chart the epidemic have been quite consistent in their statements. AIDS is a sexually transmitted disease, they have long said, and heterosexual intercourse with an infected partner carries some risk, however small. The chance of transmission is vastly lower in vaginal than anal intercourse, studies have shown, and the virus passes much more easily from man to woman than the other way. Transmission is eased by the presence of venereal diseases such as syphilis.
In Sports Illustrated last week, Johnson denied rumors of homosexuality and said, "I am certain that I was infected by having unprotected sex with a woman who has the virus."
 
'No Wilt Chamberlain'
 "His announcement was a carefully staged event," observed Dr. Andrew Moss, an epidemiologist at the University of California at San Francisco. "I hope it's all true. People want to buy into his story, as President Bush already did. He can be so useful for those trying to deal with young black men and women."
One can only guess whether Johnson would have received the Presidential invitation, whether his commercial ties would have been reaffirmed, had he said that he used drugs or was a homosexual. Stars like him seem if anything to be venerated for their heterosexual exploits. Wilt Chamberlain hyped his recent autobiography with a ludicrous claim that he had slept with 20,000 women. Even discounting by a factor of 10, that would be tempting the normally slight chance of getting HIV. "I'm no Wilt Chamberlain," Johnson said, but "I was never at a loss for female companionship." There has been little public comment about the presumably innumerable women Johnson unknowingly placed in jeopardy.
An end to moralistic condemnations of people with HIV is vital to an attack on the epidemic. Still, the question remains: Will the adulation of Johnson, promiscuity and all, produce equal sympathy for the urban poor at risk of AIDS -- enough to overcome the stereotypes of promiscuity and recklessness that so often provide an excuse for not spending more tax dollars?
Voluntary testing for HIV is a cornerstone of prevention strategies, and Johnson has already encouraged those who have reason to worry to seek the test. The theory is that the sooner people learn of their infection, the sooner they can obtain helpful medical care. They also, experts believe, will be less likely to pass the virus to others. Even for the lucky ones who test negative, the agony of waiting for results may teach a chilling lesson.
But it is one thing to be tested if you have access to care, another if, like so many prospective AIDS victims, you are poor and uninsured. "The only thing society can offer in return for getting tested is good medical care," Dr. Moss said. "There's a kind of contract. We ask these people to get tested, to bring in their sex partners and to behave safely. And in return they should get anonymity and good care."
For many who are likely to spread HIV in the years ahead, society cannot keep its end of the bargain. All too often, poor people who test positive get a session of counseling and a list of phone numbers of overburdened public clinics. Many never get the expensive immune tests and drugs that can prolong their lives. In New York City clinics, "there can be a one- to four-month waiting list just for an initial appointment," said Ronald Johnson of the minority task force. "Then it takes all day at the clinic, so if you have a job you have to take the day off."
Many poor people with HIV infections do not qualify for Medicaid, the Federal-state insurance program, until -- in a horrible catch-22 -- they are declared "disabled" because they develop outright AIDS. Hence they may miss the irretrievable chance to stave off disease as long as possible.
"Without the proper followup services, testing becomes a hoax," Ronald Johnson said. "We are losing ground. The number of cases is growing faster than the funding."
 
 
 
THE LONG ROAD FROM HIV TO AIDS
 Who has AIDS? The definition has become a political as well as a medical question as people infected with the human immune deficiency virus, HIV, compete for treatment. For years, people weren't considered to have AIDS until they showed symptoms of certain infections and cancers that invade the body once the immune system breaks down. But after complaints that many ailing people were being excluded from the count, the Federal Center for Disease Control has begus revising its definition to include every infected person whose number of T4 helper cells, an important measure of immune-system strengh, has faller below 200 per cubic millimeter of blood; the normal; level is around 1,000. It has been estimated that the broader definition, which is expected to go into effect next year, will add 160,000 people to the current caseload of 200,000 classified as having AIDS.
AZT, DDI and other drugsmay prolong the lives of some of these patients. In the absence of treatment the path from HIV infection to AIDS commonly takes about 10 years, with death often following two years later. Though timing and other details vary widely, the following pattern is typical
 
Early stage: T4-cell count=1,000
5 Years
 
The HIV virus enters the bloodstream but antibodies cannot be detected for six weeks or in unusual cases a year or more. Even after testing positive, many people show no symptoms, though some briefly develop a disorder similar to mononucleosis with fatigue, fever, swollen glands and possibly a rash. These initial symptoms disappear, usually in a few weeks. As the virus quietly multiplies, most people continue to feel fine, though some have chronically swollen lymph nodes.
 
Middle stage: T4 cell count=500
5 Years
 
Though many people still have no symptoms, the number of T4 cells drops to about half the normal level. Treatment with AZT, DDI and other anti-viral drugs is recommended. As the infection progresses, skin tests show that another line of immunological defenses, called cell-mediated immunity, is also disintigrating.
 
Last stage: T4 cell count=200
2 Years
 
As the number of T4 cells is halved again, many people initially remain asymptomatic. But the risk that bacteria, viruses, fungi and parasites will take advantage of weakened immunity increases dramatically. to prevent one of the most common opportunistic infections, pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia, antibiotic treatment can begin. Early in this stage, some people suffer weight loss, diarrhea, lethargy and fevers. Also common are infections of the skin and mucous membranes, including a fungal infection called thrush, in which white spots and ulcers appear on the tongue and mouth, and chronic herpes simplex.
As the immune system collapse continues, the opportunistic diseases move deeper. The brain might be attacked by a parasitic infection called toxoplasmosis; the nervous system, liver, bones and skin by the cryptococcus fungus. Cytomegaloviris can cause pneumonia, encephalitis and blindness. The list goes on and on.

HEADLINE: THE REGION;
More Than Just Another Fiscal Crisis

BYLINE: By SAM ROBERTS

 BODY:
FOR fully a year now, maybe more, the New York region has been gripped by a crisis of unparalleled proportions. This one is no mere municipal or state fiscal crisis. It goes beyond yet another crisis of confidence in government. Instead, New Yorkers are frozen in the most numbing crisis of all: a crisis crisis.
The $7 billion deficit facing New York City over the next four years and the projected $3 billion gap in New York State's budget this year and next represent the latest chapters in what has emerged as a perpetual crisis. And because it has been so enduring, it has become routinized -- and so, arguably, has government's response. Despite the magnitude of the deficits and their potential to disrupt and to refashion the delivery of services, no climate of crisis prevails. 
 "Each succeeding crisis raises the threshold of what shocks New Yorkers," said Henry J. Stern, president of Citizens Union, a civic watchdog group, who often ratchets up the shock value of his oratory to get quoted. "Gaps would appear and then disappear, triumphantly closed. Now there appears to be a yawning gap. Crises must go into nine figures before they become a crisis."
Ten, actually. Maybe more.
Government's response seems to defy the very definition of crisis: a pivotal turning point with potentially profound consequences. The fiscal crisis has become a customary part of everyday life, creating what Mr. Stern calls the "Beirut Syndrome." Just as the daily shelling became a way of life for those living in Lebanon's capital, New Yorkers are bombarded with threats of thousands of layoffs that are somehow averted, doomsday warnings that zoos and swimming pools will have to be closed though they are spared at the last minute and apologies for lowering expectations about shrinking services that cost more.
Fiscal crises aren't new, but they used to be called panics or collapses or crashes -- names that connote immediacy and finality. Delivering his first State of the City speech in 1969, Mayor John V. Lindsay warned presciently of a grave fiscal crisis -- a phrase that gained greater currency and was invoked with greater accuracy six years later when bankers revoked the city's credit.
New York City's inability to borrow precipitated a cash crisis, which caused the city to miss payments on short-term notes -- a default that was euphemistically called a deferral. If annual but unredeemed warnings of impending doom had inured New Yorkers to the possibility that a real fiscal crisis would actually materialize in 1975, this one conformed to the definition. It marked a turning point and the consequences were severe: among them, thousands of layoffs of municipal employees, a subway fare increase, the imposition of tuition at the City University of New York and the loss of home rule to a state-imposed overseer.
Another legacy was that "the fiscal crisis" entered New York's political lexicon, a phrase that usually needed no date, just as "post-war" unambiguously referred for years to the period after World War II. Since then, though, it has become hackneyed. This year the term appeared in articles about the New York region in The New York Times an average of nearly every day. Since the stock market crash in 1987 and the ensuing recession, declining revenues have plunged New York -- and a growing number of other jurisdictions -- into a prolonged period of retrenchment that has reached crisis proportions, but without the defining moments that marked the fiscal crisis of 1975.
Moreover, official signals were sometimes conflicting. The debate in Albany seemed, at times, to suggest that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was being too pessimistic (as it turned out, he wasn't) while the Legislature was often rose-coloring its own economic forecasts. At City Hall, public perception was clouded by the Dinkins administration's sometimes confusing record and oratory. Mayor David N. Dinkins postponed police hiring as one of his first official acts last year, then announced an ambitious police hiring plan to which he has largely remained wedded, despite the city's deteriorating fiscal condition. His announcement of the plan was sandwiched in the same week between two seemingly contradictory events: a generous contract settlement with the teachers union and the threat that thousands of employees would be laid off to bridge a worsening deficit.
Last year, Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, which was created in 1975 to borrow on the city's behalf, contrasted the 1975 fiscal crisis with the latest "budget crisis." He lamented, though, that no single event had elevated the current problems to the critical point at which all of the players are driven to the bargaining table. City Hall suggested last week that Mr. Rohatyn's threat to withhold from the city budget a billion dollars that might be generated by a M.A.C. bond-refinancing represented an effort to create such a crisis in order to infuse relatively complacent perceptions with grim realities.
"We don't have a crisis," Mr. Rohatyn said last week. "What we have is a situation that is worse than anything I've seen in years."
Whatever it is called, what New York and other governments really have is the latest manifestation of the recurring clash between competing goals that Martin Shefter outlined in "Political Crisis/Fiscal Crisis: The Collapse and Revival of New York City": between getting elected and preserving civil harmony on the one hand, and nurturing the local economy and maintaining the city's ability to pay its bills, on the other. Before those agendas can be reconciled, the various goal-tenders have to get past the current identity crisis and find a turning point at which they abandon business as usual.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Congress Does Something, But Mostly Just Stands There

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT may be the national polls, or the Pennsylvania election, or it may just be that hope for adjournment concentrates the Congressional mind, but all at once Congress is dealing with domestic issues, from taxes to health care to the recession.
It is not necessarily solving them, and not always even passing bills to try to solve them. In an era of persistent divided government, continually soaring Federal deficits and a fear of taxes that conquers all, real legislative solutions seem all but out of reach. 
 Consider what was voted on last week. A banking bill that would have allowed some interstate banking was defeated in the House when a coalition of Democrats who thought it either gave the banks too much or gave them too little combined to sink it. A few spending bills were acted on. The House did pass a bill requiring employers to grant employees unpaid leaves of absence for family emergencies, but by a margin clearly too weak to override President Bush's threatened veto.
The family leave bill, which the Bush Administration contends would unfairly burden business, falls into the same category as the various Democratic tax cut proposals -- a political statement for 1992, intended to sharpen the definition of their party as the one concerned with middle-class Americans while Republicans worry only about foreigners or the rich.
Only when it came to the recession did Congress clearly overcome those influences that seem to compel inaction or ineffectiveness. After four months of arguing, and a bitter two days of Senate debate focusing on why one state got less than another, Congress sent to a suddenly willing President Bush a bill to provide extended unemployment benefits for about 3 million people out of work at least half a year.
Nor is there likely to be a great deal of last-minute voting on major bills in the 10 days before Thanksgiving. The House may vote on campaign finance, and the two bodies are likely to refill the nearly empty coffers of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits, and the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is overseeing the savings and loan bailout.
 
The President's Demands
 Of Mr. Bush's two main demands, a highway bill and a crime bill, the first one would create jobs and is therefore likely to be approved by a House-Senate conference commitee. The crime bill, whose driving force has always been politics, is more likely to be left behind as, for obscure reasons, Senate Republicans have kept it from even being considered by a conference committee.
And little more would pass if Congress worked on into December. The general snarling temper of the place was apparent last week even on a bill so generally regarded as critical as the unemployment measure. Senators snapped at each other, made unusual accusations of greed and bad faith. The Senate's No. 2 Democratic whip, Wendell H. Ford of Kentucky, embarrassed his leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, by blocking his request for a unanimous vote to take up the unemployment bill and move fast on it. A long winter's nap might improve the prospects for good will that a broad banking bill or energy bill would require for passage.
There are several reasons for the limited level of accomplishment, but the biggest and most basic of them are politics and divided government. First of all, after 11 years of Republican Presidencies and Democratic Congresses, the list of problems which both sides agree are serious and worth compromising on has been whittled down quite a bit. Clean air was done last year. Civil rights this year, and unemployment made it, after a long delay. But the big problems the Democrats see are rarely the same as the ones Republicans seize on.
One obvious target for both parties is health care and its costs. Congressional Democrats have lots of plans but no consensus, and Senate Republicans have a plan, too. But without a push from the President, nothing major is likely to happen, and his political handlers have been advising Mr. Bush to hang back until after he is re-elected and not make enemies over this issue.
Even if he ultimately rejects that advice and settles on a proposal, it will be much harder to make it into a law than it used to be. Indeed, solving almost any big problem is tougher these days. For there are two ways the Government tries to solve most problems -- by passing laws regulating private conduct, often involving employer-worker relations, or by spending money.
This year's civil rights bill, making it easier to sue in cases of alleged job discrimination, was a prime example of the first sort. Passage of the bill, the major legislative accomplishment of this session, involved extraordinary effort by Senator John C. Danforth, Republican of Missouri, who argued it was bad for the country and for his party to use race as a political weapon.
But the Administration rarely supports bills that tell business what to do, whether it is to provide family leaves or not to hire striker replacements. Moreover, Republicans are not alone in their disinclination to increase Government control of private conduct. Democrats may complain that in Republican hands existing regulations are not enforced, but they have become much less eager to propose new areas of control.
Attempting to solve problems by spending money is even harder. Last year's budget agreement has meant there is just about no money at all for new programs. No one wants to cut old ones, and no one wants to vote for new taxes to pay for new ones, no matter their political worthiness. The House has even refused to debate a $5.60 per worker per year tax on employers to pay extended unemployment benefits, or a 32 cent a month tax on electric bills to encourage use of wind and solar power.
The budget agreement, of course, allowed Congress to raise taxes if it wanted to buy something new. But what the budget act gave, political fear of television commercials labeling an incumbent as an advocate of taxes has effectively taken away.

HEADLINE: VOTER POLL SHOWS BIG EDWARDS LEAD IN LOUISIANA RACE

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Voters surveyed as they left polling places in Louisiana said today that they had chosen former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards as their next governor over David Duke by almost two to one.
The actual margin for Mr. Edwards, a Democrat, could be narrower because supporters of Mr. Duke, a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan running as a Republican, have consistently been reluctant to state their preferences to poll takers. 
 The Secretary of State's office reported this afternoon that there had been a heavy turnout of voters, and the survey suggested an unprecedented turnout by black voters was largely responsible.
 
Campaign of Stark Choices
 Voter Research and Surveys, which conducted the surveys, projected Mr. Edwards the winner shortly after the polls closed at 8 P.M.
The election reflected the stark choices of a campaign that has divided this state as few other political contests have done anywhere in recent history.
On the one hand was Mr. Edwards, who served three terms as governor but was discredited in the last by corruption scandals. On the other was Mr. Duke, who could not be forgiven by many voters for his past as a racist and neo-Nazi.
Black voters questioned in the survey today almost unanimously said they had voted for Mr. Edwards. A sizable number of white voters in the New Orleans area also said they preferred Mr. Edwards. That city was the focus of a huge advertising campaign by Mr. Edwards and his supporters predicting that the city's tourism and convention business would collapse if Mr. Duke was elected.
The survey found that white voters statewide split evenly between the two candidates. Mr. Duke ran strongest in Northern Louisiana. Republican voters also split evenly between the two candidates, while voters who had supported the current Governor, Buddy Roemer, in last month's primary divided three-to-one for Mr. Edwards.
 
National Issues Surface
 Voter Research and Surveys is an organization created last year to conduct exit polls on behalf of ABC News, CBS News, CNN and NBC News. The New York Times subscribed to today's poll. In it, voters were asked to fill out written questionnaires as they were leaving 30 randomly selected polling places around the state.
On the eve of a Presidential election year, the campaign has confirmed that the nation's political agenda is dominated by the voters' frustration with the economic slowdown, and the volatile emotions of racial resentment. Moreover, Mr. Duke emerged from weeks of intense news media coverage as a national political figure.
The survey of voters indicated that Mr. Duke might receive a smaller proportion of the vote in this election than the 44 percent he took in an unsuccessful bid last year to unseat United States Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat.
Given a choice of nine issues that most influenced their choice, survey respondents who said they voted for Mr. Duke most frequently cited "reforming the welfare system," while Edwards voters named the "state's economy and unemployment."
The two candidates won the right to compete in today's runoff election when they took the top two spots in an nonpartisan primary on Oct. 19. Mr. Roemer came in third in Louisiana's unusual primary, which put all candidates on the same ballot regardless of party affiliation. Under the state's election system, if neither of the top two vote-getters in the primary receives more than 50 percent of the vote, they compete in a runoff election.
Political battles in Louisiana are traditionally waged by force of personality rather than through political party organizations. This election was a duel between an old lion and a young insurgent. And their differences in style, generation and ideology produced a vote today that was sharply polarized by race and geography.
Mr. Edwards, 64 years old, served three terms as governor between 1971 and 1987. He was introduced by the moderator at one candidates' forum as "the Queen Victoria of Louisiana politics" because he has been such a domineering figure for so long.
 
Two Transformations
 The 41-year-old Mr. Duke, who was grand wizard of the Knights of the Ku Klux Klan from 1975 to 1980, did not seize the political spotlight until 1989, when he was elected State Representative from the New Orleans suburb of Metairie.
For both candidates it was a campaign of transformations as they tried to shed the burdensome aspects of their pasts.
Mr. Duke cited a religious conversion to explain that he was now more tolerant, but the voters were constantly reminded of Mr. Duke's 20 years of overtly racist and neo-Nazi activities by news reports and the Edwards camp.
Mr. Edwards, who was twice tried but never convicted on Federal corruption charges in his last term in office, also declared himself a changed man. But Mr. Duke took every opportunity to recall the scandals and the former Governor's reputation as a flamboyant scoundrel.
The sincerity of Mr. Duke's assertion of a religious conversion became an issue in the last week of the race as leaders of the conservative Christian movement, a crucial Duke constituency, questioned his veracity and a top aide quit his campaign, saying he questioned Mr. Duke's beliefs.
In the end there was only one real issue in the campaign and that was Mr. Duke himself. Pre-election public opinion surveys confirmed what was evident on the campaign trail: The state was divided between those who loved him and those who hated him.
This overwhelming dynamic turned the Edwards campaign into an effort not so much to elect a candidate as to defeat an enemy.
At Mr. Edwards's last major rally, on Thursday night in New Orleans, one speaker after another took to the microphone to denounce Mr. Duke until it seemed that Mr. Edwards's candidacy was being mentioned only as an afterthought. And when the candidate himself took the microphone, he was greeted not by cheering but by chants of "no more Dukes."
By default Mr. Edwards became the beneficiary of a coalition drawn solely by its abhorrence of Mr. Duke. It included Democrats and Republicans, business and labor groups, environmentalists, civic groups and women's organizations.
"Because of the nature of my opposition," Mr. Edwards said at a rally this week, "I've been able to put together a coalition never before assembled of my supporters and people who have never supported me before. I realize this is a unique opportunity and I am not going to pass on it."
 
Few Duke Endorsements
 Mr. Duke received no endorsements from any major newspapers nor from any of his colleagues in the Legislature nor from any significant political figures or citizens' groups. And he wore this as a badge of honor.
Drawing ardent crowds to rallies across the state Mr. Duke presented himself as the avenging agent of change who would right the wrongs carried out against his white working- and middle-class constituents.
He promised to battle "the liberals" and "the special interests" who, he said, have raised taxes and presided over corrupt, inefficient government.
Poor blacks were Mr. Duke's scapegoats. Changes in welfare, like incentives to get mothers to use birth control, he said, would solve problems ranging from high crime rates to the high cost of medical care.
Yet Mr. Duke also echoed mainstream Republicans when he argued that social welfare programs were a costly failure and that affirmative-action policies discriminated against whites.
This campaign was unusual for the amount and the ferocity of the negative advertising that was aimed at a single candidate.
Aside from the Edwards campaign itself, the Democratic Party, several independent groups and even individual citizens produced volleys of 30-second commercials opposing Mr. Duke.
 
 
HOW THE SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED

The poll is based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout Louisiana on Saturday.
The poll was conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, and NBC News.
The results are based on 1,675 voters in 30 randomly selected precincts statewide.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from a poll like this, when based on the entire sample, should differ by no more than three percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all those who voted in Louisiana on Election Day.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: Can Foie Gras Aid the Heart? A French Scientist Says Yes

BYLINE: By MOLLY O'NEILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: AUCH, France

 BODY:
Here in the land of the Three Musketeers, the Gascony region of southwest France, goose and duck fat are slathered on bread instead of butter, the people snack on fried duck skin and eat twice as much foie gras as other Frenchmen, and 50 times as much as Americans.
It was no surprise when Dr. Serge Renaud, in a 10-year epidemiological study that included surveys of eating habits, concluded that Gascons eat a diet higher in saturated fat than any other group of people in the industrialized world. Dr. Renaud is the director of research at the National Institute of Health and Medical Research, a Government center in Lyons. 
 But scientists crinkled a collective brow over Dr. Renaud's related finding about this region, which produces much of the world's foie gras, the fattened livers of ducks and geese. "The foie gras eaters of the Gers and Lot Departments in southwest France have the lowest rate of death from cardiovascular disease in the country," he said. Foie gras is the fattened livers of ducks and geese.
 
U.S. Participation Sought
 According to the World Health Organization's Multinational Monitoring of Trends and Determinants in cardiovascular disease, or Monica, which is currently studying eating habits and mortality rates in Toulouse and a surrounding area that includes much of Gascony, the difference is remarkable. Out of 100,000 middle-aged French men, approximately 145 die of heart attacks annually, but in Toulouse the number is about 80. In the United States, 315 of every 100,000 middle-aged men die of heart attacks each year.
In a paper presented to a convention of duck and goose producers in France last spring, Dr. Renaud suggested that goose and duck fat may improve cardiovascular health. Only clinical studies can determine the benefits of the fat from web-footed birds, but chemists agree with Dr. Renaud, who said in a recent telephone interview, "Goose and duck fat is closer in chemical composition to olive oil than it is to butter or lard."
Dr. Renaud has teamed up with Dr. Curtis Ellison, chief of preventive medicine and epidemiology at the Boston University School of Medicine, to request a $3 million grant from the United States National Institutes of Health for a five-year continuation of Dr. Renaud's work.
"The changes in the American diet in the past 10 years are laudable," said Dr. Ellison. "But we are still dying faster and of more heart attacks than the French, and I want to know why." While taking into account the role of genetics and life style, his study will focus on the role of consumption of wine, dairy fats, vegetables, fruits, and goose and duck fat.
To the American heart specialists whose research has brought lean-beef and the low-fat diet, the very thought of a beneficial dietary fat is anathema.
"Heart attacks are less frequent in France, but they are still the leading cause of death there," said Dr. Dean Ornish, a heart specialist at the University of California in San Francisco. For several decades, the low rate of heart disease in France has stumped scientists. Last summer an article in In Health magazine dubbed the mystery "Le Paradoxe Francais."
Dr. Ornish doubts that duck fat is a significant player in the paradox. "We know that fats and cholesterol are not the whole story of heart disease," he said. "But a single epidemiological study could overlook the things like positive social support systems or low stress that could even offset harmful dietary choices like pate or foie gras."
Dr. Renaud acknowledges that many factors need to be considered, but he said, "It is obvious that this fat doesn't increase cholesterol dramatically and, my goodness, it is even possible this fat may provide some kind of protection."
 
Foie Gras as Health Food
 For the farmers and exporters of Gers, the department that includes the heart of Gascony, Dr. Renaud's research may be manna from heaven -- or sauteed foie gras on toasted brioche.
"If we can label foie gras health food, ah, the world is then ours," said Jean Michel Justumus, director of the Regional Center for Agricultural and Technological Innovation in Auch, the capital of Gers. The center studies the technology of foie gras growing and processing.
Eighty percent of the foie gras in the world is produced in France, primarily in Gers, which has the highest proportion of people making a living from agriculture in France, Mr. Justumus said; half of them produce foie gras.
Like contemporary d'Artagnans, they fiercely defend their agricultural economy against foreign competition, animal-rights advocates and, the biggest foe of all, health concerns.
Wearing a white lab coat and sitting at his desk, Mr. Justumus looked every bit the cool pragmatist, shepherding a traditional industry into the 21st century. But like a man who knows no fear when he duels for the honor of his country, he waved aside the suggestion that the liver's fat content might help explain why it is generally savored in small amounts. (A tablespoon of foie gras has 60 calories and is 87 percent fat, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.) Fear of foie gras, he said, is a "longstanding prejudice."
"When something tastes very good, people think it must be very bad," Mr. Justumus said. "Even the French think this. And Americans. . . ." His voice trailed off, then rallied. "But a label that says, 'Eat foie gras, live longer'; what a marketing tool!"
The Gascon farmers are facing the threat of fattened livers from Eastern Europe. Last month a French television news program carried a report of a shipment of Eastern European foie gras that was hijacked in southwest France where it was to be processed. "Other countries can raise the ducks and geese cheaper," said Yves Saint-Pe, who fattens geese and ducks on his farm outside Auch.
Gascon farmers have also jabbed back at animal-rights advocates who contend that force-feeding ducks and geese to fatten their livers is cruel. Gesturing to the blue skies above her farm near Auch, Lucette Baron, who raises about 400 ducks and 150 geese a year, defended the practice. She said that before wild ducks and geese migrate, they stuff themselves, engorging their livers with fat to provide energy for the flight.
Mrs. Baron sees herself as the keeper of a holy tradition. "The Romans did this," she said. Walking into the barn to feed her flock, she was puzzled by the charge of cruelty. "My ducks don't run away from me," she said.
Mrs. Baron is the rare farmer's wife who keeps a small flock and, in the final three weeks of fattening, uses the traditional hose-necked funnel to pour corn directly into the birds' stomachs. Today, a typical foie gras producer raises 20,000 birds a year, favors ducks over geese (ducks fatten faster) and has an automatic feeding system. The 12,000 producers in Gers make more than a ton of foie gras a year, which can retail for as much as $25 an ounce.
And they think that in the work of Dr. Renaud they may have found the ultimate sword to defend their industry in a diet-conscious world.
"Eat Foie Gras for Health!" said Mr. Justumus jubilantly. In his office he is trying out slogans. "Even 10 years ago, you would have been laughed out of France for saying such a thing, but no one is laughing now."
In fact, scientists are following Dr. Renaud's research and the Monica study with interest. "Duck and goose fat contains saturated fat, but it may also contain a fatty acid that has a positive affect on blood platelets," said Dr. Ellison of Boston University.
Dr. Ornish is skeptical. "What people don't realize is that even if part of a fat has a beneficial mechanism, it cannot counterbalance the overall effect of fat in the diet," he said.
Dr. Adam Drewnowski, director of the human nutrition program at the University of Michigan, finds the study worthwhile. "Who knows?" he said. "First we had the Mediterranean diet. Maybe next we'll get the Southwest of France diet."
The basic Gascon in his blue beret would not be surprised. Standing in his barnyard Mr. Saint-Pe listened to Dr. Renaud's findings as though he were being told the obvious. "The people in my family live to be 90 years old," he said. "We cook everything in duck fat. We have foie gras on Sunday. Everybody knows this is the long-life diet."
Other locals were equally surprised that such common knowledge could be a marketing tool. "Scientists say we should be dead by 40 because we eat duck and liver and salt and wine," said Bernard Verduzan, 87, as he laid out his fattened livers at the foie gras market in Eauze in southwest France recently. "And then they say it is big news when they read the obituaries in the newspaper and see how long we live." Straightening his shoulders and puffing out his chest, he said, "I am still young."
Robert Jacquerez, 95, who dines daily at the Hotel de France in Auch, contends that the key is balance. "Always have a salad with your cassoulet, bread with your foie gras," he said. "Always drink as much mineral water as wine." His eyes dropped to the menu of the hotel, where Andre Daguin, the chef and owner, is renowned for creating entire meals of foie gras and has earned two Michelin stars for his rich regional fare.
Instead of describing the various preparations, the menu simply states, "The fat of birds may be good for health."
"I've written this finding as a conditional, pending further research," said Mr. Daguin grudgingly. Dr. Renaud's studies will not begin until spring, and waiting for science to corroborate the obvious frustrates this eighth-generation Gascon cook.
It also frustrates Mr. Justumus, who grew up in Gers, eats foie gras once a week and said that members of his family live into their 90's. Looking out his laboratory window toward the rolling, open farmland that the foie gras industry has preserved he said, "Too bad we won't have the follow-up study for this Christmas season."

HEADLINE: Interest Is High As U.S. Revises Rule on Tankers

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15

 BODY:
In a crowded conference room at the Coast Guard's headquarters on Thursday, Lieut. Drew Wojtanik huddled around a table with a group of experts in oil transportation. He was in his shirt sleeves, and up to his elbows in regulatory minutiae.
All day long participants in a workshop, broken into 10 discussion groups like one the lieutenant was leading, had been debating how the Coast Guard should regulate the operation of vessels to insure that they are prepared to respond quickly to catastrophic oil spills, as called for by a new law. 
 "I don't want to get down to the boots and gloves," Lieutenant Wojtanik said in the discussion, "but what other types of larger equipment should be carried on board?"
 
'Appropriate' Response
 The answer will come in the fine print of a new set of environmental regulations required under the Oil Pollution Act of 1990, an overhaul of oil tanker safety laws prompted by the Exxon Valdez spill in Alaska in 1989. The law itself calls for vessels to carry "appropriate" equipment using the best technology that is economically feasible, taking safety into account. Now it is up to the Coast Guard to define exactly what Congress meant.
The ships, about 5,000 of them, ranging in size from supertankers to river barges, are supposed to be properly equipped by next August.
If the Coast Guard required substantial equipment aboard each one, it could cost billions of dollars. But judging from comments by industry and government representatives at the workshop last week, that appears unlikely. Most cleanup equipment wouldprobably be stored on shore and governed by a related set of regulations the Coast Guard must write.
And those two sets of rules are just the beginning. At least two dozen sets of regulations must be written in the three years after the law was enacted, and that took place in August 1990.
Already, the Coast Guard has fallen behind schedule in putting out proposals for rules by which oil tanker companies will have to live.
 
Both Sides Are Concerned
 But as inexorably as the tides, if not quite on such a fixed schedule, the regulations are coming. And with each proposal published comes a wave of debate among shipping companies, environmental groups, citizens and governments in areas affected by such shipping, and international insurers.
On several issues, the industry has objected to what it calls overregulation, while environmentalists are pressing for more aggressive action.
Among the issues are how insurance policies should be written to guarantee payment for the costs of cleaning up spills, how quickly tankers should be required to be outfitted with double hulls and other design changes to help prevent catastrophic groundings and how harbors should be equipped to track movements of tankers to prevent collisions.
On the responses of vessels to oil spills, the Coast Guard wants to negotiate a regulation that is acceptable to all parties, avoiding possible litigation. So even before the first draft is written, there have been extensive offerings of comments. The workshop on Thursday was not a formal hearing, but a brainstorming session, Coast Guard officers said, and 195 people showed up.
Most of those commenting advised against putting major cleanup equipment on oil vessels. Oil shipping companies say there is a dearth of equipment that can be used from the decks of a tanker after a spill.
It is not yet clear whether the Coast Guard's rules will go far enough to satisfy environmental groups and state environmental agencies, which have argued for putting at least some cleanup equipment on the tankers.

HEADLINE: Conference Lauds Anita Hill, Exultantly

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 16

 BODY:
In her most extensive public comments since her Senate testimony against Judge Clarence Thomas riveted the nation, Prof. Anita F. Hill told a cheering, exultant crowd of women here on Friday night that sexual harassment was "a form of violence against women" and "a form of economic coercion" that "will not go away."
Addressing several hundred female state legislators from around the nation, who twirled hundreds of pink napkins and pounded tables for minutes after she entered the room, Professor Hill issued a ringing call to arms against inappropriate sexual behavior in the workplace. 
 She said workplace harassment was a "beast" that was exacerbated when women did not report its occurrence because they feared not being believed by male managers or even by other women.
"We are angry because we have been betrayed," she said, her calm tone a contrast to the severity of her words. "The reality is that this powerful beast is used to reinforce a sense of inequality to keep women in their place, notwithstanding our increasing numbers in the workplace. We are angry because we have so little positive outlet for our anger."
 
No Mention of Thomas
 Not once in her remarks, which she offered during a panel discussion on sexual harassment, did Professor Hill mention by name Clarence Thomas, whose nomination to the Supreme Court was jeopardized by her accusation that he sexually harassed her when she worked for him at the Education Department and later at the Equal Employment Opportunty Commission. Her appearance here fell one month to the day after Judge Thomas was confirmed by the full Senate.
Professor Hill, who teaches law at the University of Oklahoma, received a raucous response from her audience, female lawmakers who met here this week at a bipartisan conference sponsored by the Center on the American Woman in Politics at Rutgers University.
The delegates had been talking about her for days in hearings, forums and fervent hallway discussions. Many began sporting "I Believe Anita Hill" buttons on Friday afternoon. As she rose to speak and thanked the momentarily quieted crowd on Friday night, one woman hollered back, "Thank you!" Minutes later, dozens took up a chant, "We believe Anita!" Some threw flowers.
But not every delegate responded warmly. Grace Davis and Nadine Thomas, lawmakers from Georgia, Justice Thomas's home state, were among the few who did not rise or applaud when Professor Hill spoke.
Asked later what she thought of Professor Hill, Ms. Davis seemed uncomfortable. "You have to weigh what she said," Ms. Davis said. "In any situation, you have a positive and a negative. It's not a question of whether you believe her."
But the Georgia lawmakers were far outnumbered by Hill supporters.
Conference organizers said Professor Hill's travel and lodging expenses had been paid for but like the other panelists, she had not been paid for her appearance.
Fund-raisers, poll takers and political strategists attending the conference said the Thomas-Hill hearings before the Senate Judiciary Committee had provided female candidates a rare opportunity to get voters' attention.
 
'Left With an Image'
 "The country has been left with an image, a picture of a Government that's overwhelmingly male," Ruth Mandel, the director of the Rutgers center. "Women's absence was felt and noticed in a powerful way."
Ms. Mandel said the sexual-harassment discussion here had been added to the conference's agenda after the hearings prompted female legislators to call her, asking if the subject would be addressed.
Indeed, even before Professor Hill's arrival here, that subject had taken center stage.
On Thursday, 29 witnesses appeared at a hearing called by female legislators from California and gave their personal accounts of harassment. One witness, Louette Columbano, a former San Francisco police officer, told the lawmakers that male colleagues had chased her, had forced her to watch a prostitute perform oral sex on a male officer and, when she complained, had taken turns spitting on the windshield of her car.
"This happened in 1984," she said. "I never thought I'd be sitting here telling this story again."
Professor Hill's testimony to the Senate, Ms. Columbano and other witnesses said, made their own complaints seem more credible.
 
Frequent Applause
 At times during Professor Hill's appearance on Friday night, the women in the hotel ballroom seemed exhilarated by her very presence. On several occasions, they appeared unable to stop themselves from laughing and applauding, interrupting her after nearly every sentence. "It was cathartic for all of us," said Pauline Menes, a state legislator from Maryland.
It seemed cathartic for Professor Hill as well. Throughout her remarks and during a brief question-and-answer period afterward, she smiled broadly and thanked the delegates profusely for their support.
Professor Hill was shielded by an unusual show of security, with guards posted at every entrance to the building and to the room in which she appeared.
She told the lawmakers that they should capture their rage "and turn it into positive energy."
"Making the workplace a safer and more productive place for ourselves and our daughters is, and should be, on each of our agendas," she said.
Although cautioning that she is an academician and not a politician, she said she would "continue to educate people about these issues."
The question-and-answer period, in which Professor Hill and the other panelists responded to written questions that they selected from many submitted by the audience, took a light turn when one questioner asked her the correct pronunciation of the word "harassment."
It does not matter how the word is pronounced, Professor Hill responded, adding, "I say once and for all: Let's pronounce it dead."

HEADLINE: Dinkins Gets Boost From Ruling on Police Raises

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Dinkins administration officials, under fire for months for their faltering labor policy, said yesterday that they believe a binding arbitration settlement with the police union has put the Mayor in a better position to demand concessions from other municipal unions.
The three-member arbitration panel ruled on Friday that the cost of any wage increase above what the city has set aside in its budget should come from work-rule concessions from the union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. Such a tradeoff has become the crux of the city's position in stalled contract talks with other unions. 
 "The panel said we accept the city's position that if you want a wage increase you've got to fund it," James F. Hanley, the city's Labor Relations Commisioner, said yesterday. "This clearly sets a pattern."
But labor leaders reacted cautiously, saying it was too early to tell if the decision by the panel would break the logjams in other negotiations. Without major concessions from the unions, the adminstration has little hope of closing $7 billion in budget shortfalls over the next four years.
The decision reached on Friday grants members of the P.B.A. a retroactive 3.5 percent wage increase over the first 12 months of the 15-month contract and an additional one percent for the remaining three months of the contract, which expired on Oct. 1. Veteran officers will receive raises that will in some cases boost their paychecks by 7.5 percent, but money for those raises was to come from a freeze on wages for newly hired officers, according to the ruling.
 
Message to Unions
 The wage settlement is identical to the pact the city reached with two large non-uniformed unions forthe same period. It sends a strong message to other uniformed services negotiating contracts -- firefighters, corrections officers and sanitiation workers -- that no wage increases are likely without work-rule concessions. Like the police, other uniformed workers have historically won wages higher than civilian workers.
Throughout more than 18 months of negotiations, the police had hoped to match the 5.5 percent wage increase given to the city's teachers' union for the same 15-month period. Mr. Dinkins, who had agreed to the teachers pact because it was partly financed by state aid, insisted that the city could not afford a similar settlement with the police because no state aid was available. The two sides agreed to arbitration in mid-September.
While negotiators on both sides spent much of yesterday poring over numbers to determine the true cost and benefits of the settlement, city labor officials said the ruling helped shore up what some fiscal monitors saw as an unrealistic weak spot in the Mayor's five-year spending plan: Mr. Dinkins's vow to freeze salaries over the next two years except for those unions that agree to changes that make their workers more productive. Aides to the Mayor say the ruling lends credibility to the plan.
"The reality and the perception are that the Mayor stood tall on these very important principles about what the city could afford to pay in last year's settlement," said Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel, who is acting mayor while Mr. Dinkins is traveling in South Africa. "That's just important to all public discussions under way now in virtually every arena about the Mayor and this administration's ability to hit these marks. It goes directly to the question of the credibility of future labor negotiations, the financial plan, and his leadership in general."
 
Talks Still Ahead
 While the decision is likely to set the tone for negotiations with uniformed workers, leaders of other municipal unions said yesterday that they do not believe the ruling had weakened their position in the current round of contract talks.
"If they are going to use this as a leverage against us, they are making a sad mistake, because they have blown many opportunities and suggestions from us," said Stanley Hill, president of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents 140,000 city employees.
Barry Feinstein, president of Teamsters Local 237, representing 14,000 city workers, said the ruling "has no impact, no bearing about any settlement that we make." He warned that if city negotiators try to use the police decision as a model for negotiations with the Teamsters, "they're going to have a war starting Monday."
Through a spokeswoman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman, said she could not predict what effect the arbitration would have on the teacher's negotations until she had studied it.
 
Haunted by Teachers' Pact
 City officials hope that the arbitration panel's ruling will restore stability to labor talks that were thrown into tumult in October 1990 when Mayor Dinkins, over the objections of his Budget Director, agreed to give the teachers a 5.5 percent raise that was paid for in part by the state. The teachers' contract also raised eyebrows among fiscal experts inside and outside government who said New York City could not afford it. The teachers eventually agreed to defer a portion of the increase.
"The good thing about the aribitration, regardless of who won or who lost, is that it finally clears the board of the mistake made with the teachers and will let the city and the unions get down to real task at hand," said Raymond B. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a private fiscal monitoring group.
The president of the P.B.A., Phil Caruso, said the union received as good a deal as was possible during a recession. "Considering the dire economic conditions, we're satisfied to the extent there are more pluses than minuses in the contract," he said. "I'm not totally happy, but we could live with it."
The 70-page decision added $1,000 per year to the annual salary for officers who serve more than five years. That automatic raise in pay, known as longevity pay, went to $2,000 from $1,000 for officers with five years service, to $3,000 from $2,000 for those with more than 10 years, to $4,000 from $3,000 for those with more than 15 years and to $5,000 from $4,000 for those with more than 20 years. The longevity pay raises mean a wage increase of more than 7.5 percent for officers with more than five years on the job, P.B.A. officials said.
 
Slew of Contract Changes
 But younger officers will pay for those gains, the P.B.A. said. The ruling ordered that the starting salary of all officers hired after June 1991 be frozen at the old levels, starting at $25,977, for the first five years the officer serves. Rookie officers also will receive about half the differential pay that veteran officers will get for working overnight shifts.
The union will also have to accept concessions on overtime. The department will be able to call in officers for special shifts on short notice 10 days a year without paying overtime.
Although the contract covered by the ruling has expired, it will remain in effect until agreement is reached on a new pact. Talks on a new contract will begin shortly, city and union officials said.
City budget officials said yesterday that they were still trying to untangle the complex question of how to pay the officers retroactive raises when much of the money is to come from savings from work-rule changes that have not gone into effect.
 
Paying for the Contract
 The entire cost of the 3.5 percent wage settlement through June 1991 will be $32.5 million dollars, Philip R. Michael, the city Budget Director, said. Of that, about $14 million was set aside in last year's budget. About $9.8 million will come from funds diverted by the city from the police pension fund to pay for raises. The rest -- about $8.7 million -- is supposed to be paid for through the labor concessions that, as a practical matter, can only take effect now.
But Mr. Michael said the city may have to pay some of the $8.7 million from the city general fund, but in the long run, it will recoup it from the concessions.

HEADLINE: Market Plunge Is Warning Sign, Cuomo Tells Business Executives

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 16

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo told an audience of leading corporate executives today that the stock market plunge on Friday should wake Washington up to the country's deep economic problems.
Speaking to the Fortune 500 Forum, an annual meeting of top executives from the country's largest companies, the Governor added another proposal to a package of economic-growth initiatives he has long endorsed. In order to provide banks with capital and liquidity, Mr. Cuomo suggested, the Federal Reserve Bank should invest $20 billion to $25 billion in bank stocks. 
 Mr. Cuomo, who is still considering whether he should enter the 1992 Presidential race, received a standing ovation from the crowd of about 200 people gathered in the ballroom of the Omni hotel. It was a particularly warm response for the New York Democrat, given that many in the audience would be directly affected by a proposal Mr. Cuomo reiterated today -- that a reduction in capital gains taxes should be accompanied by an increase in income taxes on those making more than $200,000 a year.
But the Governor seemed to strike a chord with his message that the economy requires extensive reform, and that neither the Republican White House nor the Democratic Congress have shown the will to address it.
Mr. Cuomo said he hoped that Friday's losses on Wall Street, in which the Dow Jones industrial average fell 120 points, would drive home the message.
"It does seem to me that what happened on the stock market said rather clearly that there is a growing acknowledgment that this economy is indeed crippled in a fundamental way," Mr. Cuomo said. He added that the economy "needs more than just prayers to some cyclical economic god or magic one-shots like a quick single tax cut to cure it."
Mr. Cuomo challenged the traditional Republican assertion, voiced recently by President Bush, that Democrats who are complaining about the economy are preaching doom and gloom.
"This is not 1982," he said. "There's less resiliency now. There are fewer options for corrections now.
"Can't you say that without being unpatriotic? I think so."
 
Economic Growth Plan
 Mr. Cuomo outlined an economic growth plan that would include a tax credit for investments in machinery and other capital, the gradual liberalization of depreciation schedules and the expansion of investments in research and development. "We need an investment-led recovery," he said.
Mr. Cuomo also called for Federal investments in roads and bridges, energy, education and human services. He said he would finance those initiatives by cutting defense and entitlement programs, improving tax collections and raising income taxes on the wealthy.

HEADLINE: L.I. Woman Is Killed, Apparently Trying to Stop Her Son's Suicide

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
A 34-year-old Long Island man and his mother were found dead in the basement of their ranch-style home in Roslyn yesterday -- both apparently the victims of the son's suicide, the police said.
The son, Charles Freed, frayed the wires on an electrical cord, wrapped it around his neck and plugged it in, electrocuting himself. His 71-year-old mother, Mildred, appeared to have died trying to save him, said Sgt. Daniel Severin of the Nassau County Police Department, though it was not clear if she had also been electrocuted or had died of a heart attack. 
 Their bodies were discovered at 10:30 A.M. by police officers searching the two-story house at 36 Regent Place, a winding street in an exclusive Roslyn neighborhood, after a daughter had called a neighbor to say no one answered the phone.
"It looks like he frayed the cord himself," Sergeant Severin said, "then wrapped the cord around his neck, and plugged the cord into an outlet."
Sergeant Severin said that a timer was attached to the electrical outlet, but that it was impossible to say if it had been used in the suicide. The medical examiner's office is to conduct an autopsy today to determine the time and the exact cause of the deaths.
Mrs. Freed's daughter in San Francisco, unable to reach her mother since Thursday, telephoned a neighbor early yesterday and asked her to check the house. The neighbor, Anita Weisfeld, then telephoned the police after noticing that three days' worth of newspapers and telephones books had gone uncollected and finding the front door unlocked.
"I was scared," Mrs. Weisfeld said. "I didn't go in."
Mrs. Weisfeld said she knew little about Mrs. Freed, except that she lived alone with her son and that four other children lived in California and Colorado. She said the son seemed "a little disturbed."
The police found no note or anything else to suggest why the son would kill himself, but Sergeant Severin said he was unemployed and had undergone psychiatric treatment in the past.

HEADLINE: Praise for Catholic Bishops' Statement on Children

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
A statement by the National Conference of Catholic Bishops calling on the nation to make the needs of children and families its first priority got favorable reviews Friday from both ends of the political spectrum.
The statement combined opposition to abortion and "permissive divorce" with support for "broad-based child care," an increased minimum wage, tax benefits for parents, guaranteed access to health care, affordable housing policies, flexible job hours and parental-leave policies for family and medical needs. Weaving together themes of moral values with concerns about economic pressures and discrimination, the statement was intended to overcome what it termed "an unfortunate, unnecessary and unreal polarization in discussion of how best to help families." 
 Marion Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, a generally liberal child welfare advocacy group, said, "I'm so pleased about all the points of agreements, about causes and remedies, and that the bishops are making this call to action and lifting a strong moral voice on behalf of children, especially in an election year."
William R. Mattox, Jr., director of policy analysis for the conservative Family Research Council, said the bishops' statement was part of "a growing consensus that not only are our children at risk but that the problem is not simply an economic problem or a political problem or, for that matter, a moral problem, but one that includes all of those elements."
The bishops approved the 15,000-word statement on children during the closing session Thursday of what had been a rather lethargic four-day meeting. The 300-member body meets twice annually.
The bishops also approved a statement on the environment, their first step into an area where other religious groups have been active. The statement, drawing upon Catholic teachings about creation, nature and social responsibility, warned that "care for the earth" should not lead to "choosing between people and the planet."
The environmental statement was welcomed by Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, who helped organize a "Summit Meeting on the Environment" attended by religious leaders last June in New York City.
 
'Tremendous Leadership'
 "A lot of environmentalists do not get past the church's position on birth control to see the tremendous leadership role of the church and the Pope where the global environment is concerned," the senator said in an interview yesterday.
But approval of a statement recognizing the sufferings of American Indians, a counterpoint to the bishops' planned 1992 commemoration of the arrival of Columbus and Christianity in the Americas, was delayed because it required a two-thirds' majority of active conference members.
So many bishops had left the meeting early that the conference will have to canvass absent members by mail. Several bishops said that the early departures were a sign of frustration with a meeting that had spent much time debating, and ultimately rejecting, a proposal to reduce the number of holy days of obligation, the six major feast days on which Catholics are expected to attend Mass in addition to Sundays.
In the statement on children, the bishops commented, "No government can love a child and no policy can substitute for a family's care," but "government can either support or undermine families."
"Money alone will not solve the problems of poor families, but there is no substitute for wise and thoughtful investment," they added.
But the bishops also emphasized that "traditional moral values are not relics of a bygone age."
 
Attacking 'Family Values'
 "Our news and entertainment media, despite some laudable efforts, too often attack family values, undermine moral principles, expose children to violence and to sexual themes on a daily basis," the bishops said. "Fundamental values of integrity, compassion, respect for others and honesty must be encouraged and reinforced by the culture at large."

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
For Dinkins, an Evolving Opinion on South Africa

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 16

 BODY:
For Mayor David N. Dinkins, who weighs his every word, finding the right ones to describe his revulsion at the pervasive racial inequities here has been a challenge.
For years, in speeches in New York, he has referred to apartheid as "the only form of legalized slavery in the world." That drew derisive commentary in the white South African press before his arrival because the country has moved to dismantle many of the legal underpinnings of apartheid, although blacks still cannot vote. 
 Now the Mayor has been groping for a new way to describe apartheid that acknowledges both the changes and the work left to be done.
Just before he left New York he said South Africa had "the only form of legalized racism in the world."
On his arrival Tuesday, he said it had "the only form of legalized white supremacy in the world, and it is immoral."
A day later, he said the country had "the only form of legalized white supremacy in the world, and it is under attack and crumbling."
The one thing he cannot yet call this country is the one thing he most wants it to become -- "a non-racial democracy."
 
Driven to Be Selective
 The Mayor's party has also had to thread its way through more threatening diplomatic thickets. In Johannesburg, his dozen-car entourage has been escorted by local traffic police, but also by the South African National Police, long a pillar of the white-minority Government.
But on his overnight visit to Cape Town on Friday, where relations between the police and Mr. Dinkins's host, the African National Congress, are touchier, the delegation had only local traffic police and A.N.C. security force members as escorts. That was so, said the Rev. Allan Boesak, the regional A.N.C. chairman, because the state police had insisted on an intolerable degree of control, including the right to drive the Mayor's car.
"We have had some history of being driven by the South African Police," Mr. Boesak said, noting that on his last trip with them he was taken to jail. "And we had no wish to repeat that with the Mayor of New York. To the extent that the police are observing us, it will be in the sense that they always are."
It was enough to worry the Mayor's own New York police bodyguards, especially because only two of them have been allowed to carry their guns. Though the Mayor has been warmly received by peaceful crowds in black townships everywhere, there have been risks. A planned visit to the Crossroads squatter camp outside Cape Town, for example, was called off at the last minute because of fighting between the police and blacks that was serious enough to warrant Page 1 pictures in the local press the next day.
 
A Couple of Glitches
 When Mr. Dinkins moves around here, he leaves a big wake -- more than 50 people altogether, including advance people, aides and the traveling press. It is a logistical nightmare that has generally been handled with great precision, especially for an administration that regularly runs an hour and a half behind schedule at City Hall.
But there have been a couple of hitches. In one, two cars used by his entourage collided while speeding up a mountain road with lights flashing and sirens blaring, heading for the spectacular pink stucco tile of the Mount Nelson Hotel, where Mr. Dinkins was staying in Cape Town. No one was hurt, though the Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, who was riding in one of the cars, briefly became even more animated than his usual animated self.
The other bit of trouble came at the hotel itself. So sybaritic was the Mount Nelson, with its chintz curtains, canopy beds and sweeping views of Table Mountain, and so early the Mayor's return to Johannesburg today, that no one in his party wanted to leave. In fact one person didn't. The city Personnel Commissioner, Douglas H. White, overslept, and no one noticed in the rush to leave. He had to take a later flight.
 
Divide and Conquer
 South Africa may be on the road to change. But the many groups contending to shape its future are still arguing over the shape of the table, sometimes among themselves, and that came out in all sorts of small ways this week.
On Wednesday, the American Ambassador, William L. Swing, held a reception for Mr. Dinkins in Pretoria, to which the Mayor's entire entourage was invited. But not everyone went to sip cocktails and eat meatballs and rumaki from a 1960's style American buffet. Some A.N.C. officials badly wanted members of Mr. Dinkins's subcommittee on housing and economic development to skip the reception and attend a play, "Baby Come Duza," at the integrated Market Theater in Johannesburg. After a long discussion, the group sent representatives to both.
Among those dispatched to the play was Ron Shiffman, executive director of the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn who is accompanying the Mayor to advise South Africans on building housing here. The play, it turned out, consisted of a series of songs about an area called Sophia Town that was bulldozed to displace the blacks who lived there.
"It was a much more comfortable place for me anyway," he said.
 
The Unwelcome Mat
 While the Mayor has been greeted by hundreds of well-wishers on his tour, some South Africans clearly wish he had not come at all.
After a speech by Mr. Dinkins to the Cape Town Press Club on Friday, in which he pressed for continued economic sanctions against the white-minority Government, an Afrikaner woman, a descendent of white settlers, approached New York reporters traveling with the Mayor.
The woman, Amanda Botha, bitterly criticized the Mayor, saying he was meddling in South Africa's affairs. She then turned to Joe Bragg, a black reporter for WRKS radio who is traveling with the Mayor.
"How would you like people coming to your country telling you what to do, telling you how to help?" she said.
Mr. Bragg, who grew up in North Carolina, replied without missing a beat: "I need all the help I can get! I'm still living with the legacy of slavery."
