HEADLINE: Despite All the Talk of Tax Cuts, People Can Expect to Pay More

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
With the economy mired in recession and incumbents running scared, tax cut fever is once again loose on the land. But recent history offers little reason to believe this latest rush to placate voters will yield enduring tax relief.
A decade after property tax revolts in a dozen states and the across-the- board tax cuts of the Reagan era, the percentage of income that Americans pay in taxes is back to a postwar peak. Only the very richest, and perhaps the poorest, have remained a step ahead of the tax collector. 
 Few people doubt that voters are ready to punish the bearers of bad tax tidings. In New Jersey, for example, Republicans gained veto-proof control of the Legislature in an election widely seen as a referendum on the $2.8 billion tax increase sponsored last year by Gov. Jim Florio, a Democrat.
 
Realities of Finance
 But one way or another, economists and budget analysts maintain, the political pressure for tax reduction will be dissipated by the immovable realities of government finance. Unless Americans are prepared to sacrifice cherished services and retirement benefits -- notably Social Security -- the cost of government will continue to rise faster than incomes.
In 1980, Washington collected 20.3 percent of the gross national product in taxes and fees. The enormous tax cuts of 1981, the result of political competition between the Reagan Administration and Congressional Democrats, knocked a percentage point and a half off the take from the personal and corporate income taxes. Declining revenues from excise taxes clipped a bit more off the overall tax burden.
Yet those cuts were offset by a steady rise in Social Security payroll taxes and a series of minor tax increases aimed at containing the budget deficit. By the end of the decade, taxes had come full circle. After slipping to 19.6 percent of G.N.P. in 1985, total Federal revenues from taxes reached 20.3 percent in 1990.
The numbers tell a similar story for state and local governments. In 1980, their revenues stood at 14.3 percent of the G.N.P. -- seven-tenths of a percentage point less than in 1975, before the property tax revolts that forced rollbacks in many states. By 1990 the figure had crept up to 14.7 percent.
And the burden on taxpayers was far greater than these statistics suggest, said Robert Ebel of KPMG Peat Marwick in Washington, because it masks a decline in Federal aid. State and local revenues from non-Federal sources actually rose from 11 percent of G.N.P. in 1980 to 12.2 percent in 1990.
All told, Americans paid 32.6 percent of G.N.P. to government in 1990, compared with 31.3 percent in 1980 and 30 percent in 1975. And the greatest burden has almost certainly been borne by middle-income families -- those earning $20,000 to $60,000. Their payroll tax deductions have risen by roughly one- third since the mid-1970's.
 
The Big Payroll Tax
 Indeed, few Americans are apparently aware how much the payroll tax has grown. Economists generally agree that both the employee and employer shares represent a tax on wages. And when both shares are counted, the Congressional Budget Office estimates that two families out of three now pay more in Social Security tax than in Federal income tax.
Only the top 1 percent of earners (who reaped the benefits of lower maximum tax rates) and the bottom 20 percent (who gained from cuts in the personal taxes and more generous earned income tax credits) have come out ahead on Federal taxes.
It is harder to generalize about the diverse changes in taxes in the 50 states and thousands of localities. But their heavy dependence on sales, property and excise taxes virtually guarantees that levies represent a greater portion of the income of the poor and middle class than of the wealthy.
Robert McIntyre of Citizens for Tax Justice, a nonprofit liberal lobbying group in Washington, says the generally regressive state and local tax system has grown more regressive since the mid-1980's. While every income class is paying more this year than in 1985, he estimates that the percentage increases for families in the top 5 percent are smaller than the average.
Frank Levy, an economist at the University of Maryland, believes that parallel changes in the distribution of family earnings have sharply magnified the sense of grievance about taxes among middle-class Americans. Congressional Budget Office figures support his contention.
Adjusted for household size and inflation, the incomes of the richest 20 percent of American families rose by 33 percent from 1977 to 1988, and the incomes of those in the top 1 percent rose a whopping 95 percent. Pretax incomes of the middle-fifth of families, by contrast, grew by just 4 percent in the same period -- a gain that left few smiling since it was entirely dependent on the rise in the number of hours spent working outside the home. The incomes of those in the bottom two-fifths of the pecking order, the majority of younger, blue-collar families, actually fell.
That has set the political stage for tax relief, with the focus on assuaging middle-class frustrations before next year's elections. Some Democrats have taken aim at the Social Security payroll tax, which now totals 15.3 percent of the first $53,400 in wages; others would provide tax credits for families with children or allow middle- income families to shelter more income in retirement accounts.
And after concluding last month that revisiting tax policy would destroy last year's deficit reduction pact, President Bush has reportedly decided that the Democrats cannot be allowed to grab the tax cut issue as their own. Administration sources expect that the White House will come up with a tax package containing both capital gains breaks and payroll tax cuts.
 
No More Bracket Creep
 But the laws of arithmetic pose daunting obstacles to those who would get Uncle Sam off the taxpayers' backs. Before 1984, notes Eugene Steurle, an economist at the Urban Institute and the author of the forthcoming book "The Tax Decade," so-called bracket creep in the progressive income tax served as an automatic tax increase. That gave Congress an easy source of revenue to give back periodically in the form of cuts in tax rates. Since 1984, however, tax brackets have been indexed to inflation, a reform that reduced potential revenues in 1990 by a whopping $57 billion.
Washington could pay for a tax cut with spending cuts. But a large and growing portion of the budget is devoted to interest on the national debt and to programs like Social Security and Medicare that are widely viewed as untouchable.
Military spending, by contrast, seems a juicy target in the wake of the collapse of the Soviet threat. But Barry Bosworth of the Brookings Institution suggests, "We've pre-spent the peace dividend."
Under the 1990 budget accord, annual military spending must fall by about $25 billion over the next two years. Thereafter, total discretionary spending must be cut by roughly 3 percent annually in real terms -- most of which, analysts believe, will have to be met by proportionately larger cuts in military outlays. Indeed, with growing political demand for a greater Federal contribution in health care, day care and education, it seems likely that the peace dividend will be spent more than once.
Simply to cut the overall deficit to about 2 percent of G.N.P., as envisaged in the budget agreement, the economy would have to grow by about 2 1/2 percent annually over the next five years. But that rate is at the outer fringe of current forecasts. "They'll have to raise taxes just to stand still," Mr. Bosworth concludes.
State and local governments seem in no better position to give taxpayers an enduring break. While the public may attribute the disproportionate growth of state and local spending to waste, William Baumol, an economist at New York University, thinks there is a simpler, if less satisfying, explanation. Education, health care and police protection, which absorb the bulk of the state and local tax dollar, are essentially "handicraft industries," he says, which resist growth in productivity.
General Electric may be able to triple the number of clothes dryers a worker can make by automating its production lines. But gains for nurses and kindergarten teachers are far harder won -- indeed, the quality of education is often measured by the teacher-pupil ratio. As a result, Professor Baumol says, the costs of such services inevitably rise faster than overall inflation in the long run. And that effectively guarantees taxpayers will have to shell out more, in return for less.
A closer look at state and local finance confirms the diagnosis. Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of the States at the Rockefeller Institute in Albany, points out that the states' spending from their own tax sources for Medicaid and prisons have risen twice as fast as personal income since the mid-1970's. Total state outlays as a percentage of personal income barely grew -- but only because school enrollment slumped as a percentage of the population and the mentally ill were largely left to their fate on the streets.
 
Could Get Worse
 Mr. Gold notes, moreover, that the past is only prelude. School enrollments are rising faster than in the 1980's, as are the number of people eligible for Medicaid. And the 1980's surge in the prison population is not likely to be spent before the middle of the decade. That probably explains why the focus in state and local tax analysis these days is on reforms that broaden the tax base and insulate vital services from the anticipated effects of lagging revenue growth.
As a question of governance, the picture seems bleak: With voters apparently unreconciled to paying for services they demand from government, taxes are likely to remain an irritant eating at the fabric of rational public policy. But Richard Cooper, an economist at Harvard, does offer one slightly brighter perspective.
The tax burden on Americans, he notes, remains a little lower than the burden on Japanese and far lower than the burden on most Europeans. What is more, average tax burdens in the other advanced industrialized countries have been growing more rapidly.
This hardly proves that Americans are undertaxed; much obviously depends on democratically perceived need for government services. But Mr. Cooper points out that it does put the burden of proof on those who argue that high taxes are at the core of America's lagging economic performance.

HEADLINE: Sanctions Won't Hurt Qaddafi, His Foes Say

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 16

 BODY:
The latest confrontation between Western powers and the the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi comes as Libya's ties with African and Arab countries are fraying, its ability to carry out or support international acts of terror severely constrained and its economy beset by mismanagement and huge expenditures on questionable development projects.
Still, Libyan opponents of the Qaddafi leadership say the expected imposition of further economic sanctions, possibly next week, will only complicate the lives of ordinary Libyans without provoking Colonel Qaddafi's fall from power, which has been the desire of Western and some Arab governments. 
 "The idea of squeezing the Libyan people so that they in turn squeeze Qaddafi out does not work in our region," said Mansour Kikhia, a former Libyan foreign minister and now a leading opponent of the Government living in exile in France. "This has been amply demonstrated in Iraq where Saddam Hussein is still in control."
Like other opponents, Mr. Kikhia concedes that the external opposition groups are too feeble and divided to overthrow the 22-year-old Qaddafi leadership, while internal opponents, primarily Muslim fundamentalists, have been savagely repressed with arrests, detention without trial and torture.
"Our only hope is that he will continue to create his own problems until his regime becomes so embroiled in them it will simply collapse," Mr. Kikhia said in a telephone interview.
Nevertheless, the American indictment on Thursday of two Libyan Government intelligence agents in the Pan Am 103 bombing and the issuing of arrest warrants by a French judge last month for Libyans suspected of roles in the explosions of two passenger airliners in 1989 have made it highly unlikely that the North African country can regain international economic standing.
Arab diplomats here also noted that coordinated actions taken by the United States, France and Britain against Libya in the last few days constituted a clear signal to other militant governments in the Middle East, particularly Iran and Syria, that support of terror could bring severe reprisals.
 
Qaddafi's Unmet Goals
 Colonel Qaddafi, who overthrew the Libyan monarchy in 1969, has seen virtually none of his revolutionary ambitions come to pass. These foiled objectives have included:
*Efforts to export a political system based on a "rule of the masses" to any country, along with advocacy of a third-world theory intended to supplant capitalism and Communism. This doctrine, contained in a manuscript called the "Green Book," has become the laughing stock in African and Arab newspapers.
*Monetary or weapons support for Arab terrorist groups like the Palestinian renegade organization of Abu Nidal, and violent nationalist movements like the Irish Republican Army. These groups are strained by internal dissent and hampered in their existence by the collape of international Communism.
*Economic progress and development. Despite a yearly income from oil estimated at $7 billion to $8 billion, Libyan growth is severely hampered by a 300 percent yearly inflation rate and an expenditure of $25 billion to create a man-made "artificial river" to transport potable water in giant pipelines hundred of miles from the Mediterranean coast to the desert.
Salameh Ahmed Salameh, managing editor of the Egyptian newspaper Al Ahram, said: "They are throwing so much money on this project, which will only function for 50 or 60 years and deplete the underground reserves of sweet water. What is happening in that country can only be described as unreal." .
Now, anger against Libya in the wake of the Pan Am 103 indictment and French judicial action has opened the possibility that oil, virtually the country's only exportable product, may soon be boycotted by several important Western buyers, including France, Italy and Germany.

HEADLINE: Haiti's Exiled Chief Seeks to Punish Coup Plotters

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov.15

 BODY:
Six weeks after a violent army coup ousted his Government, Haiti's exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has called for national reconciliation, but says it must begin with the punishment of the officers who overthrew him.
Father Aristide's comments in an interview on Thursday came a day after a mission of the Organization of American States left Haiti with an agreement from legislators to continue efforts to restore constitutional order in the country. 
 Speaking in the hotel here that has been his base since the coup, Father Aristide appealed to Haiti's upper classes to compare their concerns over human rights and legal questions during his tenure of nearly eight months with the bloodshed and repression the country has seen under the military-backed provisional Government that replaced him.
"I will ask, as I have already asked, for all of the population, every segment of the population to make concessions around the table of dialogue, to extend each other a hand, and make the rights of everyone respected," Father Aristide said in his heavily guarded 20th-floor suite overlooking downtown Caracas.
 
Democracy 'Assassinated'
 Throughout the interview, Father Aristide returned bitterly to the army commander, Brig. Gen. Raoul Cedras, and a group of Haitian officers under him who he said must be punished before any solution to the country's political crisis could be achieved.
"The majority opted for democracy with their vote," said Father Aristide of his overwhelming victory in Haiti's first democratic elections last December. "Today," he added, referring to the army's senior commanders "Cedras, Maj. Francois Valme and their little group of putschists have assassinated that democracy by killing more than 1,000 people in one week."
International human rights groups have estimated the coup-related death toll at 180 to 500, but Father Aristide repeatedly used the figure of 1,000, citing what he said was the discovery of many victims in mass graves.
Some of Haiti's legislators have urged that General Cedras keep his post if Father Aristide should return, but the deposed leader rejected the idea out of hand, calling the army commander the author of crimes against humanity. If the army leaders are not jailed or exiled, he asked, "how can you protect democracy?"
Father Aristide said enlisted men, who some diplomats believe may be as violently opposed to the President's return as their superiors, merely "obey the commands they receive" and would be offered amnesty.
Asked if he could work with members of Parliament who had acquiesced in his overthrow by naming a provisional Government, Father Aristide said "the Constitution will decide." His bitterest comments were reserved for Haiti's interim Prime Minister, Jean-Jacques Honorat, formerly the head of a human rights monitoring group. Mr. Aristede said Mr. Honorat was "standing atop a pile of cadavers."
Father Aristide repeated an often-stated belief that the economic embargo imposed upon Haiti by the 34 members of the Organization of American States, which cut off gasoline and most other supplies to the country this month, would eventually enable him to return to power.
Expressing frustration over the growing length of his exile and the hardening sentiment against his return among many in Haiti's small elite, however, Father Aristide, who has previously ruled out the use of force, suggested for the first time that foreign intervention might be required.
"We can increase the sanctions if we must," he said. "In the case of Iraq, they knew it was necessary and they did it. In Moscow, there was no embargo and yet they removed that coup within three days. In Haiti, it has been a month and a half."
 
A Critical Measure
 In a bid for conciliation, the deposed President, who spoke in French throughout the 40-minute interview, said that he was willing to dissolve his Government "at the opportune moment" and replace it with a new Prime Minister and Cabinet to be selected in consultation with members of the opposition. Diplomats close to the O.A.S.-led talks called this offer a critical confidence-building measure.
Father Aristide, whose support remains strong among the poor who make up the bulk of Haiti's population, dismissed concerns expressed by many in the elite over his Government's commitment to constitutional rule and his perceived encouragement of mob violence.
"There has never been a government in Haiti that has respected human rights as much as ours," Father Aristide said.
During his time in office, he added, "there was never one case of Pere Lebrun," the popular name given to street lynchings with burning tires. Complaints about these incidents, he said, are "a pretext waved around as if you could hide the forest with a tree."
 
Comments Disputed
 In a telephone interview from New York, however, Kenneth Roth, deputy director of the human rights monitoring organization Americas Watch, disputed Father Aristide's comments on popular violence.
"To say there was no Pere Lebrun is ridiculous," Mr. Roth said. "By our count there were at least 25 cases, and we didn't imagine them.
"The biggest problem is not that Aristide did nothing to stop these incidents, despite his tremendous moral prestige. But in the last couple of months of his presidency, he actually gave two speeches encouraging Pere Lebrun."
Despite these concerns, however, Mr. Roth said the Aristide Government had made advances in human rights over other recent Haitian regimes.

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Are the Mets Waving $28 Million at Bonilla?

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
The Mets let Darryl Strawberry escape from New York last November, perhaps intentionally, but they have every intention of trying to lure Bobby Bonilla home. They may be so determined to achieve their goal that they will offer Bonilla $28 million for five years.
It isn't known if the Mets will make that offer to baseball's No. 1 free agent in their meeting scheduled for today. But word that has emerged from a circle of baseball people close to the Mets is that General Manager Al Harazin has decided to try to secure Bonilla's services with the staggering offer of $5.6 million a year. 
 No confirmation of the figures was available. Harazin did not return a telephone call seeking comment on that report; he wouldn't disclose his plans anyway. Another baseball executive familiar with the Mets' general thinking said: "I don't know that, but I can believe it. They want Bonilla very badly. They have to do something striking to improve their fan base."
Once Bonilla became a free agent, it was generally felt that he would get at least $5 million a year for five years. He and his agent, Dennis Gilbert, certainly are confident of that because they recently rejected the Pittsburgh Pirates' latest offer of $18.5 million for four years.
Because the California Angels, buoyed by Gene Autry's ready-to-spend money, are also eager to add Bonilla to their lineup, it was further believed that the outfielder very likely could reach $6 million a year. If the Mets are serious about offering $5.6 million, what's another $400,000 a year?
Why would the Mets be prepared to give Bonilla $28 million? They certainly weren't willing to go anywhere near that level to keep Strawberry a year ago, although the nagging suspicion remains that they didn't want to keep him. There are two ways of viewing the likelihood of such an offer.
One is that it is highly unlikely. Harazin has grown up in the baseball business under the conservative Frank Cashen, this argument goes, and he wouldn't be able to break out of the fiscal constraints that Cashen employed in his lengthy tenure as general manager.
The other view, however, is that Harazin deliberately, though not altogether insanely, would flex his economic muscles to establish his own identity, to serve notice that he is no Cashen clone. How better to achieve that aim than by overwhelming Bonilla and inserting him in the middle of the Mets' lineup, where Strawberry once cavorted.
Harazin has another reason to make a dramatic move and instantly restore the Mets to contending status. He wants to prove himself worthy of his new job.
Until a year ago, the Mets planned to replace Cashen, when he retired, with a two-headed team of Joe McIlvaine and Harazin. McIlvaine would have handled the personnel end, Harazin the business side. But McIlvaine stunned the Mets by becoming general manager of the San Diego Padres, and that left Harazin to be in charge of personnel as well.
Harazin has come to the job, though, with the reputation that all business-side executives have: they don't know personnel. Harazin feels otherwise and wants to show he can do the job. Catapulting the team back into contention would support his view.
If Harazin is prepared to offer Bonilla $28 million for five years, he would be making a bold move. But what would he do if Whitey Herzog offered more on behalf of the Angels? Harazin has said he won't do anything stupid or crazy. Would he be willing to raise his bid?
The answer to the question may lie in Harazin's definition of stupid and crazy. He hasn't said, but $6 million a year probably would be it.
 
On Selig, Signings and Sanity
 As chairman of the Player Relations Committee board of directors, Bud Selig screams out for fiscal sanity. When he hears about the kind of signing Bonilla will be, he shakes his head, looks forlorn and warns of imminent disaster. "He's absolutely vitriolic," one colleague said.
But in the best do-as-I-say-not-as-I-do tradition, as owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, Selig undergoes a metamorphosis and authorizes some highly questionable signings.
Last year, he gave Ted Higuera $13 million for four years despite the pitcher's lengthy history of physical problems. Six starts into the contract, Higuera was finished for the season with a torn rotator cuff. His future status as a pitcher is far from assured.
Discussing the Higuera signing last August, shortly before the left-hander's operation, Selig stressed that the rotator-cuff tear was unrelated to his previous problems, which involved his back, a knee and an ankle.
"We knew it was a gamble, but it was a gamble on other parts," the owner said. "You could say we should have seen it coming; if it was his back, I could say we were dumb. But his back, knee and ankle are fine."
What, then, is Selig's excuse for ignoring his own preaching about not giving players more than three years, and signing Bill Wegman last week to a four-year, $9.5 million contract?
Wegman had shoulder surgery in 1989 and elbow surgery in 1990, serving on the disabled list for the last four months of each season and the first 25 days of the past season. The Brewers are taking a four-year gamble not on the pitcher's back, knee and ankle but on his arm.
Wegman himself acknowledged surprise that he got four years, saying he thought it would be difficult to get the three years that he wanted.
Selig did not return telephone calls to explain his thinking on the Wegman signing, but Sal Bando, his new general manager, said that the Brewers indeed practiced "fiscal responsibility" in the signing.
"There's no way we would have done the money they were asking for three years," Bando said. "We had to do four years. I think Bud's in a difficult position because they're preaching fiscal responsibility. I'm saying we thought we were in terms of the final product."
 
No Elbow Room in Boston
 Even in the unusual configuration of Fenway Park, Mike Greenwell, Ellis Burks, Phil Plantier, Carlos Quintana, Tom Brunansky and Mo Vaughn do not fit into three outfield positions and first base. Someone -- or two -- has to go.
The crowd might seem like a problem for the Boston Red Sox, but it's really their strength. Like most teams, they desperately need a starting pitcher or two -- Roger Clemens can pitch only once every five days -- and they are one of the few teams with legitimate players to trade.
"You've got to move somebody," General Manager Lou Gorman said. "There's a chance we would do something."
The arrival of Plantier in the outfield and Vaughn at first base this year created the crowd. Plantier, who batted .331 and drove in a run every 4.2 times at bat, can play left field or right, meaning he could replace Greenwell or Brunansky. But Quintana, a .295 hitter, also can play right, especially if Vaughn drives in enough runs to play first regularly.
Brunansky is the member of the group the Red Sox would most like to shed, but he woouldn't bring the quality pitcher Greenwell or Burks would. Of the two, Greenwell is the most likely to be traded because his value would be higher than Burks's right now, and Burks is the only legitimate center fielder the team has.
Plagued by physical ailments this year, Burks batted .251 and drove in 56 runs, the nadir of his five-year Red Sox career.
"He could bounce back and have a heck of a year," Gorman said.
 
Cubs' Corporate Ladder
 First Don Grenesko, president, and now Jim Frey, general manager, have paid the corporate price for moves that didn't work.
Last month, The Tribune Company, owner of the Chicago Cubs, "promoted" Grenesko into a corporate position as vice president and chief financial officer. He was deemed to have bungled the managerial move the Cubs made last May when he replaced Don Zimmer with Jim Essian.
Frey, a friend of Zimmer since boyhood, lost that battle and last week he lost the war, though not deservedly so. He was replaced by Larry Himes and will return to Baltimore, where he will serve out the remaining year of his contract as senior vice president, a glorified title for a scout.
After Frey persuaded the bottom-line owners last winter to commit $25.2 million for the free agents Danny Jackson, George Bell and Dave Smith, he was asked if his job would be on the line if the team didn't win.
"I don't feel that that's the natural consequence of spending money," he said. "If that was the case, there would be 25 clubs at the end of the year where the general manager should probably feel uncomfortable."
It wasn't just that the Cubs didn't win that bothered Tribune officials. It was that Jackson, an injury-prone pitcher, was injured much of the time -- he made only 14 starts -- and Smith, too, broke down.
Frey, who learned of the change at 5:30 P.M. Wednesday, took it philosophically.
"When it's time to leave," he said, "there's always disappointment and frustration at not getting where you want to be. But over all, I've had a great time in Chicago. I managed the team, we won a division championship and I came back as general manager and had four great years. There was a lot of disappointnment this year because of our high expectations. I guess that's why I'm leaving. Because of developments here the last month, it was a little surprising. All you heard and read about was a new president and my role would be same. Then a couple of days ago they made a switch."
In scouting players in East Coast parks, Frey will encounter Dallas Green, who works out of Philadelphia in a similar role for the Mets. Green, who was the Cubs' president, fired Frey as the team's manager in 1986, and the two have not cared for each other since.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Berlin's Denkmal War

 BODY:
Paint it purple. Let vines grow on it. Put it in quarantine by storing it in a museum. Or tilt it sideways, thus mocking its purpose.
These were among the imaginative ideas advanced in the great German debate about the 60-foot statue of Lenin in eastern Berlin, an argument now settled by a court decision ordering its removal. Unresolved is a harder question for Berliners: What other reminders of their past should be kept, or thrown away? 
 Opinions on this are almost as plentiful as the Denkmals, or memorials, that abound in what used to be Berlin's Communist half. Especially contentious is the fate of plaques and street names honoring victims in the anti-Nazi resistance -- many of them Communists who died opposing Hitler's monstrous Reich. Is their sacrifice negated by the misdeeds of an East German regime for which they bore no responsibility?
This recent visitor felt like an eavesdropper in a passionate family quarrel.
Alfred Kernd'l, Berlin's city archeologist, speaks for the preservationists: "All the memorials are now part of our history. Germany doesn't have that much national identity. It would be far more honest to connect with our past, rather than close our eyes to it."
Christoph Stolzl, the director of the new German History Museum, pertinently notes that Allied forces in 1945 forbade the public display of Nazi symbols, a ban made permanent by West and East German regimes. "And does anyone regret that?" Whatever case can be made for saving Denkmals honoring German leftists, he goes on, "I draw the line at Lenin, Stalin's mass-killing predecessor -- I'd feel the same about a statue to Goering."
Hans Otto Brautigam, a former West German diplomat and now Minister of Justice in Brandenburg, adjoining eastern Berlin, makes a distinction between destroying a monument in the euphoria of revolt and doing so as a calculated act. "It's perhaps best to let the people who live with it make the decision."
As the argument rages, some people have already removed tablets from their homes recording the death of anti-Nazi fighters. Young "guerrilla archeologists" have responded by putting up fresh markers. An especially troubling dispute concerns a high school once named for Mildred Fish Harnack, an American who was guillotined by the Nazis in 1943. It is now the "Fifth Comprehensive School," pending a decision by the Berlin Senate on whether to restore the old name -- as its students and teachers wish.
My parents knew Mildred in Wisconsin, where she married a German economist, Arvid Harnack. They returned to Germany, where Arvid became co-leader of a Berlin resistance group that Hitler's Abwehr named "the Red Orchestra." After their arrest and torture, Arvid was sentenced to death, Mildred to hard labor. Her retrial was ordered by Hitler himself, and a compliant military tribunal ordered her execution. She was 40.
In the West, the Harnacks' memory has been clouded by the controversies over their group's transmission of military secrets to the Soviet Union. Yet German Communists and their Marxist allies were among the first to challenge Hitler from within -- indeed, no resistance faction endured more executions. That truth is generously recognized in a museum in western Berlin devoted to the resistance, scrupulously documented by its director, Peter Steinbach of Passau University.
The Lenin statue is a simpler matter; so is the removal of hammers and sickles. But to strip the Mildred Harnack School of its name would dishonor a brave American and historical truth. She and her associates did what they could to oppose a truly evil regime. Their resistance was a moral, not a political, choice; it should not be forgotten. -- KARL E. MEYER

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Infamy Is Still Infamy

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
As Dec. 7 and the 50th anniversary of the day of infamy approach, Japanese are embracing an infamous explanation to excuse their guilt for World War II. Japan, so the story goes, did not really launch a sneak attack against Pearl Harbor.
It is an elaborate tale about a diplomatic message so badly mishandled by Japan's Embassy in Washington that the warning of war it contained did not get through until after Japanese aircraft had already loosed their bombs and torpedoes. 
 The tale has such power that when it was raised recently in the Diet, or parliament, Foreign Minister Nakayama felt compelled to make "a bow of contrition for an event that occurred when he was a schoolchild," as Ayako Doi writes in The Daily Japan Digest.
The suggestion of innocence is as frightening as it is preposterous. What would have been changed if the Japanese Embassy had given advance notice of attack as required by international law? What consciences would have been quieted if the U.S. had been provided with what amounted to a few minutes' warning? The results would have been the same at Pearl Harbor and in the minds of horrified Americans.
That so many Japanese fail to understand this demonstrates the galactic chasm still separating the two societies, one that transcends economic competition.
The story as recounted in Japan Digest is an old one that has gained new currency on the eve of Pearl Harbor. Here it is.
On Saturday, Dec. 6, Tokyo transmitted a 14-page telegram to its Washington embassy. The critical last page with delivery instructions was not even translated until Sunday morning because the officer in charge was busy organizing a Chinese dinner for a departing colleague. A First Secretary was told to do the translation and typing himself. His typing was very slow and inaccurate, forcing Ambassador Nomura to delay his Sunday 1 P.M. appointment with Secretary of State Cordell Hull until 2 P.M. The Ambassador arrived at 2:05 and was kept waiting until 2:20. By that time, the attack had been under way for an hour. (And by the way, hours after the U.S. had already intercepted and decoded the same message.)
These facts are apparently not in dispute. The question is the meaning of the facts. Many Japanese want them to mean that Tokyo intended to observe accepted rules of war and declare war before striking. If the diplomats had done their job properly, they say, the action at Pearl Harbor would have been a "surprise," but not a "sneak" attack. Thus, restored honor and no Japanese guilt.
That explanation is of a piece with the prevailing Japanese view that because President Roosevelt imposed economic sanctions on Japan, Tokyo had no choice but to attack as the only way of avoiding economic strangulation. Lost in this rendition of history is the fact that U.S. sanctions came in stages and only after Japan had invaded Manchuria, China and Indochina.
Japanese also pair Pearl Harbor and Hiroshima, writes Columbia historian Carol Gluck, and see them as forming "a tidy moral calculus in which Japan's aggressive attack is balanced by the nuclear bombings. . . ."
John Toland, the great popular historian of this period, believes the Japanese have good grounds for thinking they behaved no worse than other colonial powers like Britain and France. He also believes the Japanese were special victims because the U.S. dropped two atomic bombs on them "that weren't necessary." He said in a telephone interview that there is no need now for a Japanese apology.
A group of Japanese historians and civil activists think otherwise. They have petitioned their Government "to apologize publicly for these transgressions," pay damages to the victims of Japanese aggression and conduct an inquiry into the historical facts of the war.
The Japanese people should listen to these voices, and not to the siren songs of their historical revisionists who destroy all sense of cause and effect, right and wrong. These contortionists give new weight to Japan-bashers and to those who argue it is hopeless for Americans to communicate and cooperate with the Japanese.
As the Pearl Harbor anniversary nears, this much is clear: If Japan wants to rewrite World War II with self-indulgent myths, the infamy will linger and the end will be the same.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Let's Reward Investments That Aid Economy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The depressing news about the lack of growth in the economy is again raising discussions about tax relief and heating up the debate over special tax rates for capital gains. The theory behind capital-gains tax preferences is that they stimulate the economy by rewarding people who invest in creating new capital assets. 
 In reality, most capital transactions have nothing to do with creating new capital assets, but are trades of publicly held securities or of real estate. To reward those who invest their excess funds in stocks or buildings, rather than savings accounts is another way of rewarding the richest segments of the community at the expense of the rest of us.
But real capital investment is essential to economic growth and should be rewarded. Real capital investment involves creation of jobs and the purchase of all kinds of capital goods. Thus, a person who buys a new issue of stock, where the proceeds go to the company, which uses the money to increase inventory or build production facilities, really does make a contribution to the economy, and the investor deserves special tax treatment. But what has the person who buys the stock from that investor done to aid the economy -- nothing.
Similarly, when an investor builds a building and creates something of value, those profits should receive special treatment. The syndicate that then buys it should receive no special benefits. If the later buyer improves the capital asset to produce a positive effect on the economy, the profits on that portion of the proceeds should be entitled to special treatment.
We have to stop using catch phrases like economic growth as a justification for hurting the middle-income taxpayer more. Why not reward those who help our economy and tax those who produce nothing except profit from buying and selling the work product of others?
If we have learned nothing else from the disastrous excesses of the 1980's, we should have learned that Wall Street has long since ceased providing a means of collectively financing the growth of an industrial society, and to a sickening degree has become the arena of those who only take.
 
BARTON A. PASTERNAK
Wyncote, Pa., Nov. 1, 1991

HEADLINE: Let's Reward Investments That Aid Economy;
Interest-Rate Puzzle

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Lower interest rates always have been a good way of stimulating the economy," says Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman (front page, Nov. 2). This fundamental wisdom is offered daily by economists, government officials and television pundits. As a nonexpert, I don't understand it. 
 I can see how lower interest rates may benefit banks, savings and loan institutions, insurance companies and other lenders, as well as Wall Street speculators and big corporations that borrow millions of dollars. But I cannot see how lower rates benefit the millions of Americans out of work and the millions of families scraping by with two or more breadwinners, not to mention the millions who are poverty stricken and those on welfare. They don't have money to buy, whatever the interest rates. At the same time, lower rates reduce the purchasing power of the retired and others who have some savings.
Interest rates have come down steadily; yet the economy "is heading back into recession," according to Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, chairman of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee. It seems to me this interest-rate notion is merely part of the trickle-down theory, which didn't work for Herbert Hoover and isn't working for George Bush.
The only common-sense way to escape the economic morass is to put dollars in the pockets of the millions of Americans who need to spend them to stimulate our vast production machine. And the only productive way to put those dollars there is, as the New Deal experience showed, through massive Government-sponsored public works -- on the infrastructure, the environment, health care, housing, education and other parts of our society needing repair and improvement.
While awaiting some real proof that interest rates play the determining role in the economy, all I can see is that both are going down, down, down.
 
GEORGE F. NELSON
New York, Nov. 3, 1991

HEADLINE: Let's Reward Investments That Aid Economy;
To Boost Spending

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The most recent increase in the unemployment rate to 6.8 percent is, almost literally, the tip of the iceberg. Our economy is cold and threatens to get colder. The chilling fact is that layoffs continue, even by strong, profitable companies and states and municipalities that must balance their budgets. Add to this the hundreds of thousands of Persian Gulf war veterans who will displace their substitute workers or be added directly to the ranks of the unemployed. 
 It is not only the jobless who are not prime prospects to buy the big-ticket items and power the economy by consumer spending. Millions of the employed are chary in spending, fearing the dreaded pink slip.
Our projected Federal budget deficits are rising, and the actual figures from 1969 to 1988 have exceeded projections by a whopping 41 percent.
One of the few bright spots has been the improvement in our balance of trade. But before we do cartwheels, consider these two facts. We are still running tens of billions on the negative side. Then, our better trade balance is destined to be ephemeral. Our stronger dollar, by about 25 percent from its low, makes us less competitive and will be reflected adversely in several months.
Taxes, under various names, are being raised at the city, state and national levels, further reducing disposable funds. One of the few boom sectors is bankruptcy law. Bankruptcies rose 20 percent in 1990 over 1989 and a horrific 50 percent for the first six months of 1991.
Instead of beating our breasts and banging our heads against the wall, what should we do? We have an option requiring bold decisions.
We have the dubious distinction of being the largest debtor nation in the world. Yet, when you owe trillions, it would not exacerbate your financial condition much to borrow the hundreds of billions for a positive remedy -- repair of our decaying infrastructure, improvement of our second-rate educational system, adoption of Jack Kemp's building program.
There are hundreds of competent business people, including those prematurely retired, who would be proud to serve on such constructive programs.
 
HERBERT BARCHOFF
New York, Nov. 6, 1991
 
The writer served on the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

HEADLINE: The Bleu-Plate Special

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER KENNEALLY; CHRISTOPHER KENNEALLY lived and worked in Brittany this spring.

 BODY:
THE French do not necessarily eat better than Americans -- the difference lies in that they eat with deep conviction. In France, food is handled with the care usually reserved for that which is sacred, and meals are conducted like religious rituals -- thoughtfully, respectfully, but especially slowly. Even at lunch, a sort of culinary pit stop for most Americans, several courses are ceremoniously served, often concluding with both cheese and dessert. Coffee arrives long after the last dishes are cleared away.
Inevitably, especially on an extended trip, the real American longs, in spite of higher principles, to get a meal over with quickly. On the road, one begins to wish for the sort of place so common at home, where an entire meal arrives on one plate and coffee is poured even before ordering. 
 Of course, if speed is the only consideration, one could pull over at a McDonald's, which in French towns are usually on what the billboards call "McDrive." Somehow, though, that seems like cheating.
So, on an extended stay in Brittany last spring, our quest became to find a native experience, roughly the equivalent of an American truck stop. The search, however, was not easy. For one thing, there are no obvious architectural clues. The French apparently were never introduced to chrome-skinned, streamlined diner cars. In the country, modern French roadside architecture is, sadly, a monotonous collection of enormous prefabricated warehouses and hypermarkets broken up only by cinder-block bar-restaurants. The name for such a bar-restaurant -- un relais -- dates from a time when coaches would pause on their routes to change horses. The average relais is not much to look at and is usually little more than a local watering hole or whatever the French would call a dive.
In Brittany an honest-to-God truck stop would seem to be a necessity. Les routiers, the French truck drivers who ride high up in their cabs, hidden behind soccer team pennants strung across the windshields like blinds, are always racing up and down the Breton roads, hauling their loads to and from Channel ports and surely working up healthy appetites.
Trucks are common on local roads, too, because all French superhighways are expensive toll roads. Economically minded routiers haul their rigs on the four-lane nationals and even more narrow departmental roads. They made life rather anxious for anyone driving an Opel the size of a paperweight, but their presence raised considerably the chances that we would come upon a genuine truck stop.
Our patience and attention were rewarded on a departmental route outside Paimpol in Cote-du-Nord, Brittany's northernmost department. The road through the countryside was lined with dusty, newly plowed fields and lush pastures. Just after noon, we passed at a fast clip a plain, vanilla-colored, peak-roofed Bar Restaurant. The single-story building was long and massive and stood alone among the grazing cows and growing corn. The parking lot beside it was as big as a field and was neatly arranged with rows of rigs. Not much farther up the road, we made a U-turn.
All types and sizes of French trucks were there, from semis with long trailers and Citroen repair vans to the ubiquitous Renault 4, the drayhorse of French plumbers and tradespeople. In the parking lot, I began singing.
"POUR me another cup of coffee/ For it is the best in the land/ I'll put a nickel in the jukebox/ And play the 'Truck Drivin' Man.' " As I pulled the door open, I did not hear any Buck Owens playing on a jukebox. A sign advertised that the day's "menu" was available for 46 francs (at that time, about $7.50). Inside, the bar was nearly empty. A few older men sat by a window table with little glasses of red wine in their greasy fingers. Near the cash register, a middle-aged woman, peroxide blonde, exhaled smoke and waved us on into the next room.
A hallful of routiers looked up from their meals as we entered. The place was as completely male as a locker room, and my wife was regarded with suspicion -- almost certainly because she was a woman who was not carrying a tray of food.
We received directions from a pale waitress with a sweaty brow who was working the hall alone. She motioned to a cafeteria-style display of hors d'oeuvres -- pleasantly arranged plates of pungent saucisses, pate and melon -- and we were told to sit where we liked. Already we were impressed, for this was by far the quickest first course we had ever been served in France. We would not, though, be getting our meal on one plate.
The hall was rather plain, with large windows at one side that looked out on the parking lot and only a few cheap landscape paintings hanging on the walls. There was no music at all. Of course, because this was France, a smokers' paradise, a thick blue haze hung between the tables and the ceiling.
At the table beside ours, a half dozen truck drivers were in the midst of their meal. We spotted several empty wine bottles. The waitress brought the men a large tray of bread, and we were awed as they dispatched it roughly and instantly. A moment later, she returned with a tray on each muscular arm, one plate heaped with steaming boiled potatoes, the other loaded with baked turkey breasts in gravy. A wine bottle was uncorked and passed around. I had not seen food so roundly attacked since dinners at Boy Scout summer camp.
THE wine, we soon learned, was included in the price of the meal along with mineral water. We uncorked and sniffed our own bottle of Blason d'Or, a blend of red table wines, the label explained, from the countries of the European Community. The Eurowine had no discernible taste and rather quickly delivered a dull ache to the temples, but our glasses could be refilled as endlessly as coffee mugs in diners back home.
We, too, ate the baked turkey -- the other choice of the day, roast veal, was fini -- which was hot and tender and plentiful, more than we two could finish. The service was quick and, considering the waitress was outnumbered 50 to 1, cheerful. It felt good to be eating, for once, without the usual French pomp and circumstance, but the difference between a Gallic truck stop and an American one was so striking as to amount to a revelation of sorts.
For one thing, no one was eating alone at this "rendez-vous routiers" -- the proper name, we later learned, for such places. There are no solo acts in French restaurants, it would seem, not even on the road. A dusty driver could no more haul himself in there and order a piece of pie and coffee at the counter than a diner in the United States would serve a cheese course.
What is lacking in France -- without implying that the lack is a negative one -- is the culture of the road that is so much a part of American life. The windows at the rendez-vous routiers we visited subtly acknowledged that by disregarding the road entirely. At home, a diner or truck stop always has the road in view.
The road is enjoyed in America for its own sake, often by the solo traveler, a springboard for independence or merely flight. Turning their backs to the road, the French routiers we ate among had re-created home in their rendez-vous, complete with a substitute wife, overworked and unappreciated. The men ate and talked at table as family members might.
Moreover, the French are so entirely devoted to food and to eating that even at a truck stop, about as godless a dining experience as exists, they refused to lapse into culinary atheism. Our meal went on after the turkey and potatoes to include a selection of cheeses as well as dessert. The cheeses were a bit on the dry side, but the dessert -- a rum-soaked cupcake topped with a red maraschino cherry and whipped cream -- had a satisfying gooeyness. Remarkably, we knew what we were eating the entire time.
It was approaching 2 o'clock before we took the last sips of coffee. Around us, the tables now were nearly empty and a cloud of dust in the air above the parking lot was the only indication that once a crowd of empty trucks had waited there. There was still a good bit of Blason d'Or left, and we judged that we could drive safely. We walked back through the dark bar, paid up for the meals and the coffee, and hit the road.

HEADLINE: Focus: Charleston, S.C.;
For a Mansion, T.L.C. With No Plan to Sell

BYLINE: By LYN RIDDLE

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, S.C.

 BODY:
IN this city's historic Battery District, where century-old mansions grace picturesque streets at river's edge, the din of hammering and sawing has become as much a part of life as gawking tourists in horse-drawn carriages.
But for Edward L. Henning, the sounds soon will cease. After four years, the restoration of his Italianate mansion at 21 King Street, a block from Charleston Harbor, is now only two rooms shy of completion. 
 He won't say what the work has cost him, but the word about town is that the bill approaches $2.5 million, not including the $625,000 he paid for the 12,000-square-foot, 140-year-old house in 1987. The restoration, which has involved about 60 craftsmen, is expected to be completed early next year, Mr. Henning said.
History buffs and preservationists call it the grandest remake ever of a private home in South Carolina.
And they praise Mr. Henning, who is a McDonald's restaurant franchisee, for turning a lackluster antebellum relic into an elegant heirloom.
Unlike some who have bought historic properties to fix and sell at a profit, Mr. Henning has no plans to sell his. And that is what the market needs badly, brokers say: More Mr. Hennings to take advantage of the glut in grand old houses -- there have never been so many for sale at one time -- sink money into them, and not plan to resell any time soon.
In the area where Mr. Henning lives, five houses are on the market now, joining numerous others in the surrounding downtown neighborhoods.
Vic Brandt, a broker who specializes in selling houses in the Battery area, said the market is glutted for two reasons: repairs from the disastrous Hurricane Hugo in 1989 have delayed sales and the recession has restricted the real estate market overall.
One notable house for sale is the Battery Carriage House, a well-known inn with an asking price of $3 million. It is across the street from White Point Gardens, a park, better known as the Battery, at the tip of the peninsula where the Ashley and Cooper Rivers meet.
The inn -- it was used in the television miniseries "North/South" -- has 11 rooms plus a 9,500-square-foot residence at the rear. Mr. Brandt estimates it could take $1 million to repair the damage left by the four feet of water swept inside by Hurricane Hugo and other rain damage.
OTHER homes now offered for sale are held by empty-nesters or widows who want smaller residences. They include a 181-year-old house covering 5,100 square feet with an asking price $1.95 million and a 6,230-square-foot house built in 1768 by a cousin of George Washington. The asking price for that house, which faces Charleston Harbor, is $1.7 million.
The cost of the historic mansions here has remained relatively low, although most are now over $1 million, Mr. Brandt said. As recently as 1983, a 10,000-square-foot Baroque-style mansion built in 1850 on East Battery (along the Cooper River) sold for $315,000.
"Before 1985, they were viewed as white elephants," said Mr. Brandt.
Prices have edged upward primarily because of the newcomers who move here, attracted by Charleston's mild climate (average temperature 65 degrees), diversified economy and low real estate costs, said Mr. Brandt. Many sold high-priced homes in the Northeast and bring with them the means for serious renovations. Half of the mansion buyers here pay cash.
In January, an English couple bought a museum-quality Georgian house for just over $1 million. And last year the New York art dealer Andrew Crispo spent $2 million for his 1802 "pineapple-gate" mansion, the most ever paid for a house in Charleston, Mr. Brandt said.
Charlestonians say Mr. Henning's accomplishment stands out even in a city known for historic preservation and for the extensive restoration work it has had to do in the two years since Hurricane Hugo swept through. Charleston is South Carolina's oldest city and in 1931 it became the first in the nation to pass a historic preservation ordinance.
Most of the 42 houses in the Battery District, which looks out on Fort Sumter about three miles to the southeast in the harbor, were damaged by the hurricane. The venerable homes withstood the storm's high winds but were brutalized by the ensuing rains that poured into damaged roofs.
The hurricane set Mr. Henning back a year. Water damaged the interior, which had been stripped of paint but not yet repainted, and the wind furiously shook three stories of newly built porches.
But the poor condition of the house after the hurricane did not exceed what Mr. Henning found when he bought it.
"This house was a total wreck," he said. "It had not been fixed up in 75 to 100 years."
Like most people who undertake a renovation, the 54-year-old Mr. Henning soon found it all-consuming. Time and money flowed out like blood from a wound.
BUT he faced problems most renovators don't: He stripped 50 coats of paint from the walls. Nearly 2,000 pieces of molding at the roof line needed replacing. Plaster ceilings were reworked and elaborate door fixtures repaired.
"Every room in the house had to be redone," said Mr. Henning, who owns 14 McDonald's restaurants in the area. "And since they don't usually do this type of work, most of the craftsmen had to learn how. We kept digging and digging until we could go no further."
The library ceiling's elaborate detail was redone five times, Mr. Henning said.
"The house demands this quality," he said. "It's not a palace, but for architectural detail, there's nothing like it here."
THE house was built over nine years by Patrick O'Donnell, a master builder, as a home for himself and his future bride. But as sometimes happens, the fiancee grew tired of waiting and married someone else. The house became known as "O'Donnell's Folly," a name that has stuck.
The three-story house, the largest on the street, fills its a narrow lot. A sweeping staircase rises from the entranceway, with two formal ballrooms on the left, a dining room, library and kitchen at the rear.
As in most houses of the mid-19th century, the reception rooms on the first floor are taller and grander than the bedrooms on the two upper floors.
The ceiling designs and other ornamental features have been painted to bring out the intricate patterns.
Moldings, too, are painted in several colors to highlight the detail.
"God, I don't want to do this again," said Mr. Henning. "But it's very difficult not to develop an affection for this place. It's incredible."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Edward L. Henning outside his Italianate mansion on King Street. His renovation there is almost over. (Lyn Riddle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
'Edge Cities': The People's Answer to Planners

BYLINE: By Witold Rybczynski; Witold Rybczynski, the author of "Waiting for the Weekend," is a professor of architecture at McGill University in Montreal.

 BODY:
Many would argue that "North American city planning" is an oxymoron. After all, the typical American city exhibits few of the physical features generally associated with the traditional planned cities of Europe. There are exceptions -- the squared quadrants of Philadelphia and Savannah, the ceremonial axes of Washington, the formal civic parks of New York and Chicago -- but these only underline the fact that the regularly gridded cities of Canada and the United States appear to owe more to the surveyor than to the city planner.
 And whether one looks down from an airplane or out from a moving car, not even the street grid is enough to dispel the impression that the development of most cities has been casual, almost haphazard. No overpowering vision seems to have guided their evolution -- like Topsy, they just grew. 
 Not that North American cities lack form, but their shape seems to be the result less of the resolution of an individual's will -- of a Peter the Great, a John Nash or a Baron Haussmann -- than of anonymous, pragmatic decisions to build railroads, highways, or factories. To understand the shape of the American city one has to appreciate the ripple effect of technologies like the commuter train, the automobile, steel frame construction and the elevator.
 And what about the influence of master plans? One has to go back to the turn-of-the-century City Beautiful movement and Daniel Burnham's ambitious plan for Chicago, which inspired downtown civic centers in cities like San Francisco, Cleveland and Pasadena, to find a time when the physical form of American cities was shaped by artistic considerations. Houston, which tripled in population between 1970 and 1980, is infamous among planners as the only major American city that has grown without the benefit of zoning regulations, that is, without one of the chief tools of the city planner. What is striking about Houston, however, is not how different it looks but how familiar. Like most other North American cities, Houston is the expression, by and large, not of an esthetic ideal but of economic forces.
 Perhaps that explains why the most insightful texts on city planning have been written by observers rather than practitioners. In Europe, the authors are professional planners like Camillo Sitte and Patrick Geddes, or in the case of Rob Krier's "Urban Space," an architect. In America, they are social critics like Lewis Mumford, Jane Jacobs, Herbert Gans and William H. Whyte, or by essayists like Tom Wolfe and Richard Sennett. Not that American planners and architects haven't addressed the subject, but their proposals have usually seemed slightly irrelevant and beside the point, and just about as useful as a copy of the Larousse Gastronomique would be to a short-order cook in a roadside hash house.
 "Learning From Las Vegas," a 1972 book by Robert Venturi, Denise Scott Brown and Steven Izenour, did try to grapple with the architectural implications of unbridled, commercial urban growth, but one was never sure if the authors were really embracing their subject or merely using it as an unlikely source of formal -- and ironic -- inspiration, which is not quite the same thing. Yet even such a mild manifesto as "Learning From Las Vegas" was anathema to most planners, architects and other design professionals, who generally deplored the commercial forces that were shaping the city.
 The prejudices of planners and architects -- cars are bad, density is good -- put them at odds with the general American public, which believes the exact opposite. And although planners are aware of the suburbs, they assume that these outlying areas can be ignored since they will always be dependent on the traditional city center, whose revitalization has remained the focus of architectural attention. As for a city like Los Angeles, which appears to be following a different path, it is scornfully disregarded as a Southern Californian aberration -- "Isn't San Francisco so much nicer?"
 In fact, as Joel Garreau points out in his new book, "Edge City: Life on the New Frontier," every single American city that is growing today is growing precisely in the fashion of Los Angeles, with multiple urban centers at some distance from the old downtown. What Mr. Garreau (a journalist, not a planner) calls "edge cities" usually begin as a shopping mall at the intersection of two interstate highways. The mall gets bigger, office space is added, a hotel; several corporations establish their headquarters nearby (conveniently close to a regional airport, which also expands). Employees need housing, and housing means schools, community centers, golf courses and medical facilities. Pretty soon, the intersection of two highways (which may still have no formal name -- Mr. Garreau refers to an edge city in New Jersey as "287 & 78") is providing jobs and retail services for thousands of people.
 On paper, then, these centers have most of the attributes of cities (employment, stores, entertainment); on the ground, they are completely unlike any traditional idea of the city. They are spread out, which is why they are often confused with suburbs. Instead of streets and blocks, there are highways, parking lots and vast interior malls (although often referred to as shopping malls, these are really pedestrian mini-cities).
 Towns have always been built in response to transportation technology, whether it was the clipper ship, the canal barge or the railroad. Obviously, it is the automobile that has produced the low-density edge city (as it did Frank Lloyd Wright's theoretical proposal for Broadacre City), but as Mr. Garreau notes, two other technologies have also played an important role: the jet plane and the computer. The ability to move people and information quickly from one place to another has enabled corporations to radically decentralize their operations, relocating their headquarters and most of their staff from the downtowns and into the country.
 In the last 30 years, this migration has produced peripheral centers on the edges of Los Angeles, Houston, Atlanta, Toronto, Montreal, New York, Boston, Washington and San Francisco. Indeed, almost all urban growth now takes place in these peripheral cities. And they are big: Houston's Galleria is larger than downtown Minneapolis; Fairfax County, Va., the site of several centers, now has a greater population than adjacent Washington.
 All this adds up to what is probably the most vigorous period of city-building in the last hundred years. And yet, Mr. Garreau's insightful book apart, it is going on largely unremarked. Perhaps that is inevitable. We often appreciate cities most when they are, so to speak, in their dotage, forgetting that even such charming places as Venice and London were, at one time, raw, unrefined and immature, centers of commerce rather than culture. And while the American edge cities are, for the moment, singularly bereft of visual charm, who is to say that these awkward teen-agers will not also one day grow into engaging adults?

HEADLINE: The Executive Life;
A Little Light Magic Gets the Word Out

BYLINE: By Nancy Marx Better

 BODY:
Relocating offices is never easy and a slumping economy makes it even worse. That's why, when a big insurance company decided to relocate 300 executives from New York to Hartford earlier this year, it hired Bill Herz to help.
Mr. Herz didn't provide psychological counseling for executives afraid of the transition or professional guidance for their spouses. No. He did tricks. Magic tricks. And now the company does not even want him to mention its name because if shareholders were to find out, they might consider it frivolous in light of further bad news it plans to announce soon. But magic, according to Mr. Herz, serves a purpose. Although it may not make executives want to move, he said, "it cushions the blow." 
 Mr. Herz has been doing a lot of that lately as the blows -- from lower earnings, layoffs, all sorts of financial troubles -- strike deeper and harder into the country's corporate landscape. Indeed, Mr. Herz has become something of a corporate Cassandra: chances are, if he appears on the scene, the company has bad news to convey. Mr. Herz may herald a relocation, a merger or a takeover. He may augur disappointing fiscal results or a cost-cutting program.
"Magic can add levity to a tense situation," said the 35-year-old Mr. Herz, who holds an M.B.A. from Cornell and a certificate from the National Canadian Mime School. "It's a way of communicating difficult messages."
Take the recent merger of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and NCR. After the deal, Mr. Herz was hired for a company sales conference to perform tricks with a "teamwork" theme. One involved shuffling an oversized deck of cards and then cutting it diagonally with scissors; when two randomly chosen halves were fitted together, they formed a perfect whole. "The atmosphere was incredibly nervous," Mr. Herz said. "I had to relax the audience, so management could discuss how the combined sales force would operate."
Yet experts caution against confusing illusion with delusion. "If people are dealing with bad news, they shouldn't be patronized," said Marilyn Puder-York, a New York executive psychologist. "Their fears shouldn't be given a superficial response."
Indeed, corporate America hardly seems in the mood for magic. In the wake of the insider trading and banking scandals, words like "hoax" and "deceit" are not exactly welcome. "Everyone's so concerned with ethics now," said Dr. Puder-York. "People don't want to be associated with any sort of misrepresentation."
Still, Mr. Herz is betting that plenty of executives wouldn't mind having a few tricks up their sleeve. The excessive 80's may be over, but companies still want gimmicks to motivate employees. Mr. Herz's business is better than ever; he expects to serve more than 300 corporate clients in 1991, up from 30 in 1987, when he entered the market.
In the first week of November, for example, he said he worked for General Foods, Rubbermaid, A.T.& T., First Boston and MCI Communications. This may be because his services -- ranging from $1,000 for a couple of simple card tricks to $100,000 for a full-scale production -- are cheaper than other options, like rock stars and celebrities, that companies use to introduce products and entertain clients.
His first book, "Secrets of the Astonishing Executive," hits the shelves this month. This volume -- which contains tricks like the "Extra-Special Mind-Reading Rolodex" and the "Forget-Me-Not Business Card Handout" -- comes laden with testimonials from prominent executives.
"Corporate bullies won't kick sand in your face after you master a few tricks," exhorts E. James Morton, chairman of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company. "These techniques turn ordinary executives into artists who thrill and baffle," claims Bert C. Roberts Jr., president of MCI.
But several of the tricks in Mr. Herz's book conjure up dubious images. Take the "Just-Sign-Here Instant Approval Kit," which involves getting the boss's signature on a birthday card for a colleague -- and then forging it on a memo to the personnel department requesting a raise. Or the "Crispy Currency Ice Breaker," which involves doctoring dollar bills to "break the ice" with a difficult client.
Mr. Herz admits that his more wily devices might not be entirely appropriate in the executive suite. "Magic shouldn't insult or offend anybody," he said. "It should be a humanizing factor."
Some executives use Mr. Herz's tricks to demonstrate hard-to-grasp concepts. As director of A.T.& T.'s center for executive education, George Ort recently gave a presentation entitled, "The importance of perfect execution in large-scale decision-making." To illustrate this notion, he asked a client to choose a card from a deck. He then announced that he had a card inside his suit jacket -- in a sealed envelope -- with exactly half the value of the chosen card. When the client drew the seven of clubs, Mr. Ort revealed his card -- the three-and-a-half of clubs. "My point was, you can't afford to be half right when making big decisions," Mr. Ort said. "People really remembered the trick -- and my point."
Then there are those executives who use magic to enhance their image, rather than their business. Mel Feinberg, vice president of New York Life Insurance, asked Mr. Herz to teach him a few tricks for a conference last spring.
"When it comes to actuaries, we don't have a reputation as being too entertaining," Mr. Feinberg said. "Doing magic helps lighten the atmosphere."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Knight-Ridder Faces a Newspaper Puzzle

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
A year after Knight-Ridder Inc. reinvented The Boca Raton News in Florida as a newspaper calculated to appeal to baby boomers, the results are both heartening and frustrating.
Readers overwhelmingly approve of many of The News's innovations, including a rigorously enforced prohibition against having articles continue on another page. According to an April survey by the Simmons Market Research Bureau, 91 percent of The News's readers "mainly like" that particular change. 
 Readers were just as smitten with the heavy use of national, world and local maps that accompany virtually every article of importance, and 97 percent endorsed the paper's rigid determination to have specific types of news and features in the same place in the paper every day.
 
Seeking Long-Term Gains
 But what remains unclear is whether increased reader satisfaction with The News, which seems unmistakable, will translate into long-term circulation gains and whether occasional News readers can be turned into regular readers by tailoring a newspaper to reader tastes.
"We know the satisfaction is good, and now we are watching to see whether it makes people read and buy," said Bill Baker, vice president for news for Knight-Ridder, which owns 28 daily newspapers including The Miami Herald and The Philadelphia Inquirer.
The News must also resolve whether advertisers or readers have a higher priority; one innovation in classified advertising delighted readers, but alienated some advertisers.
Indeed, what is happening at The Boca Raton News is a subject of intense interest throughout the newspaper industry as papers struggle to attract the young readers who are essential to the future. Total newspaper circulation has been frozen at about 62 million for more than 20 years as the population has steadily grown.
 
Industry's Worst Nightmare
 The News experiment is particularly important because it baldly addresses the industry's worst nightmare: that people can like a newspaper, find it enjoyable and useful and accessible, and still not read it with any degree of regularity for such reasons as a lack of time.
Mr. Baker said The News's circulation jumped more than 20 percent in the first three months after the new design was introduced in October 1990 with a big promotional effort. But he said the rate of increase had steadily slowed. The paper has a paid daily circulation of about 24,000 and Sunday circulation of about 25,000, and also distributes several thousand free copies each day.
The residents of Boca Raton and Boca Raton West, perched on the southern border of Palm Beach County, are highly educated and affluent. Advertising sales material for The News notes, "This is the No. 1 market in the U.S. for per-capita ownership of luxury cars."
But this attractive audience has drawn furious competition from larger papers. Indeed, The Fort Lauderdale Sun-Sentinel's circulation in South Palm Beach County is about a third higher than that of The News. Thomas P. O'Donnell, publisher of The Sun-Sentinel, said the edition of his paper zoned for that area has shown as much circulation growth in the last year as has The News. The Palm Beach Post and The Miami Herald also circulate in the area.
And a News innovation that is very popular with readers may have cost it dearly with classified advertisers.
A year ago, The News began listing such things as rental apartments, condominiums for sale and used cars in a grid that allowed readers to compare what was offered more easily. For instance, all the used BMW 715's were listed together in descending order by model year and then by price.
The survey found that 87 percent of readers loved the grids.
But some advertisers did not.
Clement C. Winke, Jr., publisher of The News, said apartment rental agencies were particularly unhappy, because their classified ads for all kinds of apartments are calculated to prompt calls of inquiry. A prospective renter whose eye was caught by an ad for a modest apartment can then be encouraged to spend a little more to get one with a pool.
Effectively, the girds turned renters into much more informed consumers by making price comparisons easier.
"The grids were a real reader benefit, but a real estate advertising disaster," said Mr. O'Donnell, who added that The Sun-Sentinel's classified advertising in the South Palm Beach County edition had increased 82 percent compared with a year ago. Mr. O'Donnell credits advertiser animosity toward The News's grids for much of his paper's gains.
Mr. Baker said The News's classified advertising was about where it was expected to be in an economic downturn, but did not give specifics.
But he said The News would stick with the grid classifieds for at least another year because advertisers were beginning to grasp that their popularity with readers was drawing an increased audience.
The process of shaping The News has been a combination of listening to readers and involving the paper's staff, especially the news staff, by having them observe focus groups of readers critiquing various prototypes and then holding discussions to address reader complaints.
This process, he said, had convinced many previously skeptical reporters and editors of "the need to broaden the definition of news," words that to many journalists have been shorthand for pandering to readers and turning away from serious news coverage.
In focus groups, readers complained that they wanted serious news, but in a form that they found appealing and illuminating. In general, this meant personalizing the news and expanding coverage into new areas.
For instance, Mr. Baker said The News now covers the local I.B.M. plant, which is a leading employer, as an ongoing news story with issues of policy and corporate intrigue that can have a big local impact.
And dispute over education policy might now be covered not as a dry analysis, but through a profile of a particular school principal who has strong views on the issue.
