HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Hard-Hitting Spots Assail Clothing and Textile Imports

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
AMERICAN consumers will find a large lump of coal being put in their Christmas stockings by an organization seeking to insure that those stockings bear labels reading "Made in U.S.A."
In television commercials running from today through Dec. 15, the Crafted with Pride in U.S.A. Council Inc., the trade organization representing apparel, fiber and textile manufacturers, is undertaking its hardest-hitting, highest-budgeted campaign against the flood of imported merchandise that has decimated the operations of its more than 500 members. 
 The spots' deliberately downbeat images are meant to convince viewers of a direct relationship between the purchase of imports and the 581,480 jobs that the council says its industries have lost since 1980. The 15- and 30-second doses of gloom and doom contrast starkly with the cheery commercialism that greets consumers during the Christmas shopping season.
"These are not feel-good commercials, intended to make people feel jolly," Madeline Lewis, senior vice president of Warwick Baker & Fiore, the council's advertising agency, said last week. "This is a time of year when people are finding what they can and can't afford to give their loved ones. So the notion that you can't afford to give the people you love a future hits hard."
That is an intensely more serious, and ominous, message than was delivered by Warwick's previous campaigns. From 1985 to 1989, warm and fuzzy spots featured celebrities like Bob Hope revealing "Made in U.S.A." labels inside their clothing and on their towels and sheets.
The accelerating loss of jobs at member companies led the council to ask Warwick to alter the campaign's direction for 1990. So tougher spots showed a textile plant closing and a mother telling her young son that because "a lot of people are buying clothes made in other countries, not ours," Dad had lost his job and the family must move.
But research indicated that the council still "wasn't telling our story effectively enough," said Robert E. Swift, its executive director.
One key ifference is that the new spots convey an idea that individuals "don't have to wait for somebody else to take action, that they can help," by changing their buying habits, said Susan Small-Weil, executive vice president at Warwick.
This thought is taken to its logical conclusion, she added, "that if they don't, somebody else won't, and they have to take responsibility for that."
One spot depicts an apparently endless line of unemployed people, slowly moving into a building. A stern-voiced announcer identifies them as the Americans who have "lost their jobs because we don't realize the impact of buying imported goods." They are all waiting to see a lone clerk at a window labeled "Unemployment." The clerk mutters, "Next" -- a device that viewers are supposed to interpret to mean they, too, could be next to be discharged, Ms. Small-Weil said.
In a second spot, men, women and children on a pier watch a crate stenciled "Imported" being unloaded. The announcer says that "because we're buying so many imports," the nation is "in danger of losing the U.S. apparel and home-fashions industry."
"And the worst part is," he adds, "we're doing this to ourselves."
Testing the spots before their introduction, Mr. Swift said, the council and Warwick found that among the primary target market, women aged 25 to 49, an important measurement of effectiveness soared to a range of 68 to 69 percent, from 35 percent to 40 percent for the previous campaign.
So the budget for this campaign will exceed the council's average ad spending, he added, which over the last three years has totaled $40 million. That money will buy time during programs primarily watched by women on broadcast and cable networks, from daytime soap operas like CBS's "The Young and the Restless" to nighttime soaps like ABC's "Homefront" to the "Holiday Movie Classics" on the cable superstation WTBS.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A commercial produced by the Crafted with Pride in U.S.A. Council depicting an endless line of unemployed people identified as American garment workers who have lost their jobs because of competition from imports.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Issue by New York City To Cut Borrowing Costs

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
For the better part of three years, City Hall in lower Manhattan has not been a fount of good economic news. This week, however, some should trickle out.
New York City is expected to offer investors $1.21 billion worth of uninsured general obligation bonds tomorrow. The negotiated sale itself is not noteworthy, since New York is by far the nation's largest issuer of tax-exempt debt securities, but this issue is different: over the 30 years it will cut the city's borrowing costs by well over $100 million. 
 Using a plan conceived by public finance specialists at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc., proceeds from the financing will be used for the nullification, or defeasance, of outstanding bonds backed by insurance companies or commercial letters of credit.
Through such a defeasance, a process by which payment of interest and principal will come from a pool of Treasury securities rather than from the city, New York will be able to issue more bonds backed by insurance companies or bank letters of credit.
Borrowings that carry such guarantees are rated triple-A and are generally sold at interest rates as much as a percentage point lower than uninsured debt securities.
Insurers have been unwilling to provide backing for new New York City bonds because their exposure is already enormous: $2.5 billion worth of outstanding city securities are covered by insurance. This issue will cut that exposure by a little more than 40 percent.
"When we focused in on the city and its problems, it was obvious that they had a capacity problem," said Eric H. Altman, a managing director at J. P. Morgan. "The logical thing to do seemed to be to get it off the books of the credit enhancers by defeasing the securities."
Sally Hernandez-Pinero, Deputy Mayor for finance and economic development, said, "It's good news, but it is hard to convey to a general audience."
Soon -- probably next month -- the city will be able to take advantage of new credit-enhancing guarantees from bond insurance firms and banks by issuing variable-rate bonds. Interest rates on these securities could be adjusted as often as daily and generally require backing from banks. But they can be sold with interest rates as low as 2 percent or 3 percent, analysts said.
The move to pare borrowing costs will help improve the city's financial fortunes, but only at the margin, because enormous problems remain.
The metropolitan region remains mired in a recession and wrangling continues over ways to streamline a four-year financial plan in order to obtain $1 billion in additional assistance from the Municipal Assistance Corporation.
Mindful of these realities, the Standard & Poor's Corporation has assigned an A- rating to the city bond offering. A rating of Baa-1 is expected from Moody's Investors Service Inc.
Talk in the market in advance of the sale put a maximum yield on the securities to be sold at around 7.75 percent, well under the 8.10 percent yield on 30-year bonds sold by the city in early August.
"The city's timing is very good in terms of the direction of interest rates," said Neil G. Budnick, a senior vice president at the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation. "And while New York is not the highest-tier creidt, it still has positive credit fundamentals."
 
A Busy Municipal Market
 The New York City sale is a focal point in what looks to be the most active week in the municipal bond market in years.
Between $8 billion and $8.5 billion worth of new tax-exempt issues are expected to be priced this week.
Like New York City, this week the New Jersey Turnpike Authority will be seeking to lower its financing costs when it refunds $1.6 billion of 7.20 percent securities originally issued in 1985.
The securities are rated A by both Moody's and S.& P.
Reflecting the higher ratings the authority has over New York City, price talk in advance of the issue put a maximum yield on the securities at somewhere between 6.625 percent and 6.75 percent.
This week's activity will add to what has already been very heavy volume of new tax-exempt securities this year.
Through last Thursday, more than $179 billion worth of new municipal securities, both new financings and refunding issues, was brought to market this year, according to figures from the Securities Data Company. For all of 1990, the total was $163.5 billion.
For both issuers and investors "one thing has been driving the municipal market more than anything else this year," said George D. Friedlander, a managing director at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. "And that is the collapse of short-term rates."
Because of the sharp decline in interest rates on instruments like bank certificates of deposit, "demand for intermediate to long-term municipal bonds is up enormously," Mr. Friedlander said, "and it is not going away anytime soon."

HEADLINE: An Anxious Oil Industry Meets

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The American Petroleum Institute expects that when it opens its annual meeting here on Monday, attendance will be better than in any year since 1985, with about 2,000 drillers, refiners, distributors and retailers gathering to talk business.
Despite the promising turnout, the industry gathers with a number of dark clouds overhead. 
 The Clean Air Act and state initiatives to clean the air mean new challenges for refiners, some not yet clearly defined. New legislation on oil tankers poses financial burdens. Legislation to give the industry its most cherished goal, permission to drill in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, was recently defeated in the Senate before it could even reach the floor for debate.
 
'Not a Cheerful Year'
 Though the price of oil is up a bit from the days before the Persian Gulf war, many analysts say it is disappointingly low, given that Iraq, normally the world's third-largest exporter, is out of the market. In addition, Kuwait's shipments are far short of the prewar level, and the Soviet Union seems likely to ship less in coming months.
Many people think the price is poised to decline. "This is not a cheerful year, altogether," said John H. Lichtblau, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation in New York.
Charles DiBona, the president of the American Petroleum Institute, was even less sanguine. In a telephone interview at the institute's headquarters in Washington, before he left for the meeting, he said that all things considered, the situation was "bad, bad, bad."
 
A Plunge in Profitability
 "The economics are just a disaster," Mr. DiBona said. "The price of crude's gone up a little, but all of the margins on the downstream are as low as they've ever been," a reference to the profit margins for refining and marketing petroleum.
He added: "The profitability of the companies has plunged. They're all cutting back staff again."
In trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange on Friday, crude oil closed at $22.79 cents a barrel for December delivery, up 27 cents, on news that the Russian republic will block some exports. Comparisons with last year are not meaningful because at the time of the last meeting, a year ago, Iraq was occupying Kuwait and threatening to occupy Saudi Arabia. The price then was about $10 a barrel higher.
Most oil companies are looking ahead, not back, however, and many traders are worried that inventories are high and that the recession is lingering. Eventually, Iraq and Kuwait will re-enter the market, perhaps producing more than they were before the war, adding even more supplies.
In the past, prices have been propped up by Saudi Arabia's willingness to keep some capacity idle, but since the war the Saudis have worked to increase their capacity, stressing their need for oil revenue. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is scheduled to meet on Nov. 26 in Vienna, but almost no one expects the group to announce plans to restrict production to below the current level of 23.65 million barrels a day.
There are some countervailing factors. The Oil and Gas Journal, an authoritative trade publication, predicted last week that demand for heating fuels would rise substantially this winter. The American Midwest has had record cold temperatures recently. And the magazine noted that last year the East, where most heating oil is used, had an unusually mild winter. In addition, prices were higher last year, depressing consumption.
 
Russians Rubbing Elbows
 Attendance is likely to be up in Houston, because at least for now, the price of oil is a bit stronger. This year, the convention is in the heart of the oil patch, and the featured speaker is Margaret Thatcher, the former Prime Minister of Britain, a major oil producer.
Also expected this year are about 50 Russians. "They're probably just trying to rub elbows," Mr. DiBona said. "We don't have anything planned for them."
In fact, the Russians appear to have a great deal planned, with many hours of meetings set up with Americans in three conference rooms at a hotel near the conference headquarters.
Russia, which produces more than 90 percent of the Soviet Union's oil and gas, has recently approved joint ventures in both production and refining and seems to be shopping for more. Mr. DiBona said American companies were looking for places to drill, since "what we're being told by the public of the U.S. is, we should go abroad, import more oil, and not produce in the U.S."
 
One Enemy Is Uncertainty
 Smarting over the loss, at least for now, of permission to drill in Alaska, and over restrictions in California waters and on other offshore projects, Mr. DiBona said, "Every other country in the world is dashing around, begging U.S. companies to help develop oil and gas."
At the other end of the industry are refiners, who will face a new, as-yet-undefined standard for gasoline in dozens of major markets in coming years. Refiners here will compare notes on what specifications are likely and how they would produce such fuel.
Refinery experts say that billions of dollars in investment will be required. Mr. Lichtblau says that most refineries think about the performance of new equipment over a 25-year period, but that with natural gas, methanol, electricity and other transportation fuels on the horizon, "it isn't clear that 25 years from now, gasoline consumption won't be on the decline."
"There is an awful lot of uncertainty," he said, "and that is one of the worst enemies -- uncertainty."

HEADLINE: Effort to Cap Credit Card Rates Is Attacked

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
The Bush Administration mounted an attack today on a measure to limit credit card interest rates, which was approved in the Senate last week with little debate.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said that the proposal was "wacky" and that it had caused the sharp decline in stock prices on Friday. Vice President Dan Quayle predicted that the President would veto the measure if it won approval from both houses of Congress. 
 The measure was introduced by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, and Mr. Brady used unusually sharp language in criticizing the action of another Republican.
 
'Wacky, Senseless'
 "I think the legislation that was passed earlier in the week with only 30 minutes' discussion disturbs people who think about the market," Mr. Brady said today on "Meet the Press," the NBC News program. "In other words, they expect our governmental bodies to be considered, quiet and sensible. This is wacky, senseless legislation, and when it goes through quickly, people wonder."
The drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday, he said, "was in reaction to the very quick passage through the Senate of the credit card legislation." The Dow fell 120.31 points, or nearly 4 percent.
In a separate appearance later on the same program, Senator D'Amato was asked if he agreed that his legislation was "wacky." He replied, "It certainly is not."
Mr. D'Amato said that as many people were facing economic hardship, they were not benefiting from lower credit card interest charges, even though other interest rates, like the discount and prime rates, were declining.
He said he introduced the legislation because there was no competition among banks to force down credit card rates.
"There's no free market," he said. "They're charging 19.80 -- right to the decimal -- 19.80, 7 of the largest 10" banks.
Mr. D'Amato added, "If there was competition, this legislation wouldn't be necessary." He said the support his measure enjoyed could be seen in its passage by a vote of 74 to 19.
Mr. Brady asserted that if banks were forced to reduce the rates they charge credit card customers, they would issue cards only to higher-income people, whom they would consider most likely to pay their bills.
"This legislation is bound to result in credit cards which are elitist," Mr. Brady said. "If this legislation went through, the only people that'd have credit cards would be the rich people in this country."
Mr. D'Amato disagreed. "It's not elitist," he said, asserting that under the current system, "people who are credit addicts who shouldn't be getting credit" were being given credit cards by banks.
As a result, he said, "you have working, middle class people paying enormous, enormous rates to make the banks profitable."
The Senator said it was "nonsense" and "ridiculous" to attribute the decline in stock prices to the credit card measure. Rather, he said, the contributing factors included the "triple-witching hour, when the options were exercised, and when the biotech stocks led the decline."
In fact, a triple-witching hour, when stock options, futures contracts and index options all expire, often resulting in stock-price volatility, did not occur on Friday. But Friday was the expiration date for futures and options contracts tied to the Major Market Index, a widely followed market barometer. This occurrence is known on Wall Street as a "double-witching hour."
 
Quayle's Skepticism
 Vice President Quayle, who appeared today on the ABC News program, "This Week With David Brinkley," said of the D'Amato measure: "I'm not sure the Congress will pass it now, after what happened to the stock market Friday. Congress likes to have both sides of an issue, and this is a perfect case for them, because now they're on record one week supporting a cap and the next week they'll say, 'Oh, well, we really didn't want to have the stock market react like this.' "
Mr. Quayle added: "Furthermore, there was no debate on this issue. We didn't realize that millions of people would lose their credit cards if we pass this legislation."
Asked whether President Bush would veto the measure, Mr. Quayle said, "I am confident that the President will make sure that this does not become law, and if that requires a veto, so be it."
Mr. Quayle also asserted that the move to cap credit card rates "was certainly a factor" in the stock market decline.
 
Seidman Opposes Bill
 L. William Seidman, who recently stepped down as the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, also appeared on the NBC program and said a limit on the interest banks could charge for credit cards "perhaps would be something to look at" if banks "were making a huge amount of money."
But, he said: "They're not. They're in weakened condition, and a stronger bank is what we need to get out of this recession.
"All we need is to have something else hit the banks now to help us move deeper into a recession. So I think this is a bad idea any time, but is a very bad idea right now."

HEADLINE: Few New Jobs Seen by Panel

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The lackluster economic recovery expected next year will create few new jobs, the Conference Board, a business-oriented research group, said in a report released yesterday.
The group's Human Resources Outlook Panel said unemployment was expected to average 6.8 percent of the work force in the first six months of 1992. The national unemployment rate was 6.8 percent in October, according to the Labor Department. 
 The panel predicted that the rate would fall slightly, to 6.6 percent, in the third quarter and slip to 6.5 percent in the last three months of the year.
The Conference Board said that most of its panelists thought the worst of the recession had passed and that the economy "could be positioning itself for longer, more sustained growth ahead."
"The panel's confidence is linked to a belief that the American economy is knuckling down to work," it said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Buyer Sought For a Magazine

 BODY:
New York Woman, a five- year-old magazine aimed at sophisticated young New York women, has been put up for sale by the American Express Publishing Corporation. The magazine has been struggling recently because of sagging advertising revenues.
"It's true that it is up for sale," said Betsy Carter, the magazine's founder and editor. "We are doing everything we can do to find a buyer." 
 Like other city magazines, New York Woman is heavily dependent on local advertisers like restaurants and stores. These are usually the first to cut back in a recession.
New York Woman, which has a circulation of 110,000 and publishes 10 issues a year, recently added several feature sections in an effort to attract more readers and advertisers.
For weeks, reports have circulated within the industry that American Express wanted to sell all of its city magazines, which include Atlanta, L.A. Style and D, a Dallas-based publication. American Express officials deny that the magazines are for sale.

HEADLINE: Overtures to Asia Pose Risk For U.S. Aerospace Industry

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Negotiations by America's second-largest aircraft maker, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, about selling a big stake in its civilian aircraft operations to a consortium of Asian companies are threatening to accomplish what Congress spent the late 1980's trying to prevent: teaching Asia's strongest industrial powers how to build giant commercial jets.
So far, aerospace has been one of the few American high-technology industries virtually free of competition from Asia. To keep it that way, Congress has insisted in recent years on extraordinary restrictions to prevent the transfer of commercially valuable aerospace technology to Japan and South Korea, even slowing down the joint production of a new fighter. 
 It is still a matter of debate whether the technology used to build military fighters could be applied to big passenger jets, but there is little question that McDonnell Douglas's proposal to sell up to 49 percent of its commercial aircraft business could teach Asian manufacturers a lot.
On Friday, Taiwan Aerospace confirmed that it was neogtiating for 40 percent of the commercial operations of the Douglas Aircraft subsidiary of McDonnell Douglas. McDonnell Douglas says the price being discussed is roughly $2 billion.
On the same day, one of Japan's oldest and largest business trading firms, Mitsui & Company, said it, too, was considering an investment.
 
Talks Began Last Month
 A team of Mitsui executives traveled to the United States last month to begin talks, though a Mitsui spokesman, Hidemi Mori, said that so far taking a stake in the giant aircraft maker is only an idea.
"Of course we want to cooperate to keep America's aerospace industry strong," said a senior official of Japan's International Trade and Industry Ministry, which has struggled unsuccessfully for a generation to make Japan an aerospace competitor. "But I think it is fair to say that in most such arrangements, our own firms are looking for a chance to hone their skills."
McDonnell Douglas says it needs to raise cash for Douglas Aircraft to develop a more efficient airliner for Pacific service.
Douglas Aircraft, based in Long Beach, Calif., has two parts. One makes only civilian airliners; the other makes the C-17 military tranport. The parent company, which is based in St. Louis and is the nation's largest military contractor, makes the F-15 and F/A-18 fighters, the Apache helicopter, the Tomahawk missile and other mainstays of the nation's arsenal. The Seattle-based Boeing Company, however, is the world's largest aircraft maker over all.
McDonnell Douglas seems acutely aware of the political sensitivity of the negotiations -- especially in a pre-election climate, when the issue of declining American competitiveness is already ripe.
So the company decided that it would not offer any part of its military operations, a move the Pentagon and Congress would undoubtedly halt on national security grounds.
So it opened negotiations with Taiwan Aerospace, a recently formed company that has never built an airplane part much less a plane and whose chief qualification for partnership seems to be its ample supply of capital from the Taiwanese Government. Without question, the company seems like less of a potential threat to the health of the American aerospace industry than do the Japanese, who had a thriving aircraft industry before World War II and make little secret of their desire to revive it.
 
Potential Rival to Airbus
 Ultimately, McDonnell Douglas is expected to make a deal that creates an Asian version of Airbus Industrie, the European consortium whose success in building commercial airlines has put pressure on McDonnell Douglas and Boeing. Beyond Taiwan Aerospace and Mitsui, Singapore and South Korea are expected to provide other potential investors.
No one yet knows how such a consortium would work, or even whether some of Asia's most jealously competitive nations could manage a partnership. But few here doubt that McDonnnell Douglas would be expected to share its expertise in return for investments.
Publicly, at least, both McDonnell Douglas and the Bush Administration say there is little to be concerned about and that international consortiums are the only option in an age when it can cost $5 billion or more to design and build an airliner.
At a breakfast meeting on Saturday with a small group of reporters in Tokyo, Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, suggested that foreign investment in a company like McDonnell Douglas is a logical extension of the kind of manufacturing alliances that have arisen in the last decade.
In Japan, for example, three Japanese companies, led by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, are building more than 20 percent of Boeing's new 777. They are also investors in the plane itself, though not in the company. And the Japanese Government is leading a big research project on supersonic jets that Pratt & Whitney, General Electric and Rolls-Royce, which all make aircraft engines, have joined.
Several weeks before the current negotiations were announced, John F. McDonnell, the company's chief executive and son of its founder, said: "The U.S. is not going to stay a leader in aerospace by becoming Fortress America. We're going to stay a leader by sharing today's technology and developing tomorrow's."
 
Long-Range Aircraft
 The project for which McDonnell Douglas is seeking cash is the MD-12, a long-range, wide-body aircraft designed to compete primarily with the Boeing 747. If successful, it would have a range of 9,000 miles, 2,000 miles more than the 747. The aircraft should prove particularly popular among Asian airlines and other lines flying to the Pacific, which is the world's fastest-growing air market and has some of the longest commercial routes.
But to design and build it, McDonnell Douglas will need billions of dollars in outside financing and better connections to the Asian carriers. And it will need lower labor costs, a delicate issue with its unions.
It also seems to be taking whatever steps it can to address what were the core of Congress's objections to the Japanese FSX fighter project -- that the deal jeopardized the nation's economic security.
One risk that McDonnell is running, however, is that Taiwan Aerospace will bring little manufacturing expertise to the table. Earlier this year, Lawrence W. Clarkson, senior vice president for international affairs at Boeing, said one big advantage of the production agreement with Mitsubishi had been the manufacturing techniques that Boeing was able to adopt.
A second risk is that Taiwan Aerospace will not be able to deliver many customers to McDonnell. Taiwan's national airline, while growing fast, is small in comparison with Japan Airlines, All Nippon Airways, Singapore Airlines and Korean Airlines. And McDonnell's involvement with Taiwan could easily anger mainland China, which is currently producing parts for the MD-80, a twin-jet aircraft that can carry 150 passengers, in a joint venture in Shanghai.
Such problems could be alleviated by bringing in extra partners, like Mitsui. The company has represented McDonnell Douglas in Japan and regularly invests in many different ventures. But Mr. Mori, Mitsui's spokesman, said that before making any equity investment "we would have to determine what advantage there is, over just investing in the plane itself."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Senator Seeks Inquiry
 LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, plans to ask the Bush Administration to investigate the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's efforts to find Asian investors for the commercial operations of its Douglas Aircraft subsidiary.
In remarks reported in The Los Angeles Times on Saturday, the Senator said he would seek to block such a deal if it was judged harmful to American strategic interests.
And Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Majority Leader, called the negotiations "a very negative development for the United States," which amounted to a giveaway of American technology.
The president of Douglas Aircraft, Robert Hood, said, however, that little technology would be transferred to foreign companies.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Similarities to 1987, and Significant Differences

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES

 BODY:
At first glance, the similarities between 1987 and 1991 are haunting: a long, increasingly exuberant rally in the stock market that abruptly ended, on an autumnal Friday, with a selling frenzy that slashed more than 100 points off the Dow Jones industrial average.
But market professionals see telling differences between last Friday and Oct. 16, 1987, which was followed by "Black Monday" on Oct. 19, the worst one-day market crash in the nation's history. 
 These critical distinctions in the current market's anatomy include:
*Declining interest rates on bonds and certificates of deposit, which leave fewer attractive investment alternatives than in 1987, when bank and bond rates were high and climbing.
*Calmer mutual fund customers, who do not appear to be repeating their 1987 stampede out of stock funds. That should mean mutual funds will not be forced to sell stocks today to raise cash for redemptions, as they had to do in 1987.
*A variety of restrictions on institutional trading that have been imposed by the nation's stock markets and futures exchanges, giving regulators some room to maneuver on days when trading turns turbulent.
*Less widespread and more sensible use of institutional hedging techniques, the so-called "portfolio insurance" strategies that were blamed for seriously destabilizing the market during the 1987 collapse.
 
A Wall Street Caveat
 Many on Wall Street warn that it is one thing to avoid another devastating single-day panic, however, and quite another to avoid a new bear market, given how weak the nation's economy is compared with 1987.
Indeed, one widely cited trigger for Friday's nose dive was investors' concern that already-troubled banks and retailers would be hurt if Congress approved a proposal to cap credit card interest rates -- an idea that Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said yesterday "will never see the light of day." [Page D7.]
The first sign of what today's trading may be like came from Tokyo, whose stock market opens 14 1/2 hours before the New York exchanges. Stocks in Tokyo were down 2.9 percent today, more than half of Friday's fall in New York.
Some cynics note that a long roster of history's financial disasters have been built on the glib assumption that "it's different this time."
But Joan Lappin, president of Gramercy Capital Management, an institutional money manager in New York, said the differences between now and 1987 do matter.
"Everybody is saying it's just like '87," Ms. Lappin said. "But it is not at all like '87, because then, the Government was raising interest rates and constricting the money supply. Today, they're lowering rates, and for the past three or four weeks have been aggressively pumping up the money supply."
 
Rates Down Since January
 Interest rates on the 30-year Treasury bond, a determinant of consumer rates across the financial markets, have fallen to the current 7.88 percent from 8.31 percent in January. The decline is even steeper in the rates on three-month Treasury bills, a common haven for corporations and institutional investors fleeing the stock market. Those rates have fallen to 4.61 percent in recent weeks from January's 6.43 percent level -- a drop of nearly 30 percent.
So if the anemic economy casts some clouds over the optimism that had been energizing the stock market until Friday, the bond market yields still stand in puny contrast to the double-digit gains generated by stock market investments so far this year.
The Nasdaq Composite Index and the Russell 2000 Index, both of which measure the performance of smaller companies' stock, have made the sharpest gains. Even after Friday's downdraft, the Nasdaq index is up nearly 45 percent since the first of the year and the Russell index nearly 40 percent. And the Dow begins trading today nearly 20 percent higher than its low point in January.
 
Buying on Weakness
 Indeed, stock market investors seem to have developed "a very well-conditioned impulse to buy on weakness," said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, a credit markets magazine. "If you take a very long view of things, that has been a very profitable strategy going back to 1975, and especially since 1987."
Since individual investors have played a more significant role in the market this year than they did, for example, during the "mini-crash" of Oct. 13, 1989, their behavior is being closely monitored by market professionals. And so far, they seem exceptionally calm.
Major mutual fund organizations reported a relatively quiet weekend, with no signs of either energetic buying or of panicky selling. Marcia Sawyer, director of media relations for Fidelity Investments in Boston, said that Saturday had been about 25 percent busier than normal but that most of the 100 extra personnel added to Fidelity's telephone banks for the weekend had been sent home early on Sunday afternoon.
By a three-to-one margin, most callers to Fidelity, the nation's largest mutual fund organization, were simply checking the value of their accounts, rather than making buy or sell decisions, she said,
"People are essentially standing pat," she added.
 
Gauging the Institutions
 Measuring the mood of big institutional investors is more difficult. Obviously, a market decline as sweeping and swift as the one on Friday entailed a considerable amount of selling by major institutions. But some clues amid the rubble suggest that the decline was not fed by blind panic.
For one thing, the trading volume on Friday, while large, was not monstrous. Total volume on the New York Stock Exchange was about 236 million shares, compared with the 343 million shares traded on the Friday before Black Monday in 1987. That Monday, more than 605 million shares changed hands.
And there is less distortion this time around in the closely watched relationship between the price of stocks in the cash market and the price of the "surrogate stocks" traded in the form of stock-index futures contracts. This is important, since many institutional arbitrage traders tend to buy whichever form of equity looks cheap, and sell whichever looks dear.
 
A Narrow Cash-Futures Spread
 On Friday, the Standard & Poor's 500 index -- the cash market -- declined 14.53 points, to close at 383.62. That put it fairly close to the price of the most actively traded futures contract on that index, the December contract, which fell 14.45 points, to close at 383.50.
The December contract remains slightly cheaper than its cash-market equivalent, and some analysts say the difference may generate some additional selling early today by arbitrage-driven investors. But the gap is relatively small, portending none of the panic-driven liquidation seen in 1987.
Such cash-futures distortions can be keenly important. On Friday, for example, the sagging market was hit in the afternoon with a wave of stock sales that were related exclusively to the expiration of stock-index futures and options contracts in the Chicago markets. A trader at one major Wall Street firm said that expiration-related selling accounted for 20 to 30 points of the Dow's 120-point decline.
 
Rules Are Different Now, Too
 Finally, the market rules are different today than they were on Black Monday. The major stock exchanges and the futures exchanges in Chicago have put in place various measures that limit institutions' ability to engage in certain forms of arbitrage trading when such trades might contribute to a turbulent selloff.
One of the more modest limits, which requires that arbitrage trades be done only when the previous trade in that stock produced a price gain, was triggered on Friday after the market fell 50 points. Stiffer restrictions, which in effect slow down the processing of arbitrage-based orders, kick in after a 90-point decline. After a 250-point decline, all trading is halted for an hour, and at the 400-point mark, trading can again be halted for two additional hours.
 
Less Use of 'Portfolio Insurance'
 Moreover, the hedging technique known as "portfolio insurance," which proved a spectacular failure in 1987 and was cited by the Presidential Task Force on Market Mechanisms as a leading cause of Black Monday, is a much less important force in the market now. And while the hedging techniques in 1987 tended to rely on futures contracts, current forms tend to rely more on the options markets, making them less likely to distort the cash-futures relationship.
What no form of market regulation can contain, of course, is fundamental pessimism about the future course of the economy, and the effect that will have on corporate health and earnings -- a picture that is far less bright that it was in 1987, said Mr. Grant, the credit markets analyst.
"Bernard Baruch used to throw around the concept of 'the continuity of bullish thought,' " he added, referring to the financier who was an adviser to Franklin D. Roosevelt. "I suspect that the real significance of Friday was that the continuity of bullish thought was broken."

Eyes on Stocks
The similarities between big market drops on Fridays in 1987 and 1991 seem haunting at first glance: long, exuberant rallies abruptly ended with frenzied selling. HEADLINE: Stocks Lower in Tokyo

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Prices were sharply lower on the Tokyo Stock Exchange today in reaction to Friday's 3.9 percent drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.
The Nikkei index of 225 issues finished 699.06 points lower, or down 2.9 percent, to 23,400.12. At midday, the index was down 639.11 points, or 2.6 percent, to 23,460.07. The Nikkei lost 77.36 points on Friday. 
 In the first 30 minutes today, the Nikkei fell more than 2 percent.
"Tokyo can ignore New York's strength, but not its weakness," Paul Migliorato, a trader with Jardine Fleming Securities, said after morning trading. "Everyone's nervous."
Traders added that worries over the Japanese economy also caused selling. Others said the sell-off was more technical.
"The market got hammered today," one broker said at the end of trading. "But it's completely overreacted to New York's drop, which was sparked by the U.S. domestic situation. Selling here was technical."
In the afternoon, trading was seesaw, with the Nikkei plunging as much as 3.27 percent, before retreating slightly and then trading in a narrow range. The index climbed steadily within the last 20 minutes.
After the close, a Bank of Japan official said the Nikkei's decline posed no threat to Japan's financial stability and would not spur policy adjustments by the central bank.
"As long as it remains just a matter of stock prices, there is no broader problem," the official said.

HEADLINE: Blacks and Affluent Whites Give Edwards Victory

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17

 BODY:
As Edwin W. Edwards savored a resounding victory over David Duke in the voting for governor on Saturday, an analysis today showed that the Democrat's landslide resulted not only from a huge black turnout but also from the overwhelming support of relatively affluent whites.
Whites who voted for Mr. Edwards said they feared that race relations would worsen and that economic catastrophe would result from the election of Mr. Duke, a former neo-Nazi and grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan. 
 Mr. Edwards, the former Governor who was elected to a fourth term just four years after leaving office under a cloud of allegations of corruption, piled up 61 percent of the vote amid record turnout over Mr. Duke, whose use of racial themes dominated the election.
 
Help From Old Enemies
 Nobody was surprised that black voters went almost unanimously for Mr. Edwards. But the huge black turnout -- around 80 percent, or about the same as among whites -- helped create the landslide.
Beyond that, the key to his victory was his 3-to-1 support among those who voted in last month's primary for Gov. Buddy Roemer, many of them business-oriented conservatives who had long been enemies of Mr. Edwards and who helped turn him out of office four years ago.
In a record turnout for a general election for governor, 79.83 percent of registered voters went to the polls, with Mr. Edwards getting 61 percent of the vote, or 1,086,820 votes, and Mr. Duke getting 39 percent, or 701,024, in complete but unofficial totals.
Today the national spotlight remained on Mr. Duke, whose losing campaign nevertheless expanded the audience for his message of middle-class resentment. In network interviews, he refused to rule out the possibility of running for President. [News analysis, page B6.]
But the day really belonged to Mr. Edwards, the state's only three-term Governor now elected to a fourth, who came back from the political dead to rout Mr. Duke in a race most analysts expected to be close.
For the 64-year-old Mr. Edwards, whose storied political career appeared to have ended in disgrace four years ago after two racketeering trials and his conceding victory to Mr. Roemer after finishing in second place in the primary, it was an enormous personal victory.
"I have to tell you that practically nobody, including my closest friends and advisers a year ago, thought I had a chance of winning," Mr. Edwards said at a morning news conference packed with reporters and supporters. "I want you to know this is the most exhilarating, positive, high political note for me in my whole career."
But it was also enormously satisfying for Mr. Edwards politically, both in terms of the extraordinary coalition he put together and for his role in stopping Mr. Duke.
"I knew the people of this state were too compassionate, too progressive, too concerned, too charitable to elect him given the agenda on which he was running," Mr. Edwards said.
 
'Blacks and Roemeristas'
 In remarks at turns proud and humble, laced with overtures to past foes and his trademark wit, Mr. Edwards managed to add a final grace note of levity to the race when he talked about refusing to go on a morning news show today after being told he would have to appear once again with Mr. Duke.
"I don't want to get in another argument with David Duke about we can't tell what the weather is because the welfare recipients are in the way," he said.
An analysis of the vote today showed Mr. Edwards won his stunning victory because of the enormous black turnout created by fear of Mr. Duke and because of overwhelming support from Mr. Roemer's followers, who feared a Duke victory would result in an economic disaster for Louisiana's sagging economy.
Mr. Edwards picked up the votes of 75 percent of those who voted for Mr. Roemer, according to a survey of 1,675 voters leaving the polling places conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN and NBC News. Mr. Roemer finished third in the statewide primary in October.
"Basically, Edwards was elected by blacks and Roemeristas," said Edward Renwick, a Loyola University poll taker, using the term for the Roemer supporters whose "revolution" to clean up government four years ago was directed at Mr. Edwards. "It has to be one of the most unusual combinations in state history."
 
Income and Votes
 According to the voter surveys, white support for both candidates closely correlated with income.
Mr. Duke's strongest support came from low- and middle-income whites. He got 56 percent of the vote of whites with family incomes under $15,000, 63 percent of those making from $15,000 to $29,999, and 60 percent of those making from $30,000 to 49,999.
But 51 percent of whites with family incomes from $50,000 to $74,999 voted for Mr. Edwards, and 66 percent of those with incomes $75,000 and over supported him.
He did better with women than with men, getting 63 percent of the female vote and 59 percent of men. The poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
Mr. Edwards's election followed a campaign that was an artful blend of disparate elements.
Bill Morgan, an Edwards campaign consultant based in Baton Rouge, said the strategy from the start of the runoff campaign was to stress the economic costs of a victory by Mr. Duke.
 
Money and Morals
 That had the effect both of hitting what they felt was the freshest and strongest issue against Mr. Duke and of building bridges to the business community, which had always opposed Mr. Edwards. The result was a coalition that both brought aboard the supporters he most needed and helped change his image with voters mindful of the ethical questions that led to his defeat four years ago.
"It was the economic issues that won the race for Edwards," he said.
At the same time, other groups like the state Democratic Party and the Louisiana Coalition Against Racism and Nazism reminded voters of Mr. Duke's longstanding white supremacist ties. Many credit the coalition, which was formed after Mr. Duke entered politics and did voluminous research on his racial views, as a significant presence in shaping perceptions of Mr. Duke.
Still, many saw a mixed message in the result, particularly the idea that Mr. Duke was repudiated more as a financial menace than for his racial history.
"Is the glass half empty or half full?" asked Mr. Renwick. "Obviously, it shows there is racial divisiveness and there are racially charged issues. The racial issue is not going to go away."
 
Awakening the Ostriches
 Similarly, Senator John B. Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat and Edwards protege, said Mr. Duke had tapped into widespread fears among whites and widespread unhappiness among blacks about the efficacy of social welfare programs.
"Any American politician who does not recognize the concerns that are out there is a political ostrich who has his or her head buried in the sand," said Mr. Breaux at a news conference given today by the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, of which he is chairman. "That's why it's important that we enter this debate, because if we don't enter it, David Duke has the stage to himself."
For some, emotions were still high, particularly for Mr. Duke's supporters, brought down to earth after an emotionally charged campaign most fully expected to win.
"He's got the whole world against him," said Donald Geisler, a construction worker in Mr. Duke's home district in Metairie. "The news media hurt him. They wouldn't let up on his past."
Asked his reason for voting for Mr. Duke, he said: "I feel like the blacks get too much their own way. You don't see white people getting up in bed spitting out babies like they do."
But for Mr. Edwards's supporters, many of whom celebrated in the streets of the French Quarter last night, the mood was of extraordinary relief, as if they had been fearing an approaching hurricane that turned and moved harmlessly out to sea.
Beatrice Gautreaux, a retired school teacher who lives in New Orleans's uptown area, usually goes to bed just after dark because of high blood pressure. Last night she stayed up after midnight, napping in a chair during commercials and basking in the results long after she knew who had won.
"It's wonderful," she said. "I am very happy Duke isn't my Governor."
Mr. Edwards said Mr. Duke's defeat, in which he scored five percentage points lower than in his race against Senator J. Bennett Johnston last year, was a crushing repudiation by the people of Louisiana.
"I know this state and I know the people of this state, and there is no way David Duke can be elected Governor of Louisiana," Mr. Johnston said. "David Duke can't be elected statewide in Louisiana, period."
 
Tilting Against Bush?
 But Mr. Duke, who finished three years of almost nonstop campaigning, first for state representative, then for senator, then for governor, said his issues touched a nerve throughout the state and the nation. He was back on national television today airing the same themes he aired in the governor's race.
"Right doesn't win every battle, but right always triumphs in the end," he told cheering supporters in conceding the election Saturday.
Mr. Duke called his loss only a beginning, and speculation on his future centers on whether he will run for Congress in Louisiana or for President.
To some, his defeat last night pointed toward the questions that have been raised about his political prospects -- the difficulty of winning an election dominated by race in an electorate in which blacks make up nearly 30 percent of the voters.
"You cannot run on strictly a racial agenda and expect to win," said Silas Lee, a local political analyst.
But others say that Mr. Duke's real aspirations go beyond the state and that he helped build a national movement that could be an important fringe force in national politics.
"My guess is he'll go out in a third party for President, perhaps a kind of Ayatollah Party putting together right wing politics and fundamentalist religion," said Joe Walker, a local poll taker.
For Mr. Edwards, who takes office Jan. 13, the problems are more concrete, including a billion-dollar budget deficit, lingering questions about his ethical standards, and keeping together the unusual coalition that brought him into power.
"If the economy crashes, we'll get an ersatz Duke, not him, but someone like him, four years from now," Mr. Walker said.
But Mr. Edwards, regarded until his last term as one of the most skillful politicians in Louisiana history, seemed to relish the idea of taking them on today. He has said his main motivation in this campaign was to leave a legacy of good government, and he repeated that today.
 
Hope and Challenges
 "I want to be a good Governor," he said, his accent still flavored by the Cajun language of his youth. "I recognize the opportunity I have. I'm going to make mistakes, but they're going to be mistakes of the hear, not of the heart. We're going to do this right."
He took pains to reach out to Mr. Duke's supporters, saying he shared many of the same goals and hoped to deal with them in a way that was not racially divisive.
"I want the people to know I have the same concerns they have," he said. "I'm not going to do it at the expense of the Hispanics or the blacks or the Jews or any other group of people. We're in this together, and we're all going to do well together or no one will do well."

How the Survey Was Conducted
The poll is based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting stations throughout Louisiana on Saturday.
The poll was conducted by Voter Research and Surveys, an organization created in 1990 by ABC News, CBS News, CNN, and NBC News.
The results are based on 1,675 voters in 30 randomly selected precincts statewide.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from a poll like this, when based on the entire sample, should differ by no more than three percentage points from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all those who voted in Louisiana on Election Day.
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day may introduce other sources of error into the poll.

HEADLINE: The Louisiana Election;
Duke's Loss Brings Joy Even as It Fans Anger

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GARYVILLE, La., Nov. 17

 BODY:
From an easy chair in his living room, Cleveland Johnson stared at the television picture of David Duke as the former Ku Klux Klan leader delivered his concession speech. Finally, it was over. And Mr. Johnson began to chuckle, softly at first, and then in great, lusty gales.
"I felt like rejoicing," said Mr. Johnson, a 44-year-old steelworker who recalls the day in 1970 when he was reprimanded at work for using the restroom for whites. "Duke can say whatever he wants. Fact is, he lost. And he lost big." 
 In this tiny rural town southwest of New Orleans surrounded by oil refineries and sugar cane fields, there are six streets; three "black streets" and three "white streets." All that differs between the two sides of town is the color of the residents, but that is almost all that matters here.
Sharon Duhe, who lives a short walk from Mr. Johnson, was angry about Mr. Duke's loss. "They just have those babies and go on welfare," she said, making it clear that "they" are black.
Ms. Duhe, a 22-year-old single unemployed woman, held her 1-year-old child, Ralphie, on her lap, as she talked furiously and drew hard on a cigarette. She receives welfare payments. "But the blacks get more," she said.
From New Orleans to Shreveport, voters expressed relief that the torturous campaign, which has cast this state in a most unflattering light, had finally come to an end. But supporters of Mr. Duke vowed to fight another day. And many blacks say they now feel a bit more uneasy around some of their white neighbors.
"When I see a white person in the grocery store now I wonder: 'Is this a Duke supporter?' " said Bill Spikes, a 23-year-old accounting student at Louisiana State University. "For me, this has been the last straw. Most of the white people actually voted for Duke. I don't have the patience for people who think like this. As soon as I graduate, I'm moving to California."
At the campaign rally for Mr. Duke on Saturday night, where the only black people in the ballroom were serving the drinks, there was little question about the central theme behind the candidate. As Mr. Duke spoke, one man hoisted a hand-lettered placard that read, "Vote for the Wite Man, not the Wong Man."
"What's wrong with being proud to be white?" asked Tonya McQueen, a 35-year-old Baton Rouge woman who came to the Duke rally with her 9-year-old son, Ruston. Mrs. McQueen, who recently lost her job as a dental hygienist, wore a sweatshirt emblazoned with the slogan, "It's a White Thing: You Wouldn't Understand."
In Shreveport, where support for Mr. Duke was solid, voters pore over the newspapers this morning with their breakfasts at George's Grill on Kings Highway.
"I think the national media and the others in the state did a good job of persuading people of the dangers of a Duke election," said Andy Shehee, 32, who works in the funeral business.
 
'Put the Signs Down'
 But Mr. Duke hardly shied away from media coverage. "Put the signs down," Mr. Duke told his supporters as he prepared to deliver his concession speech, "so that people around the country can see this."
The emergence of Mr. Duke did not surprise Huey Fleming, a 56-year-old black man who lives in Garyville. "A whole lot of white people feel the way Duke feels," he said. "He just came out and expessed it."
At one of the largest black churches in New Orleans, the mood was joyous, but tempered with concern. "You better believe I'm relieved," said James Joseph, a parishioner at Greater St. Stephens Full Gospel Baptist Church. "There was some tension in this city."
In Metairie, the suburb that Mr. Duke has represented in the State Legislature, many voters were angry at whites who did not stick together. Clyde Alexander, a retired shipyard worker, said he was bitter about the failure of some whites to support Mr. Duke.
"Most of the white people are so two-faced," he said. "They say what he says in private."
James V. Farmer, an unemployed oilfield worker walking down Veterans Boulevard in Metairie, said Mr. Duke would remain a leader for angry whites. "Give him four more years, he'll be the Governor of Louisiana," he said.
Many people at the Duke rally expressed anger with President Bush. One man wore a shirt that declared, "Kill the Quail; Burn the Bush."
"People say that David Duke has made race an issue," said Edward L. Richmond, a 38-year-old owner of a heating and air-conditioning business, and a Duke supporter. "But he doesn't say anything different than Patrick Buchanan says. Most Republicans think just like David."
Many Duke supporters were not natives of Louisiana. Chuck Fiorello, a 41-year-old oilfield salesman, bounced his 6-year-old daughter, Kaylin, on his shoulders, at the Duke rally. "Why am I for Duke?" he asked. He pointed at his 9-year-old son. "Because he's white, he's going to have a harder chance getting into schools, getting jobs. It's not fair."
Late Saturday in Baton Rouge, Mr. Duke said that while "the candidate may have lost, the message goes out."
In Garyville, meanwhile, Mr. Johnson, the steelworker, said he thought to himself: "Yeah, the voters delivered a message, all right. The message is that they don't want you."

SECTION: Section B; Page 6; Column 3; National Desk

HEADLINE: The Louisiana Election;
Even in Losing, Duke Spread Message to Nation

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 17

 BODY:
For State Representative David Duke merely losing an election need not be the end of his career.
When he conceded defeat in the Louisiana governor's race to former Gov. Edwin W. Edwards on Saturday night, he said, "this is the beginning, not the end." Indeed, even as he waged a losing campaign, Mr. Duke greatly expanded the national audience for his message of middle-class resentment. And in network interviews today he refused to rule out the possibility of running for President. 
 But whatever his future ambitions may be, on Saturday Mr. Duke violated one of the cardinal rules of politics. He performed below expectations.
Now, in addition to the baggage he carried as a former Nazi and leader of the Ku Klux Klan, he bears the additional burden of being a loser. And by a big margin: he won only 39 percent of the vote to 61 percent for Mr. Edwards, a three-time former Democratic Governor who left office in 1987 under a cloud of scandal.
 
'Consider Him Damaged Goods'
 "He took a very big hit yesterday in a race against a candidate who had exploitable weaknesses," said Fred Meyer, chairman of the Texas Republican Party, "and in terms of his ability to export the David Duke phenomenon beyond Louisiana, you have to consider him damaged goods."
Playing the underdog as usual, Mr. Duke today blamed "the liberal media" and "the massive political machine assembled against me."
Indeed, a vast coalition of politicians, businessmen and interest groups backed Mr. Edwards, and a survey of voters on Saturday as they left polling places showed that 47 percent of those who said they voted for Mr. Edwards said their main motive was to vote against Mr. Duke.
Just as he proved in the campaign that he could arouse enormous intensity among his supporters by holding rallies at which he was greeted like a rock idol, Mr. Duke proved on Election Day that he could arouse equal intensity in his opponents.
 
Likely to Test Political Power
 It remains to be seen whether these vulnerablilities will outweigh the gains he made by being interviewed on at least eight network news shows in the last week alone. But it does seem likely that the 41-year-old Mr. Duke will test his political powers again soon. He may have to if only because he will be unemployed at the end of the year when his legislative term is up.
"There is no reason to assume that Duke is now going to become inconsistent, and thus far his life has been a consistent effort to push his message and himself in front of an ever bigger audience," said Douglas Rose, a professor of political science at Tulane University and the author of the coming book "David Duke: Action and Reaction" (University of North Carolina Press, 1992).
Mr. Rose warned that it was easy to underestimate Mr. Duke's political accomplishments in this race by simply looking at the bottom-line results.
 
Nationwide Name Recognition
 In fact he drew more than 701,000 votes, a 15 percent increase over the number he gathered last year in his unsuccessful bid to unseat United States Senator J. Bennett Johnston, a Democrat. And again this year he took a clear majority of the white vote.
As a perpetual candidate, he has steadily increased his constituency in Louisiana, and while he was defeated here, he scored important successes outside the state.
The intense news coverage of this race across the country insured that Mr. Duke's name recognition nationwide now exceeds that of many Federal officeholders.
In the campaign he received contributions from 46 states, and campaign finance reports show that 47 percent of his contributions came from outside Louisiana. As of Oct. 27 the reports show that Mr. Duke had received $1.4 million.
Even today, as he did throughout the campaign, Mr. Duke took every opportunity in television appearances to invite letters from those who agree with his views and he sometimes managed to announce his mailing address as well. Responses from just two network appearances generated 14,000 letters, an aide to Mr. Duke said, and so he has probably added tens of thousands of names to the computerized mailing list used for his fund-raising efforts.
And for those people who are already devoted to Mr. Duke, his defeat may not be an overwhelming obstacle.
 
May Become More Formidable
 "He might just turn into an even more formidable force now that he can play the martyr who has been trashed by the liberals and the special interests," said Kris Wolfe, a former regional political director for the Republican National Committee. "He's just so good at playing the victim."
The campaign for governor, however, disclosed flaws that might limit his career.
George Rabinowitz, a political scientist at the University of North Carolina, said, "In the long haul he may not be terribly viable as a political figure because he has boxed himself in to a certain kind of appeal and he is not going to expand it very readily."
Indeed, Mr. Duke apparently believed his own speeches when he claimed that most people shared his beliefs but did not have the courage to admit it. He made no effort to reach out to new constituencies in the campaign. Instead, he just repeated his basic themes about the evils of welfare, affirmative action and big government.
One of Mr. Duke's biggest flaws, as demonstrated by Saturday's election, is that he "falls outside the realm of acceptability," Mr. Rabinowitz said.
Like Barry Goldwater, the Republican candidate in the 1964 Presidential election, Mr. Duke was attacked not so much for any specific facets of his past or his positions, but instead he was successfully painted as a dangerous extremist.
Just as advertising with images of mushroom clouds was used to defeat Mr. Goldwater, Mr. Duke was abandoned by his suburban followers after a flood of advertisements predicted that he would heap economic disaster on the state.
While Mr. Duke may still have a future as a protest candidate in Louisiana or in a national contest, Saturday's election showed that he can be defeated when voters are faced with the choice of giving him real responsibility.

LENGTH: 1001 words

HEADLINE: Turkish Election Results May Shift Basic Policies

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 13

 BODY:
Burdened by a 70 percent inflation rate and disintegration along its borders with the Soviet Union and Iraq, Turkey is scrambling to redefine itself in the wake of the election defeat of President Turgut Ozal's governing Motherland Party.
The defeat in the Oct. 20 elections has returned Suleyman Demirel to the Prime Minister's office for the seventh time, and with him the fear that the country could slip back into the violent political infighting that led to a military coup in 1980. Mr. Demirel was ousted in that coup, as he had been once before, in 1971. 
 The election appears more likely to result in a shift by the Ankara Government away from the stongly pro-Western policies of Mr. Ozal and the conservative Motherland Party. Mr. Demirel, whose nationalist True Path Party took 180 of the 450 Parliamentary seats, is trying to hammer out a coalition with the left-wing Social Democrat Populist Party, which won 88 seats.
 
'Atmosphere Is Different'
 "We are entering a political crisis," said Kamran Inan, Mr. Ozal's Minister of State and one of Mr. Demirel's fiercest critics. "We are faced with enormous problems. We must assume a leadership role in the Middle East, the Balkans, Central Asia and beyond. We have economic difficulties and increased terrorism. We need a strong leader, but what we are getting is a man who prefers political survival over political stability."
Mr. Demirel argues that Turkey has come too far to ever slip back into thepolitical violence of the years before the coup.
"The atmosphere of the country is different, quite different," the avuncular 68-year-old politician said, seated in his office in Parliament. "The atmosphere of the world is different."
For the last decade Turkey was dominated by the voluble and high-handed Mr. Ozal, who was appointed Prime Minister by the military in 1983 and oversaw the transition from military dictatorship, propelled the country toward parliamentary democracy and a market economy and gave unreserved support to the West, in particular the United States. During the Persian Gulf crisis, Turkey shut off the pipeline by which Iraq exported most of its oil and allowed American warplanes to make sorties against Iraq from Turkish soil.
But the cozier President Ozal became with the West, the more he engendered disgust at home, and he was often attacked for his regal way of life and the wealth supposedly accumulated by his family. Mr. Demirel, during his campaign, promised to remove the President, "his crown, his throne and all."
 
Taking Aim at Presidency
 Mr. Demirel says he is determined to strip the power of the presidency, which he argues is unconstitutional, and give it to the Parliament. He says the new Parliament will take up the legality of Mr. Ozal's election by Parliament to the newly created post of President in 1989.
It would take a two-thirds majority to oust the President, and the new Parliament still has 113 members of the Motherland Party, enough to block such a move.
But Mr. Ozal, whose term expires in 1996, seems to have thrown in the towel. "The Ozal era is finished," he recently told a Turkish newspaper. "I don't want any role from now on."
In fact, the True Path Party and the Motherland Party have many policies in common. Mr. Demirel promised during the campaign to apply more strigent fiscal controls, to give the right to strike to public employees, to create a ministry for human rights and a national health-insurance system, to continue selling off state-owned businesses and to suppress leftist terrorist groups and the Kurdish guerrilla movement in the southeast.
 
Kurdish Violence Is Up
 The Kurdish violence has increased in the last year. The rebels, who have been waging a guerrilla campaign since 1983, want a separate Kurdish state.
Mr. Demirel has called for "compassion" in dealing with the Kurdish problem, telling Kurdish leaders that he will lift bans on publications in Kurdish. But on economic matters, Mr. Demirel's policies may be influenced by his coalition negotiations with a party whose distrust of market economics is only exceeded by its distrust of the United States.
The Social Democrats opposed Turkish involvement in the Persian Gulf war and are calling for a halt to the privatization of the public sector, which constitutes about 40 percent of the economy, and the creation of new state enterprises.
 
Austerity May Be Needed
 If he is to rein in the inflation rate, Mr. Demirel must convince the Social Democrats to endorse what could be an unpleasant austerity program, according to Western diplomats.
There is a budget deficit of $6 billion and a foreign debt of $44 billion. And there is little likelihood that Mr. Demirel will ever begin to deliver on some of his more outlandish campaign promises, including one to give every Turk two keys, one for his car and the other for his house.
The Social Democrats, moreover, are split by internal power struggles, and fell far short of their aspirations in the last elections. Most acknowledge that the process of economic and political reform, coupled with Turkey's drive to become part of the European Community, has advanced too far to be rolled back.
"We are part of Europe," Mr. Demirel said, "and we should stay a part of Europe."
 
Western Diplomats Worried
 Some Western diplomats worry that Mr. Demirel, forced to bend to the Social Democrats, will find himself unable to introduce the economic reforms needed to prod the economy along.
"The economy needs some major tinkering with and another impulse of privatization," a Western diplomat said. "What we fear is that things will just go on as they are with a few rhetorical statements."
But for many Turks, for whom this is the third election since the military relinquished power, the democratic transition is in itself a victory, despite all their other worries.
"Forming a government is a means now, not a goal," Mr. Demirel said. "The goal is what this government will do."

HEADLINE: Dark Skies For Bush;
Rain on His Parade Buoys Democrats

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
There are more than just a few scattered clouds over the White House in the past few days. The sagging economy, a new challenge from the party's right and some rough new attacks from the Democrats have combined to produce a siege of bad weather for President Bush.
What worries many Republicans is whether this White House, this political team and this President can adjust. Mr. Bush's fortunes, after all, have changed very quickly. In recent days, the Administration has seemed rattled and forced into playing defense again and again, feeding concerns in the party that Mr. Bush and his political apparatus are not yet ready for 1992. 
 The political awkwardness the Adminstration brings to the economy was captured today by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, as he and other Administration spokesmen tried to regain ground on the Sunday morning talk shows, after a week marked by bad economic news. Under questioning on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Mr. Brady tried to counter the notion that the nation was mired in a serious recession. "What I would say is we're in a recovery that's slower than we want it to be," he said, echoing the standard Administration line.
 
D'Amato Is Pessimistic
 His point was immediately undercut by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, who is in a competitive race for re-election next year and who wasted little time in pronouncing the nation "in a tremendous recession." Indeed, while many Republicans recognize the need to retain business confidence through comments like Mr. Brady's, they worry that the Administration's cautious style feeds directly into the Democrats' line of attack these days.
One after another, the Democratic Presidential contenders have portrayed the Bush Administration as a den of elitists with no feel for the suffering caused by the recession, and thus no sense of urgency about ending it. Senator Tom Harkin of Iowa has even resurrected the longstanding symbol of Republican inaction on the economy: Herbert Hoover.
Conservative Republicans, who long for the philosophical clarity of the Reagan Administration, are particularly concerned about how the economic issue is being framed for the coming campaign. They have watched in dismay as the Democrats have seized control of the powerful issue of tax cuts for the middle class, an issue that many Republicans consider their own.
"The Republican Party has been successful in large measure because we've succeeded in shaking off the mantle of Herbert Hoover and becoming the party of growth," said Representative Vin Weber of Minnesota, secretary of the House Republican Conference and a leading conservative. "If we go into the next election with the Democrats on the offensive on the economy while we're defending a sick economy, I have no doubt we'd lose that election. Unfortunately, that seems to be the posture that we're in today."
Still, Mr. Weber said he believed that the White House was waking up to its problems and had time to correct them. He noted that the Administration was now promising a new domestic agenda in the State of the Union address.
Many Republicans are arguing that the slow-starting schedule originally established for Mr. Bush's re-election campaign, devised back when he was soaring in the public opinion polls, has got to change. Mr. Bush now has to deal with both the attacks from the Democrats and the likelihood of a challenge in New Hampshire from Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator.
"The campaign, whether he likes it or not, has begun," said a veteran Republican consultant.
Mr. Buchanan, who has not yet formally announced, is not considered a major threat to Mr. Bush's renomination, but he has the capacity to cause considerable mischief. He could serve as a vehicle for economic anger in New Hampshire, and he could be a lightning rod for conservatives, who have long been suspicious of Mr. Bush's commitment to their cause.
 
A Sprawling Coalition
 Some political professionals say that Mr. Bush might also have to deal with a challenge in Republican primaries from David Duke, the Louisiana State Representative and former Ku Klux Klan leader, just coming off his loss in the race for Louisiana governor.
The restlessness on the right only underscores the challenge facing Mr. Bush as he heads into 1992: holding together the sprawling Republican coalition forged under Ronald Reagan. Both centrist and conservative Republicans are complaining in recent weeks that the Bush Administration lacks a clear and compelling message.
In the absence of a unifying message, divisive issues like abortion can loom large. At the moment, Mr. Bush is faced with a particularly difficult issue for his party: legislation that would overturn the rule prohibiting doctors and counselors in federally financed family planning clinics from discussing abortion. Mr. Bush must act by Wednesday, and a veto is expected.
Republicans draw solace from the notion that no matter how great their difficulties in Presidential elections, they can rely on the Democrats to kick away any chance of capitalizing on them. Still, there is decidedly less cockiness. And Republicans are praying that the White House realizes how much the weather has changed.

HEADLINE: Ms. Leinwand Has Wedding

 BODY:
Adrienne Sue Leinwand, the director of special personnel projects for the City University of New York, and David Chester Maslin, a vice president and a senior international economist at J. P. Morgan in New York, were married in New York yesterday by Rabbi Ronald Sobel at the Parker Meridien hotel.
