HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

BLACK CHURCHES JOIN THE AIDS FIGHT
Faced with the overwhelming reality that minorities account for an alarming proportion of the new AIDS cases being diagnosed, many black churches and mosques are beginning to turn their influence to the fight against the disease. Clergymen and women are speaking out in sermons, starting counseling and support groups and sponsoring housing for homeless people with AIDS. And they are doing so against the powerful traditions of their conservative theology. Page A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
MAYOR DINKINS'S TRIP TO SOUTH AFRICA ENDS
In the final hours of a trip he called "one of the most profound experiences I've ever had," Mayor David N. Dinkins accomplished a major goal he had set for his journey to South Africa: announcing a package of economic programs involving New York City businesses. But he failed to accomplish another: meeting with a top government official to press the cause of change. His meeting with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha was canceled at the last minute without explanation. Page B3.
 
SAME QUESTIONS, ANOTHER CUOMO
Andrew Cuomo, the Governor's son, who has had considerable success over the years in overcoming community opposition and government bureaucracy to build housing for the homeless, has been contemplating whether public office is the most effective vehicle for coping with the growing problem of homelessness. Metro Matters, Page B3.
 
A TRAIL OF RANDOM VIOLENCE IN THE BRONX
A man talking with his wife from a pay phone in the South Bronx was shot and killed by an unidentified man with a shotgun -- apparently a random act of violence. Two relatives standing nearby were also sprayed with shotgun pellets. The shooting occurred shortly after a dispute between two groups of men erupted into gunfire a short distance up the street. Page B3.
 
A SHOOTING IN MIDTOWN RESTAURANT
A dispute among a dozen men in a Chinese restaurant on Fifth Avenue near 32d Street erupted into gunfire on Saturday evening, leaving one man dead and another seriously injured. The police, who were still trying to identify the victims and learn what prompted the argument, said they believe the incident might have involved Asian gangs. Page B3.
A young girl died in a house fire in Queens started by her brother. Page B3.
 
REGION
 
USING CHILDREN TO RUN DRUGS
Once or twice a week, the police say, two woman from Plainfield, N.J., loaded their children into a car and drove to the Bronx, where the children hurried out to pick up packets of cocaine and heroin. Then the families drove back to Plainfield, where the children delivered the drugs to dealers. Prosecutors said they broke up the ring on Friday night with the arrest of the two women. Page B5.
 
THE GAPS BETWEEN NEW JERSEY'S CHILDREN
The first county-by-county analysis of children's well-being in New Jersey shows "startling extremes" between the richer, generally suburban areas of the state and the poor, mostly urban areas. The survey, which considered 12 factors from infant mortality to high school dropout rate, ranked Bergen County first and Essex County last. Page B5.
 
WHERE DID YOU GET THAT HAMMER?
In additions to books and other such things, the public library in Wyandanch, L.I., lends tools. After years of giving borrowers books that told them how to do things, but neglecting to give them the tools carrying them out, the library began the tool-lending program two years ago with a $10,000 Federal grant. It has been a means for the library to be relevant to a painfully poor neighborhood where many people prize a trowel more than a novel. Page B5.
 
THE TRIANGLE CLUB'S 100TH ANNIVERSARY
Princeton University threw a three-day party to celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Triangle Club, the undergraduate theater troupe almost as well-known for its tradition of men-in-drag chorus lines as for its crisp original productions. With more than 750 past members on hand, nostalgia reigned. Princeton Journal, Page B5.

HEADLINE: A Puzzle for Plainfield: Children as Drug Couriers

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 17

 BODY:
Once or twice a week, the police say, two women loaded children into a car and drove into the the Bronx, where the children hurried out to pick up packets of cocaine and heroin.
Then the families drove back to this once-proud city, now troubled by crime, where the children would deliver the drugs to dealers in homes and on street corners, investigators said today. 
 The children, third to seventh graders, provided a cover for the ring, they said. The price was their innocence.
 
'Mothers Waiting in Cars'
 "The kids would walk right into 'stash houses' and then make runs just like paperboys to low-level distributors, with their mothers waiting in cars," said the Union County Prosecutor, Andrew K. Ruotolo. "These kids not only obtained the drugs in the Bronx, but some of the older ones took orders in phone calls. Their innocence has been lost forever."
Mr. Ruotolo and his top aides surmised that the women designated themselves as ringleaders and gave the children "principal roles" in the operation to avoid arousing suspicion from law-enforcement personnel.
The children, they said, were innocent pawns. "I don't think they had any idea of the seriousness or the enormity of the activities they were involved in," said Mr. Ruotolo's first assistant, Michael Lapolla.
The two Plainfield mothers -- Valerie Jackson, 39 years old, and Shirley McCoy, a 37-year-old caseworker at the Union County Board of Social Services here -- were arrested Friday night. The main charges against Ms. Jackson and Ms. McCoy were conspiracy to distribute narcotics and employing minors in a drug scheme, officials said. Maximum sentences for the crimes are 20 years in prison, they said.
Of seven other Plainfield residents arrested Friday night in the case, four are women, including Ms. Jackson's 22-year-old daughter Tawana, officials said.
Ms. Jackson has six children -- four girls and two boys -- ranging in age from 3 to 25, friends said. In addition, she helps care for a 3-week-old grandchild, born to Tawana at the end of October.
The family lives in a two-story white-shingled Cape Cod home with black trim on Salem Road, a quiet residential street of modest homes near the high school's football field and athletic complex.
On Saturday night, her husband sat on a couch with two young boys watching a wrestling match. He leaped up in anger when a reporter, escorted by his brother-in-law, Butch Tucker, came in. "I don't know anything about the arrest," Mr. Jackson said. "All I know is I got my sons."
Then Mr. Tucker said, "You look at this house, does this look like a house of drugs?"
Today, a neighbor, Alexandra Kerencev, described Ms. Jackson as an "excellent, excellent mother" who was very protective of her children.
"Rain, sleet, or snow, she was out there driving her kids to school, sometimes in slippers and bathrobe," Ms. Kerencev said.
Mr. Ruotolo, the prosecutor, said the drug ring was thought to have been operating here for several months. He said his staff uncovered it shortly after opening a satellite office here three months ago under a $64,000 state grant to begin a crackdown on crime in Plainfield.
He said about 30 percent of Union County's crime occurred in Plainfield, a racially mixed community of about 50,000 people. Since race riots here in the late 1960's, Plainfield has evolved from a town of wealth and prosperity into one with all economic classes. Grand homes with broad lawns coexist now with pockets of poverty and boarded-up homes in some neighborhoods.
In part because the investigation is continuing, Mr. Ruotolo declined to divulge several details in the case, including the addresses of the drug distribution points in the Bronx and whether the women used their own children or others as couriers.
Officials also declined to say exactly how many children were involved in the trips to the Bronx, other than to say it was fewer than 10.
Other residents arrested and the charges against them are Richard Benjamin, 46, possession of and conspiracy to distribute drugs; Carlton Gee, 33, conspiracy to distribute drugs; Phillip King, 32, conspiracy to distribute drugs; Carolyn McCleod, 37, possession of narcotics; Celeste McCray, 29, possession of narcotics, and Jacquelin Fitz, 39, possession of drug paraphernalia.

HEADLINE: Library Lends Tools to Build Pride

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WYANDANCH, L.I., Nov. 16

 BODY:
Carl Varner went to the public library here the other day and checked out a hammer. Then he took it home and used it to replace the ragged paneling in the entrance hallway. He lives in a plain split-level house with his sister, Janice, and she had been egging him to help tidy up the place.
"Right now I couldn't really afford a hammer," said Mr. Varner, who works at a plumbing supply company. "All I can say is I'm a grateful man that I can go to the library and take out a tool that makes life a little better." 
 Like the screwdrivers and the wrenches and the T squares, the hammer had been around. Brenda Donald used it to repair a rickety door frame. Jackie McQueen took it out to install some sorely needed screens. Seven-year-old Richard Ashby 3d checked it out so he could mend his mangled bicycle chain.
There are many ways that impoverishment expresses itself in a hard-luck community and one of the ways in Wyandanch is in the nagging need for a good hand tool and a way to mop the floor. And so two years ago, the local library, fueled with $10,000 in Federal money, began a tool-lending program. It was a means for the library to be relevant to a painfully poor neighborhood where many people prize a trowel more than a novel.
 
'Now There's No Excuse'
 "One of the reasons we started this is civic pride," said Richard Ashby, who runs the program. "You would drive around town and you'd see fences broken down. You'd see high grass. You would tell people to fix things up and they'd say they can't afford a lawn mower, they can't afford tools. Now there's no excuse for your lawn to be uncut, your gate to be swinging from the post, your floor to be unmopped. We're trying to get people to stop saying I can't."
Wyandanch has joined a scattering of libraries across the country with similar impulses. The Plainedge, L.I., Public Library operates a tool-lending program, as do the Grosse Pointe, Mich., Central Library and the Berkeley Public Library in California.
Wyandanch is a predominantly black community of 11,000 people where an air of unfulfilled dreams and bitter struggle hangs like a cloud. Most residents subsist on small incomes and many rear their children without the assistance of a spouse. In the surge and ebb of enervating lives of too few dollars and too many needs, not everything always gets done.
The library has a hodgepodge of about 100 tools available for loan -- including six hammers, seven tape measures, two vacuum cleaners, three lawn mowers, one post-hole digger, 18 screwdrivers, six rakes, two mops and three ladders.
Officially, the hours of the tool program are Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday from 10 A.M. to 1 P.M., but Mr. Ashby doesn't hew to the schedule. He knows that nobody absolutely has to have the new Updike at 6 P.M. on a Friday. But if someone's toilet gets clogged up at 6, they need a snake right then.
 
Tools at All Hours
 "I end up lending tools six days a week at all hours," Mr. Ashby said. "If I didn't, I wouldn't really be helping the community, would I?"
Brenda Donald does the best she can to keep her blue frame house presentable. Spare hours are rare when you're a single parent with three young children thundering through the house and when money is so tight that having a phone is too much of a luxury. When the tool program began, Ms. Donald was first in line.
She has had the hammer out, and she is a regular borrower of a lawn mower and a rake. Her small lawn was well tended since she had used a rake just the other day to spruce it up. "It's been a blessing," she said as she shooed her children down the block. "When I'm in need of something, I go to the library and use my library card. It makes a difference in my life, I'll tell you that."
None of the library's tools are power models, except for the vacuums, because of worries about insurance risks. Thus the lawn mowers are the old-fashioned push variety. "When people see that, their faces hit the ground," Mr. Ashby said. "But I grew up pushing a mower across four lots before I could go to Little League, and so I know they'll be better people for using a push model."
Two brothers and a friend happened in one day and checked out every rake in the library. Then they organized an informal lawn-cleaning business. "That was very enterprising of them," Mr. Ashby said, "but that's not the purpose of the tool program. It's for people to take care of their own homes."
Tools are lent for a week at a time, but given the economic pinch in the community, fines for overdue tools have not been levied. "Most of these people are borrowing tools because they can't afford to buy them," said Wendell Cherry, the director of the library. "So how can we charge them?"
Darkness was bringing a glow in the sky, and Rafael Llamos still had plenty to do. The basement of his home had the framing in place, but there were walls to come and myriad finishing touches. He was building a family room for his wife and three children. This was their first house, and with the budget tight, the hand tools at the library had been indispensable.
"The tool program has meant a lot to me," Mr. Llamos said. "It's not easy fixing up your first home. You stretch a dollar till it hollers. This idea ought to go on everywhere. Give the people tools and see them work."

GRAPHIC: Photo: With the help of Federal money, the public library in Wyandanch, L.I., began a tool-lending program two years ago. Richard Ashby, who runs the program, provided Hope Anderson with a lawnmower. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: New Power, Old Troubles in Trenton

 BODY:
The Republicans have won overwhelming control of New Jersey's Legislature, and an overwhelming obligation to use it responsibly. They seized both houses from the Democrats by promising to roll back unpopular tax increases. Suddenly empowered, they're talking big. Reality says they should start thinking small.
Gov. Jim Florio, who seized office from the Republicans in 1990, launched his administration with a bold $2.8 billion tax hike. It made the state's income tax more progressive, raised and broadened the sales tax and infuriated a large body of voters. 
 The Republicans will have veto-proof majorities in both houses for the two years remaining in Mr. Florio's term. He obviously must yield to some compromises. But the governorship in New Jersey is more powerful than in most other states; he need not capitulate while the office is still his.
At this stage, both parties are playing games. Some Democratic leaders, while still in charge, want to terminate the entire Florio tax package as of July 1, thus creating a huge deficit for the Republicans to close. Such cynical politics would be irresponsible.
Mr. Florio has also teased the Republicans by conceding he might be wrong in opposing two constitutional amendments to curb the Legislature's power -- term limits for legislators and authority for popular voting on initiatives and referendums. Republicans tend to favor such curbs when they're in the minority, but not when they have control; his ploy puts them on the spot.
Meanwhile, Republicans talk about undoing what Mr. Florio has accomplished in equalizing school aid and reducing auto insurance premiums. They should focus instead on the problems they have created for themselves by promising tax cuts.
Their commitment to cut the 7 percent sales tax back to 6 percent, where it was before, will cut revenue by $600 million. Also, this year's gimmicky sale of state roads to the Turnpike Authority can't be repeated -- $400 million gone.
What spending would the Republicans chop? They don't say, and probably don't know. They are banking on economic recovery to help boost revenues, but optimistic assumptions are no substitute for hard facts. Faced with the same unpleasant choices that Mr. Florio faced, they will find that it's easier to rant than to rule.

HEADLINE: No Energy Bill This Year? Good

 BODY:
A glittering pedigree guarantees nothing, as the sponsors of the Senate's energy bill discovered. The bill came to the floor with the imprimatur of President Bush and many powerful Democrats. It failed to survive a procedural vote. The country has reason to be grateful. It was a bad bill.
The main reason for the defeat was a provision opening the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling. As some senators noted, there are other places to find oil at far less risk to the environment. Furthermore, the provision symbolized the bill's mindless bias toward energy production as opposed to conservation. 
 A sound energy strategy would consist of a few simple components.
 Energy taxes -- stiff gasoline taxes, for example -- that reflect energy's social costs and that encourage efficiency and conservation.
 A larger Strategic Petroleum Reserve, to cushion temporary disruptions.
 Serious research into clean and competitive alternatives to fossil fuels. That doesn't mean repeating the costly synfuels boondoggle. It does mean searching for renewable energy sources like solar power and controlled nuclear fusion -- a field in which Europeans, operating with larger research budgets, have made breakthroughs.
The bill contained a handful of useful ideas. But mostly it offered a vision for the next year, not the next century. And by taking tax hikes off the table, the Senate forced itself into second-best strategies that are complicated and contradictory. The bill's preamble, for example, grandly pronounced the need to reduce greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide. But the bill itself provided generous incentives to the very fuels, including coal, that produce these gases.
With one big exception -- a provision asking states to let utilities make money by promoting conservation rather than consumption -- strategies for encouraging efficiency got short shrift. Why? Many people, including Mr. Bush's top advisers, seem convinced that efficiency is the sworn enemy of economic growth.
Conservation does exact a cost. But the cost is affordable, and it doesn't stop growth. Between 1973 and 1986, total U.S. energy consumption remained level, and carbon dioxide emissions actually dropped, even as the economy expanded by 40 percent. And the benefits of, say, cleaner air are not measured in conventional gross national product figures.
The House has broken the Bush proposal into bits and pieces and may have several different bills ready before adjournment. But there will be no energy legislation this year unless the Senate redraws its bill, which seems unlikely. Still, the Senate's failure has produced useful lessons to guide the next attempt at a national energy strategy. Keep it simple. And make it balanced.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Ukraine Marches Out

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
"Unprincipled" is the word used to describe President Bush by Mykhailo Horyn, a former political prisoner and founder of Rukh, the Ukrainian independence movement. "We prefer Thomas Jefferson."
Fighters for a Ukraine free of Russian imperial rule are still smarting at Mr. Bush's speech in Kiev this summer blasting "suicidal nationalism" and touting the Gorbachev center. 
 That misreading of the forces of history in his "chicken Kiev" speech not only made one American President appear to be anti-liberty, but jeopardized our relations with an emerging European power.
Ukraine (the article "the" is dropped when referring to a country, not a province) is the great, hobnailed boot that will drop on Dec. 1 on top of Moscow center's pretensions to empire. On that day of referendum, at least two out of three Ukrainians are likely to vote to assert their country's national sovereignty. On that day, the Soviet "union" will die.
The courageous early move of the Baltic states was the key to disunion, but the departure of Ukraine is the sledgehammer blow. Imagine the United States without its southeastern quadrant; subtract the old Confederacy from our map to get an idea of what an impact on Russian colonialism the separation of Ukraine's 52 million people and productive capacity will have.
On the overnight train from Moscow to Kiev, the visitor gets a notion of the potential richness of the land. Black loam, intensive cultivation and a friendly climate add up to food production and economic power as soon as frustrated farmers are given transportation and the incentives of private property and personal gain. This is potentially France, not Bangladesh.
We should shake free of our old questions (What will independence do to the Soviet Union? How will Russia survive without its breadbasket?) and address the new: What sort of nation will Ukraine be?
Strongly nationalistic, for openers. The word "Ukraine" means "borderland"; its Catholic west faces Europe, its Greek Orthodox east faces Asia. To win the coming referendum, the Ukrainians in the west have been actively selling the Russian-speaking population in the east (including those in the Crimea, a Black Sea gift to Ukraine from Khrushchev) on the glories of nationhood.
Opportunistic, too. The candidate leading the race for the presidency is Leonid Kravchuk, a longtime Communist subservient to the Kremlin and silent during the coup who has undergone a miraculous conversion to independence. He has stolen the Rukh opposition's platform, and if he gets away with the flip-flop, it will be a measure of the populace's desire for freedom from Moscow without too much change at home.
And Ukraine may spell trouble. American policy makers worry about plans announced in Kiev for a 400,000-man army, but that is a third of the Red Army troops now stationed here and may be a device for shipping the Russians home while keeping Ukrainian troops employed. The real trouble will be in enticing the new nation into giving up its nuclear weapons.
Even with milk in Kiev still suspect after the Chernobyl metldown, Ukrainian politicians, are not eager to give up the Soviet nuclear missiles located on their territory. Privately, some Kievans say that these weapons are bargaining chips for Russian cooperation on oil-for-grain trade and for Western help.
The center, as the poet Yeats predicted, cannot hold. We should stop supporting Moscow center and stop lecturing the Ukrainians on the need to ship the missiles to responsible Russia. That simplistic Bush-Gorbachev approach, typical of the offensive "chicken Kiev" speech, won't work.
Instead, as Russia's Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, hints, Washington should negotiate through the center's paper union with Russia, Ukraine and the other nuclear republics to dismantle land-based ICBM's until a level is reached at which the only missiles remaining happen to be on the Russian republic's soil. The criterion need not be insultingly geographic to bring about that stabilizing result.
Complex? You bet. But with Ukraine as a player, Washington will have to stop wishing for the good old days of union dictatorship.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
'America, Be on Guard'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
A sigh of relief: That is the first reaction to the result in Louisiana. David Duke lost, and we can put aside our worst fears. America is not so susceptible to the virus of racism.
But it is not really an occasion for relief when a man who as recently as two years ago openly peddled Nazi propaganda wins nearly 40 percent of the vote in an American state. 
 It is not an occasion for relief when a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan can master the techniques of modern politics so well that for hundreds of thousands of voters he is a hero, the voice of their frustration.
And it is not an occasion for relief when it takes weeks of effort, local and national, focused on a single election, to defeat such a man. If this had been just one of many significant races around the country, would the attention and the money have been there to fight David Duke?
"America, be on guard!" Edwin Edwards told a New Orleans crowd celebrating his victory. He said Louisiana had "rejected the demagogue," but the country could face "another assault of bigotry" in the Presidential campaign.
Yes it could. Mr. Duke got campaign contributions from 46 states. A finance report he filed at the end of October said that 47 percent of the $1,370,667 he had then received in contributions came from people outside Louisiana.
Newspapers found some of the out-of-state contributors and asked why they liked David Duke. The answers tell us a good deal about public feelings these days.
Gerard Nadeau, 74 years old, a retired engineer in Adams, Mass., contributed $50. He told Chris Black of The Boston Globe:
"The Republicans take care of the rich, the Democrats take care of the blacks and David Duke takes care of the whites. No one else is for the whites. I think civil rights have ruined this country. Black people don't want to work. They are taking over all the housing projects. This country is ruined . . ."
John E. Carlson, 61, of Marstons Mills, Mass., retired from the Air Force, said: "This country is becoming a third-rate nation. What kind of country is this when Bush pushes a free-trade bill that takes all the businesses out of the United States?"
Michael DeBeck of New York, who said he was a teacher, told Dennis Hevesi of The New York Times that Mr. Duke was saying "that there is something basically wrong with our system of government, that taxes are getting out of hand, that the laws we have are definitely discriminating. He is willing to address the mounting welfare thing."
Mr. DeBeck objected most vigorously to affirmative action. "White people are not being given a fair shake these days," he said.
The comments show how effectively Mr. Duke touched people's feelings -- feelings that often have little to do with the facts. For example, President Bush is of course not proposing a trade bill to move all businesses out of the United States.
Welfare is another area where resentful emotion overwhelms truth. Mr. Duke was cheered for saying that high welfare payments encourage babies. In Louisiana welfare pays an additional $11 a week per child.
The racial and nativist feelings come through most strikingly. Again, facts are irrelevant. Affirmative action for women and minorities has virtually nothing to do with unemployment or other economic stress felt by white males. But there must be someone to blame for the misery that millions are suffering.
Mr. Duke was only following in the footsteps of respectable politicians. Ronald Reagan told and retold his tale of a "welfare queen." George Bush waved the bloody shirt of "quotas."
But there is something special, something incredible about Americans voting in large numbers for an admirer of Adolf Hitler. Less than 50 years ago Americans died fighting the unmitigated evil of Nazism. To know that many today would overlook a politician's attachment to that evil, or would believe his thin claims to have found redemption, is to know something is deeply wrong in this country.
"We've been sending a message," Mr. Duke said as he conceded defeat in Louisiana. "Next year, you'll have the message being expanded all over the nation."

HEADLINE: Similarities to 1987, and Significant Differences;
Market's Message: No Recovery Yet

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The sudden 120-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday ended a week in which new economic data seemed to provide convincing evidence that the current recession is not behaving like other post-World War II recessions -- and that the much-anticipated economic upturn is still weeks or months away.
Many factors, apart from the economy, undoubtedly contributed to the late-afternoon selloff, among them a bill in Congress that would put a cap on credit card interest rates, a ceiling that would hurt bank profits. But the gloomy economic statistics certainly provided the appropriate backdrop. 
 "After last week's numbers, not even an optimist like myself can talk of a gathering momentum in the economy that is building toward a recovery," said Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. In half a dozen interviews with Wall Street economists, many of whom brief stockbrokers and sales representatives, the message was the same: the economy is dead in the water.
The two most convincing numbers on this count -- made public on Friday morning -- showed that consumer confidence had recently deteriorated and that business inventories had risen. The former means consumers are not in the mood to buy, and the latter that manufacturers had produced more than retailers could sell and, as a result, production would have to be cut back.
The Bush Administration, the Federal Reserve and many economists have been counting on a different course of events. Until recently, Americans appeared to be consuming more than the nation's manufacturers were producing. To meet demand, merchants sold from goods stockpiled in their warehouses, and for seven straight months those stockpiles shrank.
Manufacturers cautiously increased production during the summer and early fall to keep up with what seemed to be more consumer buying. The optimists' great hope was that companies would soon have to pay more overtime and hire more workers. This new income, in turn, would lead to more buying, more production and more hiring, and the economy would grow again. That has been the pattern in most recoveries.
Then, on Friday morning, the Commerce Department reported that inventories had risen sharply in September. Not only was it the first rise in two months, but the biggest since August of last year, a month after the recession started. Most important, much of the increase was among retail stores. The new production had stayed on shelves, unsold, raising the prospect of production cutbacks and future layoffs.
"Businesses were trying to keep a lid on inventories, and the September numbers suggested that they failed," said Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "One or two months ago, we were in a situation that if demand had not faltered, companies would have started to raise employment, because they could not work existing employees more hours. We were very close to a virtuous upturn in the business cycle, and it was nipped in the bud. Now the question is: How long will the stagnation last?"
 
Other Disappointing Data
 The September inventory figures might, of course, be revised upward a month or two from now. Such statistics are often changed as more information trickles in from the thousands of companies surveyed. But the Commerce Department's September inventory rise seemed to be in line with other data announced last week.
The nation's auto makers, for example, reported on Wednesday that car sales in early November had fallen to an annual rate of 5.7 million vehicles, from a rate of more than 6 million in most of September and October. Some auto manufacturers have already announced production cutbacks for the fourth quarter, which means layoffs or less overtime for many workers.
And on Thursday, the Commerce Department reported that retail sales in general, apart from autos, had failed to grow in October, the third consecutive weak month.
"As soon as I saw those inventory numbers, I right away talked to my sales force and said the probability of a slow recovery was disappearing and the risk was increasing of either no growth or a dip back into recession," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, a Wall Street investment house.
 
Drop in Consumer Confidence
 The consumer confidence numbers were also a big blow. The University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research, which polls Americans on job security and buying plans, sent advance word to those who subscribe to the monthly surveys that early-November polls had shown a sharp drop in the confidence index -- to 70.7 from 78.3.
The news spread quickly through Wall Street, confirming an earlier report from the Conference Board, a business organization. The Michigan Institute and the Conference Board produce the most widely followed consumer confidence surveys, and while the Conference Board had reported a sharp drop in its index for October, the Michigan survey had not shown a similarly sharp drop until the early-November numbers became public on Friday. The Michigan numbers ended lingering hopes that the Conference Board's gloomy October survey might have been a fluke.
There was other bad news last week. Unemployment insurance claims rose to their highest level in months. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's index of business activity in the region, an early measure of recent economic activity, produced its first negative reading since February. The oil rig count, a measure of exploration activity, fell to its lowest level in months. And American Airlines announced a multibillion-dollar cutback in capital spending for new planes -- a decision that could hurt the Boeing Company's so-far-robust operations centered in the Seattle area.
Perhaps most important was the stock market, which has been a source of optimism about the economy as it reached record highs in recent months.
"The stock market has been such an important glue for the positive case for recovery, that if the Dow Jones average falls below 2,700, that could itself produce a dip back into recession," said Edward S. Hyman, president of ISI, an investment house. "Until now, the market has kept spirits up."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 19, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day yesterday analyzing declines of more than 100 points in the Dow Jones industrial average on Fridays in the last five years omitted two and listed one erroneously. The average fell 108.35 points on Friday, Oct. 16, 1987, and 140.58 on Friday, Jan. 8, 1988. Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow fell 508, was a Monday.

HEADLINE: Dinkins, in South Africa, Widens Economic Efforts

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Winding up a six-day trip he called "one of the most profound experiences I've ever had," Mayor David N. Dinkins announced today a package of economic programs involving New York City businesses.
 But the trip's last day held a final disappointment for the Mayor as well, as a brief meeting at Jan Smuts Airport with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha was canceled without explanation at the last moment, according to The Associated Press. 
Before coming here the Mayor had said that he wanted to meet officials of the white-minority government to press the cause of change in this country torn for more than four decades by apartheid. He also said he wanted to tell them directly of his support for continued economic sanctions against the country until an interim government was established to draft a constitution for a new, nonracial government.
 But earlier efforts to schedule a meeting also did not pan out, and Mr. Botha and President F. W. de Klerk were both on a trip to Israel and Taiwan until tonight.
 
A Grant From I.B.M.
 The Mayor had set as a goal for his trip the promoting of economic ties between his city and South Africa. And at a news conference before their departure, the New York City officials and business people who accompanied the Mayor announced a series of partnerships, internships, pilot programs and other informal relationships with blacks and white businesses in South Africa, including a $700,000 grant from I.B.M. to bring school principals to New York for training.
 The New York City Housing Authority will provide apartments and jobs to train five South Africans selected by the African National Congress in how to manage public housing and it will raise private funds to fly them over. The city's Health Department will meet with South Africans on problems like AIDS, domestic violence and alcoholism, and the Finance Department will share information on how to collect taxes and make municipal budgets with blacks who have never done so.
 Major South African companies agreed to provide paid leaves of absence for black employees to come to companies in New York for managment training in one program, while the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will help run another. And the Pratt Institute in Brooklyn will provide copies of the new New York City Charter, and the legal arguments leading up to it, to help black local civic organizations in their negotiations on forming new municipal governments.
 
'Links for the Future'
 Mr. Dinkins said the efforts would be "links for the future" of a post-apartheid government.
 He said it was more than appropriate for the city government to help in such a way, though it was already busy confronting problems of its own.
 "Our country has shown an interest in assisting countries around the world, and there is nowhere in the world that has a legalized system of white supremacy," the Mayor said. "It seems to me this is quite appropriate."
 On Saturday night, Mr. Dinkins attended a dinner at the home of the chairman of the African National Congress, Oliver Tambo, who left a hospital bed to play host. The Mayor and his wife Joyce were dressed in African garb and were given a traditional ceremony of homecoming, in which a sheep was slaughtered and its blood daubed on the soles of their feet in a sign of communion with humankind and a leaf placed on their heads in communion with nature.
 Afterward, Mr. Dinkins termed it one of the most moving days of his life, along with his wedding and the births of his children and grandchildren.
 
'Raw Courage'
 Speaking of his long-planned, once-postponed, much-questioned trip, the Mayor said that "the single biggest thing, for me at least, was the raw courage" of black South Africans living under tremendous oppression and poverty.
 "Instead of hopelessness and despair, these people cling to the hope that there will be a new day of freedom," he said.
 The Mayor seems to remain deeply embittered over criticism of the trip, which ranged from questions by civic groups about his efforts to raise money for it by soliticing contributions from private businesses, to his initial decision -- later reversed -- not to pay his own way, to the size of his entourage, to a suggestion by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato that the city would be better off if Mr. Dinkins simply came to South Africa and stayed.
 
Political Impact
 Asked if he thought such criticism would hurt him politically, he responded with equanimity, "If it does, I can't undo it."
 On the other hand, when asked if it might help him politically, he said, "It might, yes, it might."
 The Mayor said he thought it was "not logical, not fair, not proper for people to criticize me for coming to this particular location," when they had not criticized other mayors for taking foreign trips to places important to them.
 Asked if people had done so because he was the city's first black Mayor, he said: "I don't know. You all figure it out."

An article yesterday about Mayor David N. It was not canceled; Mr. Dinkins met with the Foreign Minister for 45 minutes.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Uranium Industry Hurt by Imports

BYLINE: By Matthew L. Wald

 BODY:
SHARPLY increasing its exports of uranium to raise cash, the Soviet Union has dealt a blow to the American uranium industry.
The price of a pound of yellowcake, a lightly processed form of uranium ore, has slumped to $7 from a peak of nearly $12 in the summer of 1990. Low though the price is, experts say it may go still lower, because of the unusual economics of the nuclear fuel business. Normally if a commodity's price falls, customers buy more, and the higher demand helps to stabilize prices. But the reactor construction business is moribund, and no one in the United States is likely to break ground on a new reactor because the cost of fuel is cheap. And the customers, as regulated utilities, are unlikely to make bold purchase decisions, for fear of being judged imprudent by regulators if the market turns against them later. 
 The current $7 price "is well below even the marginal production cost of the most efficient producers in the world," said James C. Cornell, a uranium expert in the Stamford, Conn., office of Nukem, a German trading company.
Crying foul, the domestic uranium producers filed a petition in Washington earlier this month, contending that the Soviets were dumping yellowcake -- selling it for below its fair-market value. The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union joined the protest.
The complaint, filed with the Department of Commerce and the International Trade Commission, says imports of yellowcake from the Soviet Union have increased to more than six million pounds last year, from 190,000 pounds in 1989, and now account for about 17.3 percent of American consumption. In the first eight months of this year, imports of Soviet yellowcake reached more than 5.5 million pounds.
In response to slack demand, sellers are apparently trying a big push. At Northern States Power, based in Minneapolis, which operates three reactors, David P. Austin, superintendent of nuclear fuel procurement, said dealers had come to him "asking how low would the price have to get before we would consider buying material."
According to the dumping complaint, American production of uranium has fallen to 8.9 million pounds, from nearly 44 million pounds in 1980, while employment in the industry has plummeted to 1,333 from 19,000.
At Uranium Resources Inc., a Dallas-based company that has two million pounds of annual capacity, half of it idle, Joe H. Card, the vice president of marketing, said his company was insulated for a time by fixed-price contracts.
"There's no way I can replace those contracts," he said. "I can't compete, even being what I consider to be the lowest-cost producer in the United States." Some companies can outlast his, though, because they make yellowcake as a byproduct of fertilizer production or gold mining.
When the new wave of imports hit, he said, the industry was only beginning to recover from overproduction in the 1970's, brought on by inflated estimates of how many nuclear reactors would be built.
Another major domestic producer is Freeport McMoran Resource of New Orleans, which had no comment beyond the text of the complaint.
The uranium industry has its defenders. On the Senate floor earlier this year, Malcolm Wallop, the Wyoming Republican who is the ranking minority member of the Senate Energy Committee, said it was ironic that utilities buy advertisements promoting nuclear power as an antidote to dependence on foreign oil and are now dependent on foreign uranium.
But a supply crunch of the kind that sporadically hits the oil market seems unlikely in uranium. At Allied-Signal Inc., one of two American companies that converts yellowcake into a liquid for enrichment, Brian H. Grace, manager of marketing, predicted of the exporting countries, "in many cases they'll have to produce it because it's of such impact to their economies."
In many states, the cost of uranium is reflected in customers' monthly bills, through a fuel adjustment clause. But the effect on customers is likely to be small. At Commonwealth Edison, the nation's largest nuclear operator, Gary Wald, a spokesman, said nuclear fuel costs ran about six-tenths of 1 cents per kilowatt-hour, and that yellowcake represented only about one-quarter the cost of the fuel. The rest is in the cost of conversion of yellowcake to a liquid form for further processing, sorting out the uranium isotopes, a process called enrichment, and then fuel fabrication.
So if the cost of yellowcake fell by half, it would come to less than a tenth of a cent per kilowatt-hour. And the drop in the spot market will take time to work its way through to the contract market, which accounts for about 70 percent of sales.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
K Mart Net Climbs 3.4%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., Nov. 18

 BODY:
The K Mart Corporation said today that third-quarter earnings rose a slim 3.4 percent because of the weak economy.
K Mart, The nation's No. 2 retailer behind Sears, Roebuck & Company said net income rose to $109.5 million in the quarter ended Oct. 30 from $105.9 million in the period a year earlier. Earnings per share fell, however, to 50 cents from 53 cents, because the average number of K Mart's shares outstanding rose nearly 10 percent. Sales rose 6.4 percent in the quarter, to $7.97 billion from $7.49 billion. 
 On the New York Stock Exchange, K Mart shares gained 12.5 cents each today, closing at $41.875.

HEADLINE: Czechoslovaks' Big Stock Gamble

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
Some describe it as a daring leap into capitalism, others as a gambling game akin to a parimutuel. In the end, Czechoslovakia's plan to give ordinary citizens stock-buying coupons for big nationalized industries may prove to be a dose of both.
Similar programs have been proposed in Poland and in the newly independent Baltic states. But while the Baltics' privatization plans are only in the discussion stage, and Poland's draft legislation foresees distributing vouchers to mutual funds that would in turn offer shares to the public, only the Czechoslovak system affords ordinary people the chance to pick and choose companies themselves. 
 Western experts advising the Government are alert to the risks, as are Czechoslovak economists. Earlier this month, the Czech regional government ruled -- against strong objections from the national Government -- that it would postpone for at least two months, to the end of January, the deadline for approving companies to participate in the program. The Czech Minister for Privatization, Tomas Jezek, said the delay was necessary to sort out legal problems and difficulties in evaluating the assets of many companies up for sale.
 
'Educating People Quickly'
 "Under the Czechoslovak system, the stakes are higher for the shareholder," said Daniel J. Arbess, a lawyer with White & Case, a New York-based firm, who advises the Czech Government. "The potential for mistakes is higher.
"The scheme requires educating people quickly. The concern is that some may be educated the hard way."
Vaclav Klaus, Prague's Finance Minister and the architect of the Government's economic policy, asserts that there is no alternative to the coupon system. He argues that the public lacks savings to buy the companies and that the Government wants to move fast with privatization.
"We have to be impatient; we have no other choice," Mr. Klaus said last month in a speech to American businessmen visiting Prague.
The plan involves transforming state-held companies into corporations whose shares will be held by a Government property fund. Any Czech or Slovak 18 years or older can put down 1,000 crowns, which is about $35 and roughly a week's average salary, for a voucher that can be exchanged later for company shares.
The investor can pick the companies, and the value of the shares will be determined later under a complex formula involving the estimated value of the company's assets and investors' demand. In most cases, about a third of the company will go up for bidding, with the rest reserved for purchases by management, foreign investors or the Government.
 
Lining Up for Vouchers
 Initially, the Government intends to part with 200 of the roughly 1,700 state enterprises that are required by law to submit privatization plans. The list will be published in January.
Czechoslovaks began lining up at post offices for their vouchers last month. While it is too early to judge demand, Government economists estimate that about half of the eight million eligible citizens will take part, though there have been signs that interest could be dampened by the plan's complexity.
Risk is another reason some citizens are reluctant to take part. Since the program does not offer fresh management or capital, some companies may eventually face bankruptcy, leaving shareholders with worthless pieces of paper.
"Lots of people don't really understand it," said Lubos Drapal, a retired engineer. "But they can get advice from banks or friends, or just gamble."
In a recent survey by the weekly Mlady Svet, people interviewed in Hradec Kralova, east of Prague, confessed puzzlement. Others said they would pick familiar industries like electronics or construction that were sure to take off. Still others despaired of finding any gems. "I don't know any company capable of staying alive and good enough for me to invest in," Jan Kaspar, a 22-year-old electrician, was quoted as saying.
To inform the public better, the Government has begun a promotion campaign. A recent column in the daily Slobodne Slovo urged investors to learn about the investment plans of companies and the size of their outstanding loans, especially to the Soviet Union and to third world countries. Televised English lessons, which have proliferated since Communism collapsed and the nation's focus shifted to the West, feature investment jargon. On a recent night, a teacher went over sentences like "Is every shareholder entitled to a vote?" and "Does every shareholder have a no-loss guarantee?"
Such queries may prove more than academic.
Czechoslovakia, like other former Soviet-bloc countries, suffered decades of Communist mismanagement that left a business landscape cluttered wih the bones of industrial dinosaurs. These large conglomerates typically have few good product divisions, and some are clogged with outmoded equipment producing uncompetitive goods. Companies are often saddled with large debts, sometimes to Soviet customers that cannot repay. Many face huge cleanup bills for decades of environmental neglect.
 
Inside Information
 Local managers have access to inside information. Foreign investors can use armies of accountants or personal ties to former Communist managers to paint a full picture of a company's condition. But for ordinary investors, obtaining information will be a challenge, given the infant status of the financial press in post-Communist Czechoslovakia and no real disclosure laws.
"It reminds me of the years I worked with race horses," said Jan Urban, an editor of Lidove Noviny, a daily, and a former dissident who worked several years at a race track after his anti-Communist activities got him dismissed as a high school teacher. "You don't understand how it works, but you bet on the horses anyway."
Weak disclosure requirements are only one flaw. The system lacks a framework of investor protection.
Mr. Arbess, the American lawyer, said: "In their drive to create a free market, in our view they overlooked an important element, a certain degree of regulatory infrastructure and disclosure rules to give people the information to enable them to make rational choices. What is likely to happen, there will be a free market, but those with inside information, like company managers, willl have a natural advantage."
Already several companies are under investigation, together with foreign investors, for improper reporting of assets and revenues. Mr. Klaus, the Finance Minster, is under pressure to enact a "dirty money" law that would require investors to disclose the sources of their investment capital, a measure he opposes as a brake on privatization.
Lubos Rezabek, a senior adviser in the Czech republic's ministry for economic policy and development, said that all businesses scheduled for privatization were required to publish a prospectus with basic information, like sales, profits and debt, and that no endangered companies would be offered. "We are not putting up candidates for bankruptcy," he said.
But he conceded that disclosure rules were not anchored in the law, but existed simply as Government guidelines. He advised ordinary investors who mistrusted their business acumen to rely on investment bankers or fund managers.
Under the plan, banks or even ordinary citizens can start mutual funds, buying and selling shares with vouchers entrusted to them. One of the few requirements is a capital base of one million crowns, about $35,000, an amount low enough that even some Prague taxi drivers could raise it.
Mr. Rezabek acknowledged the risks. "In a way, it is a lottery," he said, "But on the other hand, what you enter is low, so the loss is not that large."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Czechoslovakia has begun a program to give citizens coupons that can ultimately be used to obtain stock in big nationalized industries. People lined up last month at a post office in Prague to pick up their vouchers. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Testing the Limits Of Pay Restraints

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
A STRIKE and a lockout have partly shut down Caterpillar Inc. in a labor dispute that highlights a new turn in the long-running process of holding down workers' wages so that American industry can be competitive in world markets. Caterpillar has clearly become competitive against almost any rival. So now the question is: Should wage restraint continue, to allow an already-efficient company to get a leg up on competitors, here and abroad?
Put more broadly, the issue is whether corporate America, after a decade of holding down wages, should turn to other methods for improving competitiveness -- better management techniques, for example, or more emphasis on research and product development. Caterpillar says its own advantage has come in part from just such efforts. But holding down labor costs keeps a permanent place in the Caterpillar formula. 
 "A company like Caterpillar, which has not given up an inch of market share, has had to put some limits on how fast incomes can grow to stay competitive," Donald V. Fites, Caterpillar's chairman, said in an interview. "That is essentially what these talks are all about."
Mr. Fites referred to contract talks with the United Automobile Workers, representing 16,000 Caterpillar employees, most of them in Illinois. On Nov. 4, the union struck two plants, trying to pressure the company into compromises. Three days later, the company shut other operations, to pressure the union. And there the matter stands: no formal bargaining and 8,000 people out of work.
The impasse has national significance because the U.A.W. is trying to end the compromises on wages and benefits that characterized the 1980's. It is insisting upon an old union principle: that labor costs should be the same for each company in an industry and, therefore, not a competitive factor requiring concessions. In the 1950's and 1960's, that principle was widely accepted in master industrywide contracts covering steel, rubber and trucking, for example, or in nearly identical contracts signed by each company in an industry.
But these uniform agreements eroded in the 1980's, as foreign competitors that paid their employees lower wages and used less costly labor practices gained strength. In response, numerous American manufacturers won labor concessions to improve their competitive positions. In doing so, they often ended up with contract terms that also differed from their American competitors'.
"Uniform agreements will never return," said Audrey Freedman, a labor economist at the Conference Board. "Competition is so diverse and open-ended that unions are under pressure to consider special situations in every negotiation."
Still, the U.A.W. has resisted the erosion of uniform agreements, on the ground that they are a bulwark against "letting American wages fall to some third world level," as Jerry Lazarowitz, the U.A.W.'s research director, put it.
More than other unions, the U.A.W. has maintained the tradition in its main arena, the Big Three auto makers, although with some slippage. And now it is trying to hold the line among companies in Caterpillar's huge industry, broadly defined as including tractors, agricultural equipment, heavy-construction vehicles and diesel engines.
Having recently signed a three-year labor agreement with Deere & Company, the U.A.W. wants Caterpillar to sign an identical contract, as it has in the past. But Caterpillar is balking, offering less than Deere on several fronts -- health insurance, for example, would no longer be fully paid by Caterpillar, and wage increases for lower-echelon workers would be less than upper-echelon raises.
Among other arguments, Caterpillar says that its main products -- tractors and construction equipment -- are more oriented toward export than Deere's farm machinery, and Caterpillar therefore deserves lower labor costs. The company insists that its labor costs are higher than those of some domestic competitors, among them Cummins Engine and Detroit Diesel, and certainly higher than its main competitor's, Komatsu Inc. of Japan. The U.A.W. challenges the Komatsu claim. Wage rates in general in Japan are slightly higher today than in the United States.
The struggle at Caterpillar is complicated by the overall economic downturn. The company's worldwide sales and those of its competitors have fallen, and Caterpillar is losing money. Rising health-care costs also weigh heavily on the negotiators.
But the main issue remains: Should Caterpillar, having achieved parity with competitors, resist a uniform contract and thus try to get its labor costs lower than Deere's, only to have Deere, in turn, ask for concessions? So far, neither side shows signs of giving quarter on this bedrock issue.

HEADLINE: A.T.& T. Plans to Offer Faster Data Transfer

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
A.T.& T., the world's largest telecommunications company, announced yesterday that it was offering a new form of data transmission nearly 30 times as fast as current methods.
Known as frame relay, the service will substantially speed the transfer of text, numbers and images among banks, hospitals, insurance companies and others whose fast computers have outpaced the capacity of telephone lines to transfer data quickly to remote offices. 
 Frame relay's usefulness is confined to data transfer, so it is expected to appeal mainly to large business and institutional customers. But perhaps frame relay's real significance is as a transition technology to an emerging method known as cell relay, which is 2,770 times as fast as current methods.
Cell relay, available in perhaps three to five years, can carry voice, video and data, and would make possible video-conferencing, conversations and the swift transfer of information simultaneously -- the "multimedia" promise of the Information Age that has been slow in coming.
 
Raising the Transfer Speed
 Current technology, known as X.25, transfers data at no more than 56,000 bits, or binary digits, a second. Frame relay works at 1.54 million bits a second and cell relay at 19.4 million bits.
In a demonstration for reporters, American Telephone and Telegraph Company officials transferred the detailed color image of a living human brain from a hospital computer in Atlanta to the conference room in midtown Manhattan. A kind of X-ray without an X-ray, the magnetic resonance image took less than a second to arrive in New York. If the same image had been transferred by X.25, it would have taken more than an hour.
A.T.& T. plans to make frame relay available early next year. Its principal competitors, MCI and U S Sprint, have already announced frame relay offerings for next year. Also, companies like Wiltel in Tulsa, Okla., and the giant BT, formerly British Telecommunications, are also offering such services.
But A.T.& T. is by far the largest company in the nascent market and by that fact alone will sharply expand frame relay's availability. A.T.& T. has nearly 500 "points of presence," or physical locations where business customers can link to its network.
The Yankee Group, a high-technology consulting firm, estimates that the market for frame-relay service and equipment could total at least $721 million by 1995, but other analysts, like the Gartner Group, say the market may easily exceed $1 billion by then.
By waiting for its long-distance rivals to announce their plans, A.T.& T. forced them to show their hands, while still making a frame-relay offering at the same time as its competitors, said Berge A. Ayvasian, an analyst at the Yankee Group.
In the same news conference yesterday, A.T.& T. announced two other services, a telephone referral service now being tested by Domino's Pizza and an information access service for business executives and others with portable computers.
The referral service, known as Store Locator, would allow a company to offer a single easy-to-remember telephone number nationwide beginning with the prefix 950. Domino's, which is still market-testing the technique, would use it to allow a pizza customer to dial 950-1430 anywhere in the country and get the nearest Domino's store.
The laptop computer service, known as Information Access Service, would allow business executives on the road to dial a toll-free number, 950-1-ATT, and gain access to customized data bases.
Separately, Alex J. Mandl, A.T.& T.'s new chief financial officer and group excecutive, told securities analysts that the company's financial performance in the fourth quarter, ending Dec. 31, was being hurt by the recession. "We are disappointed with the sluggish economy and we are experiencing some effects from that," he said, but was not more specific.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Decline Is Eased By Resurgence in Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell against major foreign currencies yesterday, but traders said the slide was moderated by the rebound in the stock market.
Gold prices rose, with gold for current delivery gaining $1.50 an ounce of the Commodity Exchange in New York to close at $361. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $361.50, also up $1.50 an ounce. 
 Many traders watched developments on the New York Stock Exchange, where the Dow Jones industrial average fell 120 points on Friday amid growing pessimism over the economy. Their anxiety was eased when the Dow steadied and gained of 29.52, closing at 2,972.72.
Robert Ryan, senior trader at the Bank of New York, said traders feared there would be a large decline in the dollar if stock prices had fallen further.
Dan Scherman, senior dealer at the Bank of Boston, added, "People were waiting for the other shoe to drop from Friday."
Mr. Scherman said the dollar saw little pressure after the Bank of France raised interest rates to support the French franc against other European currencies.
The dollar fell to 5.5055 French francs in New York trading, from 5.5365 late on Friday. In late European trading, the dollar fell to 5.4945 French francs, from 5.5985 late on Friday.
In London, the pound rose to $1.7915, from $1.7690 late on Friday. In late New York trading, the pound rose to $1.7900, from $1.7860 late on Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.84 yen, closing at 128.63. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 129.35 yen. In late New York trading, the dollar fetched 129.48 yen, up from 129.40 late on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates on Friday, included: 1.6105 German marks, down from 1.6190; 1.4295 Swiss francs, down from 1.4365; 1,217 Italian lire, down from 1,224.50, and 1.12875 Canadian dollars, down from 1.13005.
Gold rose in London to a late bid of $360.60, from $355.60 an ounce on Friday, and in Zurich, it rose to $360.50, from $355.25 late on Friday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $4.33, closing at $360.56.
Silver rose in London to a late bid of $4.04 an ounce from Friday's $4.01. In New York, silver for current delivery fell to $4.020 an ounce from $4.021.

HEADLINE: Congress Gets Cold Feet On Cap for Credit Cards

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Momentum behind legislation that would put a cap on credit card interest rates dissipated today as lawmakers got cold feet about making a political point that risked damage to the stock market and possibly the economy.
In part, the turnabout resulted from vigorous arm-twisting by the Bush Administration and the banking lobby. But it came primarily from the fear of some Democrats, who at first saw the bill as a good way to embarrass President Bush, that they would be blamed for a fall in the market. 
 A House subcommittee postponed a session on the measure scheduled for this afternoon to give Democratic leaders time to work out a compromise, and some prominent senators who voted for the proposal last week said today that they were looking for a way to reverse course.
 
Legislation Is Expected
 Some sort of legislation may still be adopted this year like a commission study on credit card interest, a deadline for banks to show more competition on these rates or authority for the Federal Reserve to set maximum rates.
But lawmakers said they saw little chance that a measure would be adopted like the 14 percent ceiling on credit card interest that passed the Senate last week. Most banks now charge 18 to 20 percent on unpaid credit card balances.
Some analysts partly attributed Friday's sudden 120-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average to the credit card legislation, and Bush Administration spokesmen encouraged that view over the weekend.
The change of tune in Congress is no doubt a relief to the President, who first broached the idea of lower credit card rates himself and then found himself in the position of potentially having to veto a politically popular measure.
 
Reflections Over Weekend
 Representative Esteban E. Torres, a California Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on Consumer Affairs, which was scheduled to begin drafting credit card legislation this afternoon, explained in an interview why he had decided to postpone the meeting.
"I reflected over the weekend on what happened in the stock market Friday," Mr. Torres said. After discussing the matter today with the House Democratic leaders, he continued, he decided to give "the Administration and my colleagues and the leadership more time to develop an agreement on what we're going to do."
The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, told reporters: "We're going to slow down on credit cards. I don't see any reason why we should rush forward without full consideration."
In the Senate, the Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, one of the 74 senators who voted last week to impose the ceiling on credit card interest, said today that the Senate vote was meant mostly to send a signal to bankers that they should change their ways and voluntarily drop their rates.
"Probably, Congress should not try to involve itself in the marketplace," Mr. Dole said.
 
Bush Brought Up Issue
 The issue first arose last Wednesday when in a political fund-raising speech in New York, President Bush urged banks to lower their credit card rates. According to an Administration official, the idea of the President talking about credit card rates first came from Kenneth M. Duberstein, the White House chief of staff at the end of the Reagan Administration, who is now a political consultant in close contact with the President's top advisers.
The official said John H. Sununu, Mr. Bush's chief of staff, wrote the line into the President's speech at the last minute without consulting with economic advisers.
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican, who was at the fund-raiser and who has long advocated low interest rates, wasted no time and brought the credit card legislation to the Senate floor for a vote Thursday. It was approved, 74 to 19, with only about half an hour of debate.
Senior officials like Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady immediately recognized that a mistake had been made. At a senior staff meeting Friday, Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, said even talk about mandatory credit card rates was foolish, one official said. The White House announced its vigorous opposition to the measure, and over the weekend, Vice President Dan Quayle said in a television interview that the President would probably veto a bill like the one the Senate passed.
This afternoon, the President said he never meant to encourage legislation setting credit card rates but only to say that he favored low rates. At a session with a group of White House correspondents, Mr. Bush went on to say he was pleased that the legislation had been "slowed down considerably."
 
Lobbyists Go to Work
Meantime, banking lobbyists were flooding lawmakers' offices with faxes and telephone calls holding that major banks might fail if the interest they charged on credit cards was fixed at a lower rate. They also said that millions of Americans with less than sterling credit ratings would have their credit cards withdrawn.
Today, seven economists, who headed the Council of Economic Advisers in previous Administrations, wrote Congress saying that a mandatory ceiling on credit card rates "would have severe deleterious consequences for the economy."
In the House, Representative Torres said he was sympathetic to credit card legislation proposed by Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat. Mr. Schumer's bill would delay a cap for a period of time, perhaps a year or 18 months, to give banks time to bring their credit card rates more in line with other interest rates. At the end of the grace period, a blue ribbon commission appointed by the President and Congress would review the situation and determine whether banks were truly competitive in this area. If the commission found they were not competitive, the President would be required to impose a fixed rate on credit card interest.
The final details of the bill were being worked on tonight, and Mr. Torres said it might come before his subcommittee later this week.
 
D'Amato to Press for Bill
 In the Senate, Mr. D'Amato said he would continue to press for his measure. But even if it does not pass, he said in an interview, he has brought the matter of excessive credit card interest to everyone's attention with the result that banks would probably lower rates on their own.
Later, Mr. D'Amato gave a speech on the Senate floor and argued that his proposal had nothing to do with the drop in the stock market. Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who heads the House subcommittee with jurisdiction over the stock market and securities matters, made the same point in a speech on the House floor.
The stock market fell, he said, because of "underlying macroeconomic conditions" and "mechanical factors," and to say the credit card legislation caused it was "like saying 2 plus 2 equals 22."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Neglected Economist Honored by President

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
For years, Friederich von Hayek was a prophet little honored in this land. In a 1944 best seller, "The Road to Serfdom," the Austrian-born economist warned the West that socialism -- whether German Nazism, Soviet Communism or the "gentler and kinder" British brand -- would inevitably lead to poverty and loss of liberty.
An ardent opponent of most government intervention in the economy, Mr. von Hayek, though respected for early contributions to monetary theory, was all but ignored by other economists for 30 years after World War II as Keynesian thought became a dominant intellectual force, the European social democracies boomed and the Soviet Union and other centrally planned economies scored impressive feats of industrialization. Even after he won the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1974, Mr. von Hayek's following in the United States consisted mostly of a small band of monetary economists and libertarians. 
 With the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, all that has changed. Mr. von Hayek's views on the economic inadequacies and political ills of central planning are now those of the mainstream. Yesterday, President Bush awarded the 92-year old Mr. von Hayek, a British citizen, the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian honor.
"More than almost anyone else in the 20th century, this guy was vindicated by the events in Eastern Europe," said Austin Furse, director of policy planning at the White House. Mr. von Hayek has a wide following among Eastern European economic reformers, he noted, including Vaclav Klaus, the Finance Minister of Czechoslovakia.
Once described as "articulate, austere and infinitely urbane," Mr. von Hayek was born in 1899 into a Viennese family of academics and civil servants. He eventually left for the London School of Economics, where he lectured throughout the 1930's and 40's. When Keynesian thought triumphed and his own reputation as an economist went into eclipse, Mr. von Hayek turned to philosophy and psychology, which he first taught at the University of Chicago, then in Salzburg, Austria, and finally in Freiburg, Germany.
Conservatives have been urging President Bush, who picks the Medal of Freedom winners himself, to honor Mr. von Hayek. The Nobel laureate's son, a British physician, was on hand at the ceremony yesteray to accept the medal on behalf of his father, who lives in Freiburg and has been ill for several years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Friedrich August von Hayek, Medal of Freedom (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Mastercard Post To Experienced Banker

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Mastercard International Inc. said yesterday that it had named William T. Sandalls, vice chairman and chief financial officer of Bay Banks Inc., Boston, to the new position of chief operating officer.
The company, which said that Mr. Sandalls would join Mastercard in December, added that he would have responsibility for the company's global payment system and would report directly to Alex W. Hart, the company's president and chief executive. 
 At Bay Banks, Mr. Sandalls, who is 47, has worked in a variety of management assignments, including posts in data processing, operations and employee benefits. He also directed the development of the company's business strategies in electronic banking, interstate banking and mergers and acquisitions. Mr. Sandalls, who is also a certified public accountant, went to Bay Banks in 1974 after working with Arthur Andersen & Company. He has been a member of the board of Mastercard since 1988.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Sandalls expressed concern that the measure approved by the Senate to limit credit card interest rates to 14 percent would bring a sharp reduction in the availability of credit cards, which could disrupt the economy.
"From my experience as a banker, I think that having freely competitive markets is important, and to put arbitrary constraints on markets -- however politically appealing that might be -- in the long run does a great disservice to consumers," he said. "I think there is a problem with this kind of last-minute legislative effort to score political points."
On his new duties at Mastercard, Mr. Sandalls said he planned to work on the company's plans to develop a debit card and to help Mastercard, which is second behind Visa in the number of card holders. "I want to work to make Mastercard the preferred method of payment," he added. "Mastercard is doing well and growing very vigorously, particularly internationally. I want to work to continue that."
Mr. Sandalls is a graduate of Yale University and received an M.B.A. from the Harvard Business School. He served as a naval officer from 1966 to 1970 with assignments in Vietnam and Washington. Mr. Sandalls is also chairman of Cirrus Syetem Inc., the international electronic banking network. He is married and has a son and a daughter.
