HEADLINE: Oil Industry Lashes Out at Restrictions

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The oil industry has begun to talk tough on the environment, after recent setbacks, for the first time since the Exxon Valdez accident almost three years ago.
About 2,000 industry executives, here at the annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute, lamented that the Senate recently voted not to consider an energy bill that would have opened the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration. Worse, they said, 11 Eastern states are rushing to join California in a new system of automobile pollution control, a program that the oil companies think will mean strict gasoline specifications. And they complained about the Clean Air Act of 1990, which mandates cleaner gasoline, and about laws intended to protect underground water supplies.
 
'Inefficient Diversions'
 Charles DiBona, the president of the institute, who has recently taken to referring to some new environmental regulations as "stupid," said in a speech to the convention, "There may have been times in the past when U.S. economic supremacy allowed this country to indulge in costly, inefficient diversions, but there won't be such times in the highly competitive world that lies ahead."
He added: "Inefficient regulation does hurt U.S. industries and working people. Plants will be driven elsewhere. Good jobs will be harder to come by."
The oil companies have long complained about the cost of environmental regulations, but most complaints were muted in the period of environmental concern after the grounding of the Exxon Valdez, the mass demonstrations on Earth Day and the passage last year of amibitious amendments to the Clean Air Act. That period of reticence appears to be over.
The institute's departing chairman, Allen E. Murray, chairman of the Mobil Corporation, said he thought the public mood was changing.
"There is no doubt that the environment is the issue of the decade, but people are beginning to realize that there will be trade-offs," he said at a news conference, citing the state of the economy. "I sense that we'll see a little bit of judgment. I hope it doesn't take harder economic times to do it."
The institute's new chairman, C. J. Silas, chairman and chief executive of the Phillips Petroleum Company, complained of "the amount of money we're spending to take care of emotional problems and not physical problems."
The attack on environmental initiatives was carried on by Margaret Thatcher, the former Prime Minister of Britain, who was the main speaker today. Mrs. Thatcher, who was once a research chemist, said oil company executives were as concerned as environmentalists about providing a clean environment for their children. But, she said, the country should "have solutions that are sound scientifically, and some of the ones proposed are not."
 
Security Issues Fade
 Another remarkable shift is the virtual end of talk about energy security, so prominent a year ago when Iraq was occupying Kuwait and the Soviet Union was still a world power.
"Environmental issues are replacing security issues in driving the oil industry," said Thomas G. Burns, manager of economics at the corporate planning and analysis department of the Chevron Corporation.
Adding to the gloom is the industry's lackluster financial performance. A survey released by the institute today said the net income of a group of 20 oil companies had fallen 51 percent in the third quarter, to $2.2 billion, from $4.5 billion last year.
But income last year was swollen by the increase in crude oil prices after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. For the first nine months of this year, net income was $11 billion, down 16 percent from $13.1 billion a year earlier. But oil did better than the rest of the economy over the nine-month period; a comparison group of 100 non-oil companies saw a 50.1 percent drop in income in that period, the survey found.
 
Low Returns
 But the industry's recent financial track record is poor. Arthur L. Smith, the chairman of John S. Herrold Inc., a consulting firm that evaluates oil properties, said the rate of return for oil companies, which was running at 20 percent at the beginning of the decade, was 2 percent last year.
"The numbers suggest that oil companies are in business for the public good, because no economic value has been created," he said.
A crucial question for oil companies is whether to invest in their refineries to produce cleaner gasoline that the Clean Air Act will require in years to come. The market for gasoline has been flat for years, and could decline if natural gas, electricity or methanol came into wide use. On the other hand, stricter environmental regulations could protect domestic refiners from competition.
"The international gasoline market is on the verge of a profound change," said Edward N. Krapels, president of Energy Security Analysis Inc., a consulting firm in Washington. The United States, with many different gasoline specifications, would turn into a "boutique market." It is not clear how many foreign refineries that now export to this country would make the investments to be able to continue to do so, he said.

HEADLINE: Stocks Up, Relieving Some Fear

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
The stock market steadied itself yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average regaining a quarter of the ground it lost in Friday's drubbing. Action on the New York Stock Exchange was hectic again, with volume surpassing even the heavy trading of the previous session.
After plummeting 120.31 points on Friday, its worst one-day loss in two years, the Dow regained 29.52 points yesterday, to 2,972.72. But much of the buying was concentrated in blue-chip issues; more Big Board stocks showed losses than gains. 
 Friday's plunge raised investor concerns about further losses, but Robert C. Walberg, an equity analyst with MMS International, said sanity had returned to the market. "It appears investors have learned from the 1987 and 1989 crashes, which afterward offered good buying opportunities," he said.
But investors' fears about the economy and its effect on corporate profits was still apparent, analysts said, in the focus on blue chips.
 
241.9 Million Shares Traded
 One trader noted that even with the market's sharp decline last week, interest rates are so low that stocks offer attractive returns in comparison.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 241.9 million shares, up from 239.3 million on Friday. Declining issues outnumbered those that rose by 989 to 723.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, another gauge of blue-chip activity, was up 2.62, to 385.24, while the New York Stock Exchange composite rose 1.11, to 213.03.
Bank stocks recovered some of their losses and closed mixed, with Banc One, which had suffered recently, up 1 7/8, to 44 7/8. Chase Manhattan rose 3/4, to 17 5/8, and Wells Fargo jumped 2 3/8, to 62. The prospect that Congress might approve a cap on credit card interest rates, one factor in the market's unraveling, appeared less likely. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said on Sunday that the measure would "never see the light of day."
The American Stock Exchange composite fell 1.44, to 379.47, while the Nasdaq composite rose 3.44, to 534.73, and the Russell 2,000 index, a measure of small-stock activity, was off a slight 0.07, to 181.65.
A fair amount of Friday's decline was options-related, Mr. Walberg said, and it may have made some issues more attractive.
"The market is back to its 200-day moving average," he said, "and to move higher it has to get above 2,975 on the Dow. Otherwise, technical selling will keep downward pressure on the market."
Technical portfolio managers place a great deal of emphasis on the 200-day moving average as an indicator of long-term trends.
Interest in stocks was not limited to certain sectors yesterday. Furthermore, investment firms reiterated buy recommendations on some stocks that had been beaten up on Friday. One sector that performed well was computers, including I.B.M., Apple Computer and Digital Equipment.
While drug stocks were up, biotechnology issues generally remained under pressure. Mr. Walberg said it might take a while for that sector to regain the trust of investors.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said it had recorded 13 program trades yesterday, a normal amount for the first trading day after the expiration of index futures and options contracts. Collectively, the nine "buy" and four "sell" programs lifted the Dow by 10.62 points.
Birinyi also noted a fair amount of block buying, a signal that large professional investors were in the market, along with retail shopping by smaller investors in select issues. But it was the Mercks, I.B.M.'s, G.E.'s, Coca-Colas and Exxons that attracted the attention of buyers.
Ricky Harrington, director of equity investments for Marion Bass Securities, said the market was driven mostly by technical factors yesterday. He also noted that the overseas markets did not collapse before American trading began.
These factors were instrumental in yesterday's move higher, he said. "I think this is a technical recovery," he said, "and we could be headed lower at any time, maybe in the next few days, maybe in the next few weeks. A psychological change took place in the market last week and signals the start of a down trend."
Stocks with high price-earnings ratios are the most vulnerable, Mr. Harrington said, while stocks that have been out of favor, like utilities, will attract investors. He said he thought issues that had done well in the last few months were likely to be most vulnerable.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Talk of capping credit card interest rates turned an unwelcomed spotlight on one of the banking industry's richest businesses at a time when it can least afford the attention. [Page A1.]
There was less momentum behind legislation that would cap interest rates on credit cards as lawmakers got cold feet about making a political point that risked damage to the stock market and possibly the economy. [D9.]
President Bush said he believed the American economy was basically sound and that he planned no major new programs to stimulate growth, but he acknowledged that he was having trouble convincing the public that his policies were adequate. [A1.]
The oil industry has begun to talk tough on the environment, after recent setbacks, for the first time since the Exxon Valdez accident almost three years ago. [D1.]
 
Markets
Stock prices recovered, and the Dow posted a gain of 29.52 points, to close at 2,972.72. Action on the Big Board was hectic, with volume surpassing even the heavy trading of the previous session. Nearly 242 million shares changed hands. [D1.]
Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell as the stock market returned to stability, but credit market participants said the drop was of minimal significance. [D16.]
The dollar fell against most foreign currencies, but traders said the slide was moderated by the stock market rebound. [D17.]
Soybean futures prices surged, leading the grain markets mostly higher amid revived hopes for a Soviet food-aid package and signs of stronger export sales. [D17.]
 
International
Can there still be such a thing as duty-free shopping in a new Europe in which there will no longer be internal borders at which customs duties must be paid? Yes, it is possible. But only until 1999. [D1.]
Czechoslovakia plans to give ordinary citizens stock-buying coupons for big nationalized industries. [D5.]
Western nations should grant debt assistance to the Soviet nation as it tries to weather the winter and reorder its economy, said Robert Strauss, the United States Ambassador. [A14.]
 
Companies
Salomon Brothers is dismissing as many as 135 professional employees, Wall Street executives said. Also, some 15 managing directors are expected to resign by the end of the year. [D1.]
A handful of wine producers have made organic wines since the early 1980's, but now their ranks have been joined by wineries like Gallo, Fetzer, Sutter Home and Buena Vista. [D1.]
A.T.&T. is offering a new form of data transmission nearly 30 times as fast as current methods. The service will speed the transfer of text, numbers and images among banks, hospitals and insurance companies. [D2.]
Midway Airlines asked a Federal judge to force Northwest Airlines to proceed with a buyout that would have kept grounded Midway in the air. [D4.]
 
Today's Columns
The labor dispute at Caterpillar highlights a new turn in the process of holding down workers' wages so that American industry can be competitive in world markets. Louis Uchitelle: Business Scene. [D2.]
By increasing its exports of uranium to raise cash, the Soviet Union has dealt a blow to the American uranium industry. Market Place. [D10.]
The first company to advertise condoms on network television was a surprise. Carter-Wallace showed a commercial for its Trojan Extra Strength brand; the maker of Ramses and Sheik condoms had been expected to be first. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D19.]

HEADLINE: Banks Uneasy at Focus on Credit Cards

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The debate in Congress that led to consideration of a cap on credit card interest rates subsided yesterday, but it turned an unwelcome spotlight on one of the banking industry's richest businesses at a time when the industry can least afford the attention.
As many of the nation's largest banks struggle with losses from commercial real estate loans, the credit card business was one of the industry's few bright spots. It accounted for a quarter of all bank profits and generated returns that have been double the amount banks strive to earn on their loans. 
 Yesterday on Capitol Hill, some Democrats got cold feet. After banks cautioned that cards might be revoked and the economy severely hurt, the Democrats backed away, fearing that an interest rate limit would expose them to blame for various economic ills. [Page D9.]
But as the threat of a Federal interest rate limit recedes, bankers face growing competition in the credit card industry from a range of companies that know a good deal when they see it: American Telephone and Telegraph, Sears, Roebuck and Ford.
What is more, in the midst of recession, income from credit cards is drifting down as more customers pay off their monthly balances and ease up on their buying on credit.
All of those factors are eroding credit card profit margins for banks. Now, many bankers look wistfully at 1989, when net profits from credit cards peaked at $4.11 billion, according to the Nilson Report, a California newsletter that covers the credit card industry, Those profits amounted to more than 26 percent of bank profits of $15.73 billion.
Last year, bank credit card profits slipped to $4 billion. This year, a further decline is expected, to $3.5 billion, according to the Nilson Report.
For many of the large banks that dominate the credit card industry, like Citibank and the Chase Manhattan Bank, profits have come from the widespread issuance of cards and the banks' ability to charge a high interest rate and annual fees on good customers that cover the losses on bad customers. But now that the 19.8 percent interest rate, which is widespread among large banks, has come under attack, bankers are wondering if they can continue with a business strategy that has part of their customer base subsidizing the rest.
A movement is under way that would provide lower interest rates for a bank's better customers, though the availability of the cards is spotty.
The mass mailings of cards over the last decade helped put 220 million Visa and Mastercards into three-fourths of American households. Those cards, combined with the nearly 1.1 billion credit cards issued by merchants, American Express and the Sears Discover card, are used to buy more than $400 billion of goods and services annually.
Visa and Mastercard are owned by the nearly 6,000 banks that issue their credit cards. The card companies help arrange for merchants to accept the cards, handle advertising and deal with communications between banks and merchants.
Data compiled by the Nilson Report show that the banks' profit margins, while healthy, are not nearly so wide as suggested by the difference between the 19.8 percent rate charged on many cards and the rates of less than 5 percent now offered by banks to savers on certificates of deposit and other savings accounts.
 
Less Than 19.8% Collected
 Effectively, the rate collected by banks is far less than the 19.8 percent because most large banks do not charge interest on the credit card bills that are paid in full. In fact, for about a third of all credit card customers who routinely use their cards for convenience, not credit, banks are in effect providing interest-free loans, since the banks make payments to merchants several weeks before the bank customer pays the credit card bill.
That means the effective rate collected by banks is only 15.44 percent, according to the Nilson Report. When combined with fees charged consumers and merchants and other income from collection of bad debts and sale of mailing lists, banks in the Visa and Mastercard business collect funds estimated at 20.18 percent of their loans outstanding.
Costs begin with the interest banks pay for money to finance their card business, estimated by Nilson at 7.41 percent of card loans outstanding. Costs increase by an additional 4.2 percent of loans from various operating expenses like data processing, collection of bad debts, postage, advertising and other administrative costs, with 4.94 percent absorbed by the cost of bad loans.
Thus, total costs equal 16.77 percent of loans outstanding. Subtracted from income of 20.18 percent, it produces a pretax profit margin of 3.44 percent, or 2.06 percent after taxes.
Although the 2 percent profit margin might seem slender relative to the 19.8 percent interest charged by many banks, it is a profit margin that pleases banks. The best-run banks in the country earn a profit of about 1 percent on every dollar of loans and other assets.
Many bankers and analysts say that if they allowed rates to fall, one way to do it is to wring more profit from customers who pay off their balances monthly.
Those customers, said Alex W. Hart, president of Mastercard International, are essentially break-even customers for banks. They do not account for any of the losses from bad loans that have climbed to nearly 5 percent of loans outstanding this year from 3.83 pecent last year, but neither do they provide any interest income, which accounts for more than three-fourths of all credit card revenue.
Moshe Ohrenbuch, a research analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, a securities firm, said that banks "will need to charge differently so that customers who do not pay interest will pay a larger share of the cost of the card."
 
Higher Fees Possible
 He said banks might reduce their reliance on interest income by charging higher fees to merchants who accept cards or by reducing the time period when banks are in effect making an interest-free loan to consumers to 10 or 15 days from the existing 25 days.
To absorb the cost of defaulted credit card loans, many banks already make judgments about the riskiness of their customers.
"Basically, you charge a higher rate for more risky customers and lower rates for those who are not so risky," said Edwin P. Hoffman, president of Household International. At Household, one of the 10 largest issuers of credit cards in the country, rates range from 21 percent to 15.8 percent.

HEADLINE: THE HOSTAGE DRAMA;
2 Western Hostages Freed in Lebanon

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The Anglican envoy, Terry Waite, and an American educator, Thomas M. Sutherland, were released by their Shiite Muslim captors in Lebanon today, amid signs that the remaining Western hostages may be freed soon.
The release today of two of the longest-held hostages came after intense negotiations by the United Nations that have led to the freeing of four other Western hostages since August. It represents a dramatic leap toward ending the nearly eight-year hostage ordeal. 
 At an impromptu, chaotic appearance before reporters in Damascus after the release to Syrian officials, Mr. Waite said his captors had told him just before his release that they would free two American hostages, Joseph J. Cicippio and Alann Steen, in the next five days and the other American, Terry A. Anderson, the longest-held hostage, by the end of the month. [Excerpts from news conference, page A16.]
 
A Captor's Apology
 "This afternoon, when we were sitting together in our cell, chained to the wall as we have been chained to the wall for the last five years and, in some cases of Tom and others, for seven years -- 23 hours and 50 minutes a day -- one of our captors came in and told us that Tom and myself would be freed this evening," said the 52-year-old Mr. Waite, looking thinner, his hair grayer, than when he was abducted in January 1987 during a mediation effort on behalf of other hostages.
"He also said to me: 'We apologize for having captured you. We recognize that now this was a wrong thing to do, that holding hostages achieves no useful, constructive purpose,' " Mr. Waite said.
Mr. Waite said he did not know when two other Western hostages -- Heinrich Strubig and Thomas Kemptner, German relief workers -- would be set free. He did not mention Alberto Molinari, an Italian businessman who has been missing since 1985. Some Lebanese security officials have said they believe he is dead.
 
Remarks by U.N. Leader
 In brief remarks to reporters at the United Nations this morning, the usually cautious Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said that both the groups holding the hostages and the Iranian Government "some time ago" had "offered" to release all of the hostages by Christmas.
The next move may be up to Israel, which has freed a number of Arab prisoners since August as part of the negotiations, but is still holding Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, an Islamic fundamentalist leader captured by Israeli commandos in southern Lebanon in 1989 and its most valuable bargaining chip.
Israel said tonight that it would not release any more of the 300 Arab prisoners in its hands until it receives word about the fate of an Israeli Air Force navigator who was shot down over Lebanon in 1986.
 
Roles of Syria and Iran
 The quickening pace of hostage releases also reflects the pivotal roles played by both Syria and Iran, which have much to gain by a resolution of the thorny issue. Teheran, which has considerable influence over the Shiite Muslim groups holding the hostages, is eager to improve its political standing in the West and rebuild its economy with extensive Western help. Syria, the main power broker in Lebanon and a player in the Middle East peace talks, has tried to move closer to the West with the breakup of the Soviet Union.
Both Mr. Waite, who had been held since January 1987, and Mr. Sutherland, who was taken captive in June 1985, appeared in both good health and good spirits as they addressed reporters under a portrait of President Hafez al-Assad of Syria. But their upbeat remarks also captured some of the pain they endured during their difficult captivity, as well as the changing sentiment of their captors about the value of keeping hostages.
 
'A Time of Joy'
 The White House press spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, described the release today as "a time of joy," and praised the United Nations and the governments of Iran, Syria and Lebanon for their assistance. But he also called for the release of the remaining hostages, adding, "Our joy is mixed, however, with deep concern over those who remain in captivity."
President Bush has repeatedly said he would not move to improve relations with Teheran until all American hostages are released. And even then, Iran's continuing support for international terrorism remains an obstacle in building the relationship, Bush Administration officials said today.
The two countries also continue to haggle in a special tribunal in The Hague over claims stemming from the seizure of the American Embassy in Teheran in 1979. The most nettlesome are Teheran's compensation claims for United States military equipment it says it paid for before the 1979 revolution but never received and claims of dual nationals against Iran.
"People are thinking about what to do, but it would be wrong to leap to the conclusion that we are about to restore relations or anything like that," said one senior Administration official. "But there may be some small steps in that direction once all Americans are freed and if the Iranians make some statement disavowing terrorism."
 
Major Is 'Delighted'
 In London today, Prime Minister John Major said he was "absolutely delighted" by the hostage release, and stressed that it was accomplished with "no backstage deals."
The release of Mr. Waite, the last British hostage, removes the most serious obstacle for an improvement in British-Iranian relations. Britain is now in a position to upgrade its diplomatic representation in Iran by sending an ambassador to its embassy in Iran, and to offer Iran much-needed financial help in the form of loans, credits, joint ventures and other commercial deals.
In his remarks today, Mr. Sutherland, a 60-year-old former Dean of Agriculture at the American University of Beirut, thanked the United Nations, Syria, Iran and Israel for their efforts on behalf of the detainees.
 
Israeli Role in Lebanon
 But in a thinly-veiled criticism of Israel's occupation of southern Lebanon, Mr. Waite described how he and the other captives had been living under constant shelling in the last year.
"All of us, all hostages, would plead with those who are holding the people of South Lebanon, innocent people being held as hostages, to release them soon, to put an end to this problem, to put an end to terrorism, and to find peaceful, humane and civilized ways of resolving the very complex problems that face the people of the Middle East," said Mr. Waite, special envoy for the Archbishop of Canterbury who over the years had successfully won the freedom of detainees in Iran, Libya and Lebanon before he himself was seized while trying to free American captives in Lebanon.
Mr. Perez de Cuellar had confided to colleagues last week that he expected all of the remaining hostages to be released together before the end of the month. United Nations officials said the release today, which they had known about for more than a week, was somewhat surprising. Still, the officials added, he is confident that the last hostage will be freed before he leaves office at the end of the year.
 
Condition of Anderson
 Mr. Sutherland offered fresh information on the condition of Mr. Anderson, who was chief Middle East correspondent for the Associated Press when he was abducted in March 1985. Mr. Sutherland, who said he spent most of his captivity with Mr. Anderson, said, "We left Terry Anderson about three or four hours ago in Lebanon and he is no longer chained to the wall, thank God, but he is still in a room that has very little fresh air and no daylight whatsoever."
Still, Mr. Sutherland said, "He is in very good health right now; he is in very good spirits," adding that the American journalist has written poetry during captivity, which he hopes to publish eventually.
Mr. Anderson is considered the captors' most valuable bargaining chip, both because of the length of time he has spent in captivity and the extensive publicity his plight has been given over the years, and the Bush Administration has assumed that he will be among the last to be released.
Both freed hostages were in such high spirits that they used their first public statements to crack jokes about each other.
"All I can say, though, about the English -- they take a hell of a long time to get things done," said Mr. Sutherland of Mr. Waite's attempts to free him. "He came to get me out of there about five years ago and it has taken him five years to get me out."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terry Waite, left, and Thomas Sutherland, right, at a news conference yesterday in Damascus, Syria, after they were freed in Lebanon. With them was Josef Shakkour, Syrian Assistant Foreign Minister. (Associated Press) (pg. A1)
 
Photos of Terry A. Anderson, Joseph James Cipippio, Alann Steen and Mohammed Ali Hamadi (pg. A16)
 
Charts: "The Pieces of the Puzzle"
 
Westerners Missing in Lebanon
 
Americans
 Terry A. Anderson: The chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, 44, has been missing since March 16, 1985. He is being held by Islamic Holy War.
 Joseph James Cicippio: The acting controller of the American University of Beirut, 61, has been missing since Sept. 12, 1986. He is held by the Revolutionary Justice Organization.
 Alann Steen: A journalism instructor at Beirut University College, 52, has been missing since Jan. 24, 1987. He is held by Islamic Holy War for the Liberation of Palestine.
 
Other
 Alberto Molinari: The 72-year-old Italian businessman, who lived in Beirut, has been missing since Sept. 11, 1985. His captors are unknown. Some Lebanese security officials have said that he is dead.
 Heinrich Strubig and Thomas Kemptner: The two German relief workers, 50 years old and 30, have been missing since May 16, 1989. Their captors are unknown.
 
Arab Prisoners
 
Held in Southern Lebanon
 About 300 Arabs are held either by Israel or its client militia in southern Lebanon, the South Lebanon Army. Most are Lebanese, but some are Palestinians. Most of these people are labeled terrorist by Israel. But some are clearly being held, or were kidnapped, as potential bargaining chips.
 Key among them is Sheik Abdel Karim Obeid, a Shiite clergyman and a leader of the pro-Iranian Party of God whom Israeli commandos kidnapped in 1989 from his home in southern Lebanon.
 Shiite groups say that the Israelis must release Sheik Obeid if there is to be any progress in the comprehensive hostage negotiations. The Israelis he will be the last to go free.
 Since early August, 66 prisoners have been released.
 
Held in Germany
 Two Shiite Muslim brothers, Mohammed Ali Hamadi and Abbas Hamadi, are imprisoned in Germany for hijacking, kidnapping and murder.
 Hostage holders in Lebanon have occasionally warned that freedom for the two German hostages hinges on the Hamadi brothers going free.
 Bonn says it will make no deals, but there have been reports quoting unnamed "pro-Iranian sources" that a swap agreement has been reached.
 
Missing Israelis in Lebanon
 Capt. Ron Arad, whose plane was shot down over Lebanon in 1986, is the only missing serviceman believed to be alive. Three others, First Sgt. Zvi Feldman, Sgt. Zachary Baumel and Cpl. Yehuda Katz, were in a tank crew battling Syrian forces in the Bekka Valley of eastern Lebanon early in Israel's invasion of Lebanon in 1982. Publicly, Israeli officials insist in learning what happened to them. Privately, they acknowledge these men are almost certainly dead.
 
Other Questions
 When Islamic Holy War released the British journalist John McCarthy in August, it demanded that all its "freedom fighters" be freed, in Israel and in Europe. Presumably, this means only the 300 being held in Southern Lebanon and not every Palestinian held in Israeli prisons since the start of the intifada. The same applies for Europe. It is not known who, other than the Hamadis, might meet this definition in other countries.
 
Iran's Claims
 
Missing Iranians in Lebanon
 Four Iranians have been missing in Lebanon since 1982 after being captured at a checkpoint of the Christian Lebanese Forces.
Iran insists the four are alive, but diplomats in Beirut have been quoted as saying that they are probably long dead. A leader of the Christian militia, Samir Geagea, has said that they were killed soon after being stopped, but he has not produced their remains.
 
Iranian Assets
 The Iran-United States Claims Tribunal in The Hague was set up under the Algiers accords that resolved the Teheran hostage crisis in 1981. Its purpose is to settle claims between the two governments and claims of citizens of each country against the other country's government. Work of the tribunal continues slowly.
 The most contentious issue involves claims filed against Iran by people who have dual citizenship, in both Iran and the United States. Iran maintains that Iranian citizens should not be allowed to pursue claims against Iran, even though they might also be United States citizens.
 Another major category of pending cases involves military equipment sold to Iran before the fall of the Shah. Iran says it paid for much of this equipment but never received it. (pg. A16)

HEADLINE: U.S. Starts to Return Haitians Who Fled Nation After Coup

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 18

 BODY:
With more than 1,200 Haitian boat people being held aboard United States Coast Guard cutters, the State Department announced today that it was starting to send them back, resuming a repatriation program suspended since a violent coup overthrew Haiti's elected Government on Sept. 30.
The decision came after a weekend in which Coast Guard ships picked up hundreds of new refugees from small boats off northern Haiti, bringing the total number of Haitians in United States custody to nearly 1,800. In addition to those still at sea, officials said, about 500 refugees are being temporarily housed at the United States' military base at Guantanamo, Cuba.
 
'A Very Tough Thing'
 Officials said the decision to resume forcible repatriation of the Haitians, which quickly drew attacks from human rights groups, was made out of exasperation after weekend Voice of America broadcasts to Haiti urging listeners not to set out for United States shores failed to stem the flow of would-be refugees. 
 The State Department officials said that the first of seven Coast Guard cutters returning Haitians would land in Port-au-Prince today.
"This is obviously a very tough thing to deal with," said an official who asked not to be identified. He said that the billeting of the boat people on Coast Guard vessels had been conceived as an interim solution.
"Our objective was to try and take care of people leaving Haiti without sending a signal to others on the island that it is O.K. for them to try to come to the United States," he said.
In recent days, the official added, the United States had persuaded several other countries in the region, including Belize, Venezuela, Trinidad and Honduras, to accept some of the boat people picked up by the Coast Guard.
 
Deaths at Sea Feared
 "We regret that it now appears that the safe-haven plan will not be sufficient to deal with the magnitude of the problem," said a statement by the State Department announcing the decision to resume repatriations. "We fear that any action by the United States to bring large numbers of Haitians without claim to asylum to the United States would bring a massive outflow resulting in large numbers of deaths on the high seas."
Coast Guard officials announced today that seven of the recently intercepted Haitian boats carried more than 100 people. One seized on Nov. 14 was a 40-foot vessel of questionable seaworthiness with 238 people aboard, they added.
Officials estimate that as many as half of those who undertake the ocean voyage to the United States die at sea.
A United States official said that the refugees now in Guantanamo would most likely be distributed among the countries that had agreed to receive limited numbers of Haitian boat people.
Those living aboard United States ships, the official said, will be interviewed in accordance with a 10-year-old agreement with Haiti. Those who do not meet standards for admission to the United States, where they can petition for political asylum, will be returned to Haiti beginning today, he said.
"Most of these people do not have a legitimate fear of persecution," the official said, adding that so far about 50 had been allowed into the United States to apply for asylum. "Those who do will be allowed into the United States."
The official said that economic conditions were the main reason most of the refugees left Haiti.
While officials in Washington sought to play down the risk faced by returning Haitians, the repatriation announcement immediately drew an angry reaction from some members of Congress and immigration rights groups, who noted the continuing climate of violence in Haiti since the overthrow of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
"This would not have happened if the refugees were Europeans," said Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, who said he had been scheduled to visit Guantanamo on Sunday to inspect refugee conditions until the trip was suddenly canceled. "It's the difference, I guess, between exporting oil and bananas."
 
'How Can We Justify It?'
 Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, also sharply criticized the decision to return to the repatriation policy that was in effect before the coup. "Returning Vietnamese, Russian Jews, Cubans, Nicaraguans and others back to the repressive countries from which they were fleeing would have been unthinkable," he said in a statement. "How can we justify it for Haitians?"
Jocelyn McCalla, director of the National Coalition for Haitian Refugees, a New York-based group, said, "What is most distressing is that the United States has clearly not extended recognition to the military junta in Port-au-Prince and is not even talking to them."
"There are clearly a good number of people who go back and suffer persecution or go into hiding," Mr. McCalla said, rebutting United States claims that returned refugees were unlikely to face punishment in Haiti.
Another group, the Lawyers Commitee for Human Rights, said it was contemplating legal action to bar future repatriations. "The cursory interviews by immigration officials are incapable of determining which individuals merit protection," said Arthur C. Helton, a lawyer with the group, commenting on the screening of refugees at sea.
Some diplomats suggested that in addition to the growing burden on the Coast Guard's resources, the decision to begin repatriating Haitians grew out of a belief that progress was near in efforts led by the Organization of American States to restore Haiti's elected Government.
"Haiti is a democracy, even if it is a suspended democracy right now," one official said. "The O.A.S. mission there just came out with good results and we hope to see negotiations begin this week for a return to constitutional order."

HEADLINE: DESPITE WAGE TAX, CONNECTICUT FACES GAP, WEICKER SAYS

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Less than three months after the largest tax increase in state history and the introduction of a wage tax for the first time, Connecticut's budget is already out of balance and headed for another deficit, Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today.
The projected gap, about $175 million, is a bit more than 2 percent of the budget of $7.6 billion, but state lawmakers said the psychological impact would probably be bigger than the actual size of the problem. 
 Mr. Weicker made the announcement on the opening day -- indeed at the very moment of the opening ceremony -- for a special legislative session to consider repealing the income-tax law.
Mr. Weicker's proposed solutions, mainly a series of spending cuts and fee increases that lawmakers had considered and rejected earlier this year, seem destined to further disturb what was already expected to be a turbulent session. And the numbers provide statistical fuel for both sides in the debate about how sick the state's economy really is and what role the tax system has played or could play in aggravating or easing the recession's effect.
 
Less Profit, Less Tax Revenue
 Administration budget officials said that corporate income taxes, sales taxes and capital gains taxes were all producing lower revenue than predicted when the budget was passed in August. The 1991-92 tax revenue from capital gains is expected to be $74 million less than anticipated in the budget, mainly because of the state's weak real-estate market; more people are taking capital losses when they sell homes and businesses.
"What it really says is that the Connecticut economy is in a lot of trouble," said Representative Jonathan Pelto, a Democrat from Storrs and a deputy majority leader in the House of Representatives. "The Connecticut state government is now going to have to make cutbacks of far greater extent than they ever have before regardless of whether you're for an income tax or against an income tax."
 
'Old System Doesn't Work'
 Mr. Weicker, who insisted that the timing of his budget announcement was entirely coincidental to the opening of the special session, said the new numbers about the budget gap underscored the weaknesses and unpredictability of all the state's taxes except the new one on wages, where collections are just about on target. Mr. Weicker, a third-party Governor with no party allies in the Legislature, proposed the tax last February, then vetoed three legislative budgets that did not have it.
"Were it not for that income tax, the state of Connecticut would not have its head above water," Mr. Weicker said. "There is no more ducking the fact that the old system doesn't work."
But leaders of the movement to repeal the income-tax law immediately charged that the new numbers bolstered their own case that withholding money from residents' paychecks would strangle the state's consumer-driven economy. Even though the expected $63 million shortfall in sales-tax collections announced today could not be directly pinned to the wage tax -- the numbers date from September, before payroll withholding began on Oct. 1 -- tax opponents said the anecdotal evidence pointed to an even further retrenchment in consumer spending since then.
"The Governor's economic theories have stunk from day one," said the House minority leader, Representative Edward C. Krawiecki Jr., a Republican from Bristol who has led the repeal drive. "You simply cannot siphon hundreds of millions of dollars out of taxpayers' paychecks and then expect consumer sales to remain constant."
 
Repealers Would Cut Spending
 Mr. Krawiecki said his repeal group would file its alternative bills on Tuesday. He gave few details, except that they would eliminate the wage tax and include an overall tax cut and sharply reduced spending.
Mr. Weicker, who had opposed even the idea of the special session, described the new fiscal troubles in a news conference in the Capitol as the voice of the House clerk echoed over loudspeakers summoning the House members to their chamber.
Connecticut, which increased state spending by double-digit amounts through much of the 1980's as the state's military and real-estate businesses boomed, fell hard to earth beginning about 1989. The use of short-term or one-shot revenue solutions aggravated the problem, building toward a shortfall of more than $900 million for the budget year that ended on June 30.
But the new 4.5 percent flat-rate income tax, which broke a decades-long taboo and ended Connecticut's status as one of only 10 states that kept wages tax-free, has not ended the state's struggles either. In September, Mr. Weicker announced that 3,700 state workers would have to be laid off and thousands of others given reduced pay and hours because the unions had refused to make concessions. That number has shrunk as some unions have settled, but most have not. In October, more than 40,000 residents went to the Capitol to protest the income tax.
 
Much of Plan Unpopular
 And given that lawmakers have already said no to almost all solutions that Mr. Weicker proposed today to the $175 million shortfall, further strife seems almost certain. One of the largest categories of spending cuts, for example, totaling more than $40 million, involves aid for local schools and property tax relief.
Mr. Weicker also suggested eliminating a $3 million program that helps pay for health services in private and parochial schools. Thousands of students in plaid skirts and blazers descended on the Capitol in waves last spring to protest those cuts when they were first suggested.
The Senate President pro tempore, John B. Larson, an anti-income-tax Democrat from East Hartford, says he believes that the Governor's new figures make repeal more likely.
Leaders of repeal in both houses claim a majority to overturn the income tax, but are still short of the two-thirds needed to override Mr. Weicker's promised veto.
Opponents of repeal, however, say that the Governor gave them new justification.

HEADLINE: High Court to Weigh Payments to Owners Of Regulated Land

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether landowners were constitutionally entitled to compensation when government bars all development in the interest of public safety or welfare.
Because the Court has been closely divided over the constitutional implications of land-use regulation, this case, involving a state-imposed ban on beachfront development along the South Carolina coast, may give Justice Clarence Thomas an opportunity to influence the development of an important area of the law. 
 In speeches and articles before he joined the Court, the newest Justice indicated that he had considerable affinity with a group of conservative legal thinkers who believe that the modern Supreme Court has given inadequate weight to the constitutional safeguards of private property.
The subject is a complex and important one, as the Federal, state and local governments increasingly seek to regulate development not only for reasons of esthetics and life style, but also out of concern for the environment and public health.
The Fifth Amendment to the Constitution provides that private property may not be "taken for public use without just compensation." It is clearly a "taking," for which compensation is required, when a government uses its power of eminent domain to take possession of private property.
But the Supreme Court has also held that land-use restrictions that leave property in private hands while stripping it of economically productive uses may amount to a "regulatory taking," for which compensation may also be required.
The dimensions of this doctrine are unclear and hotly disputed, with conservative judges generally seeking to enlarge the definition of a "regulatory taking" while liberals try to confine it narrowly to give the government a freer regulatory hand.
In a 5-to-4 decision four years ago, the Court ruled that a Pennsylvania law limiting the amount of coal that could be extracted at certain locations was not a taking because coal mining in those areas was a threat to public safety. The Court said in a majority opinion by Justice John Paul Stevens that because no one had a right to create a "nuisance" on private property "the state has not 'taken' anything when it asserts its power to enjoin the nuisance-like activity."
The South Carolina Supreme Court relied on that decision earlier this year in the ruling that the Justices agreed today to review. The state court ruled that South Carolina did not have to compensate owners of beachfront property who lost the right to develop their land under South Carolina's new Beachfront Management Act.
 
State Court's Ruling
 The South Carolina Supreme Court, noting that the Legislature had found that beachfront development hastened erosion, said the purpose of the development ban was to prevent serious public harm to the state's environment and economy. Consequently, it said, the regulation should not be considered a taking, just as the Pennsylvania coal mining regulation was not a taking.
The South Carolina ruling was appealed by a landowner, David H. Lucas, who had bought two waterfront lots on the Isle of Palms that were zoned for single-family houses, shortly before the Beachfront Management Act took effect.
Under the new law, he could build no permanent structures on his property. He challenged the law as a taking and won a $1.2 million judgment in the state trial court. That judgment was overturned by the South Carolina Supreme Court.
In his appeal to the United States Supreme Court, Lucas v. South Carolina Coastal Council, No. 91-453, Mr. Lucas is arguing that the state should not be able to evade the constitutional compensation requirement by calling a proposed development a "nuisance." More narrowly, even if there is a "nuisance exception" to the compensation requirement, he argues, his proposed development was not a nuisance.
The case may provide an occasion for the Supreme Court to overrule its 1987 decision in the Pennsylvania case, Keystone Bituminous Coal v. DeBenedictis. That 5-to-4 decision included a vigorous dissenting opinion by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. Since then, two Justices who were in the majority, William J. Brennan Jr. and Thurgood Marshall, have retired.
But the case is unlikely to provide an occasion for the Court to address the Constitutional implications of laws dealing with historic landmarks, because it concerns only regulations that deprive landowners of any use of their land. Landmark laws, by contrast, limit the economic return available from a historic property by barring modifications to the structure, but they allow some return.
In another development today, the Justices asked the Bush Administration to present a legal position on whether an American hospital worker, who asserts that he was falsely arrested and tortured by the Saudi Arabian police while working on contract in a Saudi Government hospital, should be permitted to sue the Saudi Government in Federal court.
 
Saudis Ask for U.S.'s Help
 After a Federal appeals court panel in Atlanta ruled earlier this year that the lawsuit, filed in Federal court in Florida, could proceed, the Saudi Government persuaded the Administration to take the position that the case does not belong in a United States court and to seek a new hearing before the entire appeals court.
The Administration did not take a view on the merits of the lawsuit, filed by Scott J. Nelson of Raleigh, N.C., but rather it argued that foreign governments were immune from suits here concerning their internal law enforcement activity. That position was criticized by several members of Congress, who said foreign governments should not be able to escape responsibility for torturing American citizens.
The appeals courts declined to grant a new hearing. Saudi Arabia filed an appeal to the Supreme Court this fall, Saudi Arabia v. Nelson, No. 91-522, which the Administration did not join. The Court's request for its views puts the Administration in a potentially awkward position of choosing between alienating an important ally in Saudi Arabia and facing renewed criticism for its legal position.

HEADLINE: BUSH SEES NO NEED FOR MAJOR EFFORTS TO REVIVE ECONOMY

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
President Bush said today that he believed that the American economy was basically sound and that he planned no major new programs to stimulate growth, but he acknowledged having trouble convincing the public that his policies were adequate.
Amid evidence that the continued economic sluggishness was already throwing his re-election campaign off balance, Mr. Bush called reporters to his office on short notice to strike a confident note about the country and his plans for a second term. 
 He said he felt no urgency to have a full campaign team in place, but he nonetheless said he might soon announce a top echelon of re-election officials .
 
Allaying Fears
 Just days after the stock market suffered its fifth-worst day in history, Mr. Bush took the opportunity to try to allay the fears of some supporters that the Democrats were using the poor economy to seize control of the 1992 election agenda. He said that neither he nor most top economists believed that the nation would slide back into a full-fledged recession next year.
"You see, there's some fairly good fundamentals getting out there," he said. "Inflation is down. Interest rates are down. Personal debt is down. Inventories are down. Quality -- competitiveness -- quality is going in the right direction, up, and exports are up. So it's not like we're dealing with a totally bad economy."
 
Seeking a Compelling Message
 "I'm not basing any plans on the economy getting worse," he said.
Today's session with reporters in the Oval Office, like Mr. Bush's news conference before he left for a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Rome the morning after Election Day, seemed intended to get the President off the defensive, but ended up reinforcing the impression that he was struggling to find a compelling campaign message.
Rather than holding a formal news conference today, the White House invited six correspondents recently assigned to the White House to meet with Mr. Bush.
Asked why polls indicated that many Americans believed that the country was headed in the wrong direction, he replied: "I think I've got to do better in making clear what the message is, and I think I can do better. But I think there's so much noise out there that I've got to figure out how to make it clearer that we are for the things that I have advocated that would help."
Mr. Bush said he felt that no "radically different approaches" were needed to promote further growth beyond his existing six-point legislative program, which includes a proposal to cut the tax rate for capital gains, legislation to overhaul the banking system and a highway bill that sponsors say would create thousands of jobs.
Some parts of that package, like the highway bill, appear headed for passage. Others, like the proposed cut in the capital gains tax, have been stalled in Congress for years and show few signs of moving toward passage.
In political speeches around the country in recent weeks, the President has responded to Democratic attacks by accusing Congress of thwarting his domestic legislation. That strategy has long worked for Mr. Bush and his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, but lately the unrelenting bad economic news has drowned him out.
Today's Oval Office interview came after a difficult week of reports of rising factory prices and falling automobile and retail sales. In a speech on Wednesday, Mr. Bush called on banks to reduce interest rates on credit cards voluntarily, apparently hoping to touch a chord with middle-class voters. The next day, some Republicans in Congress led a move to enact mandatory ceilings on credit card rates, panicking banks that rely on interest from credit cards to remain profitable.
That, in turn, may have helped spur a 120-point drop in the stock market on Friday and initiated another cycle of downbeat predictions about economic prospects.
Mr. Bush dismissed the steep drop in the stock market in a phrase on Saturday, telling reporters who interrupted his round of golf: "We'll see what happens Monday. No reason to get all concerned."
Today, noting that the stock market had headed back up, he said that attitude had been "the right approach" and that the President should not, and is not competent to, persuade stock traders to push stock prices upward or downward. The stock market gained 29.52 points today.
"I've tried as President to stay out of that," he said. "Perhaps what's happening in the market today vindicates that; I don't know. But let the market sort that out."
But the President defended his earlier efforts to persuade banks to lower their credit card rates, a move some experts have said is as likely to hurt the economy as help it, since lower rates will encourage financially pressed consumers to take on still more debt.
 
Not 'Interfering in the Market'
 Encouraging a decline in interest, he said, is not "interfering in the market" but something the White House regularly does in statements aimed at the Federal Reserve and other institutions that influence such rates.
Asked whether he believed it would be good for the economy if Americans made more purchases on credit, Mr. Bush appeared to respond with a qualified yes.
"That should be a decision made by individuals," he said. "But frankly, I'd like to see the cash registers ring at Christmastime. It would be very good for the economy."
The President was reluctant to say what else he might propose to help the economy or when he might propose it, except that he would wait until after Congress's scheduled adjournment on Friday to announce any new legislative programs.
That, he said, would remove Congress from the scene, enabling the Administration to "package what I'm talking about in a way that people will see it loud and clear and understand it and, hopefully, support me more."
On his own prospects for re-election, the President said that he felt "a certain confidence about it, about the outcome" of the 1992 race, but that he was taking seriously the emerging signs of challenges from both the Democrats and from within his own party's most conservative wing.
Friends of Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative television commentator and writer, have said he might enter the Republican primary against Mr. Bush, and David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader who lost decisively in Louisiana's race for governor on Saturday, said today that he was exploring the possibility of challenging the President.
Mr. Bush acknowledged that 1992 was shaping up as a potentially bad year for incumbents, based on the anti-government message that most analysts saw in this month's elections in Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Virginia and elsewhere.
After nearly 11 years in the White House, he said, he has some concern that the voters this year may start to view him as an incumbent marked for defeat. "But I think I can handle it," he said. "I also note at the same time that people seem to suggest that Congress is more to blame than the President, though."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bush said he was having trouble convincing the public that his policies were adequate. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Magic Word That Could Solve Cuomo's Budget Problems: 'Multiyear'

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 18

 BODY:
For all the bold talk about combining New York State's budget gaps into one huge problem and then crafting a grand solution to last well into 1993, nobody has yet described how it would actually work.
The lack of progress in fashioning such a plan could carry dire implications, not only for the fiscal outlook of the state, but also for the political future of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who said today that if there was no solution soon, he would not enter the campaign for President. 
 Alluding to what he said was increasing pressure from national party leaders and the announced candidates to make up his mind about a Presidential run, Mr. Cuomo said in Buffalo: "That means you have to rush your decision. But if you have to rush your decision, and I don't have a budget solution, then I would have to say, 'No.' "
Given the equivocal nature of Mr. Cuomo's recent comments about the White House, even his aides cautioned against drawing a definitive conclusion from his latest remarks.
With an elastic definition of the word "solution," Mr. Cuomo could still argue that he was ready to run if he and legislative leaders could reach agreement in the next few days on a basic approach to dealing with the budget, like a freeze on local-assistance programs and most state spending for the next year and a half.
That is one concept that has come up repeatedly in discussions here about a multiyear budget, although aides to the Governor and the legislative leaders acknowledged that it might cover barely half of the roughly $3 billion potential gap the state faces over the next 18 months.
With his comments today, Mr. Cuomo may simply be sending a veiled message to national Democratic leaders that he wants them to back off in their pressure for an answer on the Presidency, although if this is his strategy, it is not necessarily working. Ronald H. Brown, the party's national chairman, called on Mr. Cuomo today to announce his plans within the next week and said that it was "getting close to that point" where his indecision would be harming the party's prospects.
Despite his emphasis on solving the state's long-term budget problems, neither Mr. Cuomo nor anyone else in the Capitol has offered even a broad outline of how to craft the unusual multiyear plan.
Both Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller last week embraced the concept of a multiyear budget, which they said could blunt some of the spending cuts they might otherwise have to make immediately and also avoid an excruciating battle next spring over the 1992-93 budget.
Friends and foes of Mr. Cuomo have all noted that a successful "Super Mario Budget," as one strategist called it, could free the Governor to hit the road for crucial Presidential primaries that begin in February.
But how would this budget work? If the state does not cut $700 million between now and March 31, the end of the fiscal year, what will happen? Does that mean borrowing money, or sliding payments from March into April to meet the constitutional mandate to finish the year with a balanced budget? Would Wall Street raters, who have already given New York the third-worst credit rating of any state in the nation, blast such moves as fiscal gimmickry?
If the budget is stretched out, does that mean that yet another bad turn in the economy next year would leave the state budget in worse shape than if state leaders had bitten the bullet and cut all the $700 million now?
Republicans, who control the State Senate, have consistently expressed skepticism about the idea. They reiterated their insistence today that they would not go along with any plan that raised taxes, borrowed money or failed to contain deep cuts in Medicaid and welfare spending.
In one of the odder twists in the complicated relationship between the budget negotiations and the Governor's Presidential ruminations, Mr. Cuomo now seems to have almost left his decision about the White House in the hands of Republicans in Albany.
Certainly, prolonged intransigence on their part would, under Mr. Cuomo's latest pronouncement, keep him out of the race. On the other hand, the Governor might produce some major concessions that could benefit their own re-election campaigns next year, such as generous school-aid grants. Then the Republicans might go along with a budget now rather than face a fight later with a Governor who has no reason to buy their peace.
The Senate Majority Leader, Ralph J. Marino, has said he is even more interested in re-electing his members than in re-electing the President.
But without the multiyear budget, all sides concede, they will have to meet in Albany to thrash out the $700 million in spending cuts needed to balance the current budget.
"We love the idea of long-range financial planning," said Cynthia Green, a senior analyst for the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group financed by businesses. "We'd love to see a plan for a multiyear budget, balanced, without gimmicks. But until we see just how they want to get there, who knows?"

HEADLINE: Fisherman's Torpedoed Career Is Refloated

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SHINNECOCK INLET, L.I., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Capt. Daniel Hand, gazing longingly out to sea, declared that it was "a great day to go fishing" today. But he still didn't have a boat.
Captain Hand's last vessel, the Shinnecock I, in which he'd gone to sea for 18 years, was sunk eight months ago by the United States Navy after he netted a World War II torpedo along with a heavy load of fish in the Atlantic off the south shore of Long Island. 
 The torpedo had been fired by a Navy destroyer in 1942 at a German submarine, but missed its mark and sank to the ocean floor. When Captain Hand hauled it aboard the Shinnecock I this spring and notified the Navy, demolition experts declared it unstable and ordered that his boat be scuttled to prevent an explosion that could injure residents of nearby Hampton Bays.
Captain Hand, a fisherman for 38 of his 54 years, said that when they sank the 80-foot craft on March 13, Navy officials assured him that the Government would pay to replace the Shinnecock I. The vessel was insured, Captain Hand said, but the insurer would not pay because the Navy had sunk it.
 
Take It to Court
 But when he submitted a claim for Government compensation, he said, the Navy instead advised him to sue -- a process that could have gone on for years.
Friends of the captain contacted Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and Representative George J. Hochbrueckner, both Long Island residents. During a brief ceremony at the Town of Southampton dock overlooking the Shinnecock Inlet today, they came to his aid with the promise of a Government check for $220,000 in compensation for his lost boat.
Captain Hand invited the Senator and Representative Hochbrueckner to go fishing when he gets his new boat, to be named Shinnecock II.
"I've been shopping for one from Maine to Texas," he said. "I've just got to decide what the bottom figure is and what I can manage. It's not the kind of thing you can pick up at Macy's."
 
Pirates of the Pentagon?
 A new boat and equipment will cost about $300,000, Captain Hand said, and he will probably take out a new mortgage on his home to revive his fishing business. In the meantime, he said, he is "penniless" and not covered by unemployment insurance.
"What we saw last March was literally high-seas piracy," Senator D'Amato said. "The poor captain catches a torpedo and reports it. The next thing you know he's ordered to abandon ship and they blow it up on him."
The Senator said he had compromised with the Navy on the $220,000 figure, which he said was included in the Defense Appropriations Bill that was recently approved by Congress and awaits the signature of President Bush.
The 54-year-old captain, who lives in Hampton Bays, recalled that "it was a day just like today -- calm seas, clear skies and no wind" when a Navy demolition team put charges in the Shinnecock I and "blew her bottom out," then went down and blew the torpedo apart.
"All they did was break the torpedo into pieces," he said. "As it turned out, it was a dud anyway."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, right, said yesterday that the Federal Government would pay for a boat owned by Capt. Daniel Hand, left, which was destroyed by the Navy after the vessel netted a World War II torpedo off Long Island. Captain Hand's insurance company would not pay. The Senator received a thank-you note from the captain's son, Bret, as Mr. Hand and his wife, Margaret, watched. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Brazil Creates Reserve for Imperiled Amazon Tribe

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Overriding mining interests and military protests, President Fernando Collor de Mello has moved to reserve a stretch of Amazon rain forest as a homeland for the Yanomami Indians, a tribe virtually untouched by modern civilization whose ways date from the Stone Age.
The new reserve, coupled with a slightly smaller park across the border, in Venezuela, will allow the Yanomami, South America's last major untouched tribe, to roam freely over 68,331 square miles of Amazon wilderness, an area the size of Missouri. 
 "We struggled for 20 years for what has just happened," said Claudia Andujar, coordinator of the Commission for the Creation of a Yanomami Park, a private group based here."
With the fate of South America's 23,000 Yanomami an international cause, Napoleon A. Chagnon, an American anthropologist, echoed widespread American and European euphoria when he said today in a telephone interview, "This will go a long way to making cultural survival of the Yanomami a real possibility."
 
Military Resists Move
 But not everyone was clapping in Brasilia on Friday when Mr. Collor signed a decree reserving 1 percent of Brazil's land mass for the nation's estimated 9,000 Yanomami. At the signing ceremony, Gen. Carlos Tinoco, the Army Minister, pointedly abstained from joining the applause.
Charging that foreign interests secretly seek to create an independent Yanomami nation, influential elements of Brazil's military have argued that Brazil should clear a 12-mile-wide border strip to separate Brazil's Yanomami from Venezuela's Yanomami.
Searching for a mission after the collapse of international Communism, Brazil's conservative generals are increasingly taking nationalist stands on the Amazon.
"The innocence and purity of some idealists is exploited in order to keep dormant the potential of the Brazilian Amazon," warned a recent study by the Superior War College, Brazil's elite military institute.
Describing Indian and other reserves as "liberated zones" under international control, the military document predicted, "It would take a great Brazilian effort for their elimination, probably resorting to war."
But the army's political standing has been weakened in recent days by newspaper reports of fixed bidding practices for equipment procurements.
Rebuffing the army's national security arguments, Mr. Collor's announcement came on the national holiday marking the military's abolition of Brazil's monarchy in 1889.
Brazilian "sovereignty continues intact, and even reinforced," Mr. Collor said of the park. Two weeks ago, he approved 71 other Indian reserves, covering 42,471 square miles.
Mr. Collor ignored economic objections raised by governors of two states where the park will be located, Amazonas and Roraima.
Rich in gold, tin, diamonds and zinc, the park area is virtually papered with 698 requests by mining companies for exploration rights. Once an area becomes an Indian reserve, mining contracts are subject to approval by Indian communities and mediation by Brazil's Indian protection agency, Funai.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy Urges Debt Relief for Soviets

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Warning that economic pressures could bring social upheaval in the next six months, Robert S. Strauss, the United States Ambassador here, urged today that Western nations grant debt assistance to the disjointed Soviet nation as it tries to weather the winter and reorder its economy.
Mr. Strauss, emphasizing that he was expressing his personal view, urged the deferral of loan principal repayments as ministers of the Group of Seven industrial nations conferred here on the economic crisis with officials of the separate Soviet republics. 
 The Ambassador, in an interview with American correspondents, said that beyond debt assistance, it would be worthwhile for the United States to "risk a couple of billion bucks" in aid to the Soviet Union rather than see a "facist situation" evolve if tensions explode and people protest in the streets.
Mr. Strauss's comments appeared to be a departure from the cautious pronouncements of the Bush Administration on Soviet aid. In general, Administration officials have expressed wariness about committing further aid to the Soviet Union, citing budget constraints and the need for the Soviet republics to resolve their economic uncertainties.
 
A Winter of Unknowns
 But Mr. Strauss, the Democratic lawyer and Washington insider appointed by President Bush in June more for his political savvy than his diplomatic experience, spoke plainly of Soviet conditions. The Ambassador, who is known to be dismayed by the collapse of a Congressional plan to divert $1 billion in Pentagon money to Soviet relief, stressed the need to extend at least limited timely support as the Soviet nation faces a winter of unknowns.
Mr. Strauss said that the limited debt relief that he was urging, under which interest would continue to be paid, could make a "major difference" of $10 billion or more in the current economic pressures now facing officials of this crisis-ridden nation.
"It sure can blow up in our face in the next six months very easily," Mr. Strauss declared in estimating the tensions while stressing that, with some prudent risk-taking, creditor nations could see a "modestly stable government and society" emerge from the current chaos within a few years.
The Soviet foreign debt is estimated at $80 billion and Western European nations like France and Germany, which have been more willing than Washington to extend loans to the Soviets, are the main creditors.
Economic specialists have estimated the Soviet needs in the scores of billions of dollars of aid at a minimum. Mr. Strauss said that while he could not urge any investor to "bet the farm" in the current chaos, Western nations dare not take the risk of standing idly by.
The Group of Seven deputy finance ministers conferred separately with republic officials on the crisis and its most immediate symptom: how a crumbling Soviet Union increasingly short in hard currency reserves can meet such a large debt.
Ivan Silayev, chairman of the Inter-republic Economic Committee that is trying to chart a reconstruction program for the post-Communist era, said that the meeting, which will continue on Tuesday, would consider a "package of proposals" from the Group of Seven nations on granting some sort of financial aid to the Soviet republics by the end of the year. The Group of Seven consists of the United States, Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan.
Any debt relief or aid would probably entail a series of conditions about the remaining republics' willingness to assume the Soviet debt and to install a market economic system. Global wariness of the Soviet economy has been growing daily as the ruble loses value, consumer shortages deepen and conflicting reports emerge about the state of the tottering nation's currency reserves.
The debt issue is complicated by the republics' need to mute emerging rivalries and restore enough credibility in world financial markets to assure provision of vitally needed food and other basic consumer goods.
Mr. Strauss, who is not a direct participant in the Group of Seven talks, said that in the three months since he took up his post "a lot of latent anomosity" had become clear in Soviet society, leaving "a very unpredictable" future.
"I'm more bullish than bearish," the ambassador concluded. "I think they're going to get through it."
With the national union Government steadily dissolving ever since the failed Kremlin coup of last August, President Boris N. Yeltsin is trying to have his Russian republic take the lead in bolstering world credibility and introducing free-market economics.
 
Russia Seeks Dominance
 Over the weekend, he issued a series of sweeping orders to assert Russian dominance over the foundering Soviet economy, proclaiming control over Russia's dwindling reserves of oil, gold and other precious commodities and opening the republic's doors to foreign trade.
The package of new measures would lift most controls over imports, exports and foreign currency transactions on Russian territory. It would also allow the value of ruble, now dictated by the Soviet central bank, to float according to market rates on Jan. 1, a measure certain to compound social pressures.
An earlier, parallel order would free consumer prices, which already are rocketing upward, and bolster wages with anti-inflation increases. It remains far from clear, however, how much political and social resistance Mr. Yeltsin will face in tring to carry out such an economic revolution.
Among other issues, the Group of Seven meeting was expected to focus on obtaining firmer guarantees from the republics to fulfill an earlier agreement to channel hard-currency earnings to repayment of the standing Soviet debt. There have been signs of balking in some republics and Soviet television news reported tonight that Azerbaijan and Moldavia in particular were resisting the pledge to repay.
Part of President Yeltsin's economic program has emphasized that Russia, by far the nation's largest and wealthiest republic, would protect itself from assuming other republics' share of debts.
Mr. Strauss spoke positively of the relationship between the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose role has waned, and Mr. Yeltsin, whose burdens and powers are growing. "He knows there needs to be a center," the Ambassador said of Mr. Yeltsin.
Mr. Strauss counseled patience in speaking sympathetically of the separate republics' urge to flex their new-found sovereignties. He likened them to teen-agers asserting their independence of parents but then eventually qualifying their revolt when "their laundry got dirty or they need a good meal."
With announcements, warnings and confusion over the economy coming in flurries each day, the Soviet public was promised a tangible bit of free marketry this week. The Moscow Government said the first shops would be denationalized, with workers having first chance at buying and running them. If worker collectives demur, the shops are to be put to open auction, with foreign investors permitted to bid, according to the announced plan.
