HEADLINE: Rush of Callers Seek Extended Aid for Jobless

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The ink was barely dry after President Bush signed the law extending benefits for the long-term unemployed when idled workers started calling unemployment insurance offices in the New York metropolitan region to ask for their checks.
State labor officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are advising unemployed men and women who have exhausted their normal insurance since March 1 to wait for applications for extended benefits to come in the mail. Mr. Bush signed the $5.3 billion package after Congress passed an amended version late Friday, and first thing this morning calls began flooding regional labor department offices as labor union locals mobilized their laid-off members to find out if they were eligible. 
 About 40,000 Connecticut residents, 120,000 New Jerseyans and 250,000 New Yorkers are estimated to be among the 3 million Americans who have exhausted their normal 13-to-26-week unemployment benefits since March 1, the date Congress set as the limit for inclusion in the program. People who ran out of coverage before that date are not eligible, state labor officials said. Those who run out of benefits between now and June 13, 1992, will also be eligible under the measure.
"We had a real rush this morning, but things have quieted down now," said John Bachofen, manager of the New Jersey Department of Labor's Trenton office, one of 34 in the state. "The preferred method is for them to wait for their application to come in the mail, but we took them with the other people and handed them their application cards today, since they took the trouble to come down."
Thomas L. Hinds, Acting New York State Labor Commissioner, issued a statement warning that flocking to state labor offices might slow the handling of applications. Jane Burman, manager of the Department of Labor's Community Service Center at 52 West 20th Street in Manhattan, said she expected the mailings to be completed by Nov. 27. People who think they are eligible but who have not received an information packet by Dec. 2 should get in touch with a local service center, she said.
Word of the extended benefits lured more than double the usual number of people to the Community Service Center at East 149th Street in the Bronx this morning.
Richard Quatroni, the office's supervising labor services representative, arrived at his office at 7 A.M. to find a line of people that stretched around the block, 60 of whom were inquiring about their eligibility for extended payments. His office had expected the extension to attract as many as 5,000 more customers a month, and already by midafternoon today the office had seen more than 500 people -- or half its regular weekly volume.
 
Offices to Extend Hours
 In Connecticut, where officials believe idled workers have been exhausting their jobless benefits at the rate of more than 1,200 a week, officials will keep unemployment claim centers open late, until 8:30 P.M. on some days, starting next month.
Among the first questions the long-term unemployed seemed to want answered was "Will I get my money before Thanksgiving, or before Christmas?," according to conversations with people coming out of the Trenton office who said their union locals had informed them that the benefits program had finally been approved. The package had been a political football tossed between the White House and Congress this fall, with Mr. Bush twice vetoing the program because of its cost before signing the amended version Friday.
The answer to the applicants' question is Christmas. Although New Jersey officials worked through the weekend to get the first 20,000 of 120,000 applications in the mail this morning, the last documents will probably not reach their beneficiaries until the end of the month, particularly in New York.
"Man, I feel like this came from God," said Gerry Gurney, a Trenton construction laborer who said he lost his last job in April. His benefits ran out in October, he said, and he believes he will qualify for the extra stipends. "Coming in time for Christmas is going to make all the difference."
The extended benefits are especially welcome in the Bronx, which has the highest reported unemployment rate in the state, 11.3 percent, according to Kathleen O'Brien, the manager of the Department of Labor's 149th Street office.
 
Relief at Decision
 John Garcia, an unemployed engraver who spent a year unsuccessfully looking for work before a brief stint working during the summer, thought the benefits were especially useful to family men like himself. He supports his wife, two daughters and his disabled mother.
"Some people need more than six months," he said.
Those who are eligible will receive either 20 additional weeks of benefits or 100 percent of the benefit level for which they last qualified, whichever is lower. Someone who was eligible for only 13 weeks' insurance, normally the minimum benefit, would therefore receive only that number under the new program.
Payment levels are based on salary or work history and usually range between $200 and $250 a week.

HEADLINE: Republican Conservatives Picked for Top Budget Posts

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The leaders of the new Republican legislative majorities chose two fiscal conservatives today to head the finance committees in the Senate and the Assembly and to lead the fight to fulfill a Republican campaign promise to roll back taxes.
The President-elect of the Senate, Donald T. DiFrancesco, picked Senator Robert E. Littell as chairman of the Revenue and Appropriations Committee. In the Assembly, Speaker-elect Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian made Assemblyman Rodney P. Frelinghuysen chairman of the Appropriations Committee. 
 Democrats, who, for the first time in 20 years will be the minority in both chambers, today elected the Assembly Speaker, Joseph V. Doria Jr., to serve as minority leader in the new session.
The legislative budget officers hold some of the most powerful appointed posts in state government, and the jobs will take on added importance for the Republicans because they based their campaigns on anti-tax oratory and promises of tax cuts.
Mr. Littell, who sold his own appliance center in Franklin a year ago, said today that Republicans intended to keep that promise by cutting the size of government.
Mr. Haytaian cut his own leadership roster today when he announced that he would operate with 19 committees instead of the 27 used by the Democratic majority.
 
Focus on Sales Tax So Far
 His budget officer, Mr. Frelinghuysen, has served in the Assembly since 1983 and was chairman of the Appropriations Committee in 1989, the last time Republicans controlled the Assembly.
Focusing their campaigns on $2.8 billion in tax increases that the Democratic Governor, Jim Florio, pushed through a Democratic-controlled Legislature last year and the public anger it stirred, Republicans captured a 58-to-22 Assembly majority and a 27-to-13 lead in the Senate in the Nov. 5 election.
They touted the victory as a mandate to repeal taxes, but have said definitely only that they will roll back a penny on the current 7 cent sales tax, which was part of Mr. Florio's tax package.
In choosing Mr. Littell as the Senate's top budget officer, Mr. DiFrancesco passed over Senator John H. Ewing, the senior Republican member of the Appropriations Committee. Mr. DiFrancesco said Mr. Ewing would become president pro-tem of the Senate and chairman of the Education Committee.
Senate Democrats are to meet within a week to decide on their new leadership, with John A. Lynch, the Senate president, expected to keep his leadership job in the minority.
Mr. Doria's current majority leadership team will follow him as minority leaders. Democrats today voted unanimously for Assemblymen Wayne R. Bryant and Jimmy Zangari as deputy minority leaders, William J. Pascrell Jr. as conference chairman, Byron Baer as minority leader pro-tem and Joseph Charles Jr. as associate minority leader.
Mr. Haytaian and the Republicans, in paring their committee list to 19, eliminated committees like drug and alcohol abuse policy, economic growth, agriculture and tourism. But Republican officials said the responsibilities of those committees will be handled by others.

HEADLINE: On Credit Cards, D'Amato Finds Victory and Defeat

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato knows a good political target when he sees one. Saddam Hussein, for one. Credit card interest rates, for another.
But while his attacks on the Iraqi leader generated little debate, the latest attempt by Mr. D'Amato to use the rates as grist for his toughest re-election campaign set off an open battle between New York's junior Senator and the White House and is being blamed for provoking Friday's stock market plunge. 
 The confrontation with the Administration culminated a weeklong political roller coaster ride for the Long Island Republican.
The ride up began when President Bush last Tuesday called at a New York fundraiser for banks to lower their credit card rates as a way to help consumer spending.
It was exactly what the Senator had been waiting for. He came back here, recruited Senator Joseph Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat, and dusted off an amendment that would cap credit card interest rates at about 14 percent, roughly 4 percentage points less than most banks currently charge.
 
Question of Access
 It was quickly approved by the Senate. But just as quickly came a barrage of attacks on the Senator from both Republicans and Democrats who said the measure would limit access to credit, thereby possibly deepening the recession.
The amendment on the credit-card rates is only the latest effort by Senator D'Amato to increase his visibility and reverse a five-year-long slide in the polls by becoming seen as the champion of the middle class, who are being courted by both parties as the key to the coming elections.
But, one after another, his attempts to project himself as "Battlin' Al" have brought grief as well as credit.
"It's typical Al D'Amato: rife political opportunism and a quick fix," said Attorney General Robert Abrams of New York, one of several Democratic opponents. "It looks good on the surface but is going to have a devastating consequence on the working guy."
Last month, the Senator's criticism of Mayor David N. Dinkins's handling of racial disturbances in Crown Heights brought a similar rebound, as Democrats and community leaders here and in New York charged that he was exploiting racial fears.
White ethnic and Jewish voters are key elements of Mr. D'Amato's political constituency. When he won a second term five years ago, the Senator lost New York City to the Democratic challenger, Mark Green, but compensated by running unusually well for a Republican among Jewish voters.
Mr. D'Amato has turned the courtship of ethnic groups into something approaching performance art. Last year, during the Baltic states' battle for independence from the Soviet Union, he was the first Senator to defy Soviet regulations by trying to cross the border into Lithuania. And when Iraq began firing Scud missiles at Israel during the Persian Gulf war last summer, the Senator flew to Israel to demonstrate his solidarity.
The Senator is a silver-tongued campaigner with a press agents' eye for what makes the evening news -- today, for instance, announcing a settlement to compensate a fisherman whose trawler was blown up by the Coast Guard after he snagged a World War II torpedo in his nets. On a less-publicized level, he has also been a steady supporter of Wall Street firms -- who have been among his biggest contributors -- in their battles with big banks.
 
Who's Ignoring Whom?
 The Senator defends himself against charges of pandering by accusing the Northeast political establishment of overlooking local needs. And in what is fast becoming the mantra of politicians facing election, Mr. D'Amato also charges that his critics have ignored the middle class.
He notes that the discount rate, which is what banks are charged for borrowing money, has dropped to 4.5 percent from 7 percent last year, but that most banks have maintained the interest they charge to credit card customers at almost 19 percent.
"They're gouging the middle class," the Senator said today in a telephone interview after returning from New York. "They're soaking the middle class. Jesse James at least wore a mask. These guys do it as your friend and they want you to say thank you."
But in a stinging rebuke to the Senator, the Administration and many Republicans denounced his amendment, which is modeled after legislation he introduced six years ago. They said the bill would hurt the people he is trying to help.
"The only people who would have credit cards would be the rich people," Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said Sunday on "Meet the Press" on NBC-TV in blaming the Senator for Friday's stock market plunge. The bill, he added, would lead to "credit cards which are elitist."
The Senator today appeared to back down from the proposal. He acknowledged it was "terrible legislation" but said it was needed because of a "conspiracy" among banks to inflate credit card interest rates. Claiming victory even though colleagues were lining up against the bill, he predicted that the public outcry raised by the bill would force banks to cut their credit card rates.
"At the very least we've exposed the conspiracy," he said. "I think we're going to see interest rates come down. If they needed the fear of God, so be it. We've accomplished something already."

HEADLINE: Divided Pakistan Torn by Lawlessness and Scandal

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 15

 BODY:
Each time a passenger plane begins its glide toward this capital's airport, a flight attendant says, "We shall be landing soon, God willing." The invocation, while perhaps unnerving to travelers more inclined to put their faith in the pilot's training, is heard increasingly here, just one sign of the divisions that afflict this country.
Little more than three years since a return to democratic government, Pakistan is caught in a spiral of increasing lawlessness in many parts of the country. It is at war in all but name with neighboring India. A conflict between a resurgent Islamic clergy and an urban, Western-educated elite undermines efforts to forge a consensus on how Pakistan will approach the 21st century. 
 The Government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif is bedeviled by gossip, barraged by accusations of venality, castigated by the opposition and threatened by a final rupture of cordiality with the United States.
In 12 months in office, the cherub-cheeked Mr. Sharif has defied his detractors with the speed at which he has restructured the country's economy and with his tenacity at fending off political challenges.
 
State Industries Sold
 On the auction block is virtually every state industry and most of its banks. Gone are restrictions on foreign investment, on holding foreign exchange, on imports and exports. Gone, too, are many of the onerous bureaucratic regulations that have stifled private industry. The stock market has soared, and Japanese and European investors are sniffing around.
But critics, including his archrival and former Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, say officials in Mr. Sharif's Government have been equally eager to use their influence to fill the pockets of relatives and friends. Equally alarming, at least to urban, Western-educated intellectuals, is the Prime Minister's steady accession to the aggressive demands of Pakistan's religious right for a more rigid Islamic society. Indeed, the first public hangings and floggings under sharia, Islamic law, have been announced in recent weeks.
"Nawaz had everything you could conceivably think of going for him," said Najam Sethi, editor of The Friday Times, an independent weekly in Lahore that has been investigating assertions of corruption in the Government. "There were great expectations, great promises. Now all of this is stalled. The Government is efficient, unlike Benazir's Government. But it is corrupt, absolutely, astronomically corrupt, including the Prime Minister. The Government is reeling from it. Its back is to the wall. The opposition is having a field day."
The Prime Minister's senior press adviser, Husain Haqqani, derided the Government's critics.
"There is a concerted effort by some politicians in opposition, and some of their friends who are not friends of Pakistan, to weaken this Government and weaken the structure of government," he said. "They find that democracy is flourishing, that free enterprise is flourishing, and it is not happening under Miss Bhutto."
Few of this country's realities intrude on the sterile placidity of this planned capital's straight boulevards, crisp new Government buildings and palatial diplomatic houses. That nearly one in 10 infants die at birth here, that fewer than one in four people can read, that Pakistan remains one of the poorest countries in the world, stands in contrast to the well-stocked shops here and the important men with their portable cellular phones.
But beyond this city, problems are rising for Mr. Sharif. In Sind, the southernmost state, crime and violence have flared out of control as ethnic strife rumbles through the countryside. In Punjab, his native state, 700,000 people, mostly poor, lost all their savings when the state's cooperative societies, entities somewhat akin to American savings and loans, went bankrupt. Even as those co-ops failed, it emerged that the same societies had granted billions of rupees in loans to Mr. Sharif's family concern, the Ittefaq Group, a conglomerate of steel, sugar and textile industries.
Although Ittefaq hurriedly repaid the loans when the collapse of the co-ops was apparent, the damage to the Prime Minister's reputation was severe. Opposition politicians, including Miss Bhutto, have demanded Mr. Sharif's resignation, and even the country's docile newspapers questioned the Prime Minister's judgment.
Mr. Haqqani, the Prime Minister's spokesman, argued that public anger was misplaced because Pakistan does not have the same conflict-of-interest laws as Western countries.
"There are no laws barring officeholders from retaining business interests," Mr. Haqqani said. "Until we have codes and laws, it is unfair to make that into an issue."
In the end, though, what appears to matter to domestic policy is not the extent of allegations against Mr. Sharif but his two-thirds majority in Parliament.
But more often than not in recent weeks, it is not the financial peccadillos of Government that absorb the attention of urban Pakistanis, but the more salacious intimations about the Government that this country's press hestitates to report.
Across the border in India, one of that country's most respected and acerbic columnists, Tavleen Singh, has written that Mr. Sharif has been having an affair with an Indian film star. Apart from the scandal that would be attached to any Pakistani Prime Minister wooing an Indian woman, what has been bandied about this capital is the belief that Mr. Sharif, to defeat the telephone tapping of his calls to the young woman, serenades her instead with ballads from Indian musical films. The Prime Minister, for his part, has scoffed at the assertion.
More substantial, but even more titillating, has been the arrest of a woman the papers here call Madame Tahira for managing a bordello. In this country, where Islamic values are increasingly being imposed on the population, running a prostitution ring is among the greater sins. But what Madame Tahira told the police was that some of the most ardent proponents of Islamization in the Pakistani Senate were among her clients.
A leading cleric and Senator, Samiul Haq, rose on the floor of the Senate to criticize suggestions that he had been a customer of Madame Tahira's establishment.
"Fifty thousand women cannot stop me from carrying on with my mission," he said. "What will my wives and children think? I am a leader of a religious party, and other parties consider me a soldier of Islam."
But The Nation newspaper snidely observed of Mr. Haq's oration, "Interestingly, the Senator at no stage in his speech made any attempt to deny anything of what has been alleged against him by Madame Tahira."
The religious right maintains that the whole affair is a plot to discredit the influence of the clerics in national life. By whom, they do not say. But here in Islamabad, the details of Madame Tahira's taped confession to the police leaking into the alternative press provide some relief from the more routine political skirmishings and financial scandals facing the country.

HEADLINE: Mayor Returns From Africa, Buoyed by Trip

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins returned to New York City yesterday after six days of seeing poverty and racism in South Africa, saying, "It sure in blazes helps one put things in perspective." He added that some of the daily political troubles he faces at City Hall "are less important than they were before."
Asked what he meant, he told reporters traveling with him just before his plane landed at Kennedy International Airport, "Let me just say that, as the expression goes, some of those people that have been telling lies about me, I may decide to tell the truth about them." 
 Minutes later, summing up the highs of a trip that repaid Nelson Mandela's visit to New York, Mr. Dinkins struggled to hold back tears at a news conference as he recalled his reception in black townships and the courage of those he met.
The Mayor was clearly buoyed by his first visit to Africa, especially by a traditional homecoming ceremony at the home of Oliver Tambo, the African National Congress chairman, in which blessings were offered to him and his wife, Joyce. "I am now protected," he told reporters. Asked against what, he replied, "Against anti-forces."
But Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, who traveled with him and organized the trip, eyed the reporters and added, "Against you all."
 
Met With Foreign Minister
 Besides meeting with several black groups and negotiating training programs in which black and white businesses would send managers to New York for training, Mr. Dinkins met for 45 minutes on his way out of the country with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha, after efforts to schedule an appointment with the Government had not panned out.
"We had quite an exchange," said the Mayor, who argued for continued economic sanctions against South Africa until an interim government is formed to begin drafting a new constitution, while Mr. Botha argued that the sanctions were hurting the economy and the lot of blacks. Mr. Dinkins said neither changed his position, but added, "I think he and I have come to understand each other better."
The Mayor acknowledged that it would be scant comfort to New Yorkers suffering poverty and problems of their own that conditions in South Africa were worse, and said he was not arguing that. The Mayor said he would have been ashamed if he had called off the trip in the face of criticism. Asked if his critics should now be ashamed, he said, "Yes."

HEADLINE: A Place in the Sun for le Cinema

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SARASOTA, Fla., Nov. 17

 BODY:
The third annual Sarasota French Film Festival, a five-day mini-extravaganza that began on Thursday, is at once a public forum for new French films, a marketplace and a subsidized opportunity for members of the French film industry to schmooze, which they do with all the elaborate rituals and cozy familiarity displayed by the pelicans and seagulls that cluster on Sarasota's gorgeous white-sand beaches.
It is also, of course, an opportunity for Sarasota to obtain ample coverage in the French press and for Sarasotans to hobnob with a glamorous slice of the French cinematic haut monde. But this is really a French production. The festival was originally intended to be supported half by the French Government and French corporations and half by state and private money from Florida. The French have now assumed about 60 percent of the $800,000 in costs, counting such contributions as air tickets to bring some 150 French and American industry leaders, stars and journalists to Sarasota. 
 Such corporate support is not inconsiderable. "These are not people used to flying tourist class," observed Daniel Toscan du Plantier, a French film producer, record-company chief (Erato), president of Unifrance (the trade organization to promote French films abroad) and the guiding light behind the Sarasota festival.
 
Art vs., Commerce
 If film is an uneasy balance between art and commerce, the Sarasota festival reflects that tension with uncanny accuracy. On the one hand, it is a self-respecting forum for cinematic excellence, its 20 films this year having been selected by an artistic director, the critic Molly Haskell, from 70 candidates.
Her selections this year suggest that traditional French film values are still very much in evidence. The films concentrated on sex and romance, with women supposedly exerting their own kind of power through feminine wiles; on relations between lovers of widely divergent ages; on tensions between children and adults, and above all on poverty with a comedic or romantic twist: if New Yorkers fret about their own homeless, they should see the graphic depictions of Parisian poverity in Gerard Jugnot's "Epoque Formidable" and Leos Carax's "Amants du Pont-Neuf." This is hardly a trend limited to France, to judge from "The Fisher King," but the French expand on it with typical Gallic flair.
The festival is also a blatant commercial showcase. Should Ms. Haskell decline to present a film with a powerful company's patronage behind it, it could simply be offered under the rubric "Unifrance Presents." While defending the basic integrity of her choices, Ms. Haskell conceded that compromise was built into the process.
The French want a showcase, a Cannes-like environment with a human scale and what they rather patronizingly call "a real audience," by which they mean an untutored one, to prove the supposed universality of their movies. They also want an American equivalent to the French Deauville Festival, which presents new American films, because they complain bitterly about the imbalance between American films shown in France, amounting to some 55 percent of the market there, and French films seen here, which total 0.6 percent of the American box office.
"The equilibrium is ridiculous," grumbled Pierre Lescure, president of Canal Plus, the French pay-television monopoly whose huge profits ("It's hundreds of millions of dollars annually, but nobody knows for sure," said Mr. Toscan du Plantier) have made it a powerful new force in both French and international film financing.
While the French agree they would like a larger share of the American market, the consensus breaks down there. Underneath the polite talk of face-to-face exchanges of ideas and gentle persuasion lie dire threats, including the possible imposition of quotas on American films in France. "We have less than 1 percent of the American market," Mr. Toscan du Plantier said, "but that's not the demand; it's what's being offered the American public."
Most of the talk, however, concerns less conspiratorial matters. The French are convinced that language is the principal barrier to wider acceptance of their films, but are unsure how to overcome that barrier. The traditional American audience for foreign films prefers subtitles, used at this festival. To reach a true mass audience, the French believe films must be dubbed, as in Europe. But the American distributors are convinced that mass American audiences will reject dubbing, pointing to video sales of films in both versions in which subtitles outsell their dubbed competition 8 to 1. "We cannot afford to alienate our prime market," argued Meyer Gottlieb, president of the Samuel Goldwyn Company.
Harvey Weinstein, co-chairman of Miramax, a major New York-based distributor, felt that dubbing could reach a mass market here after one breakthrough film. But Mr. Toscan du Plantier spoke more guardedly of increasing the American audience to 2 or 3 percent, appealing to an elite that "thinks foreign things are sophisticated."
In fact, about one-third of the Sarasota films do find United States distribution, which Mr. Toscan du Plantier said is a decent average. And Michael Barker of Orion Classics, which has sold $61 million worth of tickets to the 30 French films it has disbributed since 1983, said the American market for French films had actually increased by 20 percent over the last 8 years.
 
Slow Pace a Factor
 But an exposure to 10 French films over the first 3 days of this festival suggested other, subtler reasons for the failure of so many films here, beyond language. French films move at a slower, more discursive pace than American films. They dwell on dialogue and personal relations instead of slam-bang action. Too many French sound tracks use accordions.
Some of that may reflect an invidious comparison between present-day French films and both their own, glorious past and American films today, which have come of age. The top prize at the last three Cannes festivals has been taken by an American entry, and Gerard Depardieu, the reigning star of French film and this year's Sarasota festival, argued bluntly that "French films are not as serious as Hollywood films; in France, everyone makes movies, but they don't take enough care with them."
French insularity may be changing now, for better or worse. There are those who contend that the recent vast amounts of television and private money available for film production will upset the traditional economic balance of the French film industry, threatening the typical small French film.
"France has too much money for films now," said Dominique Wallon, head of the French Government's principal agency for film production, the Centre National de la Cinematographie. "We have to export it." Nicolas Seydoux, who runs Gaumont, the oldest film company in the world (since 1895), took a sanguine view. "You always have new people with new money, and there is always inflation involved," he said.
Unlike Cannes or Berlin, Sarasota offers no prizes, but that did not preclude a consensus on this year's best films. Maurice Pialat's "Van Gogh," an admirably dispassionate, historically accurate look at the painter's last months, which many in Sarasota admired particularly, ultimately paled before Mr. Carax's blend of horrific realism and operatic romanticism. "Les Amants du Pont-Neuf" is the story of two homeless young people, a painter slipping into blindness (Juliette Binoche) and an alcoholic schizophrenic fire eater (Daniel Lavant), two true sans-culottes at the French bicentennial. The film triumphantly overcomes the seeming inappropriateness of its subject with Mr. Carax's thrilling grasp of the medium and the performances of his actors.
The director, who is only 30 years old, would have no part of any notion of a mutually beneficial French film community, an idea he dismissed as "superficial." "In 10 years, I have talked to only one or two other movie makers," he said. "Every director in France today is like a resistance fighter in his own corner, regarding everyone else as an invader."
As if to reinforce his attitude, he could be found a few minutes later hunkered down on a beach chair with a book, fully dressed, as the rest of the French frolicked in the distance. If by his isolation Mr. Carax symbolized the gulf between cinematic art and commerce, he was also, by his very presence in Sarasota, reaffirming their links.

HEADLINE: Musicians Take Their Case to the Audience

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
With their contract negotiations moving along at a tempo somewhat slower than adagio, the musicians of the New York Philharmonic have taken up an unusual form of behind-the-scenes lobbying. On Sunday evening, about 10 of the musicians turned up at the author E. L. Doctorow's home in New Rochelle to play chamber music for about 30 of Mr. Doctorow's friends, neighbors and colleagues and to give them an idea of some of the issues that might lead to the orchestra's first strike since 1973.
The chamber music evening at Mr. Doctorow's house was the eighth private performance the players have given since Nov. 1, mostly in Manhattan, at the homes of authors, college professors and others who promise to bring them sympathetic and, ideally, influential listeners. Among those who attended Mr. Doctorow's party were the authors William Styron and Avery Corman. 
 The Philharmonic's music director, Kurt Masur, was also there. But although several of the players described his presence as a show of solidarity, Mr. Masur, who must maintain good relations with both the management and his musicians, was more guarded.
 
Positive Spirit Perceived
 "I'm here for an evening of chamber music," Mr. Masur said. "I have no role in the negotiations. I think that the spirit of both sides is so positive that I'm full of hope that they will find a good solution. But first they have to find out what is possible, and that they can believe each other."
Sitting in the last of four rows of chairs in Mr. Doctorow's living room, Mr. Masur listened intently to his musicians' accounts of Mozart's Flute Quartet in A (K. 298) and the Schubert "Trout" Quintet, and he shook hands with them afterward. But he declined to have his picture taken with a group of the players. "This would not be good for you," he quietly explained to them. "If there's a picture, then there's a story. You don't want a story. You want results."
That result is what the musicians are calling "a breakaway contract," one that will make the Philharmonic the highest-paid orchestra in the United States. In a leaflet attached to the concert programs, they listed their reasons as including the high cost of living in New York and "the psychological pressures we undergo by performing in the world's cultural capital -- before the most sophisticated and knowledgeable audiences in the world."
 
Principle of Being First
 The players refused, however, to discuss their specific demands or the Philharmonic's offers except to say that the two sides are not close. "The principle that the Philharmonic be treated as the first among this country's orchestras is more important than the dollars," said Evangeline Benedetti, a cellist who is also on the negotiating committee.
But some of the musicians referred to "the strike" as if it were already on. And the players seemed emphatic in their agreement that the contract the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and its players signed in September would not be adequate for them. The Chicago contract gives the musicians minimum salaries of $61,800 this year, and $67,600 in 1993.
Under the contract that expired on Sept. 20, and that the players have extended until Dec. 6, the minimum Philharmonic salary is $58,240 for eight services a week. A service is a performance or rehearsal, which typically lasts two and a half hours.
"We feel as if we are always riding on Chicago's coat tails, and settling for what they got," said Glenn Dicterow, the Philharmonic's concertmaster. "It's time we were the trailblazers."
 
Economic Pressure Cited
 Deborah Borda, the orchestra's managing director -- and the player's direct opponent in the negotiations -- said yesterday that she had not attended any of the orchestra's chamber music evenings, but that she knew about them and liked the idea.
"They are reaching out to the community," Ms. Borda said, "and that can only be a good thing." Like the players, though, she would not comment specifically on the negotiations or on management's position.
"I understand their desire to be thought of as the greatest orchestra in America, or the world. But that is determined by one fact, which is how they play. What we can pay them is a separate judgment. Obviously, the economic position of the city, and the entire country, have some bearing on what we are trying to do. You can't negotiate in a vacuum. The economy has put pressure on every arts institution."
It was a conversation between Mr. Dicterow and Mr. Doctorow that led to the gathering on Sunday. "Glenn is my neighbor," the author said, "and he explained to me the problems they were having and said that the players wanted to get the word out. So I said, let's do something. I find it wonderful that their idea of union agitation is to play the 'Trout' Quintet."
The musicians could not say what effect its chamber music parties might have. But they said that they intended to continue them, and that they would like to present some free public performances if they could find the right place to do it.
Renee Siebert, a flutist and the chairwoman of the players' negotiating committee, said:
"These are difficult times for us. We're trained to play music, not to go to negotiation meetings. But there is a strong spirit in the orchestra now, and greater excitement than I've felt in the 17 years I've been there. A lot of it has to do with Kurt Masur.
"We are also feeling a new sense of ourselves as an orchestra that is part of the city, part of the community, and we don't see evenings like this as one-time things that we're doing just because of the possible strike. We've been separate from our audience for too long. We want to change that, and not only by playing in private homes. We have a political committee that is looking into things we can do for the city: playing concerts for needy causes, or whatever might be needed of us."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
The Penguins Are Sold But Price Is a Mystery

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
The sale of the Pittsburgh Penguins to a group headed by Howard Baldwin and Morris Belzberg was formally approved yesterday at a meeting of the National Hockey League Board of Governors in Manhattan.
Baldwin said the franchise had a value "in the $45 million range" but he declined to reveal how much he and Belzberg were paying. Spectacor Management Group, which operates sports facilities in many cities, is buying the lease to the Pittsburgh Civic Arena for $24 million in a separate agreement announced earlier this autumn. 
 The precise amount of money changing hands for the team remains vague. The N.H.L. said the two transactions "produced a value of $65 million." Less than two weeks ago, Baldwin said the Penguins were being bought for $36 million. Earlier reports this autumn, confirmed by Belzberg, listed the price at $31 million. In addition, the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation, the former owner, will retain a limited partnership in the Penguins.
Baldwin and Belzberg and the N.H.L. president, John Ziegler, were vague as to what the limited partnership means in terms of revenue or ownership interest. Ziegler said the DeBartolos will retain "some revenue streams" from the franchise that "may not develop." He said the limited partnership could not be described as a percentage of ownership.
 
Different Ways of Adding It Up
 "You can put different valuations on how much that is worth," Ziegler said, referring to the revenue streams. "The number may add up one way in one accounting and may come up differently in another." One possible formula could dictate that the former owners take a percentage of profit over and above a pre-determined figure. In return, they lower the sale price. It's one of many theories making the rounds in Pittsburgh.
Baldwin, formerly involved with ownership of the Hartford Whalers and the Minnesota North Stars, once again denied rumors that he and his partners planned to sell some of Pittsburgh's high-salaried players to reduce the payroll. He said he and Belzberg plan to seek local investors as partners in the near future. Paul Martha, the Penguins' vice president, had tried to buy all or part of the team but was not mentioned in yesterday's announcement. Baldwin said Martha's role would be announced Tuesday at a news conference in Pittsburgh.
Ziegler said the sale was approved by at least three-quarters of the league's 22 teams, but he declined to give a specific vote total. The board was concerned with the original structure of the deal, Ziegler said.
 
No Plan to Move Team
 "We asked them to put up more money and borrow less," Ziegler said. Ziegler said he was convinced that the new owners didn't plan to move the team. "We believe in their word," he said.
The N.H.L. is planning to expand to 24 teams next season if Tampa and Ottawa can finish paying their $50 million entry fee and satisfy other conditions of operation. The Islanders are for sale and their owner, John Pickett, has said he wants more than $55 million for the franchise, which doesn't include the lease to operate Nassau Coliseum for anything other than Islander games.
Many prospective expansion-team owners dropped out of the bidding for franchises last year, saying that the $50 million fee was unrealistically high for a league with a minor United States network television contract in the middle of a recession. The league's regular-season attendance dropped last season by 235,754 to 12,343,897 over 840 games. The board will meet again in December in Palm Beach, Fla., to discuss expansion and other matters. Tampa and Ottawa must pay the remaining $22.5 million on their entry fee by Dec. 16.

HEADLINE: What Doomed the Maya? Maybe Warfare Run Amok

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

DATELINE: NASHVILLE

 BODY:
AFTER hacking through tropical jungles in Central America and turning up stones of magnificent temples and tombs, archeologists over the years built up in their minds an idealized image of the Maya people who once flourished where now only wilderness thrives.
The Mayas' civilization was clearly the greatest to flourish in pre-Columbian America. They studied the heavens to devise precise calendars, created a true writing system and built imposing cities, with no evidence of any fortifications. Hence, archeologists assumed, the Mayas were an unusually gentle, peaceful people living in a relatively benign theocracy ruled by sage priest-kings. 
 But the earlier archeologists apparently got it wrong. In the last few years scholars have made great strides in translating the Mayas' previously indecipherable writing system. From the emerging texts and from recent excavations has emerged a new, at times bewildering, picture of the Maya civilization at its peak, from A.D. 250 to 900. Great as their cultural and economic achievements manifestly were, they had anything but a peaceful society.
Indeed, the latest feeling among scholars is that the increasing militarism of Maya society may have undermined the ecological underpinnings of the economy. Some of them speculate that siege warfare concentrated population in urban centers, caused desperate farmers to abandon previously successful practices of diversified agriculture and led to overexploitation of the forest.
Dr. Arthur A. Demarest, an archeologist at Vanderbilt University here who directs an ambitious Maya dig in Guatemala, said the evidence from stone art and texts points to the surprising conclusion that "the Maya were one of the most violent state-level societies in the New World, especially after A.D. 600."
Various writings and artifacts, Dr. Demarest said, indicate continual raiding and warfare between the elites of adjacent city-states and also the practice of ritual bloodletting and human sacrifice. The prestige of ruling dynasties, and hence their power, seemed to depend on their success in battle and the sacrifice of prisoners of war.
Dr. Linda Schele, a Maya scholar at the University of Texas at Austin, writes in this month's issue of Natural History magazine, "We don't know if the early Maya went to war mainly to acquire territory, take booty, control conquered groups for labor, take captives for sacrifice in sanctification rituals or a combination of these."
Whatever the specific goal, archeologists think that for centuries the wars were limited to ritualized conflicts between the elite troops of two rulers. The losing ruler was sometimes decapitated with great ceremony, as depicted in Maya art.
Dr. David Freidel, an archeologist at Southern Methodist University, surmises that Maya conflicts functioned to maintain a balance of power between city-states of roughly equal strength. He has called this a system of "peace through war."
But recent excavations by Dr. Demarest's team at the ancient city of Dos Pilas, in northern Guatemala, have revealed the remains of extensive fortifications seemingly erected in haste and other evidence that the character and scope of Maya warfare began to change in the seventh or eighth century. These signs of siege warfare, Dr. Demarest said, indicate an escalation of militarism involving the general population in a desperate fight for survival.
Therein may lie telling clues to the most enduring mystery about the Maya civilization -- its sudden collapse. Dr. Demarest speculates that increasingly destructive warfare disrupted the delicate balance that Maya farmers had been able to maintain for centuries in the rich but fragile tropical-forest ecosystem.
By the 10th century, Dos Pilas and other cities of the lowland Maya culture were abandoned, survived mainly by newer cities on the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico.
"It's a very exciting time in Maya studies," Dr. Demarest said. "It's time for new editions of all the textbooks."
 
Writing on the Wall
Monumental Texts On Love and War
 The critical turning point, archeologists agree, has come with the steady progress in deciphering Maya writings, complex hieroglyphics that once were thought to be incomprehensible. Scholars can now read monumental texts documenting the ascent to power of rulers, their marriages and alliances and especially their wars. Scholars are thus better able to interpret the temple ruins and stones graven with scenes of dynastic triumphs and gory ritual.
"No Egyptian tomb's discovery was ever more exhilarating than the decipherment process under way today," Dr. Freidel said. "We can now perceive the Maya past through the words and exploits of kings and queens and high nobility. We can talk about real historical individuals making difficult decisions about their government and its policies."
In what is now called the Classic Period, from 250 to 900, the Mayas built some 200 cities in southern Mexico, Guatemala, Belize and parts of Honduras and El Salvador. Places like Palenque, Tikal and Copan, with their soaring pyramids bespeaking wealth and a powerful ideology, represent the splendors of the period.
More recent discoveries, however, have revealed that the civilization was prospering in the southern lowlands of Guatemala centuries before the classic period.
Two years ago, Dr. Richard Hansen of the University of California at Los Angeles reported uncovering at the site of Nakbe the ruins of pyramids and stone buildings dating back some 2,600 years. In the same region, El Mirador, one of the largest Maya cities ever excavated, was settled some 2,500 years ago, rose to prominence with all the architectural accoutrements of royal power and then vanished in the first century.
Research at El Mirador and Nakbe and other pre-Classic ruins has led scholars to the recognition that the Maya civilization evolved earlier and was more complex and heterogeneous than had been thought. Since the Aztecs of central Mexico had not risen to prominence and power this early, archeologists can no longer attribute the rise of the Maya culture to their influence. Maya origins remain clouded, scholars say.
Dr. Peter Mathews, a Maya scholar at the University of Calgary in Canada, has analyzed the "emblem glyphs" of Maya rulers to establish the outlines of the political boundaries of the classic city-states. These glyphs appear like a crest on all the monuments of a period and place. By tracing the extent of their occurrence, Dr. Mathews could define the territory controlled by a particular ruler. Often the radius of a ruler's domain was no more than the distance a person could walk or travel by canoe in a day.
Some archeologists believe these cities were organized into some kind of loose political confederation. But new evidence seems to contradict this view. Instead, these myriad city-states were linked simply by elite interactions, trade and ideology into a single ethnically distinct system. Dr. Freidel and Dr. Jeremy Sabloff, a Maya archeologist at the University of Pittsburgh, refer to it as a "peer-polity" network.
 
Violence Abounds
Celebrating With Bloodletting
 Even the ruins of the early cities, archeologists point out, bear witness to a violent Maya past. Stones depict severed heads and rulers of these kingdoms standing with bound captives. In other ruins, archeologists have found the dismembered or decapitated remains of sacrificed victims buried under floors of public buildings.
So Dr. Schele, a leading epigrapher analyzing the Maya hieroglyphs, has concluded that "war was already a part of Maya life at the beginning of their written history, some 2,000 years ago."
The first war known from a readable record was fought in 378 between Tikal and Uaxactun, two city-states in the Peten, which is a tropical-forest region of northern Guatemala. Dr. Mathews made this discovery in deciphering descriptions on stone monuments at both cities. Dr. Freidel and Dr. Schele concluded that this had been a war of conquest.
Dr. Schele said a stone monument at Uaxactun noted the date of the conflict and the name of the victorious general, Smoking-Frog. The other side of the monument depicts Smoking-Frog holding an obsidian-edged club and a spear-thrower and wearing battle garb.
Another monument at Tikal records the same date and establishes that the city's ruler was Great-Jaguar-Paw, who celebrated the victory with a ceremony of bloodletting from his genitals. Smoking-Frog, his brother, eventually succeeded him to power, but ruled from Uaxactun. Scholars consider this strong evidence of territorial gain in a war of conquest.
The rise of Maya militarism and the transition from limited conflicts to total warfare has been most clearly illuminated in the archeological and epigraphic discoveries by Dr. Demarest's Vanderbilt team. They are exploring the Peten jungle near Lake Petexbatun in northern Guatemala, where the Mayas had six great cities and many villages.
The most revealing site so far has been Dos Pilas, a large city-state founded early in the seventh century, perhaps by people from Tikal. Last year the archeologists uncovered a huge stone stairway with carved images of warfare and the torture and execution of captives and also inscribed with hieroglyphs describing events in the city's early history.
As deciphered by Dr. Stephen D. Houston and David Stuart, young Vanderbilt epigraphers, the text documents a series of wars in the reign of Ruler I, the unnamed king in the late seventh century. The wars were between the Dos Pilas dynasty and their royal relatives at Tikal. And they ended with the defeat of Tikal in 678 and the capture and sacrifice of the Tikal king, Shield-Skull.
The next 70 years, Dr. Demarest said, Dos Pilas thrived as a military power, expanding by conquest of neighboring states, by marriage alliances and by some kind of alliance with the distant metropolis of Calakmul, in Mexico. Eventually Dos Pilas controlled more than 2,000 square miles of rain forest territory, possibly the largest kingdom in Maya history.
 
Ecological Notes
A Few Lessons For Society Today
 In assessing the mounting evidence of Maya warfare, archeologists remained puzzled by what they had not found -- any ruins of fortifications or hint that settlements were established in defensible positions. This might be understandable in the centuries of limited conflicts, when the victors did not actually conquer defeated territories, but simply returned home with a few noble captives for public sacrifice. But where were the fortifications for the escalating general warfare toward the end of the classic period?
Excavations in the last two years at Dos Pilas have supplied the answer. The Vanderbilt archeologists found the remains of hastily constructed concentric walls around the main palaces and temples. A peninsula in the lake had been cut off from the mainland by moats, creating an island fortress.
The desperate nature of the siege, Dr. Demarest said, can be seen where palisade walls were erected by dismantling palace facades for the stones. In one case, a defensive wall ran directly through the center of the royal palace. Spear points and skeletons of decapitated young men were found near the walls. Within some walls were the remains of a crudely constructed village, presumably where people from the embattled countryside had sought refuge.
Dos Pilas, Dr. Demarest said, became "a post-apocalyptic, totally militarized landscape." The city-state was defeated in 760, its ruler decapitated and his kingdom splintered into warring factions, never to rise again.
One of the many enigmas of the Mayas is that they managed to achieve what few major civilizations have done, supporting a complex society and large population on the thin soil and dispersed resources of tropical forests. Exactly how this was accomplished is poorly understood.
But the emerging view of the lowland Classic Maya culture suggests possible causes for the civilization's disintegration.
Reviewing the evidence, Dr. Demarest noted that the needs of defense could not violate the fundamental tenets of the Mayas' adaptation to rain forest living: dispersion and diversity of agriculture. Their ecology decreed that warfare had to be limited in just the way that is reflected in the archeological ruins. Before 700 in the lowlands of Guatemala at least, the Maya lived mostly in outlying settlements near their fields and in large cities, all undefended and apparently exempt from raiding.
As warfare became more widespread, Dr. Demarest and others have concluded, food shortages forced the peasants into destructive farming practices and drove others into overcrowded, impoverished cities for protection behind stone walls. The balance between ecology and "peace through war" had been fatally disrupted.
Dr. Demarest has also explored the causes for the rising militarism and speculates that it could have resulted from a case of too many chiefs. It was probably not a general population explosion that contributed to the collapse, as has been conjectured, but a sharp increase in the elite population.
"Too many noblemen were competing for power," Dr. Demarest said. "Princes are expensive. Everyone has got to have a palace, jade and expensive dress. They compete for nonutilitarian, status-reinforcing goods and for warriors to fight their wars. They tend to be selfish and think only of the short term."
Dr. Demarest paused, then suggested an analogy between the Mayas and contemporary American society. "You might say we have a too-many-elites situation ourselves," he said. "Nobody wants to be blue collar anymore."
For the Classic Maya, at any rate, archeologists are beginning to recognize that the power of rulers may have derived less from economic or territorial control than ideology. Maya art and architecture, Dr. Freidel said, shows that the Maya viewed their leaders as embodiments of the universe, and in exchange for privilege and power, elites provided religious services and acted as intermediaries with the spiritual world.
Such a political framework, Dr. Demarest suggested, sets the stage for expansion of spheres of influence through the force of a leader's charisma and through propaganda victories in inter-elite warfare. This, in turn, would account for the apparent instability of Maya states as seen in their rapid expansions and contractions. Their civilization endured these violent changes for centuries, but once the Mayas' style of life started to undermine the ecological basis on which it depended, their entire civilization rapidly collapsed and vanished into the jungle.

Reconstruction of Maya history surged after the crucial discovery that the inscriptions refer to real events and people and that a hieroglyph can be a phonetic syllable as well as a whole word or emblem.
 
Celebrating A Conqueror
 A large monument called a stela commemorates Ruler 3 of Dos Pilas, possibly the largest of all the Mayan kingdoms. On the left of this text are details from the large drawing at right, which glorifies the ruler with sacred symbols: 1, a mask of Tlaloc, a war deity; 2, a human skull, symbol of Venus, the war planet; 3, a jaguar head with the mandible of a butterfly, crowned with an owl; 4, jaguar boots and trappings, emblems of the fierce warrior and favorite ceremonial cloth; 5, the defeated, captive king who would probably have been tortured and, finally, decapitated.

 It has recently been discovered that Dos Pilas fell in A.D. 760. Researchers have found the foundations of stone walls built to protect the central precinct from the onslaught of another state, Tamarindito. Dos Pilas was defeated and abandoned. (Source: Arthur Demarest) (pg. C1)

HEADLINE: A Hoarder's Life: Filling the Cache -- And Finding It

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY

 BODY:
AS winter closes in, the stage has been set for the annual life-or-death struggle between the hoarders of food and the raiders they must fend off.
Lacking access to a year-round supermarket, the many species -- from ants to wolves -- that in the course of evolution have learned the advantages of hoarding must devote a lot of energy and ingenuity to protecting their stashes from marauders. 
 Creatures like beavers and honeybees, for example, hoard food to get them through cold winters. Others, like desert rodents that face food scarcities throughout the year, must take advantage of the short-lived harvests that follow occasional rains. For animals like burying beetles that dine on mice hundreds of times their size, a habit of biting off more than they can chew at the moment forces them to store their leftovers. Still others, like the male MacGregor's bowerbird, stockpile goodies during mating season so they can concentrate on wooing females and defending their arena de l'amour.
But for the convenience of having caches of food, these hoarders pay a price, noted Dr. Stephen P. Vander Wall, an ecologist at the University of Nevada, in his book "Food Hoarding in Animals," published last year by the University of Chicago Press. They must remember where they stashed it and defend it against others looking for a free lunch.
The hoarders have developed many different strategies to handle these problems. Some, like the eastern chipmunk, concentrate their supplies in underground burrows where it is easily guarded but risks being forfeited in a single raid. Others, like Clark's nutcracker and white-footed mice, spread their stores among hundreds of different sites which, though each is more vulnerable to raiders, give safety in numbers.
Locating buried food stores is a difficult task for which different species have evolved various strategies. Dr. Vander Wall has demonstrated how yellow pine chipmunks depend on memory of visual landmarks, not their sense of smell, to relocate caches. In an experiment he relocated the landmarks surrounding a chipmunk's storage site and found that though the animal came up empty-pawed, it dug in the correct spot in relation to the newly positioned landmarks.
 
A Prodigious Memory
 Gray squirrels, the ultimate practitioners of scattered storage, strain the limits of memory by storing each nut in a separate hole. Nonetheless, studies by Dr. Lucia Jacobs of the University of Utah strongly suggested that these busy little rodents do in fact remember where they put their nuts and may even respect the caches of their neighbors.
Dr. Jacobs dug up nuts the squirrels had buried and refilled the holes with other nuts. She also planted nuts in new holes nearby. But when it was the squirrels' turn to feed, they dug up the nuts she had buried in their own holes in preference to similar smelling nuts she had stashed in nearby holes that might have belonged to another squirrel.
But for most hoarding animals, there is keen competition for stored food. "Any creature that stores food faces myriad parasites and predators, and every foe has a different set of tools for getting through the hoarder's defenses, Dr. Thomas D. Seeley, an animal behaviorist at Cornell University, said in an interview.
As the author of "Honeybee Ecology: A Study of Adaptation in Social Life" (Princeton University Press), Dr. Seeley expressed great admiration for the way honeybees gather, use and defend their very rich energy supply.
 
Strategies of Honeybees
 He found that honeybees had evolved at least three strategies to protect the 60 pounds or so of honey that a colony of 15,000 bees needs to survive the winter:
*To prevent spoilage by fungi and bacteria, the bees treat the honey with an enzyme that generates free radicals, in effect sterilizing the honey with hydrogen peroxide. Then they remove most of the water, making the sugar too concentrated for microorganisms to survive.
*To defend against small predators, honeybees build a solid nest with a small opening that keeps out most invaders. Tiny intruders like ants that might try to sneak in are blown back by wing beats or pulled apart by a team of bees.
*And, of course, for large predators like bears and people, the bees are prepared to yield their lives by stinging.
 
Caches of Kangaroo Rats
 Kangaroo rats that live in the deserts of the Southwest have evolved quite a different strategy against spoilage. Dr. O. J. Reichman, a biologist at Kansas State University in Manhattan, said these desert rodents create huge underground storehouses containing hundreds of thousands of seeds that may be attacked by more than 30 species of fungi, some of which are beneficial but others of which produce powerful poisons.
Dr. Reichman said the animals seemed to "manage" fungal growth to favor benefits over risks. Preliminary evidence suggests that when the rats encounter a toxic substance, they can stop metabolizing it and thus prevent it from doing damage. On the other hand, he said, some fungi enhances the nutritive value of the rats' stored food, just as fermented soybeans are easier to digest than the bean itself. He showed that the rats could actively control fungal growth by repeatedly moving stored food to areas of different humidity.
Animals that eat fleshy foods have adopted a common farm technique to keep their stash from spoiling. As Dr. Vander Wall recounted in his book, small rabbit-like mammals called pikas, some of the small rodents called voles and the great gerbils that harvest fresh green vegetables in late summer and fall transport the food to hay piles near their burrows, where it slowly cures.
Some hoarders that remain active in cold weather take advantage of winter's natural refrigeration to prevent their stores from spoiling. In northern latitudes, the carcasses of rodents stored by owls in winter often freeze. Before the birds can eat, their frozen dinner must be thawed, which the owl accomplishes by sitting on the meal as if it were an egg.
 
Keeping Prey Alive
 Another way to increase the shelf life of stored prey is to keep the meal alive until the hoarder is ready to dine. Shrikes have been seen to impale their live prey on thorns or barbed wire, where the doomed captives can only wait to become dinner. Spiders often wrap their wriggling prey in silk, and spider wasps, in turn, inflict paralyzing stings on the spiders they catch. Short-tailed shrews transmit a toxin in their saliva that renders mice, earthworms and insects comatose, allowing the prey to remain alive for five days without escaping, spoiling or losing nutritive value.
Often, one species' loss is another's gain. The yellow pine chipmunk, which prepares thousands of caches of seeds each fall, never recovers all of them before the spring germination begins. In this way the chipmunk becomes a primary seed sower of yellow pine and antelope bitterbrush, a shrub that deer depend on for food, Dr. Vander Wall explained.
Indeed, some plants have adapted through evolution to make themselves more attractive to hoarding animals. For example, Dr. Vander Wall has reported, certain soft pines with wingless seeds that are not otherwise readily dispersed have evolved to produce cones with highly nutritious, large seeds that are easily harvested by jays and nutcrackers.
Other plants, like the lodgepole pine, have evolved in the opposite direction. Red squirrels are avid foragers of the lodgepole's cones, hoarding perhaps 15 or more bushels of cones in a midden and storing them under thick mats of old cone debris where they have virtually no chance to establish seedlings.
 
Keeping Out Competitors
 Dr. Chrisopher C. Smith, a professor of biology at Kansas State University, said the tree's response was to produce seeds that were unattractive and hard for the squirrels to harvest. But the squirrel also evolved, developing stronger jaw muscles that enable the animal to open the tough, spiny cones.
Some animals seem to invite marauders. Communities of acorn woodpeckers stockpile huge quantities of food by drilling thousands of shallow wedge-shaped holes into the trunks of dead trees and stuffing each hole with just the right size nut.
As the nuts dry out and shrink, Dr. Vander Wall explained, the birds move them to smaller holes, wedging them in so tightly that animals without long beaks are hard put to remove them. Nonetheless, the colony has sentry birds that stand watch over the food supply, defending it against squirrels and other potential thieves.
Honey ants of the Southwest take no chances on predation or spoilage; worker ants called "repletes" store the colony's food in their turgid bodies, then hang like quartered lambs from the ceiling of domed chambers where they regurgitate food as needed by their colony-mates.
But, as studies of the eastern chipmunk have shown, all is far from perfect in the world of food hoarders. Lang Elliott, then at the University of Maryland, found that the two-to-three-year supply of beechnuts stored in underground burrows by the chipmunks was attacked by beetles, infected by blue mold and pilfered by other chipmunks. Many of the nuts that survived this onslaught germinated, leaving the rodent with a small return on its food-storing investment.
Yet the energy expended in food gathering and hoarding must be outweighed by caloric gain or the hoarding genes would themselves fall prey to natural selection, Dr. Vander Wall noted.
"No one knows what proportion of stored food actually gets eaten," he said. "I suspect that it is half or more, but that is only a guess. Clark's nutcracker, the species I studied as a graduate student, stores two to three times the seeds it needs, so that even if the bird recovers only a third of what it stores, it is enough to survive the winter and enable it to breed in spring."
Still, he added, the animals with the best return on their investments are those that "cheat" by stealing the food stored by others, in some cases their own friends and relatives. In an experiment that simulated the caches of northwestern crows in Vancouver, more than 80 percent of clams stored by the researchers disappeared within seven days, and nearly 85 percent of horse chestnuts buried in the soil in a Canadian cemetery were removed by gray squirrels over a period of five months. In another experiment involving nutcracker-like food hoards, 57 to 95 percent of the stored nuts were snatched by cache robbers.
Another factor influencing the economics of food hoarding is the energy expended to retrieve the stored food, especially for animals that widely scatter their hoards. Studies by J. David Henry in Saskatchewan and others showed that red foxes have a bookkeeping system; they urinate to mark cache sites after they have removed the food from them. This may tell the animals not to bother digging at the site because the cache is empty even though it retains a lingering odor of food, Dr. Vander Wall suggested.
The Nevada biologist, who spent five years collecting and analyzing nearly 1,500 scientific reports on food hoarding to produce his book, said there were still many unanswered questions to invite future research. "In 10 years, I suspect it won't be possible to collect all the findings on food hoarding between the covers of one book," he said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
The Fan Who Pays The Salary

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
AT a Knick game in Madison Square Garden recently, a fan in a sweatshirt and jeans stood at courtside and shouted hello to the players. An usher came over. "C'mon, move it," he said. "Get up to where you belong." The guy had apparently found his way to the classy seats from the boonies.
"Hey, whaddya pushin'?' " the guy said to the usher. "I'm payin' these guys' salaries."
Some people in the vicinity, in suit and tie, smiled at his presumption, this guy paying Patrick Ewing his $30 million. Fact is, he is certainly contributing, and so were those nearby. And they are paying more and more, and often getting less and less. 
 This is not just with the Knicks, but with the other teams in town, too.
This came to mind when the Mets announced recently that they were raising ticket prices. Most seats for home games next season will be priced at $1 more than they were this year: If, say, you had a loge or reserved mezzanine seat last season for $11, you'll pay $12 this season; if you had a field box for $14 before, you'll have to cough up $15 now.
And since the Mets fell from second place in the National League East in 1990 to fifth place in 1991, and there is no guarantee they'll improve in 1992, then what the Mets are asking the fan to do is pay more money for less winning baseball.
But wait, maybe there's hope: "We will be doing extensive retooling of our major league club and will be active in the free-agent market," said Frank Cashen, the club's senior executive vice president. "Our stated purpose is to return the Mets to the top spot in the National League."
That is, the Mets are hiking prices so fans can help pay for Viola's new multimillion-dollar contract, and so the Mets can perhaps entice Bonilla to join them for, say, $25 million for five years. Cashen's statement indicated that because the salaries of athletes have skyrocketed, the fans, despite being battered by a foul economy, must bear some of the burden.
The fans learn once again that they are, in effect, being held responsible for the poor money management of sports teams, which, at first blush, appears pretty looney. On second blush, the owners are able, in most cases, to sell their teams at huge profits, so the strategy of the fans digging deeper has its substantial rewards, for ownership. (The Mets were purchased by Nelson Doubleday and Fred Wilpon in 1980 for $21 million, and the team today is believed to be worth in the neighborhood of $250 million.)
But fans also seem to be paying the price for some of the cheesy personnel moves of Cashen and others, trading players who have succeeded in other places, and bringing in players who haven't succeeded in this place. Where have you gone, Kevin Mitchell?
So maybe the Mets are in a bind, and feel they have no choice but to raise ticket prices to try to patch up previous mistakes. Maybe they've hit their heads against a wall to devise other ways to garner the revenue, but this year, this one year, they've come up empty.
One might wish to bleed for them, until it is recalled that the Mets raised ticket prices the year before, and the year before that, and the year before that. Go back to 1985, the year before their winning the World Series.
At Shea Stadium, the reserved mezzanine, to use a typical example, was $7.50; the price rose in each succeeding year from $8 to $8.50 to $9 to $9.50 to $10 to $11 to the current, allegedly Viola-and-Bonilla inspired, $12. In fact, the worse the Mets do, the more attendance drops (they were over 3 million in 1987 and 1988, and down to 2.28 million last season), and the more the fans pay.
Across the river, the Yankees, who haven't yet announced their ticket plans for the coming season, are also expected to raise prices.
Yankee prices have pretty much followed the Mets' prices, and gone from, for example, $8.25 in the lower reserved tier in 1985 to $12 last season, and bleacher seats have gone from $1.50 six years ago to $4.50 last year. The Yankees may have good reason to raise ticket prices. After all, they improved last season, zooming from seventh place in 1990 to fifth place, and losing only 91 games instead of 95.
Meanwhile, as the Knicks foundered, their courtside seats in the last six years leaped from $20 to as high as $65, and upper mezzanine from $10 to $16. It is just about the same for the Rangers.
And since the teams haven't given us more sports entertainment, they've sometimes tried diversionary tactics. Like the Knick City Girls, the dance troupe that is falling flat at the Garden.
The fans, including that guy who was shoved upstairs by the usher, are paying their salaries, too.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Price rise at Shea. (Vic DeLuca/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Louisiana Lesson

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Now for the really good news from Louisiana: The campaign against David Duke shows how he can be defeated again if he tries for national office -- he or the likes of him.
Yes, we all know that the country is not rid of him. And it is obvious that Patrick Buchanan, a politician who uses journalistic print and air to become the rally point for the Republican right wing, will sooner or later put hat, foot and mouth in the Presidential ring. 
 It's not the first time in American history that men of the far and nasty right have come center stage. But this time they scare more people -- and should.
The country is suffering from the social diseases that are the historic breeding grounds of bigotry and Fascism -- unemployment, bank collapses, corruption, cynicism, racial and religious clashes.
But it is no more realistic to be fatalistic about the Dukes and Buchanans, to cower and say look, the wave of the future, than to dismiss them as fringe kooks.
For this truth, the country owes a debt of gratitude to all the blacks of Louisiana, to black leaders like Jesse Jackson who spent years beseeching them to register, and to the 45 percent of white voters who decided that David Duke did not sit well with their religion or sense of country. They were a minority, sadly, but a decisive lot more than he expected.
I asked Lance Hill, director of the Louisiana Coalition against Nazism and Racism, which fought David Duke early and long, the lessons of the election that could be used again against a Duke or a dukeling. In my own synthesis, they are:
1. Do not count on "malign neglect." While you turn out the lights in disgust and go to sleep, these characters are busy in the dark.
2. "Throw water on his burning cross." That means decode, decode, decode.
When a Duke talks of unwed welfare mothers he means blacks, as if poor white girls without rings never get pregnant. When he talks about Christian European values he means "Jews out."
Mr. Buchanan also talked in easily decipherable code when he said that only the Israeli Defense Ministry and its "amen corner" in the United States wanted war in the Persian Gulf. Whole subjects are codes: the Holocaust wasn't all that bad; women should get child welfare provided they implant long-term birth control.
3. By their fruit -- and their words -- shall we know them. Don't let them get away with shucksism -- oh, shucks, folks, when I paraded in a sheet, I was just a little feller. Or I didn't knows Jews would be so sensitive to Holocaust demeanment. They knew then; they know now.
4. Don't deny the truth. It is fiction that unemployment is caused by affirmative action. It is fiction that unemployment will be solved by some cockamamie economic theory, left or right, that says that all we need is some other cockamamie theory that has not yet quite worked.
But it is fact that working people are terrified by unemployment and business people by the drying up of credit. It is fact that no politician has yet come up with solutions. But it is also fact that nation-dividing racism and the codes of hatred are the open roads to the economic graveyard.
5. Don't be frightened by talk of backlash against "outside" criticism. National attention made David Duke every bigot's pinup. But he would have been a lot more politically sexy had he won. One reason he did not was that enough whites were deeply ashamed of what the whole nation was seeing from Louisiana.
6. Organize the fight against Dukes and Buchanans across the board -- liberals, conservatives, whites, blacks, Christians, Jews, Muslims, unions, business people, clergymen, writers, individuals or organizations.
The coalition should have a unified message: This man is a danger to the kind of town, city, state, country and world, all of them, that we want to live in.
My own number 7 is: Expect reverses. David Duke may be elected to Congress and if he runs, Mr. Buchanan may do well in New Hampshire where the vote is small and fringes could count.
All right, then back to numbers one through six. For inspiration and a fast boost off your seat, think of a Duke-Buchanan ticket. That should bring the bucket brigade to the burning crosses.
