HEADLINE: Civil Rights Exemption Unfair to Asians

 BODY:
To the Editor:
We believe the exemption from the provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1991 of the very employer involved in one of the 1989 Supreme Court decisions that provided the impetus for that law should disturb all Americans. John P. MacKenzie's position in "An Exception to Civil Rights Rules" (Editorial Notebook, Nov. 8) that the exemption is an acceptable price to pay to obtain President Bush's signature on the bill is one that cannot be condoned. 
 What is the message when the Wards Cove Packing Company will itself be the only company in America that is above the law? Under basic principles of fairness and justice, the Asian Pacific American cannery workers who initiated the case, which has not been finally adjudicated, deserve to have their claims decided by the courts under the same rules that apply to every other American.
From our perspective, the Wards Cove exemption raises troubling questions concerning the politics of race. The Wards Cove case involves racially discriminatory conduct directed at Asian Pacific Americans, such as segregated housing and dining facilities and relegation of minorities to menial jobs with no realistic prospect of promotion.
These employment practices are so egregious that Associate Justice John P. Stevens stated in Wards Cove Packing Company v. Atonio (490 U.S. 664 note 4, 1989) that they bear "an unsettling resemblance to aspects of a plantation economy." Such conduct cannot be tolerated in this country.
A number of civil rights groups, such as the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, American Jewish Committee and Mexican American Legal Defense and Education Fund, opposed the Wards Cove exemption.
The Asian Pacific American community is working with members of the Senate and the House of Representatives to enact new legislation in the next few weeks to delete the Wards Cove provision from the Civil Rights Act.
 
DENNIS HAYASHI
PEGGY NAGAE LUM, DAPHNE KWOK
Washington, Nov. 11, 1991
 
The writers are officers of, respectively, the Japanese American Citizens League, National Asian Pacific American Bar Association and Organization of Chinese Americans.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Notes and Bonds Decline in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The stock market's return to stability helped to push down prices of Treasury notes and bonds yesterday, but credit market participants said the drop was of minimal significance.
On Friday, when stocks registered their biggest decline in more than two years, investors poured money into short-term notes and bills. When it became apparent that a further big drop was not likely to take place yesterday, those positions were unwound. 
 "It's generally been a quiet day," one government bond trader said. "Most economists are still looking for the Fed to lower rates once if not twice more before the end of the year. And the economy is not showing any signs of strength."
The prospect of lower short-term rates kept sales of shorter-term instruments at a minimum, and helped to increase demand at the Treasury's weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills.
In their daily market commentary, analysts at MMS International, an economic information service company, said the firm expects the Fed to lower the overnight Federal funds rate by another quarter of a percent before the end of the year and to follow that up in January with a further cut in the funds rate and a half-point cut in the discount rate.
The Fed's current target for the funds rate is widely seen as 4 3/4 percent. The discount rate is at 4 1/2 percent.
Recovery in the stock market did not seem to sit well with bond investors, however.
"Essentially, the market was just shadow-boxing with the stock market, and bonds moved in the opposite direction of stocks," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J. firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets.
 
Recovery in Equity Prices
 A decision by House leaders to postpone the markup of legislation to put a cap on credit card interest rates was "probably the major reason" equity prices recovered yesterday, Mr. McCarthy said.
Echoing a sentiment that was voiced often yesterday, Mr. McCarthy said that Congress, which has rattled financial markets repeatedly over the last few weeks as it has considered ways to stimulate the economy, would best serve the economy by putting aside all such deliberations and adjourning.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve Board chairman, who came out strongly against legislation to cap credit card interest rates late last week, will not begin his confirmation hearings for reappointment to his post today, as had been expected.
It was announced yesterday that because the Senate is expected to consider a banking bill today, Mr. Greenspan's hearing before the Senate Banking Committee will not be held until later in the week.
At yesterday's Treasury bill auction, the new three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 4.58 percent, down from the average rate of 4.64 percent last week.
Bids on the new six-month bills generated an average discount rate of 4.62 percent, compared with an average rate of 4.71 percent at the auction a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds, the 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 26/32 late yesterday, down 15/32, to yield 7.84 percent, compared with 7.81 percent late Friday.
Among note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 6/ 32, down 9/32, to yield 7.33 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 7/8, down 2/32, to yield 5.51 percent.
Tension eased somewhat in the market for asset-backed securities, which has been paralyzed in recent days because of the credit card interest rate debate.
Traders in that market said that prices of most issues were little changed, but that very few securities were actually changing hands.
In the investment-grade corporate bond market, Utilicorp United Inc. offered $150 million worth of 30-year senior notes through an underwriting group led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The 9 percent notes, which are non-callable for 10 years, were priced at $99.053, to yield 9.092 percent, 1.25 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the tax-exempt municipal bond market began to brace themselves for a huge volume of new debt securities that will be offered this week, beginning with the sale today of $1.2 billion worth of new bonds for New York City.
Municipal bond traders said that prices of most widely quoted secondary issues fell by about1/4 point yesterday.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Widens; Biggest Gap in 8 Months

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
The nation's merchandise trade deficit widened to $6.79 billion in September, the biggest imbalance in eight months, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department said the September deficit was 4 percent higher than the revised $6.53 billion August trade figure as America's appetite for foreign goods rose more quickly than United States sales abroad. 
 For September, exports climbed 3 percent, to $35.43 billion, but this gain was offset by a 3.2 percent rise in imports to $42.22 billion, the highest level for imports in almost a year. The trade deficit is the difference between imports and exports.
 
Surprise to Analysts
 It marked the highest monthly trade imbalance since a $7.37 billion deficit in January. The September imbalance came as a surprise to many analysts who had been looking for a slight improvement in the trade deficit.
It was the third straight month that the deficit has worsened, a disturbing trend given that an improving trade balance had been one of the few bright spots for the American economy.
The Bush Administration hailed the rise in exports as good news for American manufacturers. But private economists were more downbeat, contending that slumping growth in some of America's major overseas markets spelled more trouble for a faltering economy.
Private economists said the recession should be given much of the credit for the sharp contraction in the trade gap because it reduced demand for imported goods.
They were also not impressed with September's rise in exports, noting that it was only the second increase in the last five months.
"Exports really haven't gone anywhere in months," said Robert Dederick, chief economist of the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "This is just one more area of the economy where demand is failing to live up to expectations."
 
Better Than Last Year
 Even with the worsening in the trade gap over the last three months, the deficit for the year is still running at an annual rate of just $65.74 billion, far below last year's $101.72 billion deficit.
But analysts are concerned that the trend is going the wrong way and the deficit, which is forecast this year to dip below $100 billion for the first time since 1984, will start climbing again in 1992, acting as a drag on economic growth.
In September, the gain in exports was led by a $400 million increase in sales of aircraft, with smaller gains recorded in sales of oilfield equipment and semiconductors.
The jump in imports was led by a $150 million increase in foreign apparel shipments.
Oil imports fell by 5.2 percent, to $4.33 billion in September, as a drop in volume offset an increase of price. The price per barrel rose to $17.09, from $16.79 in August.
As usual, the largest deficit in September was recorded with Japan, an imbalance of $4.18 billion, which was 12 percent higher than the August level and accounted for 62 percent of the total deficit.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKET;
Dollar Closes Mostly Lower Following Tumble in Stocks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against most major currencies yesterday as traders took their cues from the slide in stock prices.
John McCarthy, chief dealer with ABN-AMRO Bank N.V., said the dollar followed the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell 41 points yesterday amid growing concerns about the economy. 
 Mr. McCarthy said comments by President Bush and Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, also darkened the foreign exchange market's mood. Mr. Bush called the economy sluggish while Mr. Boskin conceded that economic growth had slowed.
The dollar closed at 1.5965 marks in New York, down from 1.6105 late Monday. In earlier European trading, the dollar fell to 1.6020 marks from 1.6065.
"The general feeling is that dollar could come lower," Mr. McCarthy said.
The mark was a standout yesterday, surging against other currencies on speculation the German Government would raise interest rates later this week. Such a move would make the mark more attractive.
Overseas dealers said the Bank of England and Bank of Spain intervened discreetly to raise the British pound because sterling was falling close to its minimum required level against the mark.
The pound fell to 2.8740 marks from 2.8812 marks in Europe. Its minimum level required by the European exchange rate mechanism, which prevents disruptive exchange rate movements, is 2.86 marks.
The pound advanced against the dollar, rising to $1.8000 in New York from $1.7900. In London, sterling rose to $1.7965, from $1.7915 late Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.4165 Swiss francs, down from 1.4295; 5.4525 French francs, down from 5.5055; 1,207.00 Italian lire, down from 1,217.00, and 1.12875 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.4195 Swiss francs, down from 1.4265; 5.4710 French francs, down from 5.4945; 1.8045 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8115; 1,211.15 Italian lire, down from 1,214.75, and 1.1287 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1278.
The dollar rose against the Japanese yen, closing at 129.80 yen in New York, up from 129.48. In Tokyo overnight, the dollar rose 0.55 yen, to 129.48 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 129.85 yen.

HEADLINE: C.D.'s and Bank Funds Fall

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on deposit accounts ended lower in the last week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, an interest rate publication.
Robert K. Heady, the publisher, said yesterday that he thought the current down cycle in savings yields "still has four to six weeks to go before playing itself out." 
 That should push down many yields on short-term certificates of deposit to around 4 percent, he said, adding that some instititions like Citibank and Chemical Bank were already paying below 4 percent on some certificates of deposit and money market accounts.
"Shrinking loan demand is one cause," Mr. Heady said. "Also, banks are not aggressively chasing deposits to replace funds. Until Congress and the Administration set a specific, positive program for recovery, it is doubtful whether the yield downslide can correct itself without further intervention by the Federal Reserve."
The question he posed is: How far down is the bottom?
 
Big Citibank Cut
 Among banks in the New York area, Citibank made the largest cut in money market accounts, lowering yields by 41 basis points, to 3.67 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Regarding yields on three-month and six-month certificates, National Westminster Bank made the largest cuts, dropping them by 21 basis points, to 4.50 percent, and by 26 basis points, to 4.55 percent, respectively.
On average, the New York commercial banks have lowered the yields on their money market accounts by 5 more basis points, to 4.33 percent, in the last week. Yields on three-month certificates and on six-month certificates dropped by 6 basis points each, to 4.44 percent and 4.54 percent, respectively.
The Bank Rate Monitor said the average yields on money market accounts at 20 large banks outside the New York area had been cut by 5 basis points, to 4.64 percent, and by 6 basis points, to 4.82 percent, on six-month certificates.
At the Treasury's weekly auction on Monday, the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 4.58 percent, compared with 4.64 percent a week earlier. The six-month bill averaged 4.62 percent, compared with 4.71 the previous week.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold and Silver Prices Rise As Investors Seek Safety

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metal futures prices rallied yesterday as investors sought refuge from the tumbling stock market in the historically safe harbors of silver and gold.
On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for delivery in December rose $2.90 to settle at $364.40 an ounce. December silver climbed 4.5 cents, to $4.072 an ounce. 
Platinum climbed $4.20, to $368.40 an ounce, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
The Dow Jones average of 30 large industrial stocks fell 41.15 points yesterday and was down more than 75 points at one point in the afternoon that coincided with the closing minutes of the metal markets.
Many investors sold stocks and fled to the perceived safety of precious metals, which historically have held their value during troubled economic times.
 
Weak Dollar Helped
 "With yields on Government debt instruments so low, people were saying why not take a flier with the gold as a hedge against an economic crisis," said Michael Segal, senior futures strategist with Geldermann Inc. in New York.
He said a weak dollar also touched off gold buying.
An offer by the seven richest democracies, including the United States, to defer interest payments on the Soviet Union's foreign debt for one year may also have supported precious metals.
Such an agreement would reduce the likelihood of large Soviet sales of gold and platinum to raise hard currency.
"It's becoming clear the Soviet Union does not have much more precious metal to sell, so any improvement on their current foreign exchange shortfall should be further supportive for the precious metals," said Fred Demler, metals economist with Paine Webber Inc.
Light sweet crude oil for December delivery fell 40 cents, to $22 a barrel. December heating oil dropped 0.96 cent, to 64.43 cents a gallon. December unleaded gasoline fell 0.78 cent, to 62.62 cents a gallon, and December natural gas plunged 9.1 cents to $1.91 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Wheat futures rose but other grain and soybean futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade amid uncertainty about new food aid to the Soviet Union and jitters about the stock market.

HEADLINE: Dow Loses 41.15 After Skid Slows

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Steady selling carved as much as 78 points from the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday, before buyers stepped in late in the day to stem the decline. The Dow ended the session down 41.15 points, to 2,931.57.
The decline was marked by a grim but orderly retreat in contrast to the hectic tumble on Friday, as the big professional traders stayed largely on the sidelines. 
 The market's decline, after a sharp drop in the morning, was fairly steady throughout the day. Traders attributed the orderliness of the market yesterday to a rule that restricts computer-driven program selling when the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks falls at least 50 points. That level was reached yesterday at 10:41 A.M., bringing the rule into play.
 
'Collar' Took Effect
 "There were a lot of programs this morning, and then the collar went into effect, and it became very orderly," said Jeffrey Tabak, a principal at Miller Tabak Hirsch. "With the collar, people know that there aren't these avalanches of sell orders coming."
The impact of the so-called circuit breakers during last Friday's plunge of 120 points is not clear. Yesterday, Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said the S.E.C. was examining the patterns of program trading to see if changes might be suggested.
Analysts said one of the explanations for yesterday's decline was an unexpectedly large 1.6 percent drop in the London stock market, which was responding to British concerns on interest rates. Traders were also disappointed about President Bush's wait-and-see remarks on the economy. Also cited was the decision of market professionals, who had been required to buy in last Friday's heavy selling, to lighten their positions yesterday to reduce expenses.
Mutual funds reported some modest individual buying of equity funds. Several professional money managers said they were sitting it out.
Volume on the Big Board was heavy at 241.4 million shares, nearly matching the 241.9 million traded on Monday. Losing issues outpaced gaining issues by 1,439 to 341.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was down 5.82, to 379.42, while the New York Stock Exchange composite index declined 3.12 points, to 209.91, and the American Stock Exchange composite index fell 5.22 points, to 374.25.
In Nasdaq trading, the index was down 11.26, to 523.47 and the Russell 2,000, was off 4.10, to 177.55.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trades, noted 12 in all yesterday. The combined impact lowered the Dow by 35.75 points, with buy programs at the end of the session adding 27.75 points, Birinyi said.
The unexpected drop on the London market surprised investors in the morning and set the tone for Wall Street yesterday, even through the London decline was attributed to worries that the Government of John Major would have to raise interest rates to keep the pound within its fixed trading range in the European Monetary System.
Paul J. Kronlokken, a technical analyst for Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood Inc., said the good news was that the Pacific Basin markets, which were mixed, with Tokyo off, were not a factor. "There seems to be continued carry-over from Friday's market, despite Monday's rally," he said, adding that Monday "was not all that good a day," since the advance was only in the large-capitalized stocks, with high liquidity and safety.
One source of market anxiety, Mr. Kronlokken said, was President Bush's remarks that the economy was basically sound and he planned no major new programs to stimulate growth.
Large mutual funds reported that telephone calls from customers yesterday were much heavier than normal, but in most cases no clear trend emerged from the calls.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New York State's Bonds Plunge

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A sharp upward revision in the size of New York State's budget deficit for the current and coming fiscal years sent prices of the state's outstanding bond issues sharply lower yesterday.
The effect of the new figures helped to create a logjam in what had been expected to be a record week of new offerings in the tax-exempt municipal bond market. 
 Given woeful economic conditions, the fact that state officials raised the projected revenue shortfalls was not altogether surprising, analysts said. But the timing of the announcement, as well as the size of the new projections, came as a shock.
 
2 Issues Priced Last Week
 The state released its new deficit estimates a day before two debt issues priced last week, one for the Metropolitan Transit Authority, the other for New York State, were scheduled to be released to investors.
The new estimates show that the revenue shortfall could be twice the $1.8 billion projection made in July for the 1992-93 fiscal year.
The huge increase represented a material change in the outlook that had been presented to investors when the M.T.A. and New York State issues were priced last week, and created doubt about whether the securities would be released as scheduled.
"For anyone who follows the state's finances, this is not an entirely unexpected event," one municipal bond trader said. "But the problem is that the state is not as organized as it should be, and when something of this nature comes out between the sale of a new issue and when it is scheduled to close, it is an event."
 
Status of Offerings
 Telephone calls to Goldman, Sachs & Company seeking comment on the status of the M.T.A. deal were not returned. Goldman served as lead underwriter on the offering. An official at the New York State Comproller's office, who asked not to be identified, said the New York State issue would close as scheduled.
The revised numbers created a turmoil in the market for outstanding New York State bonds. Traders said prices of some bonds fell by as much as a point after the figures were released.
The news also had an effect on New York City, which was poised to price $1.2 billion in refunding bonds yesterday. Because of the uncertainty created by the revised budget projections, underwriters of the city issue decided to delay the pricing for at least 24 hours.
In all likelihood, the city's decision to postpone its offering will cause the New Jersey Turnpike Authority to put off pricing $1.6 billion in securities. The issue had been scheduled to be sold today.
 
Other Reverberations
 Besides the New York City offering, the University of California Board of Regents chose not to price more than $353 million worth of refunding bonds yesterday. California pulled the issue because it did not like the preliminary pricing on the securities.
"This is clearly one of the more confusing new-issue days I have ever seen," said Stephen C. Leslie, a senior vice president at M. R. Beal & Company. "It was a tough day."
Some $8 billion to $8.5 billion in tax-exempt bonds had been scheduled to be sold this week, but analysts said yesterday's developments created a logjam that might take several weeks to sort out.
It is unlikely that such a large volume of new securities would be offered during the rest of the week. And because of Thanksgiving, new issues that might otherwise have been priced next week will probably be delayed, the analysts said.
 
The Dow's Influence
 Stock prices, not New York State, was the primary influence on developments in the secondary market for Treasury securities yesterday.
Once again, the steep selloff in the equity market persuaded investors to buy short-term Treasury bills and notes. Bond prices fell however, and long-term interest rates moved higher.
"People are willing to sell bonds no matter what the news," one government securities trader said. "It seems like the money that went into bonds at the refunding auctions has come back out again."
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101, down by 7/8 point, to yield 7.91 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 31/ 32 in late trading, down by 7/32, to yield 7.36 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 29/32, up by 2/32, to yield 5.50 percent.
 
Short-Term Rates Down
 Short-term Treasury bill rates moved lower.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.52 percent, down by 4 basis points, or four one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 5 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.55 percent. And one-year bills were offered in late trading at 4.58 percent, down by 4 basis points.
Activity in the investment-grade corporate bond market was highlighted by a three-part, $450 million competitive offering of securities by the Public Service Electric and Gas Company.
Yields on the securities range from 7.185 percent on notes maturing on Nov. 1, 1997, to 8.79 percent on bonds that mature on Nov. 1, 2021.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Pricing Insurers Out of Business

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
TO most Americans, government-dictated prices have always seemed like a variation on the theme of "Yes, we have no bananas." Price controls guaranteed that everything for sale would be affordable, while assuring there would hardly be anything to buy.
But this time, argues Orin Kramer, the head of a Princeton, N.J., consulting firm and the author of a new study of auto and workers' compensation insurance for the Insurance Information Institute, the joke is on us. He contends that regulated rates are eroding the industry's capacity to pay out claims and are creating a crazy-quilt of subsidies in which low-risk consumers cover the expenses of high-risk consumers. Perhaps more important, he says, price controls are masking the core problem of accident insurance, delaying the day when policy makers tackle escalating legal and medical costs. 
 The obvious reason for regulating insurance is to guarantee that insurers deliver on their promises. To that end, most states set minimum standards for financial reserves and the provision of backup coverage for bankrupt insurers. But since the 1960's, Mr. Kramer writes, the emphasis has turned to containing premium inflation.
At first, regulators pushed for more competitive pricing, barring the cozy cartel arrangements that allowed insurers to conspire against "disruptive" competition. In the last decade, however, regulators and state legislatures have responded to rate inflation in auto and workers' compensation insurance (which account for half of all casualty insurance premiums) by wading into rate-setting waters.
In some cases they have capped rates informally, refusing to clear requested increases. In others, they have prohibited rate discrimination by sex, age or geography. And in California they have jumped in head first, setting a maximum allowable rate of return for insurers, much the way states regulate public utility monopolies. As of last count by the National Association of Independent Insurers, 21 states were considering California-style rate-of-return regulation.
Mr. Kramer calculates that in 1989, some $32 billion in auto and workers' compensation premiums -- 15 percent of total industry premiums -- were collected in states that kept rates below competitive levels. All told, he estimates, rate suppression deprived insurers of $9.5 billion in earnings in 1987 through 1989, with the lion's share ($7.3 billion) coming on workers' compensation policies. These figures do not count the effects of the big rollback in California's auto insurance rates, which only began in 1990.
Insurers (who paid for Mr. Kramer's analysis) obviously worry about rate suppression. But why should anyone else?
Mr. Kramer focuses on solvency questions. An insurer who wrote nothing but workers' compensation policies in rate suppression states would eat through its capital reserves in five years, he estimates. Of course, few companies issue just workers' compensation policies and fewer still issue them only in rate suppression states. But Mr. Kramer sees evidence that rate caps have contributed to insolvencies and expects that hostile regulation will become a significant factor in insurance failures in the next few years.
Such arguments are not likely to impress drivers who have watched their premiums double or triple in the last decade in spite of more aggressive regulation. Indeed, many would no doubt hoist a glass at the prospect of their unfriendly neighborhood insurance company biting the dust -- as long as someone covered their claims. But Mr. Kramer thinks that rate suppression is already taking a direct toll on consumers, and it is bound to increase.
Price controls, he notes, have led to enormous growth in the percentage of customers insurers will not voluntarily insure. In New Jersey and Massachusetts, for example, half the drivers were relegated to this "residual market" in 1987. They were still able to buy coverage. But by tossing so high a proportion of customers into the pool, competitive pressures that linked rates for classes of policyholders to expected claims ceased to matter. Relatively good drivers were thus forced to subsidize relatively bad ones.
The deeper problem here is that attention has been diverted from the real sources of insurance cost inflation. For believe it or not, insurers are not making a big buck: the average return to their stockholders' capital in the 1980's was well below profit rates for American industry as a whole.
The keys to accident insurance woes, Mr. Kramer says (and the numbers corroborate), are the rapidly rising costs of hospital care and the explosion in litigation. No matter how much policy makers bob and weave, no matter how clever they become at squeezing insurers, the cost problem will not go away until it is attacked at the core.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Maxwell Loan Investigated; Company Shares Hit Hard

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
A British Government agency, the Serious Fraud Office, said today that it was investigating a loan to a company that had been part of Robert Maxwell's holdings. In response to that news and a negative credit development, Maxwell Communication's shares lost nearly a quarter of their value and dragged down banking stock prices as well.
The inquiry by the fraud office came in response to a complaint made to the police by the Swiss Bank Corporation concerning a 55 million ($99 million) loan it had made to Adviser 188, which is controlled by a private Maxwell company, Headington Investments Ltd. 
 The Financial Times, which disclosed the inquiry today, quoted an unidentified banker as saying that collateral was deficient on the loan. Some analysts said the same assets might have been used as collateral for more than one loan.
Separately, the British credit rating agency IBCA Ltd. said it had placed Maxwell Communication on credit watch because of potential disruptions to the media company's bank credit. The move means IBCA is reviewing the company's soundness and could possibly lower its rating, which would make it more expensive for Maxwell Communication to borrow money.
 
Problem for Sons
 Inasmuch as Mr. Maxwell had pledged stock in his publicly held companies as collateral against private loans, the drop in the value of the stock raised questions about whether the British publisher's sons could hold his empire together.
That empire includes an array of holdings in Europe and the United States, ranging from scholastic book publishing companies to tabloid newspapers, including The Daily News in New York and The Daily Mirror in Britain.
Declines in Maxwell Communication's stock price, and thus the value of the collateral, could prompt bankers to require the Maxwell family to put up more collateral or repay its loans.
Kevin Maxwell, one of Robert Maxwell's sons and chairman of Maxwell Communication, has said banks have pledged their support, and he has accelerated the sale of assets to pay debts. He has also defended the use of stock as loan collateral as a "perfectly standard method of borrowing."
Still, analysts were bearish.
"It's very bad news," Valerie Conner, an analyst with the London investment firm Henderson Crosthwaite & Company, said about the stock drop. "The banks are in a very delicate position because they won't want to act too precipitously."
 
Drop in Share Value
 Maxwell Communication's shares sank 14 pence, or 25 cents, to close at 46 pence, or 83 cents, on the London Stock Exchange today. The shares have fallen 62 percent since Mr. Maxwell died on Nov. 5 during a stay on his yacht. His body was recovered in waters off the Canary Islands.
Shares in the other major Maxwell company, Mirror Group Newspapers P.L.C., fell 3 pence, or 5 cents, to close at 114 pence, or $2.05.
As a result of the weakness in Maxwell Communication's share price, National Westminster Bank P.L.C., Maxwell's lead bank, was off 8 pence, or 14 cents, at 305 pence, or $5.49, at the close of trading.
Derek Brock, an analyst with the Nomura Research Institute, said, "Clearly, the more pressure there is on the Maxwell family, the more pressure there's going to be to sell assets."
Although analysts say the family has not provided them with enough information about its loans to know for sure, a drop in Maxwell Communication's share price to below 50 pence, or 90 cents, was believed to be the trigger point for banks to take protective action.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Federated Stock: Dispute on Value

BYLINE: By Eben Shapiro

 BODY:
IN these bleak times for traditional department stores, a large stock offering by such a retailer is unlikely to set off a stampede of investors. But early next year, some investors are likely to receive 80.6 million new shares in the company that owns Abraham & Straus, Rich's and Bloomingdale's. They do not have any choice.
These reluctant shareholders are the creditors of the Federated and Allied department store chains, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in January 1990 after their costly acquisition by the Campeau Corporation. 
 The Cincinnati-based retailers plan to emerge from bankruptcy in February as a single entity. Much of their debt will be paid in the form of new stock issued to creditors.
The banks and bondholders will receive shares in a new company, Federated Department Stores Inc. The company will have no connection to the Campeau Corporation, and its shares will be traded over the counter.
In anticipation of the issuance of the shares, a dispute has begun over the proposed value of Federated's shares.
Federated's investment bankers, Shearson Lehman Brothers, say the stock is worth $25 a share. That valuation is disputed by some creditors and bond analysts, who put it closer to $15 to $17.
Barbara Wedelstaedt, a bond analyst with Duff & Phelps in Chicago, said the company's projections were too aggressive. "We just don't think that the levels of profitability are as high as the projections the company has put together."
Even as the economy improves, she said, retailers will face a crowded, competitive arena, which will mandate lower profits than those outlined by Federated's management. "These companies will not be able to achieve the same gross margins that were achieved in the 80's," she said.
She added that turnarounds were hard to accomplish in a retail operation. She values the stock at $17 a share.
Federated's advisers stand by their valuation, but acknowledge that the stock may trade at a price below $25 when it is issued next year.
Creditors are now voting on whether to accept Federated's plan. Most creditors and analysts expect the plan to be accepted by creditors and approved by Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. of United States Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati, allowing the company to emerge from bankruptcy early next year.
In addition to analyzing the restructured company's business prospects, Joe Amato, director of high-yield research at Kidder, Peabody, is considering technical stock-trading issues. When issued, some of the shares will carry restrictions to prevent them from being sold for a certain time on the open market.
"Supply and demand is important, and it will be a big issue the first couple of months," Mr. Amoto said. He said that the firm was still analyzing the situation but that the selling restriction was likely to depress the stock price temporarily.
Investors are exploring different possible approaches. One investment banker said he had considered buying Federated and Allied bonds as a "cheap way to get the stock." But upon closer examination, he said, the stock did not look like a bargain, "and we just passed."
Federated has gotten high marks for keeping its reorganization moving briskly along. Its management has used the bankruptcy court's protection to make a host of sorely needed changes to improve efficiency, escaping from leases and closing 40 unprofitable stores. The company has also consolidated, centralizing its buying, data processing and credit card operation. It also merged its Maas Brothers/Jordan Marsh division into the Burdines division.
When it emerges from bankruptcy, the company expects to have 225 stores in 26 states, with sales of about $7 billion.
When Federated and Allied filed for bankruptcy protection nearly two years ago, the two operations owed $8.7 billion to more than 40,000 creditors.
Analysts are mixed on what the future holds for the group of department stores. Allen I. Questrom, chairman and chief executive of Federated and Allied, is considered a top retailing executive, but he faces well-financed competition and a weak economy.
George Ashur, director of corporate bond research for Chase Securities, said traditional merchants like Federated would have a difficult time competing against retailers like the Limited and the Gap. "I use 'traditional management' in a pejorative sense," he said. "The norm has changed so much."
Edward Weller, a retailing analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco, said the company had a powerful presence in markets like Atlanta, with Rich's, and in Florida, with Burdines. He said the stores were not in bad shape before the costly buyout. "The problem was the financial structure of the company, not the quality of the business," Mr. Weller added.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
BellSouth Wins Bid For Australia Service

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
The BellSouth Corporation, the regional Bell company based in Atlanta, said yesterday that it was part of a three-nation consortium that won the right to provide telecommunications services in Australia.
BellSouth said the group, which includes Cable and Wireless P.L.C. of Britain, bid the equivalent of $640 million. 
 The venture, known as Optus Communications, will compete against the Government-owned entities, Telecom Australia, which provides local service, and OTC, which provides long-distance service.
BellSouth and Cable each own 24.5 percent of the venture. BellSouth's share of the purchase price is about $157 million. BellSouth will offer expertise on cellular telephones and Cable and Wireless on international long distance. They will jointly operate domestic long-distance service.
Optus's majority holders are Australians, as mandated by law. They are Mayne Nickless, a transportation and health services company; the Australian Mutual Provident Society and National Mutual, two life insurance companies, and AIDC Ltd. Telecommunications Fund, a mutual fund.
Like other Bell companies, BellSouth has tried to cope with slow-growing domestic markets by searching for opportunities abroad. Though Australia is in a deep recession, BellSouth is betting that the economy will revive and prosper. Australia's gross domestic product per capita is about $18,000 a year, compared with about $22,000 in the United States. Australia's distance from other countries could also increase long-distance calling.
Optus plans to spend $3.1 billion over the next five years to modernize Australia's telephone network with fiber-optic cables. BellSouth said it would contribute $300 million of its own money over the next four years and that the contribution will hurt earnings by 4 cents a share in 1992 and 7 cents a share in 1993. BellSouth earned $1.63 billion, or $3.38 a share, on revenues of $14.3 billion in 1990.
On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, BellSouth shares lost 62.5 cents each, closing at $46.875.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

MARKETS
Stocks dropped steadily, until late buy orders trimmed the losses. The Dow Jones industrial average, down as much as 78 points at one stage, closed off 41.15 points at 2,931.57. The decline followed a tumble in the London market. [D1.]
Credit markets were roiled by a sharp upward revision in the size of New York State's budget deficit. It sent prices of the state's outstanding bond issues down sharply, and created a logjam in new municipal offerings. New York City delayed an issue. [D16.]
Yields on certificates of deposit dropped in the last week, with some below 4 percent. [D7.]
The dollar tumbled against most major currencies, as traders responded to the slide in stock prices. [D18.]
Precious metal futures rallied, with gold for December delivery up $2.90 a troy ounce to settle at $364.40 on the Comex. [D18.]
 
THE ECONOMY
A streamlined banking bill was reported out of the House Banking Committee, as President Bush lobbied the Senate for passage of broader banking legislation. The House measure would provide billions of dollars in taxpayer loans to insure bank deposits. [D1.]
The merchandise trade deficit widened to $6.79 billion in September, the biggest in eight months, the Commerce Department said. That was 4 percent above August's revised $6.53 billion. [D2.]
The oil industry will face costs of $15 billion to $23 billion a year by the late 1990's, as a result of new Federal regulations meant to reduce air pollution, oil spills and contamination of underground water supplies, the American Petroleum Institute predicted. [D2.]
 
COMPANIES
A $1 billion Government computer contract, one of the richest ever, has gone to two small companies, Compuadd of Austin, Tex., and Sysorex Information Systems of Falls Church, Va. [D1.]
McDonnell Douglas announced a preliminary agreement to sell 40 percent of its commercial aircraft to Taiwan Aerospace for $2 billion. [D1.]
Cray Research introduced its most powerful supercomputer yet. It can compute at four times the speed of the company's most powerful present systems. [D6.]
A loan to one of the late Robert Maxwell's companies, is under investigation by Britain's Serious Fraud Office. That news and a negative credit development depressed shares of both Maxwell Communication and Maxwell's banking creditors. [D4.]
British Airways is negotiating a takeover of KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, a Dutch transport workers union said. [D4.]
BellSouth said it won Australian rights for telecommunications services. It was part of a three-nation consortium that includes Cable and Wireless of Britain. The group bid $640 million. [D4.]
 
TECHNOLOGY
M.I.T. and private industry are in partnership to put traffic-management theories to work for America's 135 million cars. Congress is paying for highway-automation research. [D1.]
Comnetix Computer Systems of Canada has given police on-screen mug shots that match a suspect's description. [D9.]
 
TODAY'S COLUMNS
Insurance price controls are masking the core problem of rising accident insurance costs, delaying action by policy makers, a Princeton consultant argues. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [D2.]
Creditors of the bankrupt companies that own A.&S., Rich's and Bloomingdale's will get 80.6 million shares in a new Federated Department Stores. The value is disputed. Market Place. [D10.]
Whittle Communications is said to be considering introducing an elementary school version of Channel One, its controversial advertising-supported daily news program for high schools. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D22.]

HEADLINE: CUOMO AIDES SEE DOUBLING OF GAP IN ALBANY BUDGET

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget office said today that the gap in the coming state budget may rise to $3.6 billion, double its previous estimate, or more than 10 percent of total projected spending.
Officials said they based the new figure on forecasts that the state and national economies would take still another turn for the worse, depressing tax collections and increasing spending on social services. 
 The news set off a tremor on an already jittery Wall Street, where the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was forced to postpone a planned closing on $440 million in bond sales. It acted after investors, citing uncertainty over the state's finances brought on by the announcement, pulled back from the deal.
 
'Bad Mood' of Investors
 The New York City government also put off for at least one day a $1.2 billion bond sale that it had been hailing as a sign of good economic news. The sale involves a refinancing of old bonds that was expected to save the city at least $100 million in borrowing costs.
Technically, the financing of the city bonds had nothing to do with state budget conditions, but one city official said the "bad mood" among investors who learned the state's budget news led the city to conclude that a brief delay might allow it to hold down the yield it would have to pay buyers of the bonds. Such a move may only change the yield by a fraction of a percentage point, but that can represent millions of dollars over the life of the bonds.
 
The Presidential Question
 At the state level, Mr. Cuomo's Presidential aspirations could hinge on a successful budget plan, or at least general agreement on an approach to the problem. Earlier this week he said he would stay out of the Presidential race if he and the Legislature could not agree soon on a "solution" to the state's persistent fiscal problems.
The M.T.A. and city moves were a stark reflection not only of the severity of the state's budget news but also of how such news can affect the psychology of the bond markets that the state, the city and a host of public agencies rely on to stay afloat financially.
The State Budget Director, Patrick J. Bulgaro, said tonight that he could not give a precise estimate of the gap. But in assessing the state's fiscal prospects that the state was required to issue as part of the authority's bond sale, he said the $1.8 billion gap projected several months ago "will increase and, based on the most recent information, could double."
The state is already facing a gap of at least $689 million in its current $29 billion budget, and Mr. Cuomo has warned that this could go higher.
At a news conference here this evening, Mr. Cuomo sought to play down the impact of the state's budget announcement on the M.T.A.'s and the city's problems with bond sales.
 
'Not Surprised'
 Citing the glut of municipal bonds on the market now and the recent stock market downturn, with the Dow Jones industrial average declining 41.15 points today, he said, "Now all of these factors come together and investors say: 'Wait a minute, what does this mean for the bonds? Do the interest rates go up, down?' So I'm not surprised that earlier today they should have said, 'Whoa, boy, let's put everything on hold.' "
Mr. Cuomo did seize on the worsening state budget problems as all the greater reason for legislative leaders to agree on a multiyear budget that he said could begin to attack the deficit problems now rather than on April 1, when the 1992-93 fiscal year is to begin.
The Governor has repeatedly warned in recent days that sluggish retail sales for the holiday season could further drive down tax collections.
Several analysts said it was impossible to know whether today's problems in the credit markets, which were unusual although not unprecedented, were a harbinger of even worse difficulties for the state and the city in arranging financing.
They said the situation clearly amounted to a warning shot, but, just as there is little agreement on whether the stock market slump will continue, there is no consensus on whether investors will pull away from city or state bonds in the long term.
And none of the analysts were projecting at this point that the problems signaled any severe shift, like a full-scale closing of the credit markets to New York's public agencies, which was the condition that provoked New York City's fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's. Among other things, there are a host of safeguards now that were not in place at that time to insure that public bonds will be paid off.
City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said New York City decided to hold off on its bond sale, which it now hopes to offer on Wednesday, only because "it was clear the market conditions were not optimal, and we like to market our bonds in the best possible circumstances."
While the city looked to delay as a strategy to drive down the interest it must pay on the bonds, the reverse was true for the Transportation Authority, which had planned to close on the sale of an issue of bonds that would have carried a maximum of 7.13 percent interest in their 30-year life, said an authority spokesman, John Cunningham.
The delay could drive up the interest rate, although Mr. Cuomo said tonight that he believed the sale would come on Wednesday.
Analysts at two major credit rating agencies, Moody's and Standard & Poor's, said they were not particularly surprised by the state budget announcement today because they had been in touch with the budget office and were aware it would increase.
But, said George W. Leung, managing director at Moody's, "This development just heightens the need for real reform in containing the budget busters," which he cited as Medicaid, corrections and welfare spending.

HEADLINE: 8 Soviet Republics Said to Agree To Take On Entire Foreign Debt

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Eight of the remaining 12 Soviet republics reportedly agreed today that they would shoulder the entire foreign debt of the Soviet Union if necessary to bolster the fractured nation's credibility in the eyes of industrialized countries whose help is considered vital to a rescue of its economy.
In response, officials of the seven leading industrial nations were reported ready to move ahead with a plan to ease debt repayment terms over the next year and provide some relief to the failing Soviet economy. 
 Before considering the extension of new credit and aid with the approach of winter hardships, wealthy nations have been demanding such reassurances that past Soviet debts will be repaid.
 
Meeting With Wealthy Nations
 The republics' agreement was reported by a participant at a critical meeting between officials of the now-sovereign republics and ministers of the Group of Seven wealthy industrial countries.
The ministers -- representing the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Italy, Germany and Japan -- are here to offer advice and badly needed aid conditioned on evidence of common resolve by the republics to deal with the chaos of the post-Communist economy.
With four republics balking, the others at the meeting "took on themselves the entire external debt," Prime Minister Vyacheslav F. Kebich of Byelorussia told correspondents during a break in difficult private discussions over how to reconstruct the economy.
The Ukraine, Uzbekistan, Azerbaijan and Georgia were reportedly skeptical about immediately signing a memorandum committing them to share in the Soviet debt of about $80 billion owed to Western governments and banks. Those that agreed to take responsibility are the Russian, Byelorussian, Moldavian, Armenian, Turkmen, Tadzhik, Kazakh and Kirghiz republics.
 
Baltic Lands Independent

Three of the 15 Soviet republics -- the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia -- have received international recognition as independent nations in the aftermath of the failed coup by hard-liners in August. They are pursuing the debt issue separately as they attempt to create their own place in the global market economy.
The republics balking over the debt left the discussions when the Group of Seven ministers began disclosing details of their aid proposals, which were not immediately made public.
One participant, the Moldavian Prime Minister, Valeriu Muravsky, said a one-year moratorium on interest payments worth about $5 billion plus a bridge loan of $1 billion were included in the Group of Seven's proposals.
 
Deferral of Payments
 But firm details and any final agreement were not expected until the conference resumes Wednesday. Going into the meeting, the understanding in Washington was that the Group of Seven officials had advanced a package that involved a deferral of payments through the winter on principal, not interest; such a deferral could save the Soviet Union $1 billion.
In addition, the officials were prepared to offer a "bridge loan," with Soviet gold reserves as collateral, from the Bank of International Settlements, a clearing house for Western central banks based in Basel, Switzerland. The size of the proposed loan was uncertain.
The negotiations were "extremely slow," said David C. Mulford, the United States Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs. "But there has been some progress," he added.
The balking republics did not flatly refuse to share in the debt eventually. But they demanded detailed assurances that there would be a fair apportionment of in the Soviet debt as well as its assets.
The Ukraine, currently the most assertively independent of the republics, termed the debt memorandum a "promissory note with no amount indicated," in the words of its Prime Minister, Vitold Fokin.
 
'We Need Clarity'
 "We need clarity, we demand nothing more," he said, terming the debt-pledge memorandum a "card trick" and a work of "mass hypnosis."
But the other republics, sensing urgency in the aid visit by the Group of Seven delegation, agreed to step forward and assume an extra share of the common debt, if necessary, according to Prime Minister Kebich of Byelorussia.
Soviet currency reserves have dwindled rapidly in parallel with the old union government's authority, leaving the surviving republics facing the risks of defaulting on the Soviet foreign debt at a critical moment when they must assure fresh credit to build for the future.
 
Convertible Ruble Is Goal
 Participants said there was a good chance some of the four balking republics would join the agreement in the next few weeks once details of the debt sharing have been worked out and the prospects for future outside help improve.
While the creditor nations -- principally Germany and France -- want a common commitment, Uzbekistan officials said they would prefer to pay their share individually to avoid having to bolster weaker republics with less ability to pay a share.
The Group of Seven meeting is focusing on the debt problem that underlies hopes to create a viable new economic community from most of the former Communist republics. As planned in an earlier treaty commitment, this association would have a full range of market freedoms and aim for making the ruble convertible and the community a full participant in the world market.
Each republic is free to enact its own free-market innovations. Thus far Russian republic President Boris N. Yeltsin is attempting to set the pace with a pending series of sweeping changes, including the first steps toward making the ruble convertible.
Mr. Yeltsin proposes to begin by ending next year the current false government valuations of the ruble's worth as well as the enforced exchange rates for foreign currencies. He would let the ruble's value float in a newly freed market in which prices would no longer be government-subsidized.

HEADLINE: Delay in Bush Re-election Bid Sets Off White House Tussle

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Despite nudging from fellow Republicans, President Bush still has not named his re-election team, and the delay is feeding a vitriolic struggle for control of the campaign as well as a new round of backstage attacks on John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff.
Mr. Bush's inaction in the face of steadily bad economic news has underscored the absence of the strong team that guided his 1988 campaign, as well as the growing problem of building a team around Mr. Sununu, whose brusque style has alienated much of the Cabinet, many of the President's political associates and even members of Mr. Bush's family.
 
Two Advisers Concerned
 Mr. Sununu has heightened the political tension by spreading the word that he will run the 1992 campaign from the White House, alarming Robert M. Teeter and Fred Malek, two close advisers who expect to be named co-managers of the re-election campaign, Republican strategists and Administration officials say. 
 So far the President has not called either Mr. Malek or Mr. Teeter to offer them campaign jobs, and both are said to be increasingly edgy about taking on major roles in an organization dominated by Mr. Sununu.
Republican strategists differ on how fast Mr. Bush should move to begin his 1992 campaign, with some saying he has plenty of time to organize his drive.
But one point of agreement is that there is no one around the President now who can confront him with unwelcome news and force action if, as some Republicans fear, he is sustaining political damage on a daily basis from the troubled economy and Democratic attacks on his domestic policies.
Those urging a quick decision on the 1992 campaign note that it does not have available the seasoned talent of 1988. Mr. Bush's closest friend, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, is involved in diplomatic missions that keep him abroad much of the time. And Mr. Bush's 1988 tactician, Lee Atwater, died this year.
White House advisers said most of the President's close friends and advisers had tried to confront him about Mr. Sununu. Mr. Bush's children have taken to derisively calling the chief of staff "Governor Nunu" and even Barbara Bush, who once defended the former New Hampshire Governor, has soured on him, Republican advisers said.
But without responding directly, Mr. Bush has turned aside their criticism and suggestions that Mr. Sununu, who declined to be interviewed, be eased out. And the President does not appear to have tipped his hand to anyone.
 
Some Reasons for Waiting
 Mr. Bush has also not made clear to anyone who is willing to talk to reporters what he is thinking about the schedule for organizing his campaign staff. Associates point out that he is a seasoned political hand with a strong campaign record and that there are practical reasons for waiting before starting a formal campaign organization, including rules about paying for Presidential travel, which will become far more complicated once Mr. Bush is a declared candidate.
Republican strategists' concerns about the slow pace in forming the Bush re-election campaign have been heightened in recent days by the steady erosion of the President's political footing in the face of bad economic news, Democratic attacks and, most recently, open criticism from members of the Republican right who mistrust his commitment to conservative causes.
Some of Mr. Bush's advisers say the widely expected entry of Patrick J. Buchanan, a conservative commentator and an outspoken critic of Mr. Bush, into New Hampshire's primary in February, the first in the nation, makes it even more urgent to name a campaign team.
They insist that Mr. Buchanan is not a real threat, but his presence in the New Hampshire primary could make it more important than ever for Mr. Bush to retain Mr. Sununu, who still has considerable influence in that state.
At a White House meeting last week some officials suggested that Mr. Bush announce his campaign team in December, instead of waiting until January as had been planned. Mr. Bush has already started raising money for the 1992 campaign, even though he has not announced his candidacy. In about two weeks recently he raised more than $4 million.
 
A Man for All Troubles
 So far, however, the President has not heeded the advice, and many Bush advisers say they now fear he could get his re-election drive off to a halting start by waiting too long to put his campaign operation in motion.
Mr. Sununu has faced political heat before, during the 1990 budget negotiations, for example, and earlier this year over his use of military aircraft for personal and political travel. Each time, criticism has risen from other members of the Bush circle who would like to dislodge Mr. Sununu as chief of staff.
In recent weeks Mr. Sununu has been blamed for virtually all of the President's political troubles: the cancellation of a trip to the Far East, a poorly planned proposal for reducing credit card interest rates, the fight over Federal financing of abortion counseling, the difficulty in getting a compromise on civil rights legislation and the slow pace of the campaign itself.
 
Standing by His Aide
 Each time Mr. Sununu has had trouble, however, Mr. Bush stood by his chief of staff, leading enemies of Mr. Sununu who also admire Mr. Bush to conclude that the President must have a strong reason for not acting. The only other explanation is that he does not disapprove of his aide's behavior.
This time there are two popular theories circulating here to explain the President's apparent support of Mr. Sununu.
One is that Mr. Bush is waiting to see if Senator Warren B. Rudman, Republican of New Hampshire, chooses to run again next year. If not Mr. Sununu might, thereby removing him from the White House gracefully.
But a senior Republican strategist said he did not believe Mr. Sununu would leave his job "regardless of what Rudman does." He dismissed the anxiety over Mr. Bush's inaction on the campaign as "worrying by people in the second tier who are anxious to get things done and believe that somehow, if there were a campaign structure and daily meetings, that things would be happening differently about economic policy or anything else."

HEADLINE: 2 Senators Seek to Revive Plan to Divert Pentagon Funds to Soviets

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19

 BODY:
In an effort to break a political impasse, two senior Senators said today that they had agreed to urge bipartisan revival of a plan to use up to $1 billion from the defense budget to aid the Soviet Union.
"Let's take the pledge" to avoid injecting the issue into the 1992 campaign, David L. Boren, an Oklahoma Democrat and a senior member of the Senate Agriculture Committee, said in outlining the initiative. "It matters too much for any of us to take cheap shots and make it a campaign issue." 
 Mr. Boren's main partner in this new effort for a truce that would clear the way for Soviet aid is Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the committee's ranking Republican.
The earlier effort, sponsored by Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia and Representative Les Aspin of Wisconsin, died a week ago after the White House failed to endorse it amid mounting charges that it was being overly attentive to foreign affairs. There was particularly strenuous opposition to a provision that would have helped retrain Soviet officers at a time when the American economy is struggling to shake off recession.
Mr. Nunn and Mr. Aspin are both Democrats.
The Senators did not provide any details today of how a new plan would differ from the old one; it was understood that they would meet over breakfast on Wednesday with Mr. Nunn, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Senator John W. Warner and others to plot further strategy. Mr. Biden is a Democrat from Delaware, Mr. Warner a Republican from Virginia.
A White House representative may also attend. A Senate official said he understood that Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, had expressed willingness to take part in the effort if a political truce could be arranged.
Democratic leaders had said of the earlier proposal that without a public expression of support by the White House they would drop it rather than suffer political repercussions alone.
The original plan, advanced within days of the failed August coup attempt, called for transferring as much as $1 billion of the military budget into humanitarian aid to the Soviet Union. A primary aim was to help insure stability as central authority was eclipsed in the country, which has more than 30,000 nuclear weapons.
As part of the plan, Air Force planes would transport food and medical supplies this winter, American companies would be given incentives to invest in converted Soviet military enterprises and there would be a joint effort by the two countries to destroy Soviet nuclear and chemical weapons.
In a related development, Marlin Fitzwater, the chief White House spokesman, said today that the Administration would act within days on a much-delayed plan to send about $1.5 billion worth of food to the Soviet Union.
The White House has repeatedly delayed offering such a package since Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan promised in late October that one would be drawn up within two weeks. This, too, has been a sensitive political subject, drawing, among other fire, the accusation by some farm state Democrats that the Administration has misrepresented the true size of an aid request made last month by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
 
Envoy Expresses Concern
 The White House announcement may have been hastened by concern expressed on Monday by Robert S. Strauss, the American Ambassador in Moscow, about mounting opposition in this country to aiding the Soviet Union. Mr. Strauss, a longtime friend and an appointee of President Bush, is a Democrat; he may have provided some impetus to the revival of the Nunn-Aspin proposal as well as to fashioning the current aid package.
The main element of the food aid package is some $1.25 billion in guarantees of bank loans that the Soviets would use to buy American grain. The United States previously gave the Soviet Union $1 billion worth of loan guarantees last December and $1.5 billion of guarantees in June; the last of this grain is to be shipped at the end of this month.
Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the chairman of the Agriculture Committee, promptly assailed the Administration plan to use credit guarantees for long-term food aid.
"By giving piecemeal foreign aid to the Soviets under the guise of agricultural credit guarantees, the Administration is playing a deceptive game with American taxpayers," who bear the ultimate risk of default, Mr. Leahy said. He called for greater coordination with Europe and Japan, with these countries paying "substantially more."
As for the Boren-Lugar initiative, the Senators' hope is to have President Bush convene a Congressional group to produce a deal by early next week.

HEADLINE: Gambling Debate Rages Anew Over Sports

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Nov. 19

 BODY:
New Jersey's multibillion-dollar gambling industry says that, like the rest of the economy, it is ailing, and it wants to expand its base by legalizing sports betting.
The proposal has raised tempers as well as interest. Bills introduced in the New Jersey Legislature to allow betting on sporting events at Atlantic City casinos and at race tracks have drawn strong opposition from the National Basketball Association, the National Football League, the New Jersey Nets basketball team and the New York Giants and Jets football teams. 
 It has also caused a split in the state's Congressional delegation. Two New Jersey representatives have proposed an amendment to a Federal bill that would stop the spread of legalized sports betting; their proposal would give New Jersey two years to decide whether it wants to add sports betting to its gaming menu. But Senator Bill Bradley, the bill's sponsor, is fighting to kill the amendment and all legalized sports betting, even in Nevada, Oregon and Delaware, which have authorized some forms of sports wagering.
"Sports betting sends the wrong message to children," Mr. Bradley, who played basketball at Princeton University and later with the New York Knicks, said in a letter to Senator Joseph R. Biden, a Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. "Sports should be about personal and team achievements, not about winning or losing money."
 
Senate to Review a Ban
 A coalition that includes the New Jersey Council of Churches, several county officials and amateur athletic organizations has announced its support for Mr. Bradley's legislation.
The Judiciary Committee will soon review the version of the Professional and Amateur Sports Protection Act that was passed by the House, which includes the amendment to exempt New Jersey while it decides the issue. Mr. Bradley's bill originally exempted states that have legalized some form of sports betting, but he has broadened it to try to ban all sports wagering.
Mr. Bradley's bill would ban sports betting in Las Vegas casinos, which report handling about $1.7 billion annually in bets on athletic events. An exemption for Nevada in the original bill prompted Representatives Robert G. Torricelli of Englewood and William J. Hughes of Ocean City, both Democrats, to argue successfully for the exemption allowing New Jersey "a window of opportunity" to catch up to its major rival as the nation's gaming capital.
 
Wagering Grows
 Mr. Torricelli said the original bill would have given Las Vegas a virtual monopoly on sports betting while permanently banning it in Atlantic City. That would pose a risk, he said, to more than $5 billion in private capital that has been invested in the Atlantic City casino industry, as well as to its 70,000 jobs and the $1.4 billion in business it does annually with New Jersey companies.
"Sports gambling exists in office pools, in wagers between friends and in organized crime -- and it is on the rise," Mr. Torricelli said in testimony before a House subcommittee in September. He cited Federal figures estimating that illegal sports betting increased by almost $13 billion from 1981 to 1989.
But Mr. Bradley and representatives of professional sports leagues said the economic arguments advanced by proponents of legalization are outweighed by the potential for corruption and the destruction of the relationship between a sports franchise and its fans, who would become more interested in whether their team beat the gambling odds than whether it won the game.
 
N.B.A. Opposition
 Mr. Bradley, who said he does not want to "see athletes turned into roulette chips," recalled the point-shaving scandals that have rocked college basketball periodically, starting in the 1950's, and said, "When the state sanctions sports gambling it is essentially, no matter what anybody will say about policing it, nodding in the direction of the gamblers' game."
He also said that legalized gambling does not reduce illegal gambling, as its proponents argue. The New Jersey lottery was supposed to cut into the illegal numbers game, he said, but law enforcement officials say it had no effect because illegal operators offer credit and illegal winnings are unreported and untaxed.
Gary B. Bettman, senior vice president and general counsel of the N.B.A., told a state Assembly committee hearing last month that a fan's perspective changes the instant one bets on a game.
Mr. Bettman imagined a situation in which the Nets are leading the Knicks by four points near the close of a game for which the Nets were favored by five. A Net snares a rebound, and the team, using sound strategy, holds onto the ball to run out the clock. But thousands of Nets fans, having placed bets at the race track across the Meadowlands complex, begin to boo because the team is not trying to beat the spread.
 
Potential for Revenue
 "The fact that the Nets have just defeated their archrival is lost on these fans who tear up their betting slips as they leave the arena," Mr. Bettman said. "This is not, I submit, what our game is intended to be about or a scenario you should encourage for New Jersey."
But Thomas D. Carver, president of the Casino Association of New Jersey, called arguments about the corrupting influence of legalized betting "specious."
"This is about property rights and money, and not about the youth of our country or anything else," he said. Atlantic City must remain competitive with Las Vegas, he added, and New Jersey casinos could easily match the $1.7 billion in sports betting reported by Las Vegas. He said this would generate $18 million in increased tax revenue for the state -- $4 million from sports betting and $14 million from betting on other games by people drawn to the casinos by sports betting.
While the casinos are lobbying for sports betting, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, which operates racing at the Meadowlands and at Monmouth Park in Oceanport, has taken no position on the bills.
But Richard Van Wagner, general manager of governmental and regulatory affairs for the authority, told the Assembly hearing that if sports betting is approved, "it should be looked at, for our purpose, as an extension of horse racing or parimutuel betting rather than a new form of gambling."
