HEADLINE: Shevardnadze Returns as Soviet Foreign Minister

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 19

 BODY:
Eleven months after he resigned with a dramatic warning that a dictatorship was approaching, Eduard A. Shevardnadze returned today to head the Foreign Ministry as it prepared for a major reorganization and reduction.
Neither Mr. Shevardnadze nor President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who reappointed the Foreign Minister, made any immediate comment. But a major move had been rumored after Russia and several other republics decided earlier this month to retain a Ministry of External Affairs as part of a sharply curtailed central government. 
 Western diplomats speculated that the return of Mr. Shevardnadze, who has been a staunch advocate of retaining the Union in some form, represented both his own interest in helping preserve a unified foreign policy, and Mr. Gorbachev's interest in giving the embattled central government as much credibility and respect as possible as it begins to restructure.
Boris D. Pankin, who was appointed Foreign Minister shortly after the August coup on the strength of his condemnation of the plotters from his post as Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, was named Ambassador to Britain today.
 
Ambassador Shuffle
 His appointment was part of a shuffle in which eight Soviet ambassadors were retired or reassigned. Most notable among these was the retirement of Leonid M. Zamyatin, 69 years old, the current Ambassador to Britain and a former chief of the International Information Department of the Communist party known for his heated defenses of Soviet policy.
In his three months at the Foreign Ministry, Mr. Pankin presided over a number of developments, including the restoration of diplomatic relations with Israel and the opening of the Middle East peace conference, but Western diplomats said he was not held in high regard within the Foreign Ministry, or in high respect among the republics.
Mr. Shevardnadze, by contrast, is a man with strong credentials among the men who now lead the country. He was probably the closest ally of Mr. Gorbachev's from the dawn of perestroika, and resigned just in time to see his warnings take shape with the bloody attempts to restore central control over the Baltic republics. During the putsch in August, Mr. Shevardnadze came to the headquarters of Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian federated repubic, and mingled with the crowd outside.
 
Welcomed in Washington
 Mr. Shevardnadze's return is also likely to be welcomed by Washington and other Western governments, where he won respect and made friends for his candid style and his achievements in translating "new thinking" into the liberation of East Europe, the winding down of the cold war and a host of disarmament agreements.
But in the Kremlin and at his neo-Gothic headquarters, Mr. Shevardnadze will rejoin a Government and a Foreign Ministry whose functions, responsibilities and future size are still unknown.
If a new "Union of Sovereign States" does take shape among at least some of the former Soviet republics, the Foreign Ministry -- merged with the former Minister of Foreign Trade, cut in half and renamed the Ministry of External Relations -- is among the central institutions that are to survive in a sharply reduced all-Union government, along with the Defense Ministry, a dismembered K.G.B. and some form of central financial institutions.
That was the decision reached last week by seven republican leaders meeting with Mr. Gorbachev in the State Council, the interim collective national executive, when they agreed to work toward a loose new confederation with a central government performing such functions as the republics assign it.
 
All Decisions Tentative
 All such decisions, however, remain tentative so long as all republics remain in the grip of nationalist fervor and economic chaos. So far, for example, the second most important republic, the Ukraine, has refused to participate in any talk of a new Union, while the most powerful republic, Russia, has continued expanding its own powers at the expense of the center.
In inviting Mr. Shevardnadze to take charge of foreign affairs, Mr. Gorbachev seemed to reach for one of the few men with sufficient prestige among all republics to have a chance of restoring a unified foreign policy. Mr. Shevardnadze will also be faced with the arduous task of slashing the Foreign Ministry, regarded as one of the most professional institutions in the Soviet Union.
Mr. Shevardnadze's political position will be different. If before he was directly subordinate to Mr. Gorbachev, he will now also be answerable to Mr. Yeltsin and other republican leaders, who have made clear they do not to let foreign policy out of their purview.
Today, for example, Mr. Yeltsin named Andrei Kolosovsky as the Russian republic's envoy to Washington, where he will serve as minister-counsellor in the Soviet Embassy. The foreign minister of the Russian republic, Andrei Kozyrev, has also demonstrated that he intends to play a role in shaping foreign policy.
 
Notable Reconciliation
 Whatever his political role will be, Mr. Shevardnadze's return marks a notable political reconciliation.
It was with the silver-haired leader of the Georgian republic that Mr. Gorbachev first plotted his reforms. In 1984, a year before Mr. Gorbachev came to power, it was Mr. Shevardnadze who told him privately, "Everything's rotten; it has to be changed." A year later Mr. Shevardnadze became one of the first members of Mr. Gorbachev's new team and his Foreign Minister.
In his memoirs, Mr. Shevardnadze described Mr. Gorbachev as his "dear, dear friend," and the suave, smooth Georgian seemed the perfect executor of the revolutionary shift in foreign policy.
By this time a year ago, however, Mr. Gorbachev had surrounded himself with old-guard Communists who held Mr. Shevardnadze personally responsible for what they saw as the unwarranted dismantling of the Soviet empire. Sensing no support from Mr. Gorbachev, aware of various plans to reimpose central control by force if need be, Mr. Shevardnadze on Dec. 20 made his prophetic resignation speech to the Congress of Peoples' Deputies, declaring that he was stepping down in "protest against the onset of dictatorship."
 
Criticism of Gorbachev
 In subsequent months, he often criticized Mr. Gorbachev. In a recently published political memoir, he wrote of Mr. Gorbachev's behavior on the eve of the coup, saying it was characteristic of the President that he "always remained deaf to the advice of the people genuinely loyal to him."
In the wake of the coup, Mr. Shevardnadze told interviewers he had no intention of returning to work with Mr. Gorbachev.
But in an interview with CNN, he also said, "If I and my colleagues in the democratic camp see that it is necessary, then everything will have to be done to pull the country out of this crisis, because an unstable Soviet Union means unstable Europe, and an unstable world."
In all other interviews in the three months since the coup, Mr. Shevardnadze has continued arguing on the need to preserve a union, and perhaps he concluded that it was time to help Mr. Gorbachev once again, this time in his struggle to preserve some form of union.

HEADLINE: Ravitch Will Now Take The Train to a New Game

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Richard Ravitch, a lawyer widely known in New York business, civic and political circles, became the No. 1 labor executive for baseball's club owners yesterday. His appointment, which had been expected, raised questions on two fronts.
*Given that he was hired at a salary said to be $750,000, which would be $100,000 more than Commissioner Fay Vincent's salary, were the owners sending the commissioner a message that he should stay out of labor relations? 
 *What effect might yet another new executive director of the Player Relations Committee have on future collective bargaining?
"The clubs are clearly entitled to appoint whoever they want to be head of the P.R.C.," said Donald Fehr, the head of the players' association, who joined the union as general counsel 14 years ago. "I find it sort of astonishing that this is the sixth director of the P.R.C. since I got here. That means once again the chief negotiator will come into negotiations without any experience in this industry. Beyond that, we will have to wait and see what happens."
Ravitch, an unsuccessful candidate for mayor of New York City in 1989, has been involved in labor negotiations and strikes, as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
"I think I've always enjoyed good relations with labor unions," he said in a telephone interview. "It's always been adversarial but never hostile."
Ravitch, 58 years old, becomes the sixth chief labor negotiator for baseball management, succeeding Charles O'Connor, a Washington lawyer, who remains as general counsel. As chief negotiator, O'Connor was joined in 1990 by Vincent and his deputy, Steve Greenberg, in the effort to reach an agreement that would end the owners' lockout of players from spring training camps. They succeeded after the lockout reached 32 days, but some owners were not pleased with the results. They felt that Vincent had played a role that was too large, too soft and too conciliatory.
Union officials and players, on the other hand, welcomed Vincent's effort and looked forward to a continuing relationship.
Bud Selig, owner of the Milwaukee Brewers and P.R.C. board chairman, said Ravitch's hiring -- he would not confirm his salary -- in no way was meant as a message to the commissioner to stay out of labor relations.
"That's not the message," Selig said by telephone from Milwaukee. "The message is very clear. The P.R.C. felt it needed the best person it could find. We determined we needed a person with the most varied background, a person who had great people skills, great intellect, a person who could do a great job at a time when baseball is at an economics crossroads. It's no more complicated than that."
Ravitch, who in 1975 was asked by Gov. Hugh Carey of New York to rescue the Urban Development Corporation, said it seemed "to be my fate in life -- maybe it's some masochistic streak -- to take on tough problems."
"I don't know enough yet," Ravitch said when asked about baseball's economics. "I have certain peoples' perception of the problems. I'm trying to get a handle on the issues. I'm learning about the economics of baseball as quickly as I can."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Chairman Plans To Refocus Action Auto

 BODY:
Norton W. Rose has been elected chairman of Action Auto Rental, which provides rental cars mostly through insurance companies and auto repair shops, for drivers who have lost their vehicles through accidents, theft and other causes.
Mr. Rose, who is 62, has spent more than 30 years in the retail and insurance industries, and he hopes to use his skills in marketing to help refocus Action and revive its sagging financial performance. The privately held company based in Solon, Ohio, near Cleveland, lost $19 million in the first three quarters of 1991, compared with $7.9 million in the corresponding period of 1990. 
 "This business hasn't had a lot of marketing," Mr. Rose said, "nor has the industry as a whole. The people who are in it usually grew up in it. I hope I can bring a fresh look."
Action was founded in 1984 by Craig E. Hons, who is president and chief executive; James A. Terwoord, who is the chief financial officer; James Schiering, executive vice president, and Russell Smith, who is no longer with the company.
Action supplies rental cars in 35 states. The market has softened and Action hopes Mr. Rose, with his background in retailing, can help develop higher consumer awareness for the company.
"The industry is being impacted by the economy for the first time," Mr. Terwoord said. "Claim centers are reporting fewer accidents, so the demand is depressed."
According to Mr. Terwoord, Action Auto plans to concentrate on marketing and training personnel in customer relations to raise revenues, which is the primary reason they chose Mr. Rose. During his 33-year career at the Cole National Corporation, a specialty retailing company that owns chains like the Original Cookie Company and Things Remembered, Mr. Rose was president and chief executive officer for 14 years and oversaw the company's expansion from 300 stores to 1,900.
After leaving Cole National in 1982, Mr. Rose formed his own management consulting firm, and in 1985 became vice chairman of the Progressive Corporation, a property-casualty insurance company, under a special four-year arrangement.
"Norton's knowledge of the insurance business is clearly a plus," Mr. Terwoord said, "but it's secondary to his retail experience."
Mr. Rose agrees: "Renting cars from 180 branches in 35 states is a retail function. I hope to concentrate on the basics here: When branches make money, the company makes money."
Mr. Rose attended Ohio State for one year, he said, "and it was a very, very unimportant part of my life." He joined Cole National in 1948, and has been in business ever since.
In addition to his position at Action Auto, Mr. Rose will continue as president of his consulting firm, Norton W. Rose & Company, and will continue to sit on the boards of nine other companies.
Mr. Rose has four children and lives with his wife, Jackie, in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

HEADLINE: Back to the Bush in Zaire

 BODY:
As his country collapses around him, President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire finds that even his old American friends have deserted him. The only argument in Washington is whether he ought to be induced to share power in a transition regime or nudged aboard a midnight flight to exile. A nudge to the exit is long overdue.
Elevated to power with Western help, Mr. Mobutu in 26 years has amassed billions, including castles, palaces and luxurious estates in Europe. Meantime, the people of Zaire are poorer today than when the former Belgian Congo became independent in 1960. 
 Poverty and desperation have brought Zaire close to anarchy. An ill-paid army has run wild, inflation has soared and thousands of foreign workers and technicians have fled, crippling a once-flourishing mining industry. Hopes for a political resolution evaporated last month when Mr. Mobutu dismissed the opposition Prime Minister he had appointed only a month earlier.
Zaire's tragedy is America's embarrassment. Six successive Administrations have closed their eyes to Mr. Mobutu's kleptocracy and played down his brutality. Zaire has been viewed as "an element of stability" in Africa, a vital bulwark against Communism. But with the end of the cold war, Mr. Mobutu lost his last shred of legitimacy.
In 1960 Mr. Mobutu, then a high army officer, was nominally a supporter of the leftist Patrice Lumumba, Zaire's only elected Prime Minister. Alarmed by Mr. Lumumba's friendly overtures to Moscow, the Eisenhower Administration became convinced of the need, as one U.S. diplomat put it, to "find or develop another horse."
At that time there was turmoil in what was invariably called the "copper-rich breakaway province of Katanga," which threatened secession. A United Nations peacekeeping force was dispatched to impose a solution. In the melee, with C.I.A. complicity, Mr. Lumumba was murdered. In 1965 Mr. Mobutu seized power in a coup; the West had found its horse.
No doubt Mr. Mobutu was, as the saying went, a cold war asset. He made himself useful to Washington by aiding a rebellion against a new Marxist regime in Angola. By the 1970's, Zaire was the biggest recipient of U.S. aid in sub-Saharan Africa.
That era has passed, yet last year the Bush Administration was still pushing for arms aid to Zaire. Congress fortunately decided otherwise. The present reality in Zaire is captured in a report by The Times's Kenneth Noble from Kikwit, a once flourishing city of 400,000: "Civilization is coming to an end here," said the manager of an empty food store. "We're back where we started. We're going back to the bush."
Mr. Mobutu promises to agree by tomorrow on a formula for choosing a new prime minister who can competently head a new government. The wise and decent course is for Mr. Mobutu to honor that pledge, and then depart.

HEADLINE: The Senate's Credit Card Blunder

 BODY:
The Senate's hasty reaction to President Bush's call for lower interest on credit cards is a model of how not to govern. The President's exhortation was harmless jawboning. But the Senate's overwhelming approval of an interest-rate cap barely 24 hours later was populist folly.
Price controls, whether on goods or the cost of credit, are a bad idea except in a genuine emergency. They distort economic activity, and the eventual process of decontrol is always painful. Nonetheless, with no public hearings and only 30 minutes of floor discussion, 73 senators agreed with Senator Alfonse D'Amato's rash proposal to chop most credit card rates immediately. 
 Three-quarters of America's households have credit cards -- about 1.3 billion cards altogether. Visa and Mastercard are the most widely used, and Citicorp is the biggest issuer. But there is no lack of competition among banks, as well as from American Express, the Sears Discover card, A.T.& T. and countless stores and oil companies.
Their interest rates tend to cluster between 18 and 20 percent, but shoppers with good credit standing can find lower rates, even below 10 percent. Most don't bother, though. Roughly one-third of all card holders don't care about rates; they pay on time and owe no interest. Others may simply take the card their bank offers, or whatever comes in the mail, regardless of the interest rate.
It is true that credit card rates are high, and that they've hardly budged while other rates have plunged. But it does not follow that credit card users would benefit from a forced cut to Senator D'Amato's arbitrary 14 percent. One reason rates are slow to fall is that, in a recession, the issuers must absorb higher losses from rising defaults. Indeed, the impulsive Senator from New York couldn't have picked a worse time for his mischief.
Millions of card holders would suffer, because banks and other issuers would cancel the cards of less creditworthy customers. People with limited incomes would suffer most; they depend on the elbow room a credit card provides. Issuers would suffer too, especially troubled banks in need of card profits to offset other loan losses. And the economy would suffer. It's already sluggish, and a curb on consumer credit wouldn't help.
The House is moving more deliberately than the Senate. Unnerved by Friday's sharp stock market drop and heavily lobbied by card issuers and the Administration, it is caught between the obviously popular idea of reducing rates and the risk of doing real harm.
A sensible proposal by Representative Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, would make credit card issuers disclose their rates more conspicuously. To blunt the commotion over the D'Amato bill, there has also been talk of a nonpartisan study of the industry's competitiveness, meanwhile delaying a rate ceiling until after the study.
Such a survey would be useful, but a decision on whether to impose a cap sometime in the future should wait. It's not likely to make any more sense then it does now.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "How Many Pay What Rate" shows the number of bank cards, in millions, and the interest rate paid. (Source: Consumer Credit Card Rating Service, Santa Monica, Calif.)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
The 'Lost' Soviet Trade Bill

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Mighty matters in the U.S. Government often turn on small principles and on the whims of powerful men like Dan Rostenkowski and Richard Darman. An eight-month tiff between the imperious chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee and the devious White House budget chief explains why Congress still has not approved a key ingredient of U.S. foreign policy -- the bill to establish most-favored-nation trading status for the Soviet Union.
In June, President Bush decided that Moscow had finally removed barriers to emigration and was thus qualified for normal, or M.F.N., trade rank. His hope was to reduce tariffs quickly for Soviet exports, as one of the few inexpensive ways to help the deteriorating Soviet economy. 
 But the fates would not have it done so easily. They tapped two men renowned for jousting and jockeying, and turned matters of high policy into a legislative pie-throwing contest.
Actually the fates intervened two years ago when the Jesuit Fathers of Loyola University of Chicago asked their most influential alumnus, Mr. Rostenkowski, to help secure Federal funds for a library and business school. Like any creative legislator, he gazed upon the Pentagon budget and unearthed an odd $8 million. And who was to tell him no?
Well, the fathers told him no. They said they did not want money from the very source that was financing bloody Central American dictators. Ever the good alumnus, Mr. Rostenkowski switched the $8 million in March from the defense budget to the Education Department budget.
Richard Darman, ever vigilant against scams he did not conceive, told the chairman he could not do that. The move violated the sacred budget covenant of 1990, which barred transferring money between military and domestic spending accounts. But, replied the chairman, it was only a few million and surely Mr. Darman could find some extra dollars lying around domestic accounts to cover the small excess.
No, said Mr. Darman. A deal was a deal, and no matter how small the amount, any deviation from the covenant would cause the whole temple of government to tumble down.
You're kidding, said the chairman.
Mr. Darman wasn't kidding. He did what he was empowered by law to do -- he sequestered or set aside the necessary funds to cover the excess from every domestic budget account. This came to 0.0013 percent or an average of 10 cents from each domestic program.
The chairman was not happy. He had tried to do a good deed for his alma mater, for which generosity Mr. Darman had embarrassed him by public sequestration. The day of reckoning, however, was not far off.
In August Mr. Bush sent Congress M.F.N. legislation, and it went to Mr. Rostenkowski's committee. He immediately wrote to Mr. Darman, inquiring whether the U.S. Treasury would lose money as a result of the lowered tariffs, and whether this loss would be covered by sequestering funds from other international accounts. Mr. Darman said it was only a little amount. Mr. Rostenkowski said a deal was a deal no matter how tiny the sum, and unless Mr. Darman produced the necessary funds ($20 million for loss in revenues from the Soviet Union and another $20 million for other countries), he would not take action on the M.F.N. bill.
There matters stood until yesterday. The budget chief wrote to the chairman announcing he had found extra money, and that if the committee acted "promptly," there would be no need for sequestration. His point made, the chairman's committee passed the M.F.N. bill.
Now everybody is happy again. Loyola University will receive its $8 million from the Education Department, not the Pentagon. The Pentagon gets to keep its own $8 million for other worthy purposes. Dan Rostenkowski and Dick Darman can hold their heads high, having preserved budget principles. And the administrative bill for the 0.0013 percent sequestration ordered by Mr. Darman probably cost the American taxpayer only an additional $10 million.
Now also, M.F.N. status for the Soviet Union can make its way through Congress, and more Soviet exports will enter the U.S. at lower tariffs. That is, if the U.S.S.R. doesn't, as Ambassador Robert Strauss has warned, "blow up in our face" and turn "fascist" while Washington power brokers play their games.

HEADLINE: Carl Winter, Imprisoned by U.S. As Communist Leader, Dies at 85

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Carl Winter, a Communist Party official and former editor who in 1949 was among the first group of defendants to be convicted under the Smith Act of conspiring against the United States Government, died Saturday in New York. He was 85 years old and lived in Detroit.
He collapsed at the party's offices in Manhattan and died of a heart attack minutes after giving a speech, said a party spokesman, Si Gerson. 
 Mr. Winter, the party chairman in Michigan, served a five-year sentence in Federal prisons. On release from the prison in Leavenworth, Kan., he was immediately rearrested on parallel charges. They were not dropped until 1963.
The Smith Act, also known as the Alien Registration Act of 1940, made it a criminal offense to conspire to advocate violent overthrow of the Government or to organize or belong to any group that so conspired. After World War II, the act was used to prosecute ranking members of the American Communist Party.
In July 1948, dual conspiracy and membership indictments were handed up against Mr. Winter, but the Federal District Court in Manhattan declined a Government motion to combine them in one trial. After nine months of testimony before Judge Harold J. Medina, Mr. Winter and 10 others were found guilty of conspiracy. Six more groups of alleged conspirators were awaiting trial at the time.
The Supreme Court upheld the convictions of the 11 in 1951. When Mr. Winter emerged from prison in 1955, he and others were promptly arrested again on the membership indictments. While Mr. Winter remained free on bail, legal scholars questioned the arrest, and intellectuals petitioned President Dwight D. Eisenhower, noting that the defendants would be in double jeopardy as the case would largely echo the conspiracy prosecution.
In a 1957 decision, the Supreme Court began to amend its 1951 judgment with a narrower reading of the Smith Act, and the Court's further modification of its position in 1963 led to the dropping of charges against Mr. Winter.
Mr. Winter resumed his role as Michigan state chairman. He later was the party's Midwest director before becoming editor in chief of The Worker, the national party newspaper published in New York City, in 1966 and then co-editor of The World, its successor paper, now the People's Weekly World.
 
Joined Party in 1925
 Born in Pittsburgh, he became a draftsman, joined the party in 1925 and turned full-time party functionary in 1931 as head of the Unemployment Council of Greater New York. He then held various other party positions in Cleveland, Los Angeles and elsewhere before becoming Michigan chairman in 1945.
At the time of his death, he was a member of the National Committee of the Communist Party USA.
Mr. Winter is survived by his wife, Helen, herself a Smith Act defendant and daughter of Alfred Wagenknecht, a charter member of the party in the United States. Also surviving are their daughter, Helen, and two grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 21, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Carl Winter, a Communist Party leader who was convicted of conspiracy against the United States Government, misidentified his daughter. Her first name is Michele.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
'Smart' Plans for Clogged Roads

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Each day on the nation's streets, roads and highways, some 135 million cars -- one for every 1.8 people in the country -- are vying for the American right to freedom of movement. But during peak periods, two-thirds of the cars on interstate highways are moving at less than 35 miles an hour. And around cities like New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, many are barely moving at all.
Seeking relief from the congestion, government, academic and industry researchers have for more than two decades experimented with automated highway and driver-information systems to route cars around bottlenecks or prevent tie-ups in the first place. But so far, the work and the financing have been intermittent. 
 Now, however, at a time when Congress is setting aside more money for highway-automation research, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is gearing up a broad-based partnership with private industry to put the traffic-management theories where the rubber meets the road.
 
'More Than Just an Annoyance'
 "Traffic is more than just an annoyance; it has direct economic costs," said Moshe Ben-Akiva, a professor of civil engineering at M.I.T. and director of the project. "Highway networks are directly related to productivity in this country."
Enlisting participation and money from auto makers, electronics manufacturers, transportation companies and other businesses, M.I.T. intends to weave together various threads of research to bring forth national proposals and standards for what are known as "intelligent vehicle/highway systems." Professor Ben-Akiva said M.I.T. was "in a unique position to bring together technical, engineering and policy-making know-how in an institutional setting,"
The goal: to make real a long-envisioned system of dashboard computers with electronic links to roadways and to highway control centers. Such a network could provide instant and accurate traffic information, indicate the best available routes, enhance urban traffic management and support accident-avoidance systems.
Already, Motorola Inc. and Sumitomo of Japan have signed up for the M.I.T. project. And Professor Ben-Akiva estimated that as many as 20 other companies would each make commitments to provide $75,000 annually for at least three years to support the research. The work is expected to begin bearing technological fruit -- initially in cars, eventually in highways -- over the next decade.
 
Delays Long, and Increasing
 The Federal Department of Transportation, which supports most of the intelligent-highway research around the nation, estimates that every year traffic congestion causes more than two billion vehicle hours of delays; the department estimates that those delays will increase fourfold by the year 2000. And a study of 39 large cities by the Texas Transportation Institute at Texas A & M University estimates that productivity lost to traffic is already costing the United States more than $40 billion a year.
Congress, in an effort to stimulate solutions, appropriated $20 million for intelligent-highway research last year, and this year has approved more than seven times that amount -- $150 million -- as a provision of the Surface Transportation Authorization Act of 1991. The legislation, which has been passed by both the House and Senate, is expected to become law, perhaps before Thanksgiving.
M.I.T. is likely to receive part of the Congressional money, as are other universities in the field, including the University of Michigan and the University of California at Berkeley.
Joseph Sussman, an M.I.T. civil engineering professor on leave to work on the Transportation Department's smart-highways effort, predicts that the technology "will become the anchor for transportation for the next 30 years, just as the interstate highway system was over the last 40."
At M.I.T., which currently has about $1 million a year in research money for its intelligent-highways work, Professor Ben-Akiva's team will pull together the efforts of various departments within the university. The disparate groups include the Center for Transportation Studies; the Center for Technology, Policy and Industrial Development; the Intelligent Engineering Systems Lab; the Lincoln Laboratory electronics research center, and the Man-Machine Systems Laboratory. Professor Ben-Akiva also expects the M.I.T. Media Lab and the Sloan Automotive Lab to participate eventually.
The advanced systems aim to give drivers more timely and precise information than setups like the current network of overhead electronic signs on the Long Island Expressway -- which, when it works, often provides little more help than a message like "Delays Ahead" to the motorist already mired in traffic molasses.
Professor Ben-Akiva said that future approaches, ideally, would provide individual drivers accurate information about the best available route before they became stuck. The systems would also allow for sophisticated management of overall traffic.
Professor Ben-Akiva noted that today most people depend on low-tech alternatives like the intermittent traffic updates on local radio stations. These advisories, unfortunately, rely largely on anecdotal and highly subjective observations.
Professor Ben-Akiva has discovered, for instance, that four traffic reporters working for four Boston-area radio stations fly together every day in a single helicopter provided by Metro Traffic Control Inc. After recording and analyzing the four stations' morning drive-time programming for a week, he concluded that the motoring public was often receiving conflicting advice.
"All the reports were different in what they emphasized and the traffic picture they painted," he said, "despite the fact that the four reporters were sitting right next to each other."
 
2-Way Communications
 Various technological approaches are on the drawing board, and in some cases, already on the roadways. M.I.T.'s program is intended to pursue several intelligent vehicle-highway system concepts.
One concept is the Advanced Traveler Information System and Advanced Traffic-Management System. Such a system would offer two-way communications between drivers and highway operations centers. Computer networks would monitor the highways, and drivers would have access through dashboard computer screens to information on immediate road conditions, traffic snags and alternative routes.
In Minneapolis, a percursor to such a system employs highway video cameras, electronic road signs and orchestrated traffic lights. Motorists receive traffic updates from a special radio station. The experiment has helped to raise average speeds by 35 percent and to reduce accidents by 27 percent on a three-mile stretch of Interstate 394.
In Seattle, a conceptually similar experiment, involving electronic surveillance of highway entrance ramps and the synchronized timing of traffic lights on the ramps, has reduced average travel time to 11.5 minutes, from 22 minutes, on a 6.9-mile stretch of interstate highway.
A second research category at M.I.T. involves automated vehicle-control systems. Such systems would automate functions now performed by drivers, sensing objects around the vehicle, warning of impending collisions and braking to avoid collision. A sophisticated cruise-control function would keep the vehicle centered in its lane and detect slower vehicles ahead.
Commercial vehicle operations are a third category. These systems would provide specialized functions for commercial vehicles, like fleet monitoring, truck weighing and toll paying, while allowing highway officials to ascertain whether traveling vehicles meet weight limits and other regulatory guidelines.
Thomas D. Larson, the head of the Federal Highway Administration, said he was excited about the M.I.T. project because of the history of cooperation between M.I.T. and industrial partners, in fields as diverse as military technology and personal computing. He also pointed out that the cross-disciplinary cooperation between technology departments and policy-making centers made M.I.T.'s efforts a key to the long-range success of intelligent-highway research. "M.I.T. probably has as complete a program as you can find anywhere," Mr. Larson said.
Such efforts are crucial, Mr. Larson said, because the national highway system has reached its capacity. Limited space and the resistance of landowners mean that the historical remedy -- building more roads -- is no longer an option.
What is more, he said, the public's patience has been pushed beyond capacity, too: "Red-light running is becoming epidemic, because people are just so frustrated. We have to turn to technology. We simply must find relief."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Jersey Turnpike Issue Is Rated A

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Services yesterday confirmed its A rating on the New Jersey Turnpike Authority's revenue bond issue that is expected to be negotiated this week with underwriters. The issue totals $1.3 billlion of serial refunding bonds. 
 Moody's said the turnpike has shown strong growth in traffic in recent years, but the recession and a large toll increase have contributed to a 6 percent decline in traffic so far this year. An additional 50 percent toll increase is likely to be needed in 1995, Moody's said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields of Money Funds Are Down in Week

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
Yields on tax-exempt and taxable money market funds fell moderately in the week that ended yesterday, according to IBC/Donoghue's, which monitors them and publishes The Money Fund Report.
"There were some postponements of large municipal offerings, which affected the supply and tended to lower interest rates," Walter S. Frank, the chief economist for IBC/ Donoghue's, said concerning the yields on tax-exempt funds. "We will see a heavy supply soon, which will probably bolster yields." 
 As for the taxables, he said, "We would expect the yields to begin to bottom out, although they are still feeling the impact of the recent Federal Reserve easing."
He added that that by the end of next month, seasonal influences would have taken hold, and those should temporarily raise yields above what he called their equilibrium levels.
 
Tax-Exempt Assets Up
 Total assets of the tax-exempt funds inched up by only $192 million, to $91.3 billion, compared with the huge rise of $1.2 billion the previous week. The average days to maturity of holdings in tax-exempt portfolios slipped by a day, to 59.
The seven-day compound average yield for tax-exempt funds fell to 3.75 percent, from 3.82 percent, a decline of 7 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The seven-day simple yield for the tax-exempts dropped to 3.69, from 3.75 percent.
At the same time, the 30-day compound yield dropped to 3.87 percent, from 3.89 percent, while the 30-day simple compound yield was at 3.80 percent, down from 3.82 percent.
Among the tax-exempt funds that invest in individual state securities, the top New York fund was, once again, the Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.49 percent, down by a basis point from 4.50 percent the previous week.
 
Fidelity Leads in Connecticut
 In Connecticut, the leader once again was the Fidelity Spartan Connecticut Municipal Money Market Portfolio, reporting a seven-day compound yield of 4.11 percent, down by 2 basis points from 4.13 percent.
In New Jersey, the best showing was made by the Prudential N.J. Municipal Money Market Fund, with a yield of 4.28 percent.
The highest-yielding tax-exempt fund among those with assets greater than $100 million continued to be the Strong Municipal Money Market Fund, with a seven-day compound yield of 4.80 percent, down by 4 basis points.
The assets of taxable funds, Mr. Frank said, rose by $7.6 billion in the last week, to a total of $471.7 billion. "Of that rise, $6.7 billion came from institutional investors," he said. "This presumably was money leaving the stock market and being put into money market funds as a temporary haven. We get a snapshot only once a week."
The average maturities of portfolio holdings were unchanged at 63 days, Mr. Frank said.
 
7-Day Yield Down to 4.90%
 The seven-day compound yield on taxable funds dropped by 2 basis points, to 4.90 percent, from 4.92 percent, while the seven-day simple yield for the taxable funds dropped to 4.78 percent, 3 basis points under last week's 4.81 percent.
Meanwhile, the average compound 30-day yield fell to 5.00 percent, from 5.06 percent, and the 30-day simple yield was down to 4.88 from 4.94 percent.
The top-yielding taxable fund for the week continued to be Riverside Capital in Columbus, Ohio, with a seven-day compound yield of 5.95 percent, compared with 6.07 last week.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, a primary competitor of the money funds, dropped to a yield of 4.74 percent, from 4.78 percent a week earlier, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Reports of Soviet Food Aid Send Wheat Prices Soaring

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Wheat prices soared today on reports that the Bush Administration would offer the Soviet Union a food assistance package that would include large amounts of American wheat.
After the close of trading, the White House announced a smaller-than-expected $1.25 billion package of credit guarantees for the Soviets, to be used primarily to buy grains for cattle. 
 Nevertheless, analysts were moderately positive about the long-awaited deal, although it failed to meet traders' hopes that the grant would be worth at least $1.5 billion. The Soviet Government had requested $3.5 billion in aid.
"I think the credit package will continually feed the market with demand, and there is no fundamental reason to sell," said Bill Biedermann, an analyst at Allendale Inc.,
Wheat prices, already buoyed by China's bids for a million metric tons of American wheat this week, shot up 13 cents in the December contract to close at $3.67 a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade.
Meanwhile, January soybeans inched up 1.75 cents, to $5.64 1/2 a bushel, and December corn rose 2 cents, to $2.41 3/4 a bushel.
At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, beef and pork prices rose, with the cattle market firmer following the Government's monthly report on herd size.
Traders pointed to the Agriculture Department's estimate that during October a smaller number of cattle were placed on feedlots to be fattened. The figure caused February live cattle to rise 0.350 of a cent, to 75.10 cents a pound. November feeder cattle gained 0.375 of a cent, to 84.375 cents a pound.
A storm approaching the Great Plains helped drive up hog and belly prices, on the belief that it will be more difficult to bring animals to market. December live hogs gained 0.725 cent, to 42.525 cents a pound, and February pork bellies firmed at 0.250 cent, to 40.40 cents a pound.
An encouraging housing starts report, which showed October starts up a surprising 7.3 percent, lifted lumber prices at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. January lumber closed $1.40 higher at $205.10 for a thousand board feet.
Oil prices rebounded from their sharp downturn earlier this week on the New York Mercantile Exchange. December crude oil, in its last day of trading before the contract expires, rose 22 cents, to $22.22 a barrel.
"We may be in the midst of a rally that could last a day or two," said Peter Beutel, energy analyst at Pegasus Econometric Inc. "But, long term, what we've seen this week is an indication the market wants to go lower."
December unleaded gasoline gained 0.83 cent, to 63.45 cents a gallon, helped by the American Petroleum Institute's report that inventories had fallen last week.
Higher domestic inventories of heating oil burdened that market, and December dropped 0.70 of a cent, to 63.73 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Light Trading; Gold Prices Mostly Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced on world currency markets yesterday, but trading was light as dealers turned their attention to Wall Street.
Gold prices were mostly higher. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $364.30 a troy ounce, up 40 cents from Tuesday. The Republic National Bank said gold rose 75 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $363.65. 
 Analysts said trading was dull, with the dollar confined to a relatively narrow range. The currency's seesaw moves essentially tracked the stock market.
"When the stock market moved up, the dollar rose; when it was weakening, the dollar sold off," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the financial advisory firm IDEA.
The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial issues lost less than 2 points on the day but had been slightly higher for much of the session.
A better-than-expected 7.3 percent jump in housing starts last month failed to reverse the currency market's bearish psychology.
"The data that's been coming out recently has been pretty weak and dismal for the economy," said Kevin Lawrie, director of foreign exchange at the Bank of Boston. Despite the favorable housing starts report, "people are waiting to jump on the bandwagon to sell the dollar," he said.
Traders said the Canadian dollar came under severe pressure, and the Bank of Canada entered the market to shore up the flagging currency by purchasing it. There were rumors that a number of large institutional investors were selling their Canadian dollars despite the high interest rates available there.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.08 yen, to a closing 129.40 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 129.75 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 129.80 yen, unchanged from Tuesday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7945, from $1.7965 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.7977 to buy one pound, less expensive than Tuesday's $1.8000.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6000 German marks, up from 1.5965; 1.4200 Swiss francs, up from 1.4165; 5.4658 French francs, up from 5.4125; 1,208.00 Italian lire, up from 1,207.00, and 1.1355 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1288.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's rates, included: 1.6025 German marks, up from 1.6020; 1.4223 Swiss francs, up from 1.4195; 5.4758 French francs, up from 5.4710; 1.8055 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8045; 1,210.25 Italian lire, down from 1,211.15, and 1.1360 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1287.
Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $362.85 a troy ounce, from $363.25 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, it fell to a closing bid of $362.60 from $363.10. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.95 to close at a bid $362.52.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New York City Sale Goes Well

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
A $1.27 billion offering of New York City bonds was warmly received by investors yesterday, but the securities were sold at higher interest rates than had been anticipated late last week.
The negotiated sale produced yields that range from 4.50 percent on securities maturing in 1992, 7 percent on bonds maturing in 1996, 7.60 percent in 2001 and 7 7/8 percent on securities maturing from 2010 through 2015. 
 The maximum yield was well under the 8.10 percent generated at the last city bond sale in early August. But municipal bond market participants said late last week that they expected the maximum yield on the city securities sold yesterday would probably not exceed 7.75 percent.
News on Tuesday from New York State budget officials that the gap in the coming state budget may be twice what was estimated during the summer is almost certainly the reason why the city was forced to pay higher rates for the securities, analysts said.
The budget news created turmoil in outstanding New York State debt issues on Tuesday, and yesterday the market reaction pursuaded syndicate managers to reprice an issue of $423 million worth of securities for the Metropolitan Transit Authority.
Those securities, which are payable solely from and are secured by payments from New York State, were initially offered to investors last week.
The underwriting syndicate, led by Goldman, Sachs & Company, raised yields by anywhere from 5 basis points, or five one-hundredths of a percentage point, to 15 basis points on securities maturing in 1995 through 2006.
"We repriced them because we believed that the market was no longer reflective of where it had been relative to the M.T.A.," said David C. Clapp, a general partner at Goldman, Sachs.
 
City Bond Issue Proceeds
 Proceeds from the city bond issue will be used for the nullifaction, or defeasance, of outstanding bonds backed by insurance companies or commercial letters of credit.
Defeasance is a process by which interest and principal payments will come from a pool of Treasury securities rather than from the city. The process will allow insurers to provide more guarantees for coming city debt issues, which will result in lower borrowing costs.
"We still have to do our final calculations, but it looks like this will save the city around $120 million in borrowing costs, $87 million of which will come in the current fiscal year, " said Eric H. Altman, a managing director at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc., lead manager on the New York City underwriting.
Mr. Altman said that demand for the securities was well in excess of the amount sold. The issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Developments in the tax-exempt municipal bond market overshadowed activity in the Government securities market yesterday.
A report showing that housing starts posted an unexpectedly robust 7.3 percent increase in October helped to push down prices of Treasury securities early in the session. But those declines were reversed as the session wore on, and prices were generally higher than late Tuesday as traders headed home.
 
Encouraged by Housing Report
 After a spate of dismal economic reports, analysts said they were encouraged by the housing report. But they cautioned against reading too much into one upbeat statistic.
"It is good news, and it is conceivable we may be seeing a reaction to lower mortgage interest rates," said Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington.
"But I don't think we are seeing enough here to say that the recovery is staying afloat. We need more good numbers to be able to do that. And the recent statistics have been quite discouraging."
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 101 6/32, up 1/4 point, to yield 7.89 percent, compared with 7.91 percent late Tuesday.
Among outstanding Treasury note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101, up 1/32, to yield 7.35 percent.
Yesterday the Treasury announced it will sell $13.5 billion worth of two-year notes on Monday and $9 billion worth of five-year notes on Tuesday.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.50 percent, while the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 6.55 percent.
The auctions, which are normally held later in the week, have been moved up this month because of Thanksgiving.
The Treasury also announced that the deadline for noncompetitive bids at the two-year note sale will be moved up one hour, to 11 A.M., and that competitive bids at that sale must be submitted by noon.
No reason was given for the change, but analysts said the move seemed clearly aimed at avoiding a conflict with announcement of results from the Treasury's weekly bill sale, which will also be held on Monday.
Rates on outstanding Treasury bills moved lower yesterday.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.47 percent late yesterday, down 5 basis points. Six-month bill rates fell by 2 basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.53 percent.
A number of other issuers besides New York City offered new securities in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.
Among the other states and localities that priced new debt was the State of Florida's Board of Education, which sold $250 million worth of securities at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Dillon, Read & Company won the offering, which consists of serial and term bonds.
Yields on the serial bonds range from 4.60 percent on bonds maturing in 1993 to 6.60 percent on securities maturing in 2011.
Term bonds maturing in 2022 were priced to yield 6.72 percent.
The issue is rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.

HEADLINE: Chemical and Hanover Reach Accord With Community Group

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Chemical Bank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company have agreed with a New York community group to increase local lending. In return, the group promised not to file a protest that could have delayed the planned year-end merger of the two banks.
Under the agreement with Acorn, as the Association of Community Organizations for Reform Now is known, the merged bank, which will operate under the Chemical name, would lend $750 million over the next five years. Carol Parry, managing director at Manufacturers Hanover, said the $750 million would be "a significant increase over what the two banks have been lending." 
 The $750 million program is similar to one announced by the banks in late October, but is much less than a $10 billion lending commitment over 10 years that Acorn sought earlier in the month. The lending will mostly consist of mortgage loans for low- and moderate-income families but will also include loans for small businesses and multifamily housing.
The biggest change toward more lenient credit standards will be in a $10 million mortgage program. The banks will hold the loans themselves, rather than sell them to investors who require tougher credit standards.
For those mortgages, the bank will lend up to 95 percent of a home's value; recognize some nontraditional forms of income, like Government assistance, rent from boarders and food stamps; waive the $250 application fee, and eliminate the one-point mortgage fee if mortgage rates rise to 10 percent or higher.
Related fees for the city's mortgage tax, title search and insurance, lawyers and appraisals would be reduced to an unspecified level. Home buyers would still be required to pay for private mortgage insurance, "if we can find it at a reasonable cost," Ms. Parry said.
All applicants for the $10 million program must attend credit counseling programs conducted by Acorn or other groups.
"Once Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover see the success of their low- and middle-income lending, we think other banks will want to do the same thing, and there could be a significant increase in that kind of lending in New York City," said John L. Kest, chief organizer in New York City for Acorn.
The agreement helps clear the way for a possible approval of the merger by the Dec. 31 target date. If the Federal Reserve approves the deal before the end of this month, the Justice Department will have the 30 days it requires to study any antitrust and competitive aspects of the merger before the end of the year.

HEADLINE: U.S. May Study, Not Cap, Rates

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Abandoning the idea of a cap on credit card interest rates, House leaders agreed tonight on a measure that would force a Government study to determine whether the rates are too high.
If any measure on credit cards becomes law this year, it is likely to this one. 
 The legislation was worked out primarily by two senior Democrats on the House Banking Committee, Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Esteban E. Torres of California, the chairman of the consumer affairs subcommittee. The subcommittee plans to meet Friday to draft the bill.
House leaders rejected the idea of a 14 percent ceiling on credit-card rates, which was approved by the Senate last week. Representatives said they feared the effect of such a cap on shaky banks, on the stock market and on the economy. Many credit card interest rates are now between 18 and 20 percent.
The Schumer-Torres proposal would require a nine- month study by the General Accounting Office, the Government's auditors, to determine whether rates are excessive.
If too little competition is found, the President would have authority to impose a cap 10 percentage points above the six-month average for six- month Treasury bills. At current rates, that would mean credit card interest could be no higher than 15.5 percent.

HEADLINE: U.S. Transfers Haitians to Base in Cuba

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The Coast Guard today began transferring hundreds of Haitian refugees from its cutters patrolling the Caribbean onto a large troop ship anchored at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba.
The shift, made for what the Navy and the Coast Guard called humanitarian reasons, means that up to 800 or so of the nearly 1,800 recently rescued Haitian boat people now crammed into 15 cutters can be kept in more hospitable accommodations. The amphibious landing ship Tortuga is equipped with extensive medical installations and sleeping berths. 
 Earlier today, Rear Adm. William P. Leahy Jr. of the Coast Guard told a Congressional subcommittee that his cutters would be loaded to capacity with fleeing Haitians within the next two days, and would be unable to rescue any more refugees at sea.
 
Timing of Exodus
 Congress has become increasingly uneasy with the Bush Administration's policies on Haiti and its attitude toward political asylum for Haitians fleeing that country after the military coup that overthrew the democratically elected Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide on Sept. 30.
But the latest wave of refugees fleeing Haiti did not begin in earnest until a month later, and questions about the timing of the new exodus were left unresolved by today's hearing. Speculation in Washington is that many Haitians were waiting to see whether Father Aristide would soon be restored to power, or for the effects of an international economic boycott of Haiti to begin to be felt.
This morning, Immigration and Naturalization Service said at least 2,819 Haitians had been intercepted at sea since October. Of this number, the immigration service said, at least 1,781 refugees remained on Coast Guard cutters. Of 447 Haitians held at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba, the immigration service said, 350 were flown today to Honduras and Venezuela. The agency said only 53 had been taken to Miami to apply for asylum.
 
20 Picked Up Wednesday
 For the last several day, the Coast Guard has estimated a higher figure, about 3,000, for the number Haitians picked up at sea. Coast Guard officials said tonight that at least 20 Haitians had been intercepted today, compared with nearly 650 on Tuesday, when a Federal judge in Miami ordered a temporary stay of forced repatriation pending a formal hearing on the interdiction policy scheduled for Monday.
The State Department says there have been no reports of retribution or persecution of any of the 538 Haitians returned to Port-au-Prince on Monday and Tuesday before the stay was issued. Human-rights groups challenge that assertion by questioning the sources of information on which the United States Embassy in Haiti relies, particularly the Haitian Red Cross, which they describe as unable to defy the military Government.
Admiral Leahy said his 15 cutters, nearly half the East Coast fleet, had to be taken off normal patrol and narcotics-interception duties to pick up refugees in what he described as a humanitarian process that was saving many from drowning. But even with the interdiction policy in force, officials say that as many as half the Haitians who attempt the voyage die at sea.

GRAPHIC: Photo: More than 500 Haitian refugees were returned to Port-au-Prince early this week before a temporary stay of forced repatriation was ordered. Red Cross workers helped a sick refugee from a U.S. Coast Guard cutter. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Lawmakers Pare Agenda for a Push

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Congress continued to struggle tonight toward its goal of a pre-Thanksgiving adjournment, acting on extended unemployment benefits and preparing for crucial battles over continued financing for the depleted bank insurance fund and the savings and loan bailout.
Leaders from both parties met tonight and agreed on a short list of bills they considered essential, and the first test of their list will come on Thursday when the House votes on putting more money into the nearly insolvent bank insurance fund. 
 Congressional aides said they agreed that four other difficult items had to be on the agenda. They included legislation providing new money for the Resolution Trust Corporation, which deals with insolvent savings and loans, and a new version of the $205 billion spending bill for a variety of domestic programs; President Bush vetoed the first version of the bill over a measure on abortion counseling and the veto was sustained on Thursday.
They agreed they had to squeeze an agreement out of a House-Senate conference on the six-year $151 billion budget for transportation, and, if possible, to wring out an agreement on anti-crime legislation that has not yet even gone to conference.
 
Jobless Benefits
 Congress took all but final action on a major bill that had provided Democrats with political ammunition against President Bush since July, the effort to give extended unemployment benefits to workers idled by the recession for more than half a year.
It acted on a $5.4 billion bill that would give those workers either 13 or 20 weeks of benefits. The states where unemployed workers can now get up to 20 weeks of benefits are Alaska, Connecticut, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Mississippi, New Jersey, Rhode Island and West Virginia. Workers in the rest of the country would be eligible for up to 13 weeks.
After bitter dispute from Senators saying their states were shortchanged under an earlier version, last Friday the Senate passed the new bill, along with one extending benefits to workers in any state who had exhausted their regular 26 weeks of jobless benefits at any time since March 1.
The Administration backed these provisions, which replaced versions in which workers in 23 states could only get six weeks of benefits and those in 18 states could only get extra benefits if they exhausted their regular benefits after last Sunday. It said the provisions would only cost an additional $380 million, most of which would be offset by shortening the program by three weeks.
There was only brief debate before the House passed the bill today, 407 to 21. Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, complained that the new bill would provide too much aid in states where "jobs are readily available on every corner."
Representative Thomas J. Downey, the Suffolk Democrat who was the chief advocate of the legislation for several months, said of the repeated attempts to pass the bill, which President Bush killed twice, "We had to do it four times to get it right."
The bill was sent to the Senate, and a very quick House-Senate conference on differing details was expected.
 
Trade Benefits
 A measure to provide enhanced trade status for two East European nations and the former Baltic states was passed, with hardly any debate, as part of the unemployment bill.
The measure, also endorsed by the Administration, would provide Most Favored Nation Status for Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania and would reduce tariffs on imports from those nations. It was accompanied by another bill that would award that status to the Soviet Union, which acknowledged the independence of the Baltic states from it last summer.
The House vote on favored trade status for the Soviet Union was 350 to 78. No serious opposition is expected in the Senate.
 
Pentagon Spending
 Two major spending bills are still on the calendar, but the House today passed one of them, providing $270 billion for the Department of Defense. There was little debate over the bill, which closely resembled the Pentagon budget passed earlier in the week in imposing severe limits on spending for the B-2, or Stealth bomber. The bill passed on a voice vote and was sent to the Senate.
But some question remained about how the House would deal with the $205 billion spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education. President Bush vetoed the bill because it sought to void an Adminsitration regulation barring family planning clinics that receive Federal funds from discussing abortion with patients.
The veto was sustained Tuesday, but advocates of abortion rights today delayed any effort to bring up a new bill without that provision. Even so, Representative William H. Natcher, the Kentucky Democrat who is chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee, which handled the measure, said he would advance a bill that did not includethe provision. "We're just waiting for the leaders to tell us when," he said in an interview.
 
Intelligence Programs
 Both houses passed legislation establishing intelligence programs for the current year, calling for future disclosure of the overall spending levels on intelligence.
But in the bill that was sent to President Bush tonight the spending limits in various programs remained classified, with lawmakers saying only that they were slightly below the levels requested by the Administration.
The bill also set up several hurdles before the Central Intelligence Agency could move certain operations from Virginia to West Virginia, a shift favored by Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, but opposed by lawmakers from Virginia.
Before a move could take place, the C.I.A. would have to report to the House and Senate Intelligence Committees on alternative sites, and describe how the shift would affect its personnel.

HEADLINE: U.S. Planning $1.5 Billion in Food Aid To Soviet Peoples Through Moscow

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Amid rising concern about possible hunger and civil unrest in the Soviet Union this winter, the Bush Administration announced today that it would send about $1.5 billion worth of food aid, most of which would be channeled through the central Government in Moscow.
The announcement, which followed weeks of delay, included the first large-scale American shipments of free food to the Soviet Union in seven decades. 
 The action is part of a broadening Western effort to help the Soviet Union. The United States has already given $2.5 billion worth of food credits in the last 11 months, almost all of which has been delivered. Japan, the European Community and individual Western European countries have made separate pledges of aid in recent months, but so far have delivered very little.
All of these aid efforts are driven by concerns of food shortages and the possible collapse of new democratic institutions in the Soviet Union this winter. But these efforts are complicated by weakening economies and growing government budget deficits across much of the industrialized world, particularly in the United States.
 
Farm States Back Aid
 The aid package announced today is distinct from discussions in Congress over whether to use $1 billion from the military budget to help the Soviet Union. The announcement today is linked only indirectly to negotiations in Moscow concerning ways to help the Soviet Union with its foreign debt, variously estimated at $60 billion to $100 billion.
Congressional reaction today was divided on regional rather than party lines, with legislators from farm states favoring more aid and other legislators tending to worry that existing aid may already be excessive.
Representative David R. Nagle, an Iowa Democrat on the Agriculture Committee, said in a telephone interview that the Administration's aid plan today was "too little, too late" and added, "We haven't given them enough to get through a couple weeks."
But Representative Charles E. Bennett, the Florida Democrat who is vice chairman of the Armed Services Committee, criticized the deal for not requiring the Soviet Union to barter or sell oil or other natural resources in exchange for food. "The U.S. taxpayer shouldn't have to give a charitable gift if the Russians have the wherewithal," to buy the grain, Mr. Bennett said in a telephone interview.
 
Rationing in St. Petersburg
 In another indication of Soviet food shortages, Anatoly Sobchak, the Mayor of St. Petersburg, announced today that all types of food would be rationed beginning on Dec. 15 because the city has been receiving only half the food it needs, Reuters reported from Moscow, citing local journalists. Some American officials have worried for weeks that urban areas will suffer first from hunger this winter because farmers are refusing to sell their crops for rapidly devaluing rubles.
Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan told reporters at the White House today that the United States would guarantee $1.25 billion worth of commercial bank loans for the purchase of American grain, and would provide $165 million worth of free food, mainly through private voluntary organizations.
The Agriculture Department is negotiating with the United Way, CARE, World Vision Relief and the Seventh-day Adventists to distribute the food, said a department official who insisted on anonymity.
In addition, a much smaller but still undetermined amount of money will be used to build a model farm in the St. Petersburg area, construct model wholesale food markets near Moscow and Kiev, send American agricultural extension workers and provide credit guarantees for loans to private Soviet-American ventures in Soviet food processing and distribution, Mr. Madigan said.
 
Helping U.S. Farmers
 The program will help American farmers and "is aimed at alleviating food shortages and other dire humanitarian consequences in the Soviet Union this winter," Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said. Only the food grants and technical aid projects will result in direct outlays by the Federal Government, he pointed out.
All of the credit guarantees will go to Vneshekonombank, the Soviet central bank for foreign trade. But each of the 12 remaining Soviet republics has also accepted responsibility for the debt's repayment if the central Government or the other republics are unable to do so, Mr. Madigan said.
A detailed plan has been worked out for the amounts of food each republic will actually receive, Mr. Madigan added. The plan was intended to reassure conservatives who have warned that the central Government is not credit worthy and will use the threat of withholding food as a lever to compel the obedience from republics.
These arrangements did not initially satisfy some conservative critics.
"This appears to be a thinly disguised scheme to continue U.S. taxpayer loan guarantees to a discredited Moscow center that is totally uncredit-worthy," said Roger W. Robinson Jr., who was the National Security Council's senior director for international economic affairs from 1982 to 1985.
 
Issue of Credit Worthiness
 Federal law bars agricultural loan guarantees to countries that are not credit worthy. Mr. Madigan said that this rule was met by the agreement by the Soviet central Government, Vneshekonombank and the 12 republics to take responsibility for repayment.
Some of the credit guarantees will only be available if the Soviet Union makes payments falling due soon on previous loans already guaranteed, Mr. Madigan said.
The program announced today by Mr. Madigan calls for $500 million in credit guarantees to be made available immediately, followed by $250 million aid packages in February, March and April.
A confidential Agriculture Department study has found that while the Soviet transportation system may be clogged with deliveries of European food in January and February, very little grain has been committed for delivery in December.
 
Grain Shipment Scheduled
 The last grain from the most recent American assistance program, $1.5 billion in credit guarantees granted in June, is scheduled for shipment at the beginning of next month. If a new aid package had not been approved this week, some of this transportation capacity might have been wasted.
Franklyn D. Holzman, professor emeritus of economics at Tufts University, said the Soviet Union had paid a small percentage of the cost of the food it received from the United States during World War II. The announcement today represents the first time that the United States Government has given free food to the Soviet Union since Herbert Hoover oversaw a $20 million program right after World War I, Mr. Holzman said.
The bread lines and panic buying of food in the Soviet Union are the result of both production and distribution problems there, American officials say.
 
Grain Production Drops
 The Agriculture Secretary said for the first time in Congressional testimony on Oct. 30 that while food distribution in the Soviet Union is a serious problem, a decline in grain production this year has also become a crucial factor in a substantial Soviet need for food imports this winter.
Nearly two weeks later, on Nov. 12, the Agriculture Department reduced its estimate of this year's Soviet grain harvest to just 175 million metric tons. Last month the department estimated a crop of 185 million metric tons, and in August and September the prediction was 190 million metric tons.
Soviet crops in recent years have been close to 200 million metric tons, while last year's near-record crop totaled 235 million metric tons.

HEADLINE: Rebounding From Criticism on Economy, Bush Seeks More Stable Ground

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
President Bush sought today to strike a cautious new balance in his public remarks about the economy, apparently mindful of recent statements that experts say helped send a key barometer of the stock market skidding by more than 160 points in two sessions of trading over the last five days.
In a brief interview with reporters for six NBC-owned television stations, the President called the economy "sluggish," but declined to emphasize either its best or worst aspects. 
 "I think more than anyone else in the country, obviously, that if the President misspeaks or sounds euphorically optimistic or overly pessimistic, you send the wrong signals to a skittish market and to the people," Mr. Bush said. "So I'm trying to say, 'Look, we're in tough times; they're going to get better.' "
 
Placing Blame on Congress
 Mr. Bush repeated an accusation from his recent political speeches around the country: that Congress's refusal to enact his legislative program of banking overhaul and a capital gains tax cut was responsible for the stubbornness of the economic downturn. He picked up again on those themes in an appearance here tonight at a $1,000-a-plate fund-raising banquet that pushed his 1992 campaign chest up $1.2 million, to more than $5 million.
During the interview with the television reporters Mr. Bush placed blame for the recession on Democratic Administrations and Congresses of more than two decades ago. He asserted that the enactment of "well-intentioned" legislation in the 1960's had helped to create the "extraordinarily high deficits" that he said were now crippling the economy. The reference was apparently to the social welfare programs that were central to President Lyndon B. Johnson's "Great Society."
Mr. Bush's comments were the latest effort to find stable political ground on the economy, whose weakness has thrown the White House and the President's unannounced re-election campaign off stride.
Mr. Bush's reticence about solutions for the downturn underscores his difficulty in finding a strong campaign theme in economic hard times. Instead of taking advantage of his role as an incumbent President, Mr. Bush has appeared to be hemmed in by it lately.
The Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 120.31 points last Friday, some said because Congress had taken a cue from Mr. Bush and moved toward passing legislation that would limit interest rates on consumer credit cards, a major source of banks' income. At the last minute, the President had inserted language into a New York political speech and called on credit-card issuers to lower their rates. But the White House later said he opposed mandatory ceilings on such rates.
After steadying itself on Monday, the Dow, the most closely watched barometer of market activity, dropped again on Tuesday, by 41.15 points, after Mr. Bush said that the economy was basically sound and that he planned no legislative initiatives that would seek to alter existing policies "radically." Analysts later said the President's remarks had dismayed investors, who were looking for a stronger response to the downturn.
 
Little Comment on Debate
 Mr. Bush has declined to comment as blame was being fixed on him in the two declines. But he has noted that he was given little credit when stock prices rose to record levels earlier this year.
Mr. Bush's advisers have waged a continuing debate over whether he should try to look more Presidential, pressing his own solutions for the economy at the risk of having a Democratic Congress reject them, or whether he should simply allow Congress to dither and then blame it for the economic sluggishness. So far, Mr. Bush appears to be following the latter course.
In today's interview, the President said repeatedly that he knew some people were suffering economically and that he was not complacent about finding new ways to stimulate growth. But he also said that he did not plan to propose any significant new economic programs before his State of the Union Message in mid-January.
Nor will Mr. Bush seek to hold Congress in session past its scheduled adjournment next week to try to force votes on more of the six legislative proposals in the White House's economic program, his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today.
"They don't need the President to hold them in to get them to do something," Mr. Fitzwater said. "It's not a schoolhouse full of kids up there. If they're going to act, they ought to act."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Fitzwater also denounced as "crazy" and "foolish" a number of news reports, including one published today in The New York Times, that have described the President's re-election campaign as being in a state of political limbo while internal arguments rage over the economy and leadership of the 1992 effort.
Those reports said that Mr. Bush had failed to contact important political advisers about taking jobs on his re-election staff and that some of those advisers were becoming increasingly reluctant to serve in a campaign that may be controlled by the White House's brusque chief of staff, John H. Sununu. Today, the President twice expressed his support for Mr. Sununu, and Mr. Fitzwater denied that any advisers were considering bowing out of the campaign.
The President also said that he would not debate any Republicans who seek to challenge him in the Presidential primaries this spring. Two Republicans on Mr. Bush's right have indicated that they may contest his renomination: the political commentator Patrick J. Buchanan and David Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan grand wizard who lost a runoff last Saturday for Louisiana governor.
The White House also said that Mr. Bush had rescheduled a 10-day trip to four Pacific nations that was postponed after this month's elections. He plans to visit Australia, Singapore, South Korea and Japan from Dec. 30 to Jan. 10, Mr. Fitzwater said.
The President insisted then that he had postponed the visits only because Congress appeared likely to remain in session for part of the time he was to be away.
