HEADLINE: 7 More Patients Accuse Doctor of Botching Their Abortions

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
The Lower East Side doctor who the police say severed the right arm of a fetus while performing an illegal abortion was accused by seven patients yesterday of botching their abortions, authorities said.
In addition, the obstetrician, Dr. Abu Hayat, was the subject of a civil malpractice suit earlier this year in which a judgment was found against him. The other seven cases were reported by women who called a police hot line after they heard of Dr. Hayat's arrest on Tuesday, the police said. 
 Dr. Hayat, 61 years old, of Manhattan, was released without bond late yesterday afternoon after being charged with performing an illegal third trimester abortion on 20-year-old Rosa Rodriguez.
 
'Danger to Public Health'
 Peter Slocum, a spokesman for the New York State Health Department, said the agency was investigating Dr. Hayat and has the authority to suspend his license if officials "determine that the physician poses an imminent danger to public health."
The investigation could take several weeks, Mr. Slocum said. Until it is complete, he said, Dr. Hayat "could go back to work tomorrow."
Dr. Hayat did not return telephone calls to his office and his home. His Women's Medical Clinic at 9 Avenue A was closed yesterday.
A lawyer involved in the malpractice suit said Dr. Hayat had filed for bankruptcy on Monday. He also said that Dr. Hayat did not have malpractice insurance.
At a news conference yesterday afternoon, Miss Rodriguez described the events that brought her to that clinic on Oct. 25 and that led to the mutilation of her daughter, Ana Rosa, who was born alive but missing her arm. The baby, who weighed three pounds one ounce at birth, is in critical condition at New York University Hospital.
 
A Calm Voice
 Miss Rodriguez spoke in Spanish, in a soft, calm voice, and her remarks were translated by a legal assistant at the law firm of Trolman & Glaser, where the news conference was held and which is representing her at no charge. A small woman, about five feet tall, she said she did not look pregnant when she went to Dr. Hayat's clinic and she thought she was only three to four months into her pregnancy.
Miss Rodriguez is unemployed and the unmarried mother of a 2-year-old daughter, and she lives with her mother in Queens. She sought the abortion, she said, because she did not feel she could support a second child.
She said she found Dr. Hayat's telephone number in an advertisement in the Spanish-language newspaper El Diario, an advertisement that continued to appear yesterday. She chose his clinic, she said, because it had a Queens area code and she wanted to remain close to home, but when she made an appointment and arrived at the address she had been given, there was no clinic. Instead, she was taken by taxi to Dr. Hayat's office in Manhattan. She did not say who called the taxi.
Once she arrived at the clinic, she said Dr. Hayat performed no tests to determine how far along she was in her pregnancy. After an internal pelvic examination, she said, Dr. Hayat told her she was correct in her estimate that she was between her 12th and 16th week of pregnancy.
Doctors now estimate she was in her 32d or 34th week, her lawyer, Jeffrey Lichtman, said.
New York State law prohibits abortions after the 24th week of pregnancy unless the health of the mother is threatened or the fetus has congenital defects that mean it will not survive. Under the law, a woman is not responsible for having an illegal abortion; the doctor bears sole responsibility.
No sonogram test was done to confirm the fetus's age, Miss Rodriguez said. In fact, she said, she did not see any machines in the office. An officer present at the arrest of Dr. Hayat described the clinic as "filthy" and said there was no sonogram equipment.
Dr. Hakin Elahi, medical director for the Margaret Sanger Center, which is the Manhattan clinic for Planned Parenthood of New York City, said yesterday that "accepted medical practice requires a sonogram after 12 weeks."
After the examination, Miss Rodriguez said, Dr. Hayat told her to return the next day and he would perform the abortion.
When she returned, Miss Rodriguez said, she was having second thoughts about whether to have the abortion. She had felt the baby moving inside her, she said, and wondered whether to go through with her pregnancy. But, she said, Dr. Hayat pressured her to have the procedure.
 
$1,500 for the Abortion
 Mr. Lichtman said his client was charged $1,500 for the abortion. He said she paid $1,000 in cash and gave her passport, green card and some jewelry as collateral for the other $500. Planned Parenthood typically charges from $300 to $500 for an abortion.
Miss Rodriguez said Dr. Hayat gave her an anesthetic and she awoke later to find blood on her leg. Dr. Hayat, she said, told her there was nothing to worry about. Mr. Lichtman said that Dr. Hayat told his client that the abortion was incomplete and instructed her to go home and return the next day. Miss Rodriguez said the doctor told her that if she felt pain that evening she should not go to the hospital or seek other help but should instead call his assistant, who he said was a registered nurse.
Miss Rodriguez said she did feel pain that evening and called the assistant. The assistant said she would call Dr. Hayat. The assistant called back, saying she had spoken to Dr. Hayat and said the pains were normal and would subside, Miss Rodriquez said.
Later that evening, when Miss Rodriguez's mother, Ana, came home, her daughter told her about the pain. The two women went to Jamaica Hospital by taxi. Five hours later, the baby, Ana Rosa, was born, her arm severed below her right shoulder.
The Manhattan District Attorney's office is also investigating charges that Dr. Hayat fondled a patient during an examination. That sexual-abuse investigation is being conducted by Linda Fairstein, chief of the District Attorney's sex crimes unit. She will also handle the investigation of the Rodriguez case.
 
Investigating Complaints
 Ms. Fairstein said her office is encouraging women who believe they were mistreated by Dr. Hayat to come forward. "We will investigate any complaints against him," she said.
Law-enforcement officials would not give specifics about the accusations of the seven women who came forward yesterday. But they said that all the complaints could be documented because all the women sought other medical help after seeing Dr. Hayat.
The eighth woman, Clara Robles-Veliz, has gone public with her accusations. Last year she filed a malpractice suit against Dr. Hayat saying he perforated her uterus and cervix during an incomplete abortion during her 12th week of pregnancy in 1988. Dr. Hayat never responded to the suit, according to her lawyer, Irv Gertel, and was found guilty by default. Dr. Hayat challenged the default finding, Mr. Gertel said, but the New York State Supreme Court ruled that the finding should stand.
A settlement hearing was scheduled for this spring, Mr. Gertel said, but before the hearing Dr. Hayat declared Chapter 11 bankruptcy, asking for a rescheduling of his debts. On Monday of this week, Mr. Gertel said, Dr. Hayat filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy, asking that all his debts be discharged.
Mr. Gertel said the expected settlement in a case would be "hundreds of thousand of dollars."
Mr. Gertel and Mr. Lichtman said Dr. Hayat does not have malpractice insurance.

HEADLINE: Former Smuggler Ties Top Officials Of Cuba and Nicaragua to Drug Ring

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Senior Cuban and Nicaraguan officials, including the brother of Fidel Castro, helped the Medellin cartel smuggle cocaine into the United States during the mid-1980's, a founding member of the Colombian drug group testified here today.
In his second day of testimony at the Federal Court trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the witness, Carlos Lehder Rivas, said he met twice in Havana with Gen. Raul Castro, Cuba's Minister of Defense, to gain permission for cocaine shipments to fly over Cuban territory on their way to Florida. 
 Later, Mr. Lehder also said, the cartel organized a cocaine smuggling route out of Nicaragua with the approval of Sandinista leaders and the assistance of Cuba's top intelligence operative in Managua.
For at least a decade, there have been reports that Cuban and Sandinista officials were working with the cartel, and the Reagan and Bush Administrations have said so in arguing that the two Latin American governments should be isolated. But until Mr. Lehder took the stand today, no leader of the Medellin cartel had ever made such assertions publicly. It is difficult to determine how the jury will assess Mr. Lehder's credibility. No documentary evidence was introduced to corroborate his assertions.
 
'Cubans Were in Charge'
 "The Cubans were in charge of that cocaine conspiracy in Nicaragua," Mr. Lehder testified, in English. He said he attended several meetings in Managua in his role as head of the cartel's transportation operations. "It was not the Sandinista Government, it was the Cubans" who were in charge of organizing and running the cocaine smuggling network from Nicaragua to the United States, he said.
As a result of discussions with the Cuban and Nicaraguan governments, the cartel "did fly cocaine through Nicaragua" in 1984, Mr. Lehder testified. He said the cartel was required to pay both governments, but he did not specify the amount paid and did not say whether payments were made to the national treasury of each country or to individuals.
Mr. Lehder said the cartel turned to Nicaragua as an alternative to General Noriega, who he said had become increasingly greedy and demanding.
Mr. Lehder's politically explosive account of the Medellin cartel's dealings with the two Latin American governments that were most hostile to the United States in the 1980's came during questioning about the drug-related activities of General Noriega, the former Panamanian dictator who is being tried here on 10 counts of cocaine trafficking, money laundering and racketeering, and it had an immediate impact. At the conclusion of Mr. Lehder's questioning by an assistant United States attorney, Guy Lewis, just before noon, Judge William M. Hoeveler ordered a recess until Thursday.
Judge Hoeveler took that unexpected action after a private conference requested by Frank A. Rubino, chief counsel for General Noriega. Mr. Rubino was not available this afternoon for comment on the delay, but the timing made it clear that the recess had been granted at his request and that he was not prepared for cross-examination.
Mr. Lehder, one of nine founding members of the Medellin cartel, was captured by the Colombian authorities in a raid on his jungle stronghold in February 1987 and was immediately handed over to the United States, where he was wanted on 11 counts of cocaine trafficking and racketeering. After a 1988 trial in Jacksonville, Fla., he was found guilty and sentenced to life plus 135 years in prison.
Since then, Mr. Lehder, who is now 42, has been kept in solitary confinement in the maximum security wing of the Federal Penitentiary in Marion, Ill. In August, however, he agreed to testify against General Noriega in hope of receiving a reduced sentence and a transfer to a less harsh prison.
Mr. Lehder said today that he was, in fact, moved out of Marion after signing a plea agreement with prosecutors one week before General Noriega's trial began. He also acknowledged that eight members of his family had been flown to the United States, apparently to protect them from possible vengeance by professional assassins in the pay of the Medellin cartel.
 
Tumbled From Power
 Previous witnesses in this trial have described Mr. Lehder as a man given to violent outbursts of irrational behavior, and Colombian Government officials have said he was a heavy user of cocaine during most of the 1980's.
At the peak of his power, Mr. Lehder was reputed to be a billionaire and commanded both a private army and a neo-Nazi political party that called for the extermination of Communists.
Asked to respond to Mr. Lehder's testimony, Ariel Ricardo, a spokesman for the Cuban Interests Section in Washington, this afternoon dismissed the case against General Noriega as "more a political show than a real trial."
"If I was Carlos Lehder and I received the same sweet deal from the prosecutors that he received, I could say practically anything, too," Mr. Ricardo said.
Sandinista leaders, whose party lost the Presidential election in 1990, did not respond to a telephone call to party headquarters in Managua.
 
'Several Visits' Recalled
 Mr. Lehder said he made "several visits" to Cuba in 1981 and 1982, a time when he was managing a cocaine trafficking route in the Bahamas. In Havana, he said, he met with Raul Castro and Col. Antonio de la Guardia Font, a Ministry of the Interior official in charge of operations to circumvent the United States economic embargo of Cuba, and reached an agreement allowing cartel aircraft to pass through Cuban air space "if necessary."
In May 1984, Mr. Lehder said, he and four other top leaders of the cartel fled to Nicaragua after being implicated in the assassination of Colombia's Minister of Justice. The cartel leaders were able to take refuge there, he said, "because of our Managua connection," whom he named as Federico Vaughn, an aide to Tomas Borge Martinez, a founder of the Sandinista National Liberation Front who was then Nicaragua's Minister of the Interior.
But "the coordinator" of the cocaine trafficking operation that was soon set up in Nicaragua, Mr. Lehder said, was Manuel Pineiro Losada, a senior Cuban intelligence official. "The Nicaraguans wouldn't move a finger without his cooperation," he said.
Officially, Mr. Pineiro is head of the Americas Department of the Central Committee of the Cuban Communist Party. But officials of United States and Latin American intelligence agencies have identified him as the top spymaster in the Western Hemisphere for the D.G.I., which Mr. Lehder described as "the Cuban K.G.B."
Mr. Lehder said the cocaine trafficking route from Nicaragua was needed because cartel leaders were quarreling with General Noriega, whom they regarded as greedy and treacherous. "Noriega wanted to become more a participant and beneficiary in cartel business," Mr. Lehder said, and was demanding "a bigger piece of the pie" for allowing the cartel to manufacture and ship cocaine from Panama.
When Mr. Pineiro learned of the dispute, Mr. Lehder testified, "he emphatically said violence should be avoided" and offered Cuban assistance in mediating the matter. Eventually, Mr. Lehder said, the disagreement was settled in Havana, with Fidel Castro "acting on behalf of Officer Manuel Noriega" and a former President of Colombia, Alfonso Lopez Michelsen, representing the interests of the cartel.
By mentioning both of the Castro brothers, Mr. Lehder's account cast new light on the 1989 Havana show trial of Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez, a former commander of Cuban troops in Angola who was then emerging as a lightning rod for military dissatisfaction with Mr. Castro's rule. Accused of running a drug smuggling operation, General Ochoa, along with Colonel de la Guardia and two others, was convicted by a military tribunal and executed by a firing squad.
The Cuban Government has repeatedly described General Ochoa as a renegade who smuggled six tons of cocaine and laundered money for his own enrichment and without the knowledge or authorization of his superiors. Mr. Lehder's contention that he discussed cocaine trafficking with Raul Castro undermines that argument and suggests that Fidel Castro himself approved drug operations in order to acquire much-needed hard currency.
Last month, General Ochoa's widow told the Havana correspondent of the Madrid newspaper El Mundo that "Fidel and Raul Castro were always aware of that traffic, and they encouraged it as a fair way to get financial resources for the revolution." She also said, "My husband's only crime was to tell Fidel and his brother Raul that the war in Angola was senseless."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Guy Lewis, an assistant United States attorney, leaving court yesterday in Miami after questioning Carlos Lehder Rivas, who had testified in the trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. (Associated Press); Carlos Rivas; Raul Castro; Thomas Borge Martinez
 
Chart: "Pointing a Finger"
 Carlos Lehder Rivas testified yesterday at the drug trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega that several Communist leaders in Latin America were instrumental in the shipment of drugs to the United States. Following are sketches of Mr. Lehder and dome of the people he mentioned.
 CARLOS LEHDER RIVAS: One of the nine leaders of the Medellin drug cartel who started out as a car thief and small-time marijuana smuggler. Extradited to the United States in early 1987, convicted of conspiring to smuggle 3.3 tons of cocaine into the United States and is now serving a life sentence. Born in Armenia, 100 miles south of Medellin. Ran for political office on neo-Nazi party ticket in Colombia while being tried in the United States on drug charges.
 MANUEL PINEIRO LOSADA: Close confidant of Cuban President Fidel Castro. Chief of the Americas Department of the Central Committee of the Communist Party. Nicknamed Barba Roja, or Red Beard. Worked with President Castro on strategy sessions with Sandinista and Salvadoran commanders.
 RAUL CASTRO: Minister of the Armed Forces and brother of President Castro. Evidence presented at the 1989 smuggling trial of Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa suggests that Raul may have been aware of the trafficking.
 ANTONIO DE LA GUARDIA FONT: Executed in mid-1989 in Havana for his part in drug smuggling operation. Former chief of the special smuggling section within the Interior Ministry of Cuba. Former member of President Castro's inner circle.
 TOMAS BORGE MARTINEZ: Last surviving founder of the Sandinista Front, who was Interior Minister and head of the secret police during the years in power.
 FEDERICO VAUGHN: In 1986 President Reagan once called him "a top aide to one of the nine commandantes who ruled Nicaragua" after pictures were released showing Mr. Vaughn helping to load a plane with cocaine. Former junior aide in the Nicaraguan Interior Ministry, accused of assisting in the establishment of cocaine laboratories in that country.

HEADLINE: Dodd Navigates Political Shoals

BYLINE: By LINDSEY GRUSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn.

 BODY:
When Senator Christopher J. Dodd came here in October to talk to high school students, he was peppered with questions about the new state income tax. Recent dinners have been little more than quick bites between more angry questions.
"You couldn't get out of your car without people coming up," he says. "If you said 'I'm a U.S. Senator and have no view on this,' they would have torn your head off." 
 So after months of ducking the issue, he bowed to the political gale. He recently stopped talking about the state's need to raise more money and stabilize revenues and began to criticize the income tax as an unfair burden on the poor.
"Inequitable," he now says.
"I would not have voted for that package," he adds, mentioning what he calls a "primal scream," a dangerous loss of faith in the political system. "People have a tremendous lack of confidence in their own future, their children's future, their employer's, their town's, the state's. I've never seen anything like it."
For the first time in years there is also doubt about the 48-year-old Senator's future. Already, one Republican has announced his candidacy against Mr. Dodd, who just months ago was presumed to have lifetime tenure. But in the wake of the tax maelstrom, polls show he is vulnerable in the 1992 election.
"Six years ago, it would have taken a miracle to beat him," said G. Donald Ferree Jr., assistant director of the Institute for Social Inquiry, an independent polling group at the University of Connecticut. "Not any more. Over the last few years, Dodd has lost some of his luster. There are a large number of people out there ready to look at a challenger."
Republican political advisers see the race as an echo of last year's Senate campaign in New Jersey, where rage over Gov. Jim Florio's tax and education changes led to probably the biggest surprise of the 1990 elections: the near defeat of Senator Bill Bradley, then considered Presidential timber. The backlash continued on Nov. 5 of this year, when Republicans not only won control of both houses of the New Jersey Legislature for the first time in 20 years, but also won veto-proof majorities.
"Weicker has done for Connecticut what Florio did for New Jersey," said a Republican pollster who asked not to be identified because he works for a colleague of Dodd's. "Any time you hang the Governor in effigy in front of the State Capitol, you have a full-blown revolt going on. Incumbents had better watch out."
The Senate race here is being watched around the country as a barometer of antipathy to incumbents. Analysts say it should also provide a sign of whether pent-up demand for social services has caught up to the antitax fervor that defined American politics in the 1980's.
"It's a weather vane for all of us," one Democrat said.
While Mr. Bradley's campaign ignored the tax debate until the end, the Connecticut Senator's handling of the issue has been vintage Dodd, demonstrating his ability to combine seemingly conflicting trends.
Mr. Dodd went to Washington as a 30-year-old Watergate baby, one of the Young Turks elected in the wake of President Nixon's resignation, and he made his mark in the Senate by opposing the Reagan Administration's policies in Central America. But as the son of the famously conservative Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut, he has always been comfortable with the Old Bulls, as he calls the older Congressional leaders. A divorced bachelor without children, his domestic focus has been on family and children's legislation.
"He was politically trained with one foot in the front door, the progressive room, and one foot in the back door, the smoke-filled rooms," says Ken Crerar, a former legislative assistant who is the executive vice president for the National Association of Casualty and Surety Agents. "He can bridge the old and the new."
The training nearly came to naught. Seared by his father's censure in 1967 for misappropriating $116,000 in campaign funds, he foreswore politics. His father died in 1971. But friends say a need to atone helped persuade him to run for the House of Representatives in 1974. While Senator Dodd says he had no need to make amends, he celebrated his swearing-in to the Senate in 1981 by wearing his father's watch fob and sitting in his old chair.
But while remaining loyal, he has consistently opposed positions that defined his father. During America's crusade against Communist expansionism, the elder Dodd was immortalized by Phil Ochs in "Draft Dodger Rag." "I'm just a typical American boy from a typical American town," the anti-establishment folk singer sang. "I believe in God and Senator Dodd and keeping old Castro down."
But the current Senator Dodd is more attuned to views that blame the United States for Latin American ills and define one of the most important tasks in American foreign policy as withholding support from right-wing dictators. That led Senator Dodd to push a measure through Congress in 1981 that barred military aid to El Salvador unless the President certified improvement in its abysmal human-rights record. It was the first major foreign policy defeat for the Reagan Administration.
He also overcame lobbying by the Bush Administration to force cutbacks in military aid to El Salvador. As chairman of the Latin American subcommittee of the Foreign Relations Committee, he provided the support needed to overcome Republican opposition to the so-called Arias Plan, which led to negotiations to end Central America's civil wars.
 
A Difference in Style
 Although criticized as "soft on Communism," Mr. Dodd says his style is the only thing that is different from his father's approach. "He was a strong anti-Communist and he was dead right," the Senator says. "I agree with him. But we have different ways of dealing with it."
Senator Dodd says he learned that approach in the Dominican Republic, where he served for two years as a Peace Corps volunteer. "Other than my family, it was the single most important event in my life," he says, explaining that he went as a lost middle-class boy and "came back as a wide-eyed idealist."
While the Senator earned a national reputation opposing the Reagan Administration, most ratings show his record has never been as liberal as is assumed. Over all, it is similar to that of the state's junior Senator, Joseph I. Lieberman, who is perceived as the more conservative. Mr. Dodd has been a steadfast supporter of the country's military buildup, including the antimissile shield and the B-2 Stealth bomber.
"He's not ideological," says Stanley Greenberg, the Senator's pollster. Although Mr. Dodd voted against the Persian Gulf war, he has enraged many liberals by supporting President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador, whose pragmatism has belied the extremist past of his rightist party.
"What happened to you?" he is often asked.
"The world changed," he responds.
Still, State Representative Chris Burnham, a Stamford Republican and Persian Gulf war veteran who is the first Republican to enter the race against the Senator, says Mr. Dodd has failed to evolve.
"Chris Dodd is irrevocably locked in a 1970's mentality," Mr. Burnham says. The Senator, the representative adds, has been "insulated," "escaped scrutiny" and "for 17 years has done nothing."
"Finally, a realization has permeated the populace: This man has failed us," he said.
That criticism, a mantra among likely challengers in this recession-racked state, comes despite the Senator's success in obtaining defense contracts and his two greatest domestic triumphs: the ABC Child Care bill, which was approved last year and was the first national child-care subsidy program since World War II, and the so-called family leave bill, passed this year. It requires many employers to grant up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave for family emergencies.
The Senator's success in the back rooms has made it something of a cliche that he would have been more comfortable in the gentlemanly club that was the Senate 20 years ago. A silver-tongued off-the-cuff speaker, he is regarded as one of the finest workers of the Capitol's corridors, a consummate insider who combines a salesman's love for backslapping with a psychiatrist's ability to listen.
"He loves the interplay and likes the fight," says his best friend, Michael (Goose) McAdams.
He is also considered a consummate campaigner. Visiting the New Britain Senior Center during its annual picnic recently, he stopped at all 49 tables, talked to all 325 diners and even danced with a few. That's when Rose Maclosky snapped a few pictures. But, the Senator noticed, she was too far away for her wide-angle lens. So he chased her down, looped an arm over her shoulder and had an aide take the picture.
"One on one, the guy is the best I've ever seen," Mr. McAdams says.

HEADLINE: Mulroney Warns Quebec on Division

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 20

 BODY:
When Prime Minister Brian Mulroney visited rural Quebec last week he appeared to be testing out a new, blunter approach to the challenge of Quebec separatism, one that many prominent Canadians say may be necessary to stem pressure in the French-speaking province for a vote on independence as early as the fall of 1992.
In place of past efforts to placate and even strike alliances with leaders of the independence movement, Mr. Mulroney chose a visit to his home region of Charlevoix, east of Quebec City, to align himself with what an increasing number of prominent figures elsewhere in Canada have been telling Quebec: that if it chooses to separate, the rest of Canada would insure that the divorce would inflict serious economic and other losses. 
 Mr. Mulroney mocked assurances offered by Jacques Parizeau, leader of the Parti Quebecois, the group that leads the independence movement, that the costs to Quebec's 6.9 million people would be modest.
The assurances have been part of Parti Quebecois strategy to garner support from Quebecers -- around half of all those supporting independence, according to some recent polls -- who say they favor a break with Canada if it is accomplished on the basis of "sovereignty association," meaning the maintenance of existing economic, trade and other links.
 
No 'Part-Time Canadian'
 "They say, 'Canada is unacceptable, but by the way, don't say anything, we'll take your passport,' " Mr. Mulroney said. "They say, 'Canada is unacceptable, but we'll take the benefits of economic union.' "
"Well, the hell with you," the Canadian leader said. "If Canada is unacceptable, it's unacceptable completely. You can't be a part-time Canadian. You don't get it both ways. You can't walk about like a cafeteria, taking the best parts of Canada, saying, 'I'm going to take these, and I'm going to leave you with the rest.' "
Mr. Mulroney's message was aimed in part at English-speaking regions of Canada, where support for Mr. Mulroney and his ruling Progressive Conservative party has been below 20 percent in opinion polls for months. But as much, the tougher line on Quebec appeared to stem from a new sense, increasingly widely shared in English-speaking Canada and among French-speaking Quebecers who oppose independence, that Quebecers are in danger of sliding toward independence on the basis of misapprehensions about what would be involved.
Leading bankers, businessmen, economists, historians, native Indian leaders and retired military figures have joined in, warning that Quebec's independence, if it comes, could bring bitter recriminations that would preclude any early renewal of economic and trade links. Some have warned of a slump in the Quebec economy of as much as 10 percent, and even of civil strife and rioting over issues like the division of federal assets and debts, the welfare of Quebec's English-speaking minority of 800,000 people, and the loyalty and control of troops and military bases in the province.
 
The Issue of Land
 Potentially the most contentious issue is land, and there have been a spate of warnings that Quebec cannot expect Canada to allow it to secede with all its territory, roughly two and a half times the size of Texas. Some English-speaking Quebecers have questioned Quebec's right to a broad wedge of land lying between the St. Lawrence River and the United States border, a region of strong English-speaking settlement. Cree and Eskimo leaders have said that as much as two-thirds of the province, including its entire northern region, should remain part of Canada since it was ceded to Quebec only after the Canadian confederation was founded in 1867.
The stridency has been prompted in part by the deadline set by Quebec. The province's legislature voted in June to set Oct. 26, 1992, as the last day for a referendum on sovereignty, with the provision that Quebec should "acquire the status of a sovereign state one year to the day" from the vote if a break was approved. The statute established two parliamentary committees, one to examine the details of a move to statehood, the other to assess "any offer of a new constitutional partnership" made by the federal government and the nine other provinces.
This reflected flexibility on the part of Premier Robert Bourassa, the Quebec leader, who has said he favors Quebec's remaining within Canada so long as Ottawa agrees to surrender a wide range of economic, social and other powers. Mr. Bourassa, who studied postgraduate economics at Harvard, has said that his government will take no risks with the "economic security" of its citizens, encouraging many in Canada to believe that he will ultimately opt for more modest constitutional gains.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Ros Muc Journal;
On Europe's Edge, Irish Fear Being Left to Drift

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROS MUC, Ireland

 BODY:
The people in this wind-whipped village on the bleak western rim of Europe are used to the hard life. They wrestle existence out of a place where big rocks seem to grow overnight in the fields and the soil is thin and poor, the sheep scrawny. A few miles out along an inlet, the Atlantic Ocean yields seaweed and mackerel for the few who have boats.
Until the last year or so, things seemed to be improving. Emigrants sent back money from Britain and the United States, the Government dole provided about $75 a week, the European Community sent millions in subsidies to farmers in western Ireland, and an increase in industry in nearby cities absorbed many of the people leaving rural areas like Ros Muc. 
 But now the recession in the outside world is reaching the 600 or so people of Ros Muc. They wonder what will be in it for them when the politicians and bureaucrats meet in December 500 miles east of here in Maastricht, the Netherlands, to shape the New Europe they hear about on television.
In many ways the people here reflect the concerns of western and rural Ireland about the New Europe and political and monetary unification. And to some extent, they have the same fears as the other have-nots of the community, in Greece, Spain, Portugal and southern Italy.
They are afraid, generally, that the New Europe will forget them if the recession continues to pinch the richer countries, and the poor countries of Eastern Europe continue to compete for aid. They fear too that as these countries get stronger they will compete directly with the Irish in markets for beef, lamb, wool, fish, cheese and butter.
 
'Huge Lack of Confidence'
 "There's a huge lack of confidence among the young people here," said Thomas O'Malley, who keeps a large shop in Ros Muc. "They feel that if anybody tries to haul himself up, he'll always be beaten back down again."
In the village, unemployment is at about 65 percent and the population is declining each year. Mr. O'Malley said he had to go to the next parish to get enough men for a football team of 20. The team has a 1-7 record.
Christo Walsh, who runs a shop and a pub, knows his market by making informal door-to-door surveys himself every few years. He estimates that 200 people have left in the last 10 years, putting the population at about 575. "When I was a boy," the 38-year-old merchant said, "we would have to line up 90 pints in advance along the bar every Sunday morning to handle the rush after Mass. Now maybe a half-dozen if we're lucky come in after Mass." The school he went to had 180 pupils, he said, but now has only 44.
"Of course the families are smaller now," he said. "Then they had 8 or 10. The priest says that there are 25 funerals a year. Five or 6 births. Last year 2 weddings. One year I sold no Pampers at all. It is becoming an area of very young and very old.
"I know an old fellow, 80 years old, an invalid and his wife too. But he won't let his nephew have any land. So he stays in London. The old people have their claws into the land and they won't let go."
Late last year one of Ros Muc's few industries, a German factory that made fiber-glass tubs, closed, putting 18 people on the dole. A small factory that makes woolen sweaters still employs eight people and business is growing. But the owner, Margaret Conroy, said she did not qualify for European Community help to expand. She started the business, which sold $30,000 worth of sweaters in the United States this year, with a Government loan through its Gaelic-Speaking Authority, as Ros Muc is in an area where most of the people speak Irish as their first language. Local banks, she said, are refusing her an expansion loan.
Seosamh O'Cuaig, a producer at the national Gaelic-language radio station a few miles away, said part of the unemployment problem was the Government policy of deducting from the public assistance dole any income made by a person. "If he takes his dole and buys a bottle of poteen and drinks himself to sleep, he's legal. But if he goes and cuts some seaweed to make a little extra, he's illegal."
But Mr. O'Cuaig, who is also a member of the Gaelic-language authority, said part of the problem might be the Irish mentality. "Some say it's a habit we formed, of a colonial people, always turning to the big power for help."
He said the farmers here needed to specialize, to start breeding free-range lambs for a quality market instead of lining up each year looking for a subsidy from Europe for their sheep and wool, which lost money because of world prices."
Some 20 miles away inland, in Galway City, the Roman Catholic bishops of western Ireland were holding a conference on what to do to save the area. The academics and the politicians agreed with the people of Ros Muc that the future was unclear, at best, for the outer edge of Ireland and Europe.
What happens in Maastricht in December is crucial to Ireland. As one of the poorer community countries, Ireland qualifies for $5.2 billion in community subsidies from 1989 to 1993. But will the community's rich members, Germany and France, continue such levels of help if their own economies falter and demands from Eastern Europe grow?
There is a legend along the west coast of Ireland that in 1492 Christopher Columbus spent the night here and attended Mass before embarking on the voyage that many felt would plunge him off the edge of the earth. As the momentous events at Maastricht approach, Western Ireland is conscious again that it is near the edge.

He and his 11-year-old daughter, Molly, watched Eddie Faherty dig a ditch for a gas line into their house. (James F. Clarity for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Abortion Tearing Bush;
Battle Looms Over Party's Stand on an Issue That Will Test Ability to Hold Both Sides

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20

 BODY:
President Bush won a victory this week on abortion, but it was only the beginning of a season of political conflict on an issue that clearly torments him.
He faces a battle over the Republican platform next summer that will test the White House's theory that it can finesse the issue's divisive effect by declaring the party a "big tent" where both sides can feel at home, although the President remains firmly anti-abortion. 
 He faces a general election campaign against Democrats who are no longer timid about highlighting his anti-abortion stance, convinced that support for abortion rights is now a plus among voters of the baby boom.
 
Suspicion on Both Sides
 He faces constant suspicion from activists on both sides of the debate -- the supporters of abortion rights who have never forgiven him for becoming more anti-abortion over the years, and the opponents of legalized abortion who watch him for the slightest suggestion that he will again shift his position.
All these issues were foreshadowed in this week's struggle over legislation that would have allowed doctors and counselors in federally financed family planning clinics to discuss abortion with pregnant women. Mr. Bush vetoed the legislation, and the House failed by 12 votes to override him.
Some of the most impassioned voices against the President's position in the House this week were those of Republicans, reflecting the party's deep division over the issue.
"A lot of Republicans, including this one, are very disenchanted with where we are on issues like the gag rule, where it seems to me our party's principles are clearly in favor of doctor-patient confidentiality," said Representative John Porter, Republican of Illinois.
Already, Republicans on both sides are quietly organizing for the coming struggle over the party's platform, which now calls for a constitutional amendment outlawing abortions and for the appointment of judges "who recognize the sanctity of human life."
 
Warning From Abortion Foes
 Phyllis Schlafly, who heads the Republican National Coalition for Life, contends that any weakening of the abortion plank would antagonize a core Republican constituency -- the anti-abortion movement -- and gain the party nothing.
"You can't kick away your own constituency and win," Mrs. Schlafly said. "There are some pro-choice Republican women but they really don't have any place to go. I cannot believe that a pro-choice Republican woman is going to vote for a Dukakis or a Cuomo or any of these leftists that Democrats will put up."
Party leaders have generally tried to follow the approach pioneered by Lee Atwater, the former chairman of the Republican National Committee with a keen sensitivity to younger voters whose economic interests might lead them to the Republicans while their position on social issues aligned them with the Democrats.
In 1989, when the abortion rights movement was galvanized by the Supreme Court decision giving states new power to restrict abortion, Mr. Atwater began talking about the party as a "big tent."
Mr. Bush was opposed to abortion but the party was big enough for those who disagreed, Mr. Atwater emphasized in a deft strategic straddle. In the past few months, some Republicans, including Vice President Dan Quayle, have floated the idea of putting the "big tent" philosophy in the platform's preamble, presumably leaving the strict anti-abortion language elsewhere in the platform intact.
 
Counting on Party Unity
 In general, Mr. Bush's advisers are counting on party unity, personal loyalty and political pragmatism to avert a damaging fight at the party's convention in Houston. "The principle motivation for 99 percent of our delegates is to win the Presidential campaign," said Charles Black, a top Republican adviser. "And if they are told that a certain issue or policy is important to the President, most of them will support the President."
Republicans do have a history of party discipline that puts the Democrats to shame. But the discontent among Republicans who support abortion rights has grown in the past few years, as it seems more and more likely that the Supreme Court will overturn, or at least severely restrict, constitutional protection for abortion rights. And for all the talk of a "big tent," many of these Republicans saw the President's stance this week as a sign that the right was very much in the center ring when it came to abortion.
The expected challenge for the party nomination from Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, will probably only feed the President's wariness about antagonizing his right flank. Moreover, many political professionals argue that it is dangerous for elected officials to shift their position on abortion, and Mr. Bush already has a record of such shifts.
Mr. Black acknowledged this week that the President's position on the counseling ban might not be the most favorable political ground. But, he argued: "It's critically important that the President be consistent on this issue. And he is and he doesn't hesitate to be."
 
'Out of the Mainstream'
 "Any Democratic nominee will be able to paint George Bush into a right-wing corner on this," said Frank Greer, who has worked in abortion rights campaigns and is now the media consultant to Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas. "He is out of the mainstream on this."
In contrast, Democrats often seemed reluctant to press the abortion issue in 1988, when the anti-abortion forces were fully mobilized but the supporters of abortion rights were not.
This time, the recent actions of the Supreme Court, and the possibility that even before the election it could deliver another major ruling restricting the constitutional right to abortion, will keep the issue alive. If nothing else, the organized groups are determined to make it so.
"It's not going to be like 1988," said Kate Michelman, the head of the National Abortion Rights Action League. "Dukakis didn't make it an issue, certainly Bush didn't make it an issue, and the only time it became an issue was in the debates when a reporter would ask about it."
There are many in politics who argue that abortion will remain, however, an issue of primary concern only to 10 to 15 percent of the voters on either side. Most voters, they say, will make a decision -- particularly a Presidential decision -- on other issues. Few in politics predict that the abortion issue is a silver bullet.
Still, for Mr. Bush, it is an issue that must be managed.

HEADLINE: In Albany, Budget Troubles Linked to Years of 'One Shots'

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 20

 BODY:
On paper, there is a simple explanation for why New York State, for the third year in a row, is staring at a huge gap in its budget: the economy is in even worse shape than policy makers here thought it would be when the budget was approved. Tax collections are down, demands for social services are up, and the budget is no longer in balance.
But aside from the obvious argument that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders erred on the side of optimism, there is perhaps an even more fundamental problem at work, many analysts say, and that has to do with how the budgets have been put together to begin with. 
 Too many years of holding the budget together with "one shots" -- nonrecurring revenues, the rough fiscal equivalent of spit and glue -- have insured that a large potential deficit will show up at the start of successive years. And those problems have simply become so large that, absent a drastic round of spending cuts, it may have become all but impossible to pass a balanced budget.
Nearly every state has relied on one-shot measures to get them through hard times in the last few years. But, said Vladimir Stadnyk, managing director for Standard & Poor's, a major Wall Street rating agency, "in New York, they've done it for longer and they've done it in greater magnitude -- And that's a major part of the problem here."
It was also, he added, a major cause of the drop last year in New York's credit rating to the lowest of all but two other states in the nation, Louisiana and Massachusetts.
New York City has also relied on one shots, like borrowing from reserve funds, but it has done so to a much lesser degree than the state -- largely because of control that state leaders have themselves imposed on the city.
"That's the irony of it," said State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, who has persistently criticized the state's one-shot measures. "It's like Congress telling General Motors to obey the civil rights law, and then exempting itself."
In the last fiscal year's state budget, there were $2.7 billion in one shots, an all-time record, according to the Comptroller's office, and a figure that represented nearly 10 percent of all the spending in the budget.
Included were a speed-up of certain tax payments, an unpopular "lag payroll" plan that withheld a week's worth of state workers' wages until they retire or die, and, arguably the most infamous one shot of all, $200 million the state managed to "produce" by selling the state-owned Attica prison to itself. New Yorkers will pay the interest, $290 million in all, over the next generation.
This $2.7 billion showed up as part of the $6 billion gap that the Governor and the Legislature labored to close last spring when they put together this year's $30 billion budget, which has already fallen out of balance by at least $689 million.
Meanwhile, this year's budget itself had $1.4 billion in one-shot measures. That figure, in essence, now shows up as part of the potential deficit in the 1992-93 budget, which the State Budget Director, Patrick J. Bulgaro, said on Tuesday could rise as high as $3.6 billion.
 
Putting Off Problems
 "Basically one shots are used to pay for something that couldn't be afforded in the first place," said Raymond B. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a Manhattan-based watchdog group. "It's a question of putting off today's problem until tomorrow."
Governor Cuomo has quarreled with Mr. Regan's definition of one shots and maintained the actual amount is hundreds of millions of dollars less than the Comptroller's account, but no one denies they have been a major part of balancing the budget in the last three years.
Mr. Cuomo has defended the "intelligent use" of these nonrecurring revenues, arguing they have helped avert damaging tax increases or even more painful spending cuts at a time that reductions have already caused considerable cries of anguish from New Yorkers.
And although the Governor has often borne the brunt of blame for one shots, he has by no means been their most vigorous proponent. State Senate Republicans, for all their talk about fiscal responsibility, last spring proposed an even larger menu of one shots than the Governor did, including the sale to private operators of state-owned buildings.
 
Covering Potential Hole
 Had the economy taken a postive turn rather than remaining stalled for the last few years, there would probably be far less criticism of the practice. That is because the upturn would have helped cover some of the potential hole caused by the one-shot measures in the first place.
But because the reverse is true, the one shots have now become all the more severe a villain.
"By using one shots, you are creating potential structural imbalances," said Mr. Stadnyk at Standard & Poor's. "And if the economy continues to nosedive, that becomes an almost permanent part of your problem. It gets pushed over from year to year, so that a year from today, you and I will probably sit here and say, 'Geez, we've got another problem.' "
 
'Many Problems'
 The estimates about the economy were indeed off, although both Mr. Cuomo and legislative leaders point out that they were largely based on what many economic experts were predicting and were, in any event, still more conservative than the projections they would have used had they accepted Bush Administration assurances that the economy would be in a recovery by now.
"There are many problems with the budget process here," said Daniel B. Walsh, the president of the New York State Business Council. "But it is also fair to say that the recession is a lot deeper than almost anyone predicted it to be. The only exact science in this town is hindsight."

HEADLINE: Council Speaker Attacks The Mayor's Shelter Plan

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday passionately defended his embattled plan to place 24 homeless shelters in middle-class neighborhoods, even as City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone told the Mayor's commission on the homeless that the plan ignored "a fundamental part of the American dream, the right to a stable neighborhood."
Citing the packed meetings of angry neighborhood residents who oppose the shelters, Mr. Vallone declared: "It is nothing short of outrageous to brand all these people as heartless, or racist, or simply Nimby." 
 But at a news conference, Mr. Dinkins said it was "inhumane" to continue to house the homeless in barracks and vast armories. "The question is what we are going to do with our homeless people," he said. "They are God's children, too."
Mr. Dinkins said Mr. Vallone and others shouting "not in my back yard" have not offered alternative sites so that the homeless can be housed in smaller shelters that can treat their problems.
 
For Nonprofit Developers
 As the two principal political players -- the Mayor and the Speaker -- raised the volume of their disagreement, Andrew Cuomo, chairman of the Mayor's commission, began to sketch out an alternative way of carrying out the Mayor's plan that would have nonprofit groups, rather than the city, develop shelters for the homeless.
Mr. Cuomo, who said last week that the Mayor's plan was "dead on arrival," was more diplomatic yesterday.
In his opening remarks at the hearing, he praised the Mayor's goal of building smaller shelters that are geared to treating the problems of different segments of the homeless population -- those afflicted with drug addiction, alcoholism and mental illness.
But he continued to question whether the city should build the shelters, and whether they should be called "shelters" at all; he prefers "treatment centers."
Mr. Cuomo, who heads a nonprofit group that shelters about 500 homeless families in the city, suggested that nonprofit groups with proven track records are better equipped to develop the programs than the city.
The Mayor has called for the city to build 24 shelters to house 2,500 homeless men and women. The city would then contract with nonprofit groups to run the shelters.
Jeffrey L. Carples, an executive deputy commissioner in the Human Resources Administration, said the Dinkins administration decided the city should build the shelters to insure that the job would get done. Nonprofit groups also have a difficult time convincing neighborhoods to approve sites for shelters, he said.
For moral as well as legal reasons, the city must make progress in opening smaller shelters, he said.
State law requires that no city shelter house more than 200 people. The city has routinely obtained waivers from the state to allow the city to retain armory shelters where as many as 900 to 1,000 men sleep on a single sprawling drill floor.
"It would have been politically dishonest to put the onus on the non-profits," Mr. Carples said. "We felt we had to commit the city to developing the sites."
 
Concern for Security
 Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx testified against the Mayor's plan, saying that the city might withdraw the services needed to operate the new shelters securely. He said the city had done so in the past.
He praised programs developed and run by nonprofit groups, like those of Mr. Cuomo's group, H.E.L.P. (Housing Enterprise for the Less Privileged), as aiding homeless families to rebuild their lives and winning the support of the surrounding communities.
Mr. Cuomo asked Mr. Ferrer if he supported a strategy that referred the homeless "to experienced, proven not-for-profit providers."
"That's the right way to approach it," Mr. Ferrer replied.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "What They Say: On Shelter for the Homeless"

"The mayor's plan has broken new ground in homeless policy. The plan is premised on the fact that bigger is not always better and in fact smaller shelters are preferable to larger shelters. Public comments on the plan have tended not to dispute the mayor's policy, but rather the specific mechanisms to best implement that policy."

HEADLINE: Walkout By Teachers Leaves Rift

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITTLE FERRY, N.J., Nov. 15

 BODY:
Illegal walkouts by public schoolteachers often leave behind bitter feelings. But here in Little Ferry, a working-class borough of 10,000 residents, a strike has produced more than bitterness. The school superintendent wants to dismiss 37 teachers on the ground that their two-week strike in September has made them unfit to instruct children.
But a state judge has barred the Little Ferry School Board from acting on the case until June, when clasess end for the summer. 
 The superintendent of the two-school district that includes 53 teachers and about 700 pupils is Stacy J. Holmes. He asserts that because the teachers defied two court orders to return to work, they served as poor models for pupils and should therefore be dismissed. "It could very well be that children should not receive their instruction from someone who has broken the law," Mr. Holmes said.
 
'Vendetta' Is Charged
 State education officials say Mr. Holmes is the first superintendent in New Jersey to seek the dismissal of public schoolteachers for striking.
Elaine Shields, the president of the teachers' union in Little Ferry, said Mr. Holmes was conducting a "war" against the faculty. James P. Connerton, executive director of the New Jersey Education Association, the statewide teachers' union, accused the superintendent of conducting a "personal vendetta."
"I don't know if it's personal pride or he's trying to make a reputation as union buster," Mr. Connerton said. He said the union would demand full individual hearings for all 37 teachers if the case ever reached the State Commissioner of Education. Mr. Holmes is not taking action against the district's 16 other teachers because they do not have tenure or did not take part in the strike, which was prompted by a dispute over wages.
Statewide representatives of superintendents and school boards insist that Mr. Holmes is acting alone, without their official blessing. But they stopped short of criticizing him because they have never drafted a policy on the position he has taken.
 
Walkout Ruled Illegal
 Nationally, only a handful of school boards have dismissed teachers for striking in recent years. In 1974, the Timberlane School District, which serves four towns in New Hampshire, dismissed 94 teachers, and Hortenville, Wis., dismissed 84. In 1981, 53 teachers in Mariemont, Ohio, were dismissed after a 95-day strike.
Until recently, when Judge Kevin M. O'Halloran of New Jersey Superior Court stalled the dismissal effort, Mr. Holmes had won two important rulings.
When the walkout started on Sept. 6, Judge O'Halloran declared it illegal and issued the first of two back-to-work orders. Such rulings are customarily issued during teachers' strikes in New Jersey. And striking teachers routinely ignore them, as did they in Little Ferry.
In response, Judge O'Halloran issued two rare decisions. He fined each teacher 1 percent of his or her gross pay for each day of the walkout. Ultimately, $94,000 was collected. He also ruled that the teachers would lose their jobs if they failed to return to classes by Sept. 20. They went back to work that day without a contract.
 
'Cooling Off' Period Needed
 In the sour aftermath of the strike, negotiations have yet to resume between the teachers, whose annual salaries range from $19,000 to $50,000, and the school district, which has angered them by reducing its wage offer three times since March.
In his latest decision, Judge O'Halloran said a "cooling off" period was needed for renewed negotiations and calm in Little Ferry's two elementary schools, Memorial and Washington.
After that ruling, about 1,000 teachers, many from out of town, descended on Little Ferry, snarled traffic and demonstrated outside the two schools for about two hours, the police said.
Were the board to uphold Mr. Holmes's charges, it could suspend the 37 teachers with or without pay. The case would then go to the State Education Commissioner, John Ellis. He is the only official under New Jersey's teacher-tenure law with the authority to dismiss teachers for other than economic reasons.
Mr. Holmes said the teachers' defiance of the court orders constitutes "conduct unbecoming" a teacher. The Commissioner has final discretion in determining "conduct unbecoming," which is grounds for dismissal under the tenure law.
 
Many Contracts Unsettled
 The Little Ferry case has occurred at a time of tense and snail-paced bargaining on new teachers' contracts throughout New Jersey against a backdrop of recession. Contracts remain unsettled in about 115 of the 256 districts whose agreementsexpired in June, the New Jersey School Boards Association said.
Mr. Holmes said he was not seeking vengeance or attempting to bust the union. But in a letter to residents on Nov. 6, he accused teachers and union officials of harassing the district.

HEADLINE: At 20, a Nonprofit Theater That Has Endured

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
It may be remarkable for any nonprofit theater company to survive to its 20th anniversary, but it is positively a miracle when two of the founders are still speaking to each another. Yet there they were, Curt Dempster and Arthur Giron, sitting amid the comfortable clutter of the Ensemble Studio Theater in Manhattan, hammering out the production of the play that will be inaugurating "In Pursuit of America," the Ensemble's 50-event, yearlong celebration of its 2 decades of existence.
"Here's what I think," said Mr. Dempster, the theater company's artistic director, preparing to impart his insights about "A Dream of Wealth," Mr. Giron's play, which opens today in the Ensemble Mainstage at 549 West 52d Street. "I was up all night thinking about it." 
 "Oh, that's good!" interrupted Mr. Giron, raising a laugh from Melia Bensussen, the play's director. "You know how much sleep I've lost revising it."
Mr. Dempster glanced sidelong at a visitor. "For 20 years we've talked like this, 20 years," he said. "I guess it's one reason we're still going strong."
 
Against the Current
 Going strong, indeed: the Ensemble persists despite Federal, state and city cutbacks in financial support, despite an economic recession that has stunted nightlife in the city, and despite a growing stay-at-home impulse that has drained audiences from developmental theater venues in favor of video-store bargains and cable-television hors-d'oeuvres.
"In Pursuit of America" is more than just the Ensemble's salute to itself and the 500th anniversary of Columbus's voyage to the American continent. It is a six-month festival of plays that are historical, political, polemical, pastoral, comical, tragical and just plain theatrical in the company's home to the East of De Witt Clinton Park at 11th Avenue.
The festival has been in preparation for more than a year and a half by the Ensemble's membership, which is composed of playwrights, directors, actors, designers and technicians. The 300 members include writers like Horton Foote, Christopher Durang, Frank D. Gilroy and John Patrick Shanley, and such performers as Ellen Barkin, Danny DeVito and Christine Lahti.
"Many of our members expressed concern that our society exists in an undertow of erosion, and we hoped we could deal with that in theatrical ways," said the 55-year-old Mr. Dempster. "It's as if the country were in a strange state of denial, unable to acknowledge just how bad the reality is. Maybe we'll help the reality to surface."
 
What Else Is Planned
 The other works in the current Ensemble series are "Deposing the White House," a dramatization by Dan Isaac of declassified Iran-contra materials that opens on Saturday; "Big Frame Shakin'," a one-man show written and performed by Jim Macdonald, who appeared in "The Heidi Chronicles" on Broadway, and "Stars 'n' Bars," a late-night cabaret of music, satire and political commentary with Lew Black and Rusty Magee serving as hosts. The last two presentations begin previews on Nov. 29.
The mission of the Ensemble is "to rescue a certain kind of theater from oblivion, to create an artistic sanctuary here and permit our members to work, to teach, and to have a life in the theater," said Mr. Dempster. "Increasingly, theater is becoming an endangered language, and we feel beholden to pass it along."
It does so by creating more than 200 new projects a year. Many are readings, some are workshops and the lucky few are theatrical productions, "because we can't afford to put everything up on its feet," said Mr. Dempster.
The theater company has developed more than 5,000 new plays in 20 years, and is best known for the events that begin and end its seasonal calendar. The first is the Octoberfest, in which the Ensemble presents as many as 75 theater pieces in three and a half weeks. Recent contributors have included Arthur Miller, Shel Silverstein, Harry Kondoleon and Mr. Foote. "We set out to revivify the art of the one-act play, which had been a much-neglected form," said Mr. Dempster. The finale of the Ensemble season is the Marathon of New One-Act Plays, beginning in April, in which 12 works are presented in 6 weeks.
 
Making Do With Less
 As the recession has cut down on the company's revenues, "we've learned how to make do with less," said Mr. Dempster. "We're sharing adversity with the rest of the country, and perhaps that's made us pull together more."
About 20 percent of the company's $850,000 annual budget comes from ticket sales to 15,000 theatergoers a year (the Ensemble charges from $5 to $22.50 for a seat) and revenues from the Institute for Professional Training, a school that teaches 300 students a year the skills of play writing, directing and acting. The rest comes from gifts donated by individuals, foundations, corporations and various government entities.
But government aid is shrinking. Mr. Dempster said financing reductions included a cut of $45,000, to $23,000, by the New York State Council on the Arts; a cut of $2,200, to $7,300, by New York City, and a cut of $1,600, to $11,900, by the National Endowment for the Arts.
Such government cutbacks for arts institutions are evidence "of a silent war against the arts in this country," Mr. Dempster said. "We are an expression of the most humane aspect of society, and yet, somehow, they see us as enemies."
 
The Secret: Low Overhead
 The Ensemble has a 99-seat theater, the Mainstage, and a 50-seat studio space. "Low overhead is the secret of our survival," Mr. Dempster said of the nonprofit company's 10,000 square feet of rented space. The company has two floors of a New York City-owned former furniture warehouse in a decidedly non-yuppified neighborhood.
"Ingenuity is our other secret," he said. Indeed, pressed for space while mounting a recent Eduardo Machado play, the creative team brought up the cavernous, 8,000-pound-capacity freight elevator, locked it level with the sixth-floor studio theater nearby, and used the elevator as part of the performance space.
Throughout its 20 years, the Ensemble "has tried to encourage younger talents, women and minorities," said Mr. Dempster. "Nonprofit theater should reflect the society that supports it." As part of the company's "New Voices" series, the Ensemble holds readings of new plays, many of them chosen from more than 1,200 yearly submissions of unsolicited manuscripts to the company's Literary Department.
Among those who have written for, performed in or directed Ensemble productions are Richard Dreyfuss, Jill Eikenberry, Teri Garr, David Mamet, Joyce Carol Oates and Jerry Zaks as well as Matthew Cowles and John Seitz, who are appearing in "A Dream of Wealth."
"We've all seen each other grow, through the years," Mr. Giron said during a break in rehearsals. "We trust each other. And it's a pretty big family."

HEADLINE: Masur, as Just Plain Kurt, Gives His Audience Some Answers

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
"I want to be presented not as a kind of a star, but as just a citizen, like you are," Kurt Masur told the 600 listeners who turned up for the first Philharmonic Forum at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday evening. And for nearly an hour, Mr. Masur responded to questions, complaints, suggestions and observations, and showed how accessible and genial the music director of one of the world's great orchestras could be.
Ever since he accepted the directorship of the Philharmonic, Mr. Masur has sought ways to make connections with his New York audience, much as he has done in Leipzig, Germany, where he directs the Gewandhaus Orchestra. An approach that occurred to him early on was to hold occasional town meetings, at which he could answer his audience's questions, and perhaps pose a few of his own. Tuesday's Forum was his first attempt to do that, and seems to have been the first such meeting in the Philharmonic's 149-year history. 
 With Mr. Masur was Deborah Borda, the orchestra's new managing director, who began the discussion by telling the listeners, "What we want to hear tonight is what's important to you, what will enhance the concertgoing experience for you."
The audience was not shy. Although only a dozen people were able to ask questions -- and several asked more than one -- another dozen questioners were waiting their turns at the microphones when the 50-minute session ended at 7 o'clock. Ms. Borda said that a second Philharmonic Forum was scheduled for April 30. Tuesday's session is to be broadcast by WNYC-FM (93.9) on Saturday at 4 P.M.
Dressed casually, in a brown jacket, gray pants and the string tie that has become his offstage sartorial trademark, Mr. Masur seemed entirely at ease as the subject of a public interview. "We are not here hunting for an audience," he said pointedly in his opening remarks. "We want you to tell us what you have in mind." He added that he had felt lost when he arrived in New York, but that "the New York public made my life very quickly easygoing."
He said he believed that the Philharmonic's musical explorations were a journey that the musicians and the public could share more comfortably if he found ways to make listeners more at ease with the orchestra's repertory, particularly with contemporary works.
Actually, the audience's repertory complaints tended not to be about contemporary music. One questioner criticized Mr. Masur's choice of the Bruckner Seventh Symphony as the centerpiece of his opening program. Another said he disliked programs that included works for a scaled-down orchestra (Mozart symphonies, for example) or vocal soloists.
Mr. Masur deflected these criticism gently, pointing out, as he had in the telecast of the opening concert, that he saw the Bruckner as a bridge between the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig and the New York Philharmonic. And he said that in a program including, for example, Mozart and Mahler, the refinement of the Mozart work would make the Mahler sound even more grandly scaled than it would if he paired it with another large Romantic work.
 
Mirror, Mirror on the Stage
 Some of the suggestions had novel touches. One man wondered whether, instead of having the audience see only the conductor's back, the Philharmonic might install a large mirror at the back of the stage so that Mr. Masur's facial expressions could be seen. Mr. Masur did not think so.
"When I conduct Beethoven," he said, "I wouldn't like to replace Beethoven. He should be in your mind, not me."
Someone else asked whether the tuning at the beginning of concerts was a gimmick, a necessity or a tradition, and Mr. Masur said that it was necessary, but that he had been trying to find ways to dissaude the orchestra from warming up on the themes of the evening's works so that when the program began the themes would sound fresh. To another listener, he explained that he had put the basses on risers at the back of the orchestra to try to improve the sound.
There was an impassioned complaint from a listener who identified himself as unemployed and disabled, and who said that although most other musical organizations in New York offered inexpensive seats, the Philharmonic's minimum of $25 made it impossible for him to attend its concerts. He said he had written to the Philharmonic about this, and had received a letter saying that he was right, but that there was nothing they could do about it. Ms. Borda's response was essentially the same.
Others complained that the orchestra's program notes seemed too technical and seemed to be written for people who already understood musical form and therefore did not need the notes. Mr. Masur agreed, and said that he was seeking a new approach that would try to describe the music's spirit rather than just its structure. And two questioners asked that something be done about audience decorum, which, they said, was worse every year.
 
Decorum in the Audience
 Mr. Masur and Ms. Borda said that they were not sure what they could do about decorum, but that noise was a problem, particularly now that the orchestra's concerts are being recorded for release by Teldec Records. Mr. Masur said that it cost $100,000 each time the orchestra had to hold a recording session in order to remake sections marred by coughing.
None of the questions touched upon the Philharmonic's labor negotiations or the possibility that the musicians might go on strike in December. But the topic could not have been far from the listener's minds, since musicians in concert dress stood at the escalators, staircases and doors distributing leaflets that outlined their desires for better salaries and working conditions.
One or two of the questioners, though, sought to lure Mr. Masur into comparisons that, as a consummate diplomat, he deftly avoided. Asked to compare the Philharmonic with the Gewandhaus orchestra, for example, he said: "I will answer you honestly: I like them both." He also noted that the two orchestras came from very different traditions.
And to a questioner who asked the conductor which instrumental sections from the world's great orchestras he would draw on if given an opportunity to create an ideal ensemble, Mr. Masur smiled and said: "I'm not inexperienced enough to answer that question."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Magic, Quayle and A Message

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
WHEN Vice President Dan Quayle recently criticized Magic Johnson for advocating "safe sex" as the primary way to help beat the AIDS epidemic, and suggested instead "abstinence" for unmarried couples, he met with numerous critics, including Dr. Janet Taylor.
"He's off his rocker if he thinks most people would really abstain," she said. Taylor is a psychiatrist and could certainly have found a more medically applicable metaphor than "off his rocker," but it expressed aptly, if colloquially, what she had in mind. 
 As for "safe sex," the people whom Johnson said he was particularly trying to reach, young people in the embattled inner cities, won't respond to that, either, said Taylor. "Let's be realistic," she said. "Many of those kids have zero self-esteem, and they often have so little guidance in their homes that a life, even their own, seems to have little meaning or value. Those are the kids that'll kill you for a dime. It's survival of the fittest out there. They're getting wilder and wilder. Wear condoms? Forget it!"
Taylor's perspective in the Magic Johnson issue is an unusual one, since she works with AIDS patients, and pre-teen-agers and young adults, and since she is the wife of Stu Jackson, the former head coach of the Knicks who is currently director of basketball operations for the National Basketball Association.
Like the Vice President, and even like Magic Johnson, there are many who have no touch, never had touch, or who might have lost touch, with what lives are like away from the executive mansion, or a Hollywood home. Quayle grew up moneyed. Johnson grew up middle class. Taylor sees the other side.
Taylor works with AIDS patients in the Westchester County Medical Center, just outside of New York City, and she works with youngsters, many from impoverished backgrounds, in the hospital as well as those in the Westchester County jail.
Taylor was among the last to see Johnson play a game in person, when she accompanied her husband last month to Paris with a contingent from the N.B.A. office to watch the Lakers play two European teams in preseason games.
She believes it was courageous of Johnson to speak out about his illness, and commends his intentions to do whatever he can to inform others about the AIDS virus, and to seek a cure, a cure that if found soon, would not only save millions of lives, but Johnson's life, too.
Would seeing the possible physical decline of Johnson over the next several years have an impact among the youth she works with? "I doubt it," Taylor said. "They've seen close up their fathers, their mothers, their cousins, their aunts and uncles, their close friends, waste away from AIDS, and yet that population continues to have terrible problems.
"It reminds me of when Len Bias died from a cocaine overdose. People said, 'Oh, too bad,' and began snorting and smoking again. Maybe Magic will have an impact for a short while, and he may have an impact in the middle-class communities, but I don't see it happening among the poor.
"Quayle and Magic both suggested a change in life style, in effect. But that must come with moral responsibility. And that takes in a deeper problem, even, than sex or the use of intravenous needles for drugs. Kids from the age of one and two years old aren't taught the difference between right and wrong.
"There is a breakdown in the family structure. The parents are in their 20's and 30's and they are doing the wrong things, even though they may tell their kids that they shouldn't do them. But the kids are watching. And the church and the schools have lost their power. So the kids are out there virtually alone."
Taylor says the problem goes even beyond the inner cities. According to national statistics, more than 50 percent of all girls are sexually active by the time they are 16, and it's nearly 70 percent for boys. But it is in the inner cities where Taylor believes change is hardest.
"I even see boys 10 and 11 years old who are sexually active now," Taylor said. "They have almost no concept of pregnancy, or venereal disease, or anything else, except for sex being a macho thing to do."
Change will come, she said, when family and community structures are regained.
"Our political leaders have to face this," said Taylor. "They've got to improve the economy and the school systems there. The case of Magic has illuminated problems. Now they have to really go past the tip of the iceberg, to understand the sense of hopelessness out there. But I think it's going to get worse, until Bush gets mugged, or something. Until it hits home like that."
