HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
First a Murder, Then a Playful Sort of Metaphysics

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

Murther and Walking Spirits
By Robertson Davies
357 pages. Viking. $21.95.
In the first paragraph of this novel, the protagonist describes how he was murdered. 
 That's right. At the opening of Robertson Davies's amusing "Murther and Walking Spirits," Connor Gilmartin, the entertainment editor of a Toronto newspaper called The Colonial Advocate, catches his wife, Esme Baron, in bed with his theater critic, Randal Allard Going. When Gil, as he is called, exclaims, "My God, Esme, not the Sniffer?" -- a nickname referring to Allard Going's habit of writing, "Do we sniff an influence from Pinter (or Ayckbourn, or Ionesco, or even Chekhov) in this latest work of Mr. Whoever-it-is?" -- Allard Going leaps up and strikes Gil down with a bludgeon that he keeps concealed in his cane.
Then how can Gil be the protagonist of the novel?
Because he is a ghost, obviously enough.
He has been "roughly translated" into a ghost so that Mr. Davies can pursue certain metaphysical questions. This should come as small surprise to readers of this prolific Canadian writer's earlier works, which include his well-known Deptford Trilogy ("Fifth Business," "The Manticore" and "World of Wonders") and the succeeding Cornish Trilogy ("The Rebel Angels," "What's Bred in the Bone" and "The Lyre of Orpheus") Mr. Davies loves to build his playful plots out of intellectual arcana.
But in "Murther and Walking Spirits" -- the phrase comes from Samuel Butler's observation that "where Murthers and Walking Spirits meet, there is no other narrative can come near it" -- the metaphysics take a surprising turn. After watching his own funeral, at which the newspaper's publisher acknowledges his existence for the first time, Gil decides to attend a local film festival, partly to keep an eye on his murderer and partly because he loves the movies.
While the regular audience sees Robert Goldstein's controversial, anti-British film, "The Spirit of '76," Sergei Eisenstein's "Battleship Potemkin," Sergei Paradzhanov's "Shadows of Our Forgotten Ancestors," Tancred Ibsen's film version of his grandfather's "Master Builder" and Ingmar Bergman's "Scenes From a Marriage," the ghost of Gilmartin is shown his own private film festival involving scenes from the lives of his own forgotten ancestors.
These episodes are absorbingly narrated and relate thematically to what the regular audience is viewing. In one, Gil sees how a relative who lived in New York during the American Revolution decided to canoe her family up the Hudson to Canada because she remained loyal to the British. In another, he learns about Methodist ancestors who emigrated from Wales to Canada. In still another, he watches scenes from the marriage of his paternal grandparents. What is striking about each of the episodes is that the people in them are rather ordinary -- extremely human mixtures of enterprise and fecklessness.
At first you suspect that Mr. Davies has simply found an excessively tricky way to write a family history. After all, there needs no ghost gone to the movies to tell us about economic depression in Wales or that insufficient capital can lead to bankruptcy. Bit by bit, however, you see that there's more than quaint family history being told.
By exploring Gil's after-death experience, the author, in his usual half-playful, half-serious manner, is tracing his ghost's passage from the here and now to eternity. On the way, Gil encounters film, which he considers a medium capable of showing him his dream life, and film shows him how his ancestors did not just live in some distant past but, from their own vantage points at least, lived lives as immediate and vibrant as Gil's.
Moreover, he learns that although his ancestors weren't heroes, they engaged in what he has learned to call the Hero Struggle. As a philosophical friend of his once told him: "You're that dangerous class of fool, a trivializer, Gilmartin! To the human creature nothing that gets strongly to him is trivial. It is all on the heroic scale, so far as he can grasp it. . . . And women -- our towns and villages are jammed with Medeas and Persephones and Antigones and God knows who not, pushing their wire carts in the supermarkets unrecognized by anyone but themselves, and then probably only in their dreams. All engaged in the Hero Struggle!"
You may still think, as I did, that Mr. Davies has gone to excessively tricky lengths to make these points. But then we come to the novel's concluding section, which returns to the story's present time and takes up the matter of the crime and its punishment. Here the narrative voice waxes cynical once again, describing how Esme plans to cash in on her widowhood by writing a book, and how Allard Going, having murdered Gil, now tries to accede to his editorship.
The contrast in tones does more than all of Gil's philosophizing can to make his ancestors' lives seem worthwhile and substantial. At the conclusion of his film festival he reflects: "My parents . . . were both -- are both, I should say, for they live and I am dead as the world thinks of death -- of Puritan strain. My father, a highly educated man and, like so many highly educated men of our time, still an undeveloped child in matters of the spirit, is nevertheless unswervingly honorable and the Methodist strain in him persists as a strong, if desiccated and almost wizened, morality; he is a man with a powerful sense of what he calls 'the decent thing,' and he can always be depended on to do it, even when it costs him dear. My mother, brought up a Catholic in the harsh Irish tradition, is at root much the same sort of creature. They abandoned religion, the comfort and joys of religion as well as its night-terrors and absurdities, but its morality lives on without any emollient faith."
The question remains, can the vestige of this morality exert any power after Connor Gilmartin's death? Read "Murther and Walking Spirits" to learn the answer, and a whole lot more.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robertson Davies (Jerry Bauer/Viking)

HEADLINE: Review/Music;
Looking for the Center In Gilbert and Sullivan

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND

 BODY:
Gilbert and Sullivan grows with difficulty in New York City, but not for lack of gardeners. There are always people like Albert Bergeret to cast, direct, conduct, raise money and generally create productions out of thin air. There is an audience, full and faithful. Singers -- from aspiring or marginal professionals to after-work amateurs -- clamor for parts.
But the money and the center have never been there. Gilbert and Sullivan companies rise and fall, occasionally triumph or else creak through jerry-built productions. The ranks have been particularly thinned in the last few years, but "Princess Ida" and "Patience" have seen the light of day at different ends of town. 
 The first was by Mr. Bergeret's New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players on Nov. 10 at Symphony Space. Its concert format -- black tie and long dresses, singers and orchestra onstage together -- bespoke frugality, but economic necessity may have been pointing the way toward good sense. Then, on Saturday night, the Village Light Opera Group began a series of performances of "Patience" that will run through Sunday at the Fashion Institute Theater, 227 West 27th Street, Manhattan.
The latter had all the accouterments: credible sets and costumes, choreographed staging, a good-sized pit orchestra. But it was also a far looser affair. Ensemble was vague and blurred, with musicians in and out of tune and the production in general offering a let's-see-what-happens approach to stagecraft. The strong presences of Richard Lissemore (Archibald) and William J. Brooke (Bunthorne) and the competence of Kim Stengel (Patience) never quite atoned for the hesitant, sometimes stumbling dialogue passed back and forth within this unusually large cast.
Musical theater involves so many things that must go right and offers so many opportunities for things to go wrong that small, occasional companies are necessarily overwhelmed by detail. Maybe Mr. Bergeret has hit on a better way, given the considerations of rehearsal time and production expense. Listeners at "Princess Ida" saw a little less, but they also had the more concentrated musical experience, and in the end the more theatrical one.
In "Princess Ida," John Rubinstein's King Gama promised much. Mr. Rubinstein has the ear, the comic talent and the easy elocution. (In "Patience," Nathan Hull's Colonel Calverly articulated syllables, but rarely did they turn into comprehensible words.) As the afternoon progressed, however, Mr. Rubinstein lapsed into a star-turn sensibility. Pointless routines were added, presumably to give him more time onstage. His later moments edged toward a parody of a parody. Thus, a small but delicious part came close to being overrun.
As Hilarion, Paul Tomasko and his hard-working tenor never really let the ear relax, but Philip Reilly, Richard Slade, Richard Holmes, Del-Bourree Bach, Samuel Shaw and Michael Collins were poised and pleasurable. Ironically, in this 19th-century feminist tract, the women of Sunday's cast were put in a less happy light. Men performed from memory; at one time or another, almost all the women could be seen walking the stage with scores in hand. As Princess Ida, Linda Milani offered a powerful, almost amazonian soprano, but her glacial acting frequently stopped action in its tracks. Joy Hermalyn, Kate Egan, Jan Holland, Susan Case, Helen Breen and Jane Hamilton were usually bright and engaging performers.
Mr. Bergeret was working with a good orchestra and chorus, and his informed enthusiasm made the number "Jump for Joy" emblematic of that Sunday's high and happy spirits. At the Fashion Institute, Richard W. Noll's more casual conducting had a paternal indulgence to it. Gilbert and Sullivan deserves better.
The director for "Patience" was Bill Fabris. Sets were by Kaem Coughlin and Kis Knecht. Nancy L. Johnson designed the costumes. Susan Weinman played Lady Jane, Tom Staggs the Duke.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
It's Still a Scramble For Bucs' Testaverde To Fulfill Potential

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAMPA, Fla.

 BODY:
Could there still be a place for Vinny Testaverde in Canton, Ohio?
A more pressing question: Is there still be a place for him in Tampa Bay? 
 Testaverde is five seasons into a professional career, a time when the accomplishments of quarterbacks begin to reach an evaluation that leads to Cantonization or unemployment. At the age of 28, he is a football lifetime removed from draft day in 1987, the No. 1 choice with the size, arm, Heisman Trophy and University of Miami pedigree to make the Tampa Bay Buccaneers a winner and go directly to the Professional Football Hall of Fame.
Instead, he has become a symbol of Tampa Bay's frustration, part victim and part cause of its failures.
Going into the game here on Sunday against the Giants, the Buccaneers have a record of 18-45 since Testaverde became a starter with four games to play in the 1987 season. In 58 games, Testaverde has thrown 58 touchdown passes. He has been intercepted 90 times and has been sacked 150 times.
 
Lost and Found the Job
 This year, a 2-9 season in which he has lost and regained his starting job, Testaverde has had just three touchdown passes. He once said that while people might laugh, he still wanted to become a quarterback worthy of the Hall of Fame. But even that discussion has all but disappeared.
"I don't know if it's possible to happen," Testaverde said. "When you talk about Hall of Fame players you're talking about great players. That's what I want to be. Everyone who plays wants to be a great player.
"I guess that's all I'm really saying, just to be considered in that category. I don't think it's so much being named something as much as it is, 'You tried your hardest.' I'm going to try my best to be the best player, regardless of the situation."
The situation is this: Testaverde is in the next-to-last year of the $8.2 million contract signed all those hopes ago. That was before the questions about his ability to lead, to remain durable and to make the quick decisions the position demands.
 
Lots of Changes
 Testaverde's professional uncertainty comes at a time of change all around: His marriage to Mitzi Smith earlier this year, the exhilaration that came with the arrival of a daughter, Alicia Marie, in October, and his dismissal of his agent, Bob Woolf.
His contract length matches that of Coach Richard Williamson, who succeeded the dismissed Ray Perkins last December, and whose overall record dropped to 3-11 with the 43-7 loss to Atlanta last Sunday.
Testaverde understands that if a new coach arrives next year, he would likely want to start with a new quarterback. That is just one reason why this season has been considered a time Testaverde's professional career could be defined.
"I think as we went into the season he knew that," said Phil Krueger, the general manager since last February. "If he's going to achieve fame in the league, in the fifth year the pressure is on a guy by that time to have done something."
 
'A Lot of Disappointment'
 Krueger, an assistant coach under John McKay for the original Bucs in 1976, likened the attitude in the stands toward Testaverde to the early years of Doug Williams's career.
"I think what you face here is a lot of disappointment," Krueger said, "because this guy was so sensational in college, had such a national name. The anticipation of this guy being the Messiah -- I don't know if any guy could have come in and did what the people here expected."
"Everybody wants to say it's Vinny's fault," said linebacker Broderick Thomas. "Vinny wasn't getting any time. We've got a young team. He's a young quarterback. Vinny's been taking the rips and hard knocks since he's been here. It ain't his fault."
A reminder of the possibilities rests at home, on the mantel above his fireplace. Testaverde's Heisman Trophy became a reward for his ability to respond to difficult times early in his college career. After coming to Miami as a little-known prospect from Elmont, L.I., he resisted the temptation of transfering while playing behind Jim Kelly and Bernie Kosar before finally becoming a starter in his junior season.
"Sometimes people come in and say, 'Oh, that's it, huh?' " Testaverde said.
"Yeah, that's it.
"I'll pull it down, let them hold it."
That's when they find out how heavy the Heisman can be.
Testaverde was intercepted nine times in his final season at Miami, but five times in the confrontational Fiesta Bowl defeat to Penn State. No one could have known, but the disappointment and scrutiny made that game the emotional start of his professional career.
 
Take the Sack?
 There were 35 interceptions in 1988, his second Tampa Bay season, some of which took place when he was trying to avoid a sack. The frustrations shaped an opinion that conflicts with the coaching staff.
"I'm trying to get rid of the ball and I'm getting hit," Testaverde said. "I'm trying to throw the ball incomplete, and a lot of the results were bad. So now they're telling me, 'Get rid of the ball. Don't take a sack.' And I've been through it before, and I know the end result. It's not going to help our team win. I'd rather take a sack and tuck the ball away and let them go 80 yards instead of 20."
He does not dwell on the past. The only positive aspect of this season was the stability that came with the departure of quarterback Chris Chandler. The future is all that remains.
"I'm a fairly young quarterback," he said. "I really haven't had any major injuries. I'm healthy. I feel that I'm still in my prime, and I think I can get better. I haven't reached my peak yet."
"The guy could emerge from the cocoon and be a fantastic quarterback," Krueger said. "I'd be the last guy to say his career is done or anything like that. I think it would be foolish for anybody to say that. But the product should be emerging from the cocoon soon."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tampa Bay quarterback Vinny Testaverde scrambling away from the Jets' pass rush earlier this season. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Parody of Banking Reform

 BODY:
Sadly, the only question remaining is how irresponsible the Congressional effort to reform the banking system will become. Committees in both houses have rejected the Administration's wise plan. Now they are littering flawed bills with one ugly amendment after another.
The best outcome would be for Congress to stop the farce. That means passing a simple bill pumping $150 billion into funds that pay off depositors at failed savings and loans and commercial banks -- and leaving comprehensive reform as the first order of business next year. 
 The Administration submitted a farsighted bank reform bill last winter. It would have allowed banks to tap new sources of profit, at lower risk, by permitting them to open branches anywhere in the country and sell securities, insurance and mutual funds. The bill would also have corrected the major flaw in current law by requiring authorities to close failing banks before they went bankrupt, thereby protecting funds backing up insured deposits.
Initially, the House Banking Committee adopted an improved version of the Administration's plan. But then lobbyists for the insurance and securities industries dismantled it piecemeal and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady did precious little to salvage it. When the misshapen bill failed on the House floor, the committee produced a parody.
It would not allow banks to sell securities or insurance or open interstate branches. The Senate bill wouldn't allow entry into securities either; and it would grant interstate branching only at the price of taking away existing, severely limited rights to sell insurance.
The story gets worse. The Senate would put a cap on interest rates banks can charge on credit cards. The notion that Congress has to regulate prices in an industry with 6,000 competitors would embarrass even the Kremlin; and the cap would destroy a vital revenue source for banks wallowing in losses.
A House bill would rob other programs to replenish the fund backing insured depositors at failed savings and loan institutions. That's galling. A bank bailout is one program that Congress should finance by borrowing. By returning the loan to bank depositors, the money stays in private capital markets, insulating the economy from harm.
Rather than passing deformed reform that will harm the economy for decades, Congress could simply refund the insurance funds and fix the system next year. The U.S. is the only industrial nation, other than Japan, that keeps its banks out of securities and other financial industries. Asking Congress to bring banks into the 21st century might be too much. But why not into the 20th?

HEADLINE: Police Dept. Has Questions to Answer About New 911 Plan

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You, like all New Yorkers, are for "enhanced 911, enhanced safety" (editorial, Oct. 27), and you urge the City Council "not to delay a project that would save more lives and control more crime." Although the Police Department has released to the City Council its technical consultant firm's study, completed last March 15, the department has not offered an operating plan for the proposed new police communications system. 
 We believe the City Council's Committee on Public Safety is raising good questions about the proposed new 911 system.
While the Police Department advises that $26 million is required to install the automatic connection, number and location identification, and selective routing provided in the state legislation authorizing the telephone charge, it has decided to seek a much broader communication system, estimated to cost $203 million. An improved, more modern system is a good idea, but it is also appropriate for the City Council, the public and you to ask the Police Department to present a specific overall plan.
The technical consultant's report provides selective information about certain basics (size of the facility and its requirements, alternate sites, details of the equipment to be purchased, alternative equipment choices, information about what the equipment will do, how it will be used, what quantity to purchase).
Specific answers are needed to some questions. While a certain amount of back-up is important, why does the Police Department need a completely redundant system, estimated to cost $57 million, or about 40 percent of the basic system cost? Can the equipment be installed in modular steps, or only all at once, as Commissioner Lee Brown has advised? Why will it take four years for the expanded system to be operational?
What management and monitoring systems will assure completion of this project in the proposed schedule? What is the financing plan? Should it be financed under the capital budget or under this legislation? If financed by a telephone charge, will that begin now or when the equipment is purchased? Will the capital expenditure have a payback measured by cost saving? How will the system coordinate with other city departments, including the Transit Police?
How will this plan affect the operating budget? Should an increasing number of 911 calls and appropriate police responses be assumed, with implications for space selection and communication system personnel?
How will this program help resolve police operating issues of 911 cars and call responses? How will it be integrated with other programs, such as the effort to "demarket" 911 calls? Should there be a 912 number for nonessential calls, as in Los Angeles? What will the impact be on the "safe streets, safe city" program, and will it save personnel, speed implementation and reduce the economic cost?
The chairman of the Public Safety Committee has indicated that, if necessary, the City Council would help pay for consultants to answer these questions. Once the Council has this information, it will be able to evaluate the merits of the Police Department proposal.
 
BUD H. GIBBS
RAYMOND D. HORTON
New York, Nov. 6, 1991
 
The writers are, respectively, chairman, Citizens Budget Commission's municipal services committee, and commission president.

HEADLINE: Why We Might Regret Grain Generosity

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 For some time, voices have been raised in the United States favoring massive food aid to the Soviet Union, most notably the voice of Agriculture Secretary Edward R. Madigan. True, Mr. Madigan's voice has been muted lately. But he has a large constituency in favor of massive shipments of wheat, corn and soy beans. The legislation for such is already in existence. 
 To explain: America's largess of grain can be given to any country of the President's choosing at negotiated interest rates, with as long as three years to pay, under the Commodity Credit Corporation Act.
Under this act, President Nixon enabled Soviet grain buyers to wipe out our emergency wheat reserves in the single month of July 1972. A sharp increase in United States food prices followed this grain-on-credit move.
Such dollar-denominated credits are guaranteed by the Commodity Credit Corporation, which gets its funds from the Agriculture Department's annual budget of more than $40 billion, financed by the Treasury. The recipient country may be careful never to default on the loans. But the loans are continuously additive to the Federal budget deficit, at least from one accounting year to the next.
The Soviet Union is the largest importer of corn from the United States. Because of unusual drought conditions in the corn-producing areas of the Midwest, the United States corn harvest this year may be low. A massive offtake of corn and other food grains and feed grains at this time, as under President Nixon in 1972, may cause a sharp increase in food prices at home.
 
BEVERLY KITCHING
Springfield, Ill., Nov. 5, 1991

HEADLINE: U.S. Health System Falls Short of Canada's

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Editorial opinion is not obliged to adhere closely to fact, but the sweeping allegations about Canadian health care in "Ringing: The Health Care Alarm" (editorial, Nov. 8) goes well beyond the norm of editorial license. What are the facts? 
 Regarding costs, as the June 1991 report of the United States General Accounting Office has stated, in 1971 both Canada and the United States spent about the same proportion of gross national product on health care, while in 1989 the United States share was 11.6 percent as against 8.9 percent in Canada.
In absolute terms, Canada spends $1,805 per capita while the United States spends $2,354 in United States dollars. This is quite an accomplishment given the cost challenges that are posed by Canada's large geography and relatively small population.
As for freeloading on technology, what precisely does that mean at a time when technology -- medical or otherwise -- knows fewer and fewer boundaries? Are Americans who use insulin, discovered and patented in Canada, "freeloading" on Canada? The Canadian Government funds its share of fundamental medical research, and Canadian researchers continue to make significant breakthroughs. One of the most notable was the discovery of the cystic fibrosis gene in 1990 at the Toronto Hospital for Sick Children.
Concerning the contention that Canadian women must wait months for Pap smears, this is simply untrue. Several years ago there was, for a brief time, a delay in laboratory processing for Pap smears in Newfoundland, but the wait was quickly reduced to a maximum of two or three days. Elsewhere in Canada, Pap smears continue to be done immediately upon request, as has always been the case.
Incidentally, and in a purely personal vein, I sought a regular medical checkup in Washington recently and was advised I would have one nine weeks later. Instead, I went to Ottawa and had one on three days' notice complete with lab tests immediately following the appointment.
You, and Americans generally, are free to decide whatever health care system to choose, avoid or adapt, but the choice is not assisted by opinions unrelated to fact.
 
D. H. BURNEY
Ambassador of Canada
Washington, Nov. 8, 1991

HEADLINE: In the Nation;
Another Such Victory

BYLINE: By TOM WICKER

 BODY:
"I have a strong conviction that my ideas, these principles that I keep outlining . . . are what the American people want," President Bush told reporters the other day.
It was not readily apparent to some of us that Mr. Bush had any "principles," much less "a strong conviction." But, ever obliging, this kinder, gentler distributor of a thousand points of light quickly demonstrated that he really is a man of principle. To wit: He is absolutely, firmly, unalterably convinced that no doctor working in a federally financed clinic should have the right even to discuss abortion with a woman. 
 To prove it, the first American President to propose a constitutional amendment to limit free speech vetoed a bill that would have guaranteed free speech -- not to mention the usual doctor-patient relationship -- to medical men practicing in clinics that use Federal funds.
It remains to be seen whether this is a principle that "the American people want." Polls do not suggest that it is; it unites pro-choice activists with those who believe in free expression as well as all those who resent and fear political interference with sound medical practice.
Mr. Bush's ostensible "victory," when his veto was sustained in the House, may cause some Republicans to fear, in the words of King Pyrrhus after the battle of Asculum, that "another such victory and we are undone." A two-thirds margin is hard to obtain, and that those who opposed the President's heartless "principle" came within 12 votes of achieving it should be no cause for rejoicing in a White House that already had troubles enough.
The economy shows no sign of responding to Mr. Bush's petulant pleas for a capital gains tax. On the other hand, when he offered the innocent suggestion that credit-card interest rates were too high, the Senate mistakenly thought he must have known what he was talking about, and hastened to approve a rate cap. Before the House could rectify this goof, the bottom nearly fell out of the stock market; whereupon presumptuous reporters actually interrupted the President's golf game to get his opinion that the market plunge was no big deal. Neither, apparently, is 7 percent unemployment.
Mr. Bush's popularity keeps slipping. The deficit keeps rising. Incumbents are in trouble everywhere, and Harris Wofford showed in Pennsylvania that the middle class can be persuaded to go Democratic. Even a foreign policy President can't make Saddam Hussein go away.
The White House itself is divided about John Sununu, the high-flying chief of staff; some dislike him, while others can't stand him. With a re-election campaign coming up, neither James Baker, the Secretary of State, nor Lee Atwater, the late national chairman, will be able this time to provide political brainpower.
Pat Buchanan says he might run against Mr. Bush, putting the President under renewed pressure to prove that he's the right-winger's right-winger. David Duke, a chronic campaigner who styles himself a Republican and who derived national renown from public hysteria and from press and Presidential attention, also is talking about entering primaries vs. Mr. Bush.
On top of all that, there's this abortion thing. Mr. Bush not only vetoed free speech and nonpolitical medicine this week; earlier he refused, via veto, to allow the District of Columbia to use local funds to pay for abortions for poor women; to let a U.S. servicewoman or dependent abroad have an abortion in a military hospital, even if paid for privately; or to provide abortion funds for poor women who were victims of rape or incest. Nor would he sign legislation to allow the U.S. to contribute to other nations' family-planning programs.
And what about the Republican platform, which since 1980 has featured a plank calling for a constitutional amendment to prevent abortion? Next August in Houston, Mr. Bush's party, in the full glare of national television, will have to leave that proposal in its 1992 platform, or take it out. Either action will offend a lot of voters, and not just women.
Supreme Court watchers say it's unlikely Roe v. Wade will come before the Court in time for the Reagan-Bush majority to overturn it before the election. But with a cruel record like his, George Bush doesn't need another Court decision to make abortion a major issue against him in 1992.

HEADLINE: GORBACHEV SEEKS EMERGENCY FUNDS, BUT RUSSIANS BALK

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Armed with ever-gloomier details about the country's economic situation, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev appealed to a shrunken Soviet Parliament today to spend money it does not have to get through the winter.
But his plea for an emergency three-month appropriation, which would widen the total Soviet deficit to 300 billion rubles, was rejected by the Russian republic, which has already stopped most of its payments to the Kremlin budget as it gets ready to strike off on its own path of economic reform. 
 Mr. Gorbachev said the country as a whole was headed for catastrophe if the republics did not join in common political and economic policies. Already this year, he said, national income has dropped 15 percent, industrial production 7 percent, agriculture 9 percent, exports 31 percent and imports 42 percent.
 
Income Falls Short
 Other reports say that the Government has received about half the income it anticipated this year and that to keep the economy afloat has printed 83 billion rubles, 76 billion more than planned. In November and December alone, 30 billion more rubles are expected to come off Soviet printing presses, the official press agency Tass reported, quoting remarks by Vladimir Rayevsky, a Deputy Finance Minister, at a Government meeting.
The result is a budget deficit of 205 billion rubles, or 300 billion if the republic budgets are included. Calculated at the inflated official rate, that amounts to more than $500 billion.
 
U.S. to Send Food
 The real worth is more difficult to measure since the street value of the ruble is plummeting, but already the deficit has exceeded the most pessimistic predictions of last summer. Mr. Rayevsky put the Soviet Union's internal debt at 974 billion rubles.
[In Washington, amid rising fear of hunger and civil unrest in the Soviet Union this winter, the Bush Administration announced it would send about $1.5 billion worth of food aid, most of which would be channeled through the central Government. It would be the first large-scale American shipments of free food to the Soviet Union in seven decades. Page A18.]
As the deputy finance ministers of the world's leading industrial nations, known as the Group of Seven, meet here to discuss interim loans, credits and deferrals to help cope with foreign debt and to establish some degree of credit-worthiness, the disparate parts of the Soviet Union continue to debate who owes what and who needs whom. As new paradoxes pile onto old ones, the picture that emerges is of politics played at cross-purposes against a background of economic desperation.
 
A Plea for the Center
 Two weeks ago, before the State Council, Mr. Gorbachev warned that politicians had wasted the opportunities handed them in August with the defeat of the hard-line coup attempt. Today, before the Parliament's lower house, Mr. Gorbachev, the tireless prophet of union, again urged the republics to preserve a central state, however confederated.
But his preachings were heard by representatives of only 7 of the present 12 republics of the union, who were gathered in a forum that for most part is already ignored. The Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, is offering to keep some union agencies and institutions, like the Soviet Academy of Sciences, alive with Russian funds, even as he pulls republic funds out of the all-union budget. Last Saturday he issued a package of sweeping decrees on the Russian economy.
So far, eight and possibly nine republics have agreed in meetings with the industrial nations' representatives to shoulder their share of the Soviet debt. This was widely quoted at $68 billion until this week, when a new estimate from the Soviet Foreign Economic Bank put it at $100 billion.
 
Ukraine Demands Details
 Those republics that do not agree to take collective responsibility for the Soviet debts can expect a cold shoulder from the West, warned Grigory A. Yavlinsky, a leading Soviet economist who has been present at the meetings of the industrial powers -- the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada.
"They will be treated the same as those countries in the world which do not pay their debts," Mr. Yavlinsky said in an interview on Soviet national television tonight.
Vitold Fokin, Prime Minister of the Ukraine, said at the Kiev airport tonight that the Ukraine would withhold its signature on the joint debt agreement until it had been fully informed on the size of the debt and the extent of Soviet assets abroad. Without this information, he said, the document was "shameful" and "nonsense."
The independent news agency Interfax tonight reported that the representatives of the industrial powers, in their talks with republic leaders, discussed rescheduling $3.6 billion in debts and extending new credits worth $1 billion, taking 104 tons of gold as collateral. How much gold the Soviet Union still has in its reserves is a mystery, although Mr. Yavlinsky recnetly cited a figure of 240 tons.
Interfax also quoted Viktor Danilenko, the representative of Byelorussia, as saying that if it were not for a $500 million credit from South Korea, the Soviet Union's Foreign Economic Bank would already be bankrupt.
In their meetings here this week, Western creditors were reportedly pressing hard for uniform reforms and for common links to keep this sprawling land from falling apart under economic, social and nationalist pressures.
Mr. Gorbachev, in his hourlong speech today, argued that the West, fearing the breakup of a nuclear superpower, long ago understood the need for some form of union to survive. "But we do not understand this," said the Soviet President, who warned that unless a new state was formed in the place of the old Soviet Union, economic chaos and border clashes were sure to follow.
"We're already up to our necks with all this inefficiency, lifelessness, immobilization," he said. "The country is simply dying from this."
He argued that unity need not come at the expense of sovereignty, the catchword that first spawned the republics' quest for greater autonomy last year. Referring to the referendum on independence scheduled for Dec. 1 in the Ukraine, Mr. Gorbachev insisted that a yes vote should not mean the end of the union.
"Independence means the freedom to voluntarily take part in a process," he said. "I don't see a vote for independence as a vote for divorce."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Antitrust Play, And an Epilogue

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
BROADWAY may never get to see it, but Walter Adams, Distinguished University Professor of Economics and former president of Michigan State University, and James Brock, Moeckel Professor of Economics at Miami University in Ohio, have written a play about antitrust policy that could have everybody but economists and lawyers rolling in the aisles.
Once they are past the non-sexy title, "Antitrust Economics on Trial: A Dialogue on the New Laissez-Faire," fans of the theater of the absurd will find themselves on familiar ground. The authors say their play exhibits "an absence of communication -- a terrifying diversity of utterances, with the actors on stage listening only to snatches and fragments of the dialogue, and responding as if they had not listened at all." 
 But if this is a dialogue of the deaf, it is not of the dumb. Characters talk away, using words that "border on the meaningless and lack authentic content."
The setting is a United States district court where a witness is being examined to determine his qualifications to testify as an expert in a merger case. The three characters are the Expert, an economist of the so-called New Learning, New Laissez-Faire, Anti-Antitrust, or Chicago school of economics; the Attorney, representing the Pro-Antitrust school of the University of Chicago of 30 years ago and earlier, and a Judge, of presumed neutrality.
Early in the play, the Attorney asks the Expert to state his area of expertise.
EXPERT: Price theory.
ATTORNEY: Could you define that please?
EXPERT: It is the science explaining rational economic behavior and the operation of markets. ATTORNEY: And what is its relevance to law?
EXPERT: Its relevance is much broader.
ATTORNEY: What do you mean?
EXPERT: In recent years, economists have used price theory more boldly in an effort to explain behavior beyond the narrow confines of the business world, and many noneconomists have followed their example. We have developed economic theories to explain racial discrimination, human fertility, crime, marriage and the family, divorce, suicide, drug addiction, politics, education, etc. The "etc." includes applications of price theory to sleep and murder. Indeed, economic theory is singularly useful for explaining all behavior involving scarce resources, both market and nonmarket, both monetary and nonmonetary.
The Attorney bridles and asks whether F. A. Hayek, a Nobel laureate in economics, has not "criticized your profession for what he calls its 'abuse of reason,' its penchant for engaging in 'scientism,' and its failure to recognize that imperfect knowledge is endemic to the human condition?" Has Hayek not derided economists for "aping the methods of the physical sciences, mindlessly misapplying them to socioeconomic phenomena and reaching absurd conclusions as a result?"
EXPERT: So he has.
"Antitrust on Trial" (Princeton University Press, 1991) remains unresolved at the end. The authors assert: "That is a task for the reader."
Here, then, is one reader's epilogue to the play:
JUDGE: How important is this issue?
EXPERT: Enormously important. With the acceptance of our doctrine by the Reagan Administration and its judicial appointees, we are reducing the role of Government to the bare minimum and taming the monster, antitrust. The virtual triumph of our doctrine has cleared the way for restructuring American industry, to make it more efficient and competitive in the world market.
ATTORNEY: I see it otherwise, Your Honor. The undermining of antitrust helped clear the way for the takeover orgy of the 1980's, put droves of once-sound corporations deeply in debt, many in jeopardy of bankruptcy, in pursuit of quick deals that profited only the deal makers, diverted billions and billions from solid investment in new plant and equipment or research and development, dragged productivity, hurt consumers, damaged America's competitiveness, injured our economy in ways from which it will take years to recover.
The old Chicago doctrine held that Government should stay out of the marketplace except to prevent monopoly and excessive concentration of power. But the new laissez-faire doctrine, in the name of market freedom, accepts monopoly as a lesser evil than Government interference. I plead for the old doctrine of Frank Knight, my revered teacher at Chicago, to whom this play is dedicated.
JUDGE: I declare the old, pro-antitrust doctrine the winner. To best serve the broad public interest, the capitalist system needs both competition and regulation -- competition that is as free and widespread as possible, but regulation and antitrust action when monopoly rears its anticompetitive head and market failure occurs. Witness dismissed.
EXPERT: (sotto voce) Outrageous! Incompetent! I'm going to take this to the Supreme Court.

HEADLINE: Dow Posts Gain of 2.68, To 2,932.69

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks edged up in choppy trading, as sellers and buyers ended yesterday's session in a near standoff. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.68 points to close at 2,932.69, and that firmness characterized the broad market as well.
Analysts said the market was reaching an oversold condition that could set the stage for a bounce, with investors likely to sell going into a rally. 
 Investors remain skittish about holding large equity stakes or taking on new positions after their rough ride in the last few days, traders said.
 
Advancing Issues Hold Edge
 Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 196.2 million shares, unchanged from Wednesday. Gaining issues held a slight advantage over declining issues at 842 to 804.
Bernard Spilko, senior vice president of the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer, called yesterday's session a good two-way market with both buyers and sellers seemingly happy. "Those wishing to accumulate value issues, and those selling what they consider overvalued, kept the market moving and fairly even, as evidenced by the ratio of advances to declines, which was almost even," he said. "I think the market is preparing its next move.
"Yesterday, each time the market reared its head, it was knocked down, and it happened a number of times. I think the resistance came from the institutions, which were selling on market upticks. And what that did was take away the market's ability to bounce higher." He said the next possible test might come at the 2,850 level on the Dow. That is the base point that most traders are using as the possible market floor.
In early trading, stocks recovered from a report of an unexpected jump in weekly jobless claims; the market had been expecting a flat number.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 1.53, to 380.06, while the New York Stock Exchange composite was up 0.78, to 210.21. Trading on the American Stock Exchange carried the composite up 1.24, to 376.05.
Nasdaq stocks bounced higher yesterday, rising 4.21 points, to 530.33, and the Russell 2,000, a barometer of small stocks, rose 0.61 point, to 178.75.
In afternoon trading, stocks followed a drop in bond prices, as nervousness emerged in the credit markets over the possibility that the Government might enact new fiscal-stimulus measures.
The stock market was also responding to the latest survey by the National Association of Business Economists, which showed its members are less optimistic about the recovery than they had been in August. Fewer than 10 percent of the members participating in the survey expected a "double dip" recession; the rest foresaw a "subdued" recovery, at about half the usual rate of expansion.
 
Campbell Soup Rises
 Company news affected trading in some issues. Campbell Soup rose 4, to 76, as the company raised its quarterly dividend on common stock and declared a 2-for-1 stock split. The dividend went to 35 cents a share on a pre-split basis from 29 cents.
 Traders said Eastman Kodak opened lower on news that a heart-failure treatment made by the company's Sterling Winthrop unit might increase the risk of death. The findings were from a nationwide team of researchers reporting on the drug Milrinone, which is still considered experimental and has not yet been approved by the Food and Drug Administration. STill, the stock closed up 1/8, to 45 5/8.
 Occidental Petroleum's shares fell 1/8, to 19 7/8, as the chairman, Ray Irani, said the company had sold $2.6 billion in assets since January and was on track to complete a $3 billion debt reduction by the end of 1992.
 At an analysts' meeting yesterday, the Coastal Corporation, a natural gas distributor, indicated that its fourth-quarter performance might be below the analysts' estimates. The stock fell 2 3/8 to close at 27 1/2.

HEADLINE: Another Rise In Filings By Jobless

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
In still another portrayal of economic distress, first-time claims for state jobless benefits climbed for the third straight week, to 493,000, the highest level since April, the Labor Department reported today.
The surge of 39,000 for the week ended Nov. 9 intensified concern about the sustainability of the economy's recovery, even though analysts regard claims figures with considerable suspicion. 
 "They leave no doubt that the United States remains mired in a serious recession," said Lacy H. Hunt, chief economist in this country for the Hongkong Bank Group. "There is every reason to be concerned about prospects for the Christmas selling season."
 
Fears of a Contraction
 While Mr. Hunt is gloomier than most, today's figures did point to the growing possibility that the economy could contract again in the fourth quarter after advancing in the summer with the aid of inventory-building in the automobile industry.
The latest increase in claims, which in part reflected bad weather in the Midwest, pushed the total of newly jobless people back to levels recorded in the spring. The Nov. 9 week was the worst since April 20, when 500,000 people on a seasonally adjusted basis filed initial claims.
The four-week average, which is preferred by analysts, rose by 10,200, to 443,500, well under the peak of 511,500, recorded in the period ended March 23, but above the 403,000 low point, recorded for the four weeks ended July 20.
Today's results, which had been expected to show a small decline in first-time claimants, caused some analysts to lower their expectations for the department's monthly report on the labor market, due Dec. 6.
Ian Borsook, an economist at Merrill Lynch, said he now expects a decline of perhaps 15,000 in payroll jobs for November instead of a small gain. The monthly report is based on surveys conducted during the week that includes the 12th day of the month.
With Congress on the verge of passing legislation extending unemployment benefits to workers out of a job for six months or more, there was less complaint than usual from Capitol Hill about the unemployment level. But both parties scheduled policy statements for Friday on the economy, and the Democrats in particular are expected to renew their criticism of the Bush Administration when the unemployment bill goes to the White House.
The claims report to be published on Wednesday coincides with the monthly survey week but will be hard to interpret, analysts said, because of the Veterans Day holiday, when offices were closed. The figures are adjusted for seasonal variation but not for holidays.
Of the rise of 39,000 in claims in the latest week, 7,421 of the increase came from Minnesota, more than double its previous figure, largely because of a loss of construction jobs during a blizzard. Michigan was the second worst affected, posting an increase of 7,307 substantially related to cutbacks in automobile production.
Pennsylvania and New York had claims increases of 4,538 and 4,073, respectively, while claims in Wisconsin rose 3,192 during the first full week of this month.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off on Jobless Report, Then Regains Some Ground

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other currencies yesterday after a jump in initial claims for unemployment insurance provided further evidence of a weakening economy.
The Labor Department said initial claims for state unemployment insurance surged by 39,000 to just under the half-million mark in early November. Some economists said the news was a further sign that the economic recovery had stalled. 
 The dollar fell in response to the report, which raised the possibility of lower interest rates. Lower yields could depress demand for American investments and, in turn, the dollar.
But the dollar regained some ground in late trading. Kevin Logan, the chief economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation, said the dollar's decline "was no big deal, compared to what could have happened."
He added, "People think it's cheap, so it's not falling out of bed."
In New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 129.60 Japanese yen, from 129.80 yen late Wednesday. Overnight in Tokyo, before the unemployment claims report was released, the dollar rose to 129.55 yen, from 129.40 yen, and in London, it was quoted at 129.50 yen.
The British pound lost ground to the dollar, falling to $1.7915, from $1.7977 in New York late Wednesday. But sterling was up in London, rising to $1.7968, from $1.7945.
Other late rates for the dollar in New York, compared with those of late Wednesday, included: 1.59875 German marks, down from 1.6000; 1.4215 Swiss francs, up from 1.4200; 5.4610 French francs, down from 5.46575; 1,208.00 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.13655 Canadian dollars, up from 1.13555.
In Europe, the other late dollar rates, compared with those of late Wednesday, included: 1.5960 German marks, down from 1.6025; 1.4180 Swiss francs, down from 1.4223; 5.4515 French francs, down from 5.4758; 1.7998 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8055; 1,206.50 Italian lire, down from 1,210.25, and 1.1355 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1360.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Rises to 4-Month High After Deal on Soviet Debt

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Gold prices rose yesterday after Western nations agreed to allow the Soviet Union to defer payments on its foreign debt.
Traders said the repayment delays would ease pressures on the country to sell off part of its big gold supply. 
 The December gold contract rose $3.90, to $368.60 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York, the highest level in nearly four months.
Analysts said Soviet sales of gold and other precious metals might decline after seven leading industrial nations agreed to the one-year deferral on $3.6 billion in debt payments.
"A move like this was expected, considering the orderly, step-ladder climb the market's been making in the last few weeks," said Marty McNeill, an analyst at the Sinclair Group.
The rally carried December gold to a peak of $370.70, a level not reached since late August.
Questions about Soviet gold holdings have buffeted the metals market since the aborted coup in August as differing reports circulated about the size of the gold reserves and whether the Soviet leadership might sell or stockpile production.
Other factors, including the status of the American economy and the political strife affecting mines in South Africa, have also come into play in the metals, analysts said.
The recent plunge in the American stock market caused investors to bid up metals prices as they sought a "safe haven" for their money.
December silver gained 4.3 cents, to $4.125 an ounce, and January platinum rose $1.10, to $374.30, at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
On the Chicago Board of Trade, grain prices ended mostly lower after traders were left unimpressed by the Bush Administration's offer of $1.25 billion in loan guarantees to the Soviet Union so that it could buy American grain.
January soybeans declined 4.75 cents, to $5.59 3/4 a bushel; December corn slipped half a cent, to $2.41 1/4 a bushel, and December wheat lost 1.5 cents, to $3.65 1/2 a bushel.
On Wednesday, wheat prices soared more than 13 cents a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade in anticipation of a deal.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Security Prices Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as short-term issues benefited from an extremely large increase in initial unemployment claims during the week ended Nov. 9.
However, long-term bond traders were unsettled by a report by Market News Service that the Bush Administration has discussed providing tax credits to consumers who buy domestically produced automobiles. The White House subsequently issued a denial, which was published by Reuters. Rumors that Japanese investors were selling long-term zero coupon bonds did not help, either. 
 "If you are using the long bond as a proxy for the market, you are missing the boat," said Joseph Liro, a senior vice president and money market economist at S. G. Warburg & Company. "In truth, this is a bifurcated market. The long end has no friends, whereas the short end remains well bid."
The big increase in unemployment claims, which rose to 493,000 in the week ended Nov. 9, up by 39,000 from the previous week, stunned most analysts, even though some of the increase was probably caused by abnormally cold, snowy weather in the Middle West.
Analysts and traders said the numbers increased the chances that November's employment report, due out in early December, will be weak, and that the Federal Reserve Board will likely ease short-term interest rates once again.
Analysts said the stimulative effects of such a fiscal step would not be terribly great, and would be far outweighed by negative reaction from Japan and other major trading partners.
Nevertheless, some traders preferred to view the report as another trial balloon from an Administration that appears increasingly intent on adopting policies that will foster more rapid growth. And traders continue to believe that stimulative fiscal policy, coupled with a lax monetary policy, will inevitably lead to higher inflation.
That view has pushed yield differentials between two-year notes and 30-year bonds out to more than 250 basis points, or more than 2.50 percentage points.
But some analysts said the market's fears were overstated, and that bonds were a terrific buy.
"Bond investors are being presented with an unbelievable opportunity," said Robert Goodman, a senior vice president at the Putnam Companies, the big Boston money management firm.
"The real risk the economy faces is deflation, not inflation."
That view was not widespread yesterday, as bond yields moved back up toward 8 percent.
By late in the session, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 10/32, down 7/8 point, to yield 7.97 percent, compared with 7.89 percent late Wednesday.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 22/32, down 10/32, to yield 7.40 percent. But prices of the 6 percent two-year notes rose by 2/32, to 100 31/32, to yield 5.46 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills moved lower.
 
3-Months Bill Offering
 Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.41 percent late yesterday, down six basis points, or six one-hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 4.49 percent.
New-issue activity in the tax-exempt municipal bond market continued to be heavy, as underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company priced a $1.6 billion offering of New Jersey Turnpike Authority securities.
Proceeds from the negotiated sale will be used to refund securities originally issued in 1985.
Serial bonds offered in the sale were preliminarily priced with yields ranging from 5 percent on serial bonds maturing in 1994 to 6.55 percent in 2006.
The largest part of the issue, $378 million worth of noncallable term bonds, was initially priced to yield 6.75 percent.
Bankers involved in the transaction said that demand for the securities was very strong.
The issue is rated A by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
 
Investment-Grade Bonds
 The investment-grade corporate bond market also absorbed a large number of new debt securities.
Among the issuers was the Republic of Ireland, which offered $200 million worth of 10-year notes through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 7 7/8 percent notes, which mature Dec. 1, 2001, were priced at $99.15, to yield 8 percent, 61 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 1/2 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated AA-3 by Moody's and AA-minus by Standard & Poor's.
Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead manager for a two-part, $300 million offering from ITT Hartford Group Inc.
The issue consisted of $100 million worth of 5-year notes, and $200 million worth of 10-year notes.
 
Five-Year Securities Priced
 The 7.25 percent five-year securities were priced at $99.813, to yield 7.295 percent, 78 basis points over the prevailing when-issued yield on the new five-year Treasury notes to be sold next week.
The 8.30 percent 10-year notes were priced at $99.865, to yield 8.32 percent, 95 basis points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. These securities are noncallable for life. 
Both parts of the issue are rated A-1 by Moody's and AA- by Standard & Poor's.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose during the week ended Nov. 11.
The gains were largely in line with analysts' expectations, and the report had little noticeable impact on prices in the credit markets.

HEADLINE: Aid Voted For Deposit Insurance

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Both the House of Representatives and the Senate passed legislation today to shore up the bank deposit insurance fund, prodded by the worry that the failure to act soon could cause severe runs at banks and by weariness at weeks of debate.
But significant differences remain between the measures, and reconciling them will not be easy, lawmakers and lobbyists said. 
 The House bill, which was approved 344 to 84, was stripped of any of the proposals the Bush Administration put forward in February for rolling back more than a half-century of restrictions on the ability of industrial companies to own banks and of banks to enter the securities and insurance industries.
 
Crossing State Lines
 But the Senate measure contains a limited version of the White House's request to give banks greater ability to open branches across state lines. The Senate measure would also tighten existing curbs on banks' ability to enter the insurance business.
"The House has twice rejected a similar bill, so I think it will be a tough conference," said Edward Yingling, senior lobbyist for the American Bankers Association, referring to meetings between House and Senate negotiators that could begin as early as this weekend.
The lawmakers have been hoping to leave for the year by Thanksgiving, but they cannot end the session without acting on the banking legislation because the bank insurance fund is expected to be insolvent by the end of next month. The fund, created during the Depression and run by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, has been crippled by the largest number of bank failures in recent years.
 
With Less Fanfare
 The Senate approved its measure shortly after the House had acted, but with significantly less fanfare. Fewer than a dozen senators were on the floor when it was adopted by a voice vote. Treasury officials were smiling in the hallways after the vote, confident that they would be able to prevail in conference.
The Administration has asked for a $70 billion increase in the insurance corporation's credit line with the Treasury, now $5 billion. The Administration says borrowings will be repaid by the banks, with some money coming from the sale of assets from banks seized by the Government.
Twice in the last three weeks, the House rejected legislation that would have provided the fund with the money the Administration says it needs because of differences over other provisions.
Both those bills also had provisions on interstate banking. The first was soundly defeated on Nov. 4, after heavy Administration and industry lobbying. Many lawmakers concluded that the legislation represented a step backward not forward, because of provisions making it harder for banks to enter the securities and insurance industries than it is now.
The second measure, which failed last week, would have given banks some new authority to expand geographically, but would have imposed more severe limits than now exist on their ability to sell insurance or invest in real estate.
The latest version, which the White House said yesterday it supported to "move forward with the legislative process," also gives regulators greater authority to close ailing banks and supervise foreign institutions, restricts the Government policy of bailing out banks considered too big to fail, and limits some banks from entering the insurance business.
The Senate measure also tightens existing regulations by permitting the officials to seize banks before they are insolvent. And like the House bill it would also require bank auditors to inform regulators of any financial wrongdoing they find.
The House bill was approved by 209 Democrats and 135 Republicans and opposed by 54 Democrats, 29 Republicans and the House's sole Independent, Bernard Sanders of Vermont. It was opposed by two powerful interest groups, the American Bankers Association and the Independent Insurance Agents of America, but like the Administration, they did not campaign against it, hoping to prevail in conference.
The House vote had been expected to be considerably closer, but as it became clear that it would pass, a large number of Republicans joined the White House in supporting the bill.
In the Senate, however, even White House support was not enough to overcome lawmakers' qualms that a vote for what might later be seen as a bank bailout that would be damaging at the polls. Senator Dale Bumpers, Democrat of Arkansas, was dissuaded by Senator Donald W. Reigle Jr, the Michigan Democrat who sponsored the legislation, from asking for a roll-call vote, which would have put senators on record.
"An awful lot of people don't want to vote for $70 billion for the bank fund," Mr. Reigle told reporters afterward, commenting on the voice vote. "There is a great concern that might not be enough."
In both houses many lawmakers pointed to the sluggish economy and recent market declines as additional reasons to act promptly.
"A little more than a month from now, when we are in our home districts, the fund that insures the deposits at 12,300 banks across the nation will be insolvent -- dead broke without a penny to pay off depositors," said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking Committee.
Senate passage followed the House action by less than an hour. Aides said the Senate moved so swiftly in part because managers of the bill feared some lawmakers might move to drop the broader Senate version for the narrower House measure.
Earlier in the day, two disagreements in the Senate were resolved by splitting the difference. Senator William V. Roth Jr., a Delaware Republican, had opposed a provision that would have prevented his state from serving as the home to affiliates of several large banks, notably Citicorp and Bankers Trust, that sell insurance. Mr. Roth agreed to a provision prohibiting any new banks from entering the business.
And Senator Richard P. Bryan, Democrat of Nevada, agreed to drop a provision that would have extended the time during which shareholders can sue executives and directors of corporations for securities fraud. But the legislation explicitly says the limitations stated in the court case, Lampf v. Gilbertson, will not apply to cases that have already been filed, like the ones brought by investors against Michael R. Milken, the former Drexel executive now serving a 10-year sentence for securities fraud.
The Senate measure also includes a 14 percent cap on the interest that banks can charge credit card customers, but it is not expected to remain in the final legislation.

The Economy
The House and the Senate passed legislation to replenish the deposit insurance fund. But significant differences remain between the measures and reconciling them will not be easy, lawmakers and lobbyists said. [Page D1.] 
 First-time claims for state jobless benefits climbed for the third straight week, to 493,000, the highest level since April, the Labor Department said. [D1.]
A Federal undercover agent in the case against B.C.C.I. told a Senate subcommittee of his frustration that the investigation did not go further. [D1.]

A tentative plan to swiftly restore telephone service when accidents like the breakdowns by A.T.& T. occur was proposed by a panel convened by Mayor David N. Dinkins. [D2.]

The disappearance of Cascade International's chief shareholder and chief executive has business associates wondering about the future of the women's clothing and cosmetics chain. [D1.]
Frank King left Lotus Development. He was the overseer of the company's technological strategy for nearly four years, and the man selected to replace him, John Landry, an executive at Dun & Bradstreet, surprised many analysts. [D1.]

More than $4 billion of investor claims against former financiers like Michael R. Milken could be thrown out unless Congress takes action, the head of the S.E.C. said. [D6.]
 
Markets

Prices of Treasury securities were mixed as short-term issues benefited from an extremely large increase in initial unemployment claims during the week ended Nov. 9. [D20.]
The dollar was mixed against other currencies after a jump in initial claims for unemployment insurance. [D21.]
Gold prices rose after Western nations agreed to allow the Soviet Union to defer payments on its foreign debt. [D21.]

HEADLINE: Anger Against Governors Reflected in 3-State Poll

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
Angry about tax increases imposed in troubled economic times, residents of New Jersey and Connecticut are taking out their discontent on their Governors, giving them generally dismal approval ratings in a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.
While only a quarter of those polled in the two states said they approved of their Governor's performance, New York's Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, received somewhat stronger support, with a 37 percent approval rating among residents of New York City and six surrounding New York counties. 
 And in contrast to the tax-focused unhappiness in the neighboring states, the New Yorkers offered a variety of complaints about their Governor.
But while New Yorkers' approval of Mr. Cuomo has been slipping for some time, almost half of those interviewed in the three states said they believed that he should run for President.
 
Squeezed by Demands
 The results reflect a national need to put the blame for the problems of the crippled economy on those who lead, as scores of incumbents learned when they were turned out of office on Nov. 5. They also underscore the deep discontent in the region, particularly in New Jersey and Connecticut, where residents feeling squeezed by demands to contribute more to state coffers have taken their anger to the streets and the voting booths.
"I think it has an awful lot to do with governing in a recession and the problems laid down at the door of an executive," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
Conducted from Nov. 2 through Nov. 12, the Times/WCBS-TV News poll is based on telephone interviews with 3,212 adults throughout Connecticut, New Jersey, New York City and the surrounding counties of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange and Putnam.
The low ratings of the Connecticut Governor, Lowell P. Weicker Jr., and his New Jersey counterpart, Jim Florio, rival those of two recent Presidents in times of crisis. In a Gallup Poll in July 1974, a month before President Richard M. Nixon resigned over the Watergate scandal, his approval rating sank to 24 percent. President Jimmy Carter received a 28 percent approval rating in a July 1979 Gallup Poll.
In Connecticut, where Mr. Weicker suceeded in winning approval of the state's first income tax after a tortuous budget battle, only 23 percent said they approved of the way he was handling his job; 64 percent disapproved.
In New Jersey, where Mr. Florio pushed through a $2.8 billion tax package in his first year in office, 26 percent of those polled said they approved of the way he was handling his job, and 59 percent said they disapproved. Two weeks ago, in what was generally seen as a judgment on the Democratic Governor, the Republicans won veto-proof control of the State Senate and General Assembly.
New York is now heading into another gloomy budget season -- the Cuomo administration announced just this week that the gap in next year's budget might increase to $3.6 billion. But without the burden of sudden and major tax changes, the New Yorkers polled were more split on Mr. Cuomo's performance, with 37 percent saying they approved and 44 percent saying they disapproved.
Those who disapproved of Governor Cuomo offered a variety of criticisms, from personal dislike to general job performance to his opposition to the death penalty. In both Connecticut and New Jersey, 51 percent of those who said they disapproved of their Governors cited taxes as the reason.
 
Support for Presidential Bid
 In spite of lukewarm support for the job Mr. Cuomo is doing, almost half of those interviewed in the New York metropolitan area, Connecticut and New Jersey said they believed he should run for President. The three-term Governor continues to say he has not yet decided whether to enter the race. And 59 percent of the New Yorkers polled said he should resign as Governor if he decided to run.
When they were asked who they would vote for, Mr. Bush or Mr. Cuomo, if the election were held today, 51 percent of New York City residents chose their Governor, and only 31 percent said they would cast their ballot for the incumbent. But the reverse was true in the suburbs, with more of those interviewed saying they would support Mr. Bush.
The Times/WCBS-TV News poll, which was devised to examine the life styles and political viewpoints of residents of the region, did not include any interviews with residents of upstate New York. However, a recent statewide poll of New York by the Marist Institute showed that Mr. Cuomo's approval rating in upstate New York was similar to that in the suburbs surrounding New York City.
The pain of the worsening economy was almost palpable in the voices of some of those polled who agreed to be interviewed afterward.
With one child and another one on the way, Doug Smoot of Stamford, Conn., and his wife want to move to a bigger house. They have had their current home on the market for a year, but have had no luck selling, even though they dropped the price to 20 percent below what they paid in 1986. Mr. Smoot was unequivocal in his disapproval of his Governor.
"Raising taxes is the only thing that Lowell Weicker has done that is of any consequence," Mr. Smoot said. "
In New Jersey, Mark Wileczek of West Deptford, a salesman for a chemical contractor, said higher sales taxes in his state have driven him to do his big-ticket buying in Delaware. Governor Florio has not been good for New Jersey, he said.
The Governors or their aides said that the economy has been their heaviest burden and that constituents were reacting to that frustration in giving them low marks.
At a news conference yesterday in Manhattan, Mr. Cuomo noted that his ratings have declined from an all-time high around the time of his re-election in 1986.
"I'm the same Governor, maybe even smarter, that I was when I set the all-time popularity record in New York State," he said. "I set every record there was in my victory. Now my polls are down there. Why? I'm the same guy. What changed? The news I have to deliver is now bad. And people hold you responsible for it."
Jon Shure, Mr. Florio's director of communications, also said the overall economy had more to do with the results than did the Governor's specific actions.
Mr. Weicker's press secretary, Avice Meehan, said the Governor was not worried by the low ratings in the poll. "As the Governor frequently says, you don't stand up and applaud the bill collector," she said. "The Governor has by circumstances been placed in the role of bill collector."

How the Poll Was Conducted
Chart: "How the Governors Are Doing"
The latest New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Nov. 2 to 12 with 3,212 adults across the New York metropolitan region.
A total of 742 interviews were conducted throughout Connecticut, 632 throughout New Jersey, and 1,838 in downstate areas of New York State. The downstate New York sample included 824 interviews in New York City, 442 on Long Island, 429 in Westchester and Rockland Counties, and 143 in Orange and Putnam Counties.
The sample of telephone numbers called was generated by a computer, based on random digit dialing techniques. It was drawn by the Marketing Systems Group of Philadelphia.
Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the poll.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into each residence. Within each major geographical area, results have been adjusted for variations relating to race, sex and age. Then each of the samples was weighted on the basis of population size to reflect an accurate balance between geographical areas within the metropolitan region.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than a few percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adults in the respective populations: plus or minus four percentage points both for Connecticut and for New Jersey, three percentage points for New York City, five percentage points both for Long Island and for the Westchester-Rockland area. For the downstate New York area as a whole, with Orange and Putnam Counties also included, it was plus or minus three percentage points.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.
