HEADLINE: White House Isolation;
An Image of Bush as a Captive of Top Aides Who Make Their Own Sweeping Decisions

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Haunted by the image of Ronald Reagan, George Bush vowed from the beginning of his Presidency that he would never be manipulated, isolated or surprised by his staff.
But in the last few weeks, the President has appeared to Republicans and Democrats alike as a wavering leader, a captive of a few top aides who make sweeping decisions on their own and leave him to try to clean up the mess. 
 "It's just causing distress and dismay among Republicans that's almost like a physical pain," said Eddie Mahe, a Republican consultant with strong ties to the White House. "It's almost schizophrenic, the way the President keeps lunging in different directions. They have to stop the hemorrhaging with this disarray, this lack of planning, this lack of thought, this lack of vision, this lack of coherency. George Bush is hurting himself every time he opens his mouth."
 
An Embarrassing Moment
 In an intensely embarrassing moment that Senator John C. Danforth, the Missouri Republican, likened to a horror movie, the White House today insisted that the President did not know that his legal counsel, C. Boyden Gray, had proposed reversing long-standing civil rights policies without consulting with Mr. Bush or the Cabinet members in charge of those policies.
What had started to become apparent before the Persian Gulf war seems even clearer now: This White House does not have a traditional policy making process or a coherent communications strategy.
 
Lacking Core Philosophy
 Whenever Mr. Bush is forced to concentrate on the domestic policy area where he feels less comfortable, he seems to have no core philosophy to fall back on, and the White House shows no talent for developing a long-range agenda or even for explaining its impromptu decisions to the public.
What is now being portrayed as Mr. Gray's foiled coup on civil rights, in which he took a page from the secretive and ad hoc management style of John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, was only the latest of several White House gaffes. First, without widely consulting with top political advisers, Mr. Bush and Mr. Sununu abruptly canceled the President's trip to Asia, giving the appearance of panic over opinion polls showing that Americans think the President spends too much time on foreign policy.
Then, Mr. Bush caused a furor about lower interest rates on credit card purchases by reading two sentences that Mr. Sununu wrote into a speech at the last minute without checking with any economic advisers.
Mr. Sununu has been spreading the word that he would control much of the 1992 re-election campaign from the White House before the President has even had a chance to pick his campaign leadership.
A political intimate of Mr. Bush reported that when he talked to the President last week, Mr. Bush conceded that he knew he had serious problems with his staff, but he had not yet decided how to handle them.
 
Sununu Is Unsettled
 The combative chief of staff, whose distaste for the press, Congress and even government itself is well known, showed that he was rattled today. After the Rose Garden signing ceremony for the Civil Rights Bill, he publicly criticized Ann Devroy, a White House reporter for The Washington Post, who first reported Mr. Sununu's role in the credit card episode.
"Your story today was a lie," he told a surprised Ms. Devroy, in front of others on the lawn, apparently referring to a front page piece about Mr. Sununu's inept orchestration of the credit card interest rates commotion. "Everything you write is a lie."
The article said that in inserting the call for lower rates, Mr. Sununu bypassed the usual procedures for approving Presidential policy statements. The failure to consult with economic policy officials set off a chain of events that some analysts say led to the stock market plunge on Friday, as investors unloaded banking stocks because of fears that the Government would place caps on credit card interest rates.
Even a White House that likes to identify any criticism as being a plot by the Democrats and the press is beginning to hear from fellow Republicans that Bush's top aides are squandering precious political capital as if on a "Thelma and Louise"-style spree.
"It's a critical period," said Edward Rollins, a Republican consultant. "As they start to feel the political heat, it's more important than ever not to mix messages and to look further down the road than what's for lunch tomorrow. If they can't communicate or connect with the voters to make them believe they understand their economic problems, it will give someone else the chance to."
White House officials defend the President's inaction, his insistence on clinging to the status quo when the political and economic ground is shifting fast, by saying that Mr. Bush is convinced that the economy will improve if left alone. But they concede that they have been unable to find a way to turn "just wait" into an attractive message for voters.
 
Carving Up Policy
 As one top Bush aide said: "If the economy comes back in six months, nothing else matters. If it doesn't, nothing else matters."
Mr. Sununu and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, have "carved up the world between them" on domestic policy, as one top Administration official puts it. And now Mr. Bush, who has always avoided the nitty-gritty of domestic policy in favor of the more glamorous foreign policy arena, seems to be guided by a few powerful and secretive aides who fight to get their own views across, in the absence of any controlling ideology on Mr. Bush's part.
Each has pet projects: Mr. Sununu fights to make abortion policy more conservative; Mr. Gray fights to make civil rights law more conservative and Mr. Darman uses the budget to try to make domestic policy.
Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman, who sit at either end of the table at staff meetings, have formed a de facto alliance in which Mr. Sununu yields to Mr. Darman on a large number of budget and legislative matters and, in return, Mr. Darman does not butt into the management of the White House and the President. The partnership of these two men, both perceived as highly intelligent and imperious, has had a chilling effect on the free and energetic flow of ideas and proposals, said a dozen Administration officials and Bush intimates interviewed on the subject.
 
'There's a Lot of Secrecy'
 "It's hard to debate decisions because there's a lot of secrecy," said one top Administration official. "Sununu maximizes his influence by keeping others in the dark. He doesn't want any alternative sources of power."
Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman do not want Mr. Bush's speechwriting office to be a place where ideas ferment, for instance, because that would make it an alternative power source, as it was in the Reagan years.
Mr. Sununu has worked so hard to avoid or hold at arm's length the kind of talents that might challenge him on politics or domestic policy that some Bush officials now derisively refer to the White House staff as "John Sununu and a thousand interns."
Even officials who are well thought of in Republican circles, like the press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, the image-maker Sig Rogich and the communications expert Dorrance Smith, have been discouraged in attempts to develop an effective communications strategy.
Worried Republicans have grown increasingly bold about trying to pierce Mr. Sununu's protective wall and get their message of alarm to the President. But even White House officials with impressive titles who have tried to talk to the President to suggest that he might be taking the wrong course politically or economically report their experience afterwards with the same nervous phrase: "Sununu glared at me the whole time."
 
Strong Dislike for Sununu
 Or, as another top Bush aide put it this week: "Sununu just doesn't want anyone else in the mix."
Some Bush officials fear that the dislike of Mr. Sununu has become so intense and widespread that it is serving as a magnifying glass for all the criticism of Mr. Bush.
Echoing the common complaint among Republicans that Mr. Sununu is smart but not street smart on political matters, Mr. Rollins drily noted: "Sununu is living proof that you shouldn't give children their I.Q. test results because then they go through life thinking they're smart."
Eddie Mahe agreed, saying: "I never thought George Bush could ever be isolated. I never thought he'd let John Sununu take his telephone away."
Those who know Mr. Bush point out that while he does not like confrontation and while he always tries to split the difference, he is capable of being ruthless about personnel once he decides he is being damaged.
"He may not come around to focusing on the thing at the exact moment that friends and advisers tell him to, and sometimes it looks like he may be delaying," said Vic Gold, Mr. Bush's former speechwriter and co-author of his biography, "Looking Forward." "But suddenly, very quickly, he strikes."

HEADLINE: SECURITY COUNCIL SELECTS EGYPTIAN FOR TOP U.N. POST

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Boutros Ghali, Egypt's 69-year old Deputy Prime Minister, was unanimously recommended to become the next United Nations Secretary General by the 15 members of the Security Council tonight and appeared set to win final approval from the 166-nation General Assembly.
Mr. Ghali would become the first Arab and the first person from Africa to hold the top post at the United Nations. He would replace Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru, who has said he wants to step down at the end of this year after serving two five-year terms in the post. 
 The Council closed ranks to give Mr. Ghali its unanimous endorsement tonight after 11 members had cast their ballots in his favor on an earlier vote and none of the five members with permanent seats -- the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China -- used a veto. Four members abstained.
 
Votes for Rivals
 Mr. Ghali's two closest rivals for the $185,000 post, Zimbabwe's Finance Minister, Bernard Chidzero, and Olusegun Obasanjo, a former Nigerian head of state, each got seven votes in this first official Council ballot, or two less than the nine needed to force a runoff against Mr. Ghali.
No General Assembly vote was immediately scheduled, but diplomats said approval is a foregone conclusion in view of the Security Council's unanimous endorsement and the fact that he was one of six official African candidates nominated for the post by the Organization of African Unity and endorsed by the 106-member non-aligned movement.
 
Campaign for African
 African countries had mounted a successful campaign to choose one of their own as the next Secretary General. But during the political maneuvering that led up to tonight's vote, several black African diplomats made clear that they preferred a black African over Mr. Ghali.
"I'm very glad we have a new Secretary General and that no negative votes were cast against him," France's United Nations representative, Jean-Bernard Merimee, said as members left the closed-door meeting.
Britain's representative, Sir David Hannay, described the choice as "excellent" though he declined to say whether Britain voted for him on the first secret ballot.
He said the result showed the Security Council has entered "a new era" because no vetoes were cast during the selection process in 1981 when "the floor was littered with vetoes."
Egypt's United Nations representative, Nabil el-Araby, said it was "a great day for Africa, for the third world and for my own country."
Mr. Ghali, a Coptic Christian, is fluent in French, English and Arabic.
 
Question Raised on Age
 Although the United States and Britain both voted to recommend Mr. Ghali to the General Assembly this evening, American and British officials were saying openly until a few days ago that they felt he was too old for the job and that they would prefer a younger candidate, able to serve two terms.
Mr. Ghali, who is only a year younger than Mr. Perez de Cuellar, has said he is seeking the post for just a single five-year term.
Until recently American and British officials, and to a lesser extent those from the Soviet Union, also appeared opposed to any of the declared African candidates. They complained that none of them had the stature and political experience they felt the next Secretary General needs in the post-cold-war world when the United Nations is playing an increasingly important role in world affairs.
Instead, they said, the Security Council should "head-hunt the world" to find the best qualified man or woman.
But African countries insisted they had qualified candidates for the post and said that one of these should be chosen because Africa is the only major region of the world which has not yet provided a Secretary General.
 
3 Were From Europe
 Of the five previous Secretaries General, three -- Trygve Lie of Norway, Dag Hammarskjold of Sweden and Kurt Waldheim of Austria -- were Europeans, while U Thant of Burma, now Myanmar, came from Asia and Mr. Perez de Cuellar from the Western Hemisphere.
France supported Mr. Ghali from the start, while China made clear that it favored an African candidate.
Faced with this opposition, the United States and Britain appeared to change their attitude in recent days, diplomats say, apparently deciding that they could not prevent the election of an African Secretary General without severely damaging their political relations with the continent and that they could live with Mr. Ghali.
In an informal straw poll on Nov. 11, Mr. Chidzero emerged as the front-runner with 11 votes, followed by Mr. Ghali with 10 and Mr. Obasanjo with 8. But by tonight Mr. Ghali had moved into a decisive lead.
Diplomats suggested that once the United States realized that an African Secretary General was inevitable, it favored Mr. Ghali because he was the most sympathetic to its interests and was only seeking a single term. Although the first ballot was secret, some diplomats also suspect that Britain, perhaps the United States and two or more of the Council's African members were the four that abstained when Mr. Ghali's name was put to the vote.
The Security Council currently has three African members, the Ivory Coast, Zimbabwe and Zaire. In addition to the permanent members, the remaining nations with seats on the Council are Austria, Belgium, Romania, India, Yemen, Cuba and Ecuador.
Mr. Chidzero, a respected technician who sought successfully to dissuade Zimbabwe's white farmers from fleeing black-majority rule at independence, presided over an economy dominated by large Government-owned corporations. Some diplomats suspect the United States was one of the two countries that voted against him tonight, while another six abstained.
Among the other candidates, Kenneth K. S. Dadzie, a United Nations official from Ghana, received 6 votes, with 4 Security Council members voting against him and 5 abstaining; Michel Doo Kingue, a United Nations official from Cameroon, received 6 votes, with 4 against and 5 abstaining; James Jonah, a United Nations official from Sierra Leone, got 5 votes, with 5 against and 5 abstaining, and Msanze Terrence, a former Burundi diplomat, got 4 votes, with 4 against and 7 abstaining.
The leading non-African candidate, Foreign Minister Hans van den Broek of the Netherlands, got only 5 votes, with 7 against and 3 abstaining. Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the United Nations official in charge of Persian Gulf war relief efforts, received 4 votes, with 7 against and 4 abstaining.
Nguema Francois Owono, a Gabonese official, was supported by 3 members, with 3 against and 9 abstentions.
Norway's Foreign Minister, Thorvald Stoltenberg, got just 2 votes, with 9 against and 4 abstentions, while the country's Prime Minister, Gro Harlem Brundtland, fared even worse, with a single favorable vote, 8 against and 6 abstentions. Poland's Foreign Minister, Krzysztof Skubiszewski, received 2 votes, with 8 against and 5 abstentions.

HEADLINE: CREDITORS TO LET SOVIETS POSTPONE PAYING PRINCIPAL

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The Soviet Union's major creditors agreed today to allow the fragmented Union to defer repayment of principal for up to a year, thus postponing up to $6 billion in payments and rescuing it from the brink of default.
The Soviet Union amassed a foreign debt estimated at $65 billion to $70 billion, and was facing what one Western official described as "an extremely grave liquidity situation" because of the breakdown of central authority since the Kremlin coup in August and a sharp slowdown in oil and gas exports and economic activity in general. 
 The agreement between representatives of the Group of Seven major industrial democracies and the Soviet side -- eight Soviet republics and the Moscow Government -- tied the deferment to tangible progress on far-ranging economic changes worked out with the International Monetary Fund.
 
Russia Institutes Reforms
 These included several of the intentions already announced by the Russian republic, such as reducing budget deficits, curtailing public spending and monetary growth, and liberalizing prices and exchange rates.
The seven industrial nations -- the United States, Canada, Britain, France, Italy, Germany and Japan -- also gave the Soviet side the opportunity to borrow $1 billion against a gold collateral in what is known as a gold-swap facility. But the proposal reportedly ran into resistance from the republics because of disagreement over the ownership and even the amount of Soviet gold reserves.
Not joining today's agreement were 7 of the 15 republics that were in the Soviet Union before the coup -- the three Baltic states, whose independence has been internationally recognized, and four other republics, including the Ukraine. But Western officials expressed confidence that the holdouts would eventually accept their share of Soviet debt service, saying all had been warned that any republic's refusal to shoulder its share would have serious consequences.
 
Lure of New Credits
 "Certain republics were unable to enter in the memorandum of understanding at this time," said David C. Mulford, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, who represented the United States. "We indicated to them that if they turned their backs on the existing body of debt, they would face a bleak future with regard to attracting new credits."
Beyond its economic significance, the agreement reflected a recognition among the Western powers that they could no longer deal exclusively with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his central Government. The communique issued at the end of the talks referred to the republics, for instance, as "sovereign states," and the treaty dealt with the eight signing republics and the center collectively. Those republics taking part in the agreement are Russia, Moldavia, Byelorussia, Armenia, Turkmenia, Kazakhstan and Kirghizia.
Mr. Mulford insisted that throughout the negotiations the industrial democracies' envoys tried not to inject themselves into the grappling between the republics and the center. "But the problem can't wait for a resolution of the constitutional problem and other arrangements between the republics and the center," he said.
The agreement announced today concluded two long negotiating sessions in which representatives of the Group of Seven sought to convince the newly sovereign republics, most led by governments with little knowledge of international financing but considerable suspicion of anything associated with Moscow, that it was in their best interest to assume the Union's debt. After the first round of meetings last month, all 12 remaining republics initialled a "memorandum of understanding" accepting the princple that all were responsible for their former Union's debt.
But when the second round opened on Monday, several republics, led by the Ukraine, raised new objections over the distribution of the debt burden. Elections for a republic president are scheduled for Dec. 1 in the Ukraine, and with all candidates vying to distance themselves from Moscow, the republic has become all but paralyzed in negotiations with other republics and the Moscow Government.
At the other pole, the representative of the Russian republic, Yegor Gaidar, President Boris N. Yeltsin's top economic adviser, repeatedly declared that Russia accepted the memorandum and its obligations without conditions and was further prepared to assume the entire debt.
 
Exasperation Expressed
 The meetings with the seven wealthy nations were closed, but Western negotiators made no attempt to hide their exasperation with the recalcitrant republics. According to Nezavisimaya Gazeta, a Moscow daily, one of several requests from the Soviet side for more time to consult met with this stern reply from the German delegate: "Another 10 days and the patient will die. You have 24 to 28 hours."
At another point, Nezavisimaya Gazeta reported, Mr. Mulford told the Soviet side: "This is amazing. You're in crisis. If the repayments are missed, you will need 10 years to recover your credit-worthiness. All your programs will be stopped, including food aid."
Mr. Mulford explained subsequently that the law in the United States and some other creditor countries demands that if a debtor defaults on a payment, all other credits are automatically halted. This would block, for instance, the $1.5 billion in food credits announced by President Bush on Wednesday.
In the end, the Ukraine, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan and Georgia did not sign. Nezavisimaya Gazeta said the Ukraine did not attend the last session at all.
 
'Jointly and Separately'
 Under the memorandum of understanding, the participating republics and the central Government agreed to assume the Soviet debt "jointly and separately." According to the communique, the Soviet signers further agreed to reach an agreement by the end of November allocating responsibility for repayment and servicing of the Soviet foreign debt and to "mobilize" the foreign exchange needed to pay the debt.
The republics also declared that "as a matter of the highest priority" they would work with the International Monetary Fund "to adopt and implement during the first quarter of 1992 comprehensive and ambitious macro-economic and structural adjustment programs."
Essentially, this required all participating republics to institute quickly the sort of economic program that Mr. Yeltsin announced last weekend, when he pledged to open the door to foreign trade, let the ruble float and enact a variety of other changes.
For their part, the industrial powers agreed to defer payments on medium- and long-term debts contracted before Jan. 1, 1991. Mr. Mulford stressed that the agreement applied only to payments of principal, and not of interest, which would continue being paid.
The deferment would be reviewed after three months to see if the republics were fulfilling their pledges.
 
Called a Unique Approach
 "This is an absolutely unique appraoch, one not tried before," Mr. Mulford said. The Soviet debt, he said, was not that heavy when seen against the potential size of the Soviet economy.
"The problem is liquidity, not solvency," he said. "This is an attempt to give them breathing space. They're current in their payments. The idea is to enable them to maintain payments of interest, so that they could continue to receive credits. If there was no such arrangement, there could be an interruption and cutting of external credit."
The industrial democracies further pledged to seek comparable agreements from other countries to which the Soviets owe money.
If payments of principal are deferred over a year, Mr. Mulford, said the Soviets would be spared about $6 billion dollars in repayments, of which $3.6 billion is due the industrial democracies. The Soviet Union's principal creditor is Germany. The United States is owed about $2.8 billion.
The industrial nations also pledged to maintain short-term credits by their export credit agencies.
 
Trying to Print More Money
 A day earlier, Mr. Gorbachev appealed to the central Parliament for authority to print yet more money to cover his Government's expenses through the winter. His plea would push the central deficit to 205 billion rubles, plus another 100 billion for the republics.
The plea met with resistance from the Russian government, which has assumed the cost of some former central institutions and is trying to close many of the remainder.
According to officials, the idea of a formal budget has been largely abandoned. They said that a budget of 600 billion rubles had been planned for the central Government at the start of the year, but that the disintegration of the Union had stopped most transfer of funds from the republics to the center. Since the August coup, the officials said, and especially since the Russian government began absorbing old federal institutions in November, the central Government has been functioning largely hand-to-mouth.

HEADLINE: 135 Feared Lost As Haitian Boat Sinks Off Cuba

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
As many as 135 Haitian refugees are believed to have drowned off the coast of Cuba on Tuesday night, when their sailboat was wrecked in stormy seas, the Cuban press agency reported today.
It was the first such disaster to be reported since a sudden exodus of Haitians from their island began in late October. 
 The Coast Guard's Miami office said that it could not confirm the report of the shipwreck, off Cape Maisi in Guantanamo Province. But a Coast Guard spokesman said that the seas were running 8 feet high with 20 knot winds on Tuesday night, weather too bad for cutters to continue their normal patrols. Two cutters in the area were riding at anchor. The United States Navy base at Guantanamo was apparently also not aware of the shipwreck.
 
Deteriorating Weather
 The Cuban press agency said that 60 survivors and 16 bodies had been found, and that 119 Haitians were missing and thought to have drowned. The bodies discovered were of two children, two men and 12 women, the Cuban agency said. The report could not be independently confirmed.
With weather conditions still deteriorating today, the Coast Guard said that there had been no reports of Haitian refugee boats intercepted since a small craft with 26 people aboard was encountered Wednesday.
Seas were 10 feet high today, and winds registered 30 knots, the Coast Guard said in Miami, raising fears that many Haitians might have perished unnoticed. Many officials said they believed that only half the Haitians who put to sea -- most of them in boats that are ill equipped, overloaded and not seaworthy -- survive the voyage.
Reports of the shipwreck came as a Bush Administration effort to resume the forced return of refugees to Haiti was blocked today by a Federal judge in Miami, who also ruled that lawyers representing the Haitian exiles will be allowed for the first time to witness interviews that determine whether Haitians now in custody will be admitted to the United States.
In a ruling welcomed by human-rights and refugee organizations as a victory for those challenging immigration procedures in asylum cases, Judge C. Clyde Atkins of the United States District Court for Southern Florida upheld a temporary stay order against the involuntary repatriation that began on Monday.
In two days, 538 Haitians picked up at sea were taken back to the island. On Wednesday night, the Justice Department and the United States Attorney's office in Miami asked for the Nov. 19 stay to be vacated so that repatriations could resume.
A hearing on the class-action suit brought by the Haitian Refugee Center in Miami is scheduled to be heard by Judge Atkins on Nov. 27. On Friday the center, an advocacy organization for Haitian exiles, hopes to send a lawyer to at least one Coast Guard cutter and the Navy base at Guantanamo where refugees are being held.
 
Transfers to Base in Cuba
 The forced repatriation of Haitians on the ground that most are economic and not political refugees has provoked protests from human-rights groups and members of Congress who ask why people were being returned to the jurisdiction of a military Government the United States does not recognize as legitimate and against which economic sanctions have been imposed. The Government now in control in Haiti overthrew the elected Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide on Sept. 30.
More than 1,400 of the Haitians who have been picked up by Coast Guard cutters over the last few weeks are now being transfered to the Navy base at Guantanamo, to make room on the ships for new boat people. About 380 people remain on the cutters.
The State Department said today that 858 of the 1,400 were being put aboard the Navy's amphibious landing ship Tortuga and 572 others would go to the base. On Tuesday, several hundred were moved from Guantanamo to temporary havens in Honduras and Venezuela.
Of the 4,409 Haitians intercepted in the Caribbean by the Coast Guard in 1991, under a 10-year-old treaty with Haiti allowing the forcible return of those who do not qualify for political asylum, 2,845 people in 44 boats have been picked up since Oct. 29.
 
Visit to Haiti
 The State Department has raised the question why many Haitians waited nearly a month after the Sept. 30 coup to leave the island when much of the violence unleashed by the takeover occurred in the first few days of October.
In an interview today, one of the Haitians picked up at sea early this month gave his explanation for the delay.
The refugee, Gaston Jolicoeur, a 35-year-old carpenter, said he was in Cap-Haitien when the coup against President Aristide occurred. Mr. Jolicoeur said he had been living in the Miami area for 13 years and was visiting his family in Haiti, where his passport and other vital documents had been stolen and not yet replaced.
He was picked up off the coast of Florida by the Coast Guard on Nov. 7. Because he could remember his Social Security and alien registration number -- and spoke excellent English -- he was among 53 Haitians brought to Miami on Nov. 18 to lodge formal asylum petitions. He spoke by phone from Miami.
Mr. Jolicoeur said that for the first few days after the coup, people were terrified to leave their homes because "all this killing was going on all over." He said a particularly brutal army corps had been posted in Cap-Haitien and the local troops rotated out.
 
'I've Got to Get Out'
 Many people nevertheless continued to believe that President Aristide would be restored. They remembered that there had been a failed coup before his inauguration in February, and they expected that the country could ride out this crisis, also. But instead, the terror continued.
"When I see all the killing -- a young woman dead, young kids getting shot, young woman, young kids gettin killed, dogs eating people -- I said, hey, I got no choice," Mr. Jolicoeur said. "I've got to get out."
Lacking money, it took him more than a week -- it was then nearly mid-October -- to find someone with a boat who was willing to take him on for no fee as an English speaker who could deal with the Coast Guard. His group of 52 refugees finally set sail on Oct. 30. Four days later, they beached on a small island to ask for food and water from local people. Two days later they headed toward Miami, and were picked up on the way.
For four more days, they cruised the Caribbean on a Coast Guard cutter, picking up other refugees, who he said got sick from sleeping on the decks in the rain every night. They were given two meals a day of rice and beans. Then they were put ashore at Guantanamo, and life improved dramatically, with hot showers, sheets and pillows, three meals a day and medical care.
After interviews at Guantanamo, he was flown to Miami on Nov. 18.
"When I'm thinking of those people in Guantanamo, I'm wondering what's going to happen to them," he said. "It really bothers me. It bothers me a lot."

HEADLINE: France to Pursue Libyan Link to '89 Bombing

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 21

 BODY:
President Francois Mitterrand hardened his tone toward Libya today by pledging to pursue charges that Libyan Government agents planted a bomb on a French airliner that exploded in midair in September 1989, killing 171 people.
"I personally feel strongly that the murders of our compatriots and of other nationals should not go unpunished," Mr. Mitterrand said at a news conference. 
 His comments followed the arrival here a few days ago of Khadaf al-Dam, the reputed head of Libyan intelligence services. Mr. Dam has been trying to persuade French officials of Libya's innocence in the bombing.
There were also reports from Tunis that Libya was trying to rally support in the Arab world by calling for an Arab League meeting to discuss American and British threats of punitive action against Libya over its alleged complicity in the bombing a Pan Am airliner over Scotland in 1988, in which 270 died. Formal indictments against two Libyan Government employees were issued in Britain and the United States last week.
A ranking Arab diplomat here said that there was "little enthusiasm" among Arabs to publicly support Libya's denials of involvement in the two bombings, but that virtually all Arab countries were "adamantly opposed" to any concerted military action against Libya.
The diplomat added, however, that the Arabs would not strongly oppose any other actions.
"If the United States, France and Britain go for economic sanctions, there will not be much that the Arab League could or would do," said the diplomat, who asked for anonymity.
Mr. Mitterrand's assertion that he will push the judicial inquiry "as far as the French judicial system demands"increases the possibility that the European Community will impose broader sanctions against Libya.
France imports little Libyan oil, and Britain is self-sufficient in energy, but according to Ira B. Joseph of Petroleum Intelligence Weekly, four other Community members -- Italy, Greece, Germany and Spain -- together consume about one-half of Libya's oil exports. Oil accounts for about 90 percent of the country's exports. The United States already boycotts Libyan oil.
Mr. Mitterrand did not specify what actions France would take against Libya if it failed to deliver four Libyan officials, including a brother-in-law of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to the French authorities. Arrest warrants for the four were issued on Oct. 30 in Paris in connection with the 1989 bombing, in which a DC-10 of the French airline U.T.A. exploded over Niger.
The increasingly stern attitude taken by France toward Libya contrasts sharply with the mood of optimism and friendliness that this country tried to foster in the European Community only a few weeks ago, when it advocated the lifting of sanctions that have been in place against Libya.
Three days before the indictments were handed down in Paris, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said in Algiers that it was time "to turn the page" with Libya and lift economic sanctions imposed by Europe in 1986 for Libya's reported support of terrorism.
Like the United States and Britain, France did not repeat earlier assertions implicating Syria and Iran in the two airplane bombings.
Arab diplomats here say that the three nations appear to have singled out Libya for blame as it is largely isolated in the Arab world today and has been a vociferous critic of the Middle East peace conference that convened last month in Madrid.

Libya Rejects Extradition
 LONDON, (Reuters) -- Libya's Foreign Minister told the British Broadcasting Corporation today that he had rejected a request by Britain to hand over the two men charged with murder and conspiracy in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland.
 In an interview with BBC World Service radio's Arabic service, the official, Ibrahim Mohamed Bashari, repeated denials that Libya was in any way involved with the December 1988 bombing over the town of Lockerbie.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

TOUGH TIMES FOR GOVERNORS
Angry about tax increases imposed in troubled economic times, residents of New Jersey and Connecticut are taking out their discontents on their Governors, giving them generally dismal approval ratings in a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll. While only a quarter of those polled in the two states said they approved of their Governor's performance, New York's Governor, Mario M. Cuomo, received somewhat stronger support, with a 37 percent approval rating. Page A1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
STREETS OFFICIAL IS REASSIGNED
New York City's assistant commissioner for street reconstruction has been moved to another job amid revelations that the city may lose tens of millions of dollars in Federal highway funds because city contractors used watered-down concrete and violated safety rules on three major street repair projects. Page A1.

In subway stations and at bus stops around the city, the proposed 25-cent fare increase is cause for indignation. Many straphangers and bus riders say that their wallets have already been pinched enough by the recession and that the Transit Authority should not ask them to solve its financial problems. HEADLINE: Affirmative Action Plans Are Now Part of the Normal Corporate Way of Life

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
When the Bush Administration seemed ready to attack programs that give preferences to minority and female job seekers, it was tampering with a bipartisan concept that has become as familiar to American businesses as tally sheets and bottom lines.
Affirmative action plans that are either mandated by Federal law or sanctioned by Supreme Court rulings are so pervasive in the American workplace that a Reagan Administration attempt in 1985 to curtail them was opposed by corporate lobbyists as well as civil rights groups. 
 "Affirmative action programs are so much a part of the way industry operates today that to try to de-establish them would create enormous difficulties," said Alfred W. Blumrosen, a professor at Rutgers University Law School who was an official in the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
 
New Possibilities Open
 Since a company's jettisoning of an affirmative action program could be cited in a court case as evidence of its intent to discriminate, Mr. Blumrosen said, the civil rights bill signed today by President Bush could make companies less willing to get rid of their affirmative action programs even if they wanted to. The new law allows people to collect up to $300,000 in punitive damages if they prove they were intentionally denied a job or promotion on the basis of their race or sex. It is the first time that people would be allowed to collect punitive damages for sex discrimination.
A draft of a directive President Bush was expected to issue at the signing of the new bill gave rise to reports that he would order all Federal agencies to phase out the use of racial preferences and quotas in hiring to underscore his opposition to such measures. But the White House quickly assured civil rights leaders who had been invited to the signing ceremony that the affirmative action regulations would not be wiped out.
Race-based programs stem from 1965, when President Lyndon B. Johnson signed an executive order that required Government contractors to act aggressively, or undertake "affirmative action," to increase the number of blacks on their staffs.
Four years later, after hearings conducted by the Department of Labor uncovered widespread discrimination in the construction industry, the Nixon Administration developed the concept of using "goals and timetables" to measure the progress of construction companies with Federal contracts in increasing the number of blacks on their payrolls.
 
95,000 Companies Covered
 A year later President Nixon extended the use of goals and timetables to all Federal contractors and four years later declared that such affirmative action programs should also cover women.
Today, the program requires any Federal contractor with 50 or more employees or a Federal contract worth more than $50,000 to adopt an affirmative action plan. Labor Department officials say more than 95,000 companies employing 27 million workers and having contracts worth a total of $184 billion are covered by the Federal program.
Under the program companies would strive to make their work force match percentages of qualified minority members and women in the local labor pool.
In addition to Federal contractors, universities, hospitals, day-care centers or other businesses that receive Federal grants may be required to have such hiring and promotion programs.
 
Guidelines Are Explicit
 Several Supreme Court decisions, as well as guidelines issued in 1979 by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, spell out how companies that do not receive Federal financing can voluntarily set up their own affirmative action programs.
The guidelines state that companies should determine if their employment practices have resulted in the exclusion of women or members of minorities. If so, any plan to rectify the situation must be considered reasonable and must include goals and timetables to measure the company's progress.
"The guidelines point out a legitimate way of doing affirmative action," Mr. Blumrosen said. "They also immunize the businesses against financial liability."
While private industry has adapted to the world of affirmative action, it is public employment that has seen the greatest use of the practice, even though there is no policy that requires Federal agencies to have any hiring programs that give preferences to minority members or women. According to figures from the Office of Personnel Management, minorities made up 27.5 percent of the Federal workforce as of Sept. 30, 1990, as against 21.8 percent of the civilian workforce.
 
Major Effort in Public Sector
 "The public sector is the place where there have been the most efforts made in terms of affirmative action," said David Bositis, a senior research associate at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research organization specializing in issues involving blacks. Some researchers theorize that the use of affirmative action, especially in the public sector, is one of the prime reasons for the expansion of the black middle class in the past 20 years.
But if affirmative action has been widely accepted by industry, it remains a tantalizing target for some politicians. Republican candidates as disparate as Gov. Pete Wilson of California, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina and State Representative David Duke of Louisiana have used their opposition to "quotas" as a way to garner votes.

HEADLINE: Cheney, in Korea, Orders Halt to U.S. Pullout

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Responding to new estimates that North Korea will be able to produce weapons-grade plutonium within a year, Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney ordered a halt to long-planned American troop reductions in South Korea today "until the dangers and uncertainties of the North Korean nuclear program have been thoroughly addressed."
Mr. Cheney's announcement, the most concrete move yet to step up pressure on the Government of President Kim Il Sung, came at the end of two days of meetings here in which American and South Korean officials outlined initiatives to force the North to abandon its nuclear ambitions. 
 Among them are the proposed sale to Seoul of several batteries of Patriot missiles and an unusual show of force -- including F-117 Stealth fighters, AWACS early warning aircraft and a variety of anti-missile systems -- as part of a major military exercise here early next year.
At the same time, according to another senior official traveling with Mr. Cheney, the Bush Administration is actively considering a plan to allow international inspectors into American military bases here next year to verify that all nuclear weapons have been removed from South Korea. The United States has never before allowed such an inspection, the official said.
But he said "it would be silly to allow our usual rules to give the North an excuse" to further forestall international inspection of its own bases. North Korea has said in the past that it will never allow nuclear inspectors into the country while American nuclear missiles were deployed in the South and -- in a condition added a few weeks ago -- while Washington keeps South Korea within its nuclear umbrella.
Although Mr. Cheney's action was hardly expected to prompt Pyongyang to abandon its nuclear project, the Americans wanted to send a strong signal that their presence on the Korean Peninsula would not diminish as long as there is a nuclear threat from the north.
Although the United States has never acknowledged storing nuclear weapons in South Korea, it is widely known that it has kept more than 150 at an American air base here. All those weapons are now being withdrawn, American and South Korean officials say, including those not covered by President Bush's decision in September to remove American ship-based and ground-based tactical nuclear weapons. Officials say an agreement has also been reached with South Korea to remove air-launched weapons as well.
The practical effect of the moves will be minimal, however, because North Korea would still be in easy reach of American nuclear submarines.
United States officials told the South Koreans during the talks here that they were willing to sell them Patriot missile systems, but that they would not permanently base an American-owned Patriot battery staffed by Americans here.
The Koreans said it might be a few years before they could buy their own system and train troops to operate it, the American officials said.
Mr. Cheney and military officials took pains today to say that for the time being, they are considering only diplomatic and economic actions to force Mr. Kim's Government to comply with the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which Pyongyang signed in 1985. But they also said that by halting the military reduction here and mounting a much larger military exercise than usual, they wanted to send a clear signal to Mr. Kim.
"If they missed Desert Storm," a high-level American military official said today, "this is a chance to catch a re-run."
Taken together, the series of moves appear to reflect a growing fear in the Administration, based more on new analysis than any surprising new evidence, that North Korea may be far closer to developing a crude nuclear weapon than first believed.
"We are convinced that North Korea is developing the capability to build a nuclear weapon," Mr. Cheney said at a news conference today with his South Korean counterpart, Lee Jong Koo. Until today, the reduction of American forces in South Korea was scheduled to take place in several stages.

HEADLINE: Scrapping 'Us Versus Them,' Industry Is Giving Workers a Say and a Stake

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio

 BODY:
In times like these, the typical American company cuts costs by laying people off. It's a quick if brutal way to face a weak economy.
But at Republic Engineered Steels Inc., one of a handful of companies in the nation owned solely by the people who work there, the workers and managers have avoided mass layoffs by collaborating to cut other costs. 
 Without the savings, about 625 workers of the company's 3,980 hourly workers could have been laid off. With the savings, just 105 were.
At the root of the collaboration at Republic is something that labor experts call "empowerment," or giving workers a real place in management. For the past two years, Republic's workers and managers have owned the company outright. Workers, through their union, have as many seats on the board as management. On the shop floor, workers and supervisors sit on production management committees that look for ways to improve quality and cut costs.
Ownership is not essential to giving workers a voice in the operations of their companies. Indeed, many companies, often emulating Japanese techniques, have devised methods in recent years under which workers and managers collaborate to improve performance. But when workers have both a say and a stake in a company, they have an extra incentive to succeed.
The Bush Administration seems to support these arrangements. In September, the Labor Department cited Republic with three more conventionally owned companies, the International Business Machines Corporation, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Pepsico, for an award for "designing and managing innovative programs to improve the skills of American workers."
 
Heresy at Many Companies
 Still, Republic's form of collaboration is heresy in much of American industry. Unions and management normally see themselves as adversaries, and most are comfortable with that relationship. Unions keep losing ground, to the point where they now represent about one in eight private industry workers. Rather than contemplating ways to get along with management, most unions have been urging Congress to strengthen their powers to strike and recruit.
Companies generally welcome the unions' decline, and some egg it on by permanently replacing striking workers with nonunion workers -- blunting the utility of a strike and, therefore, of union membership.
But a small minority of companies, of which Republic is among the biggest, see the old us-versus-them relationships as too costly for both sides. Proponents of empowerment argue that both sides must bury the hatchet to survive the competition with foreign industries, many of which adopted empowerment systems years ago.
The current economic downturn has hit the steel industry hard, as orders from big customers like the General Motors Corporation plunged along with steel prices. Since October 1990, 18,000 steel jobs have been lost. Republic lost $31 million from June 1990 through June of this year on sales of $807 million. It has had to delay the start of a $400 million to $500 million modernization plan.
Republic's managers initially reacted to the tough times much like the rest of the industry, secretly considering a plan last summer to lay off 500 workers. And like the unions elsewhere, Republic's union predictably screamed.
But not so predictably, management relented, and Republic's president and chief executive, Russell W. Maier, even apologized. And since July, the two sides have redoubled their efforts to cut costs in more humane ways, achieving $25 million in annual savings through measures like curbing water consumption and recycling scrap.
 
Need for Union's Discipline
 The son of a local barber, Mr. Maier has been with the mill here since 1960, through its transitions from two prior owners. He says he first fought the notion of employee ownership. But now, he says that with the steel industry floundering he needs the union's workplace discipline and organization. To make it work, he said, "you've got to build one ingredient without which you fail." That, he said, is "trust."
C. William Lynn, president of Local 1200 of the United Steelworkers of America, the son and grandson of steelworkers and once a union firebrand, strikes the same chords. In a recent monthly newsletter to union members, he said, "We must build mutual trust between one another so we can all focus on long-range job security."
It was the cost-cutting process that most impressed the Labor Department. Employees are constantly being urged to submit savings proposals, in writing. And with jobs on the line, about 1,000 proposals had been submitted since July. Rather than let them die in a suggestion box, the company gives each proposal a file number, assigns it to a supervisor and requires a response within a week.
Typical was a suggestion in September from Gene Roman, a melter. He wrote that he had a "better way to schedule heats on No. 7 pouring platform." He suggested meeting with two supervisors, Tony Gianini and Bob Lerch, to discuss the proposal. Mr. Gianini wrote back on the form: "If schedule permits, pull Gene off for a day to work with Lerch. Then have Lerch work with Roman. Then work on scheduling."
Two supervisors, Don King and Ray Florey, and two hourly workers, Tony Milini and Moe Adams, proposed a water conservation project at the main plant, in Canton. The savings ranged from little things, like replacing two drinking fountains with coolers, to big things, like recycling rinsing water. Consumption has plunged from more than nine million gallons a month last year to less than two million, resulting in a savings of close to $50,000 a year.
"They pass these sheets around looking for ideas," said Mr. Milini, 39, a 17-year veteran of the Canton plant and an author of the water conservation proposal. "Before, they didn't want to know what I might tell them, so I wouldn't tell them. It makes you care about the product. You actually got a hand in it."
 
What's Different at Republic
 Often through devices known as employee stock ownership plans, millions of workers have acquired stock in the companies that employ them, and in some cases, a majority of the stock. But few have any more say in management than the typical small stockholder. At Republic, by contrast, the employees have both stock and a major role in running the company.
"If the market is going to drag the workers through the mud," said Joseph R. Blasi, a management professor at Rutgers University, "at least they have some influence at the board level over how it is managed."
At Republic four union members sit on the board, the same number that represents management. Five independent directors, selected by the two sides, tip the balance if management and labor divide along their usual lines. At various levels of the company, down to the shop floor, workers and managers meet weekly on company time to talk about ways of making steel better and any other subjects on both sides' minds.
These relationships arose from the two sides' decision to rescue the company two years ago. At that time, most of the company's nearly 4,000 hourly employees and 1,000 managers joined in buying the LTV Corporation's steel bar-making division, the nation's biggest producer of the steel used in making the mechanical guts of automobiles, aircraft and appliances. In a continuing struggle with bankruptcy that began five years ago, LTV decided to sell the division, and the employees feared that the most likely buyers would then sell it for scrap.
To buy the company, managers put up $4,000 each. The workers each put up $4,000, too. They set up a trust to hold the stock and parcel out new shares, the number based on employees' pay. The employees' contributions paid for 10 percent of the company, and the company borrowed $260 million to pay for the rest.
Because Republic is losing money and paying off the enormous debt, no one is collecting dividends. Someday, if the company thrives, it could sell some stock to the public, and the workers could reap big capital gains when they sold their shares. For now, they can only sell their stock back to the company, since it is not publicly traded, and only when they retire. Currently, a retiring owner would get a few hundred dollars more than he paid.
 
More Agreeable Tone
 Many workers speak of a distinctly more agreeable tone at the company. Mike Viront, a 38-year-old crane operator, and Mark Hendrickson, a 36-year-old strand caster, were having their pulses taken and cholesterol counted at a Republic health fair behind the Canton plant, the biggest of eight the company owns in six states.
"With foremen," Mr. Hendrickson said, "I can talk freely now. Before I was afraid it might come back on you."
Mr. Viront said: "They're in it just the same that we are. We're more together.
Speaking of the company's president, Mr. Hendrickson said, "Russ Maier, he comes into the melt plant and talks to us one-on-one."
Mr. Viront said: "Guy from LTV would come in here in a helicopter. He'd land out front and have security all around him. They acted like we were going to assassinate the guy."
The new tone at the company also influences how complaints are handled. Jim Bonsky, 36, a union grievance committeeman and a gauger-inspector at the Canton plant, said, "I got a call at 3 in the morning. The crew of 15 people in the blooming mill were being forced to work overtime" because ingots had arrived in the mill for rolling just as the shift was ending. Management backed down, he said, but it was likely to make such demands again.
So at a plantwide meeting, the union and management appointed a team of workers and foremen, relieved them of their jobs for a week and told them to find out why the ingots were coming in late. The team then wrote scheduling guidelines to assure prompter delivery. "I give management credit," Mr. Bonsky said, "because in the past they would never have sat down to discuss this with us."
Some workers are not yet persuaded that much has changed. They have seen no return on their investment, and some foremen are still hostile, they say. "Conflict still exists," said Ernest Romy, 55, a crane operator. "They're still the boss. You're still the employee." Vince Sama, 56, a heat treater, said: "It's the same old thing. It's us versus them generally. Workers don't believe they actually bought it."
Some foremen are a significant problem, Mr. Maier acknowledged. "You change that by changing the job, the system they work in, and then you have to educate them," he said.
He said it would be five to seven years before the change in the culture became rooted enough to hold on the way the old culture has. Part of the reason, he said, is that workers and management were comfortable with the old divisions.
"We developed a finely tuned system of adversarial relationships," he said.
Mr. Bonsky said, "I liked the old days better when I could go nose-to-nose and not have to worry about it."
Now he does have to worry, for both his job and his investment. "Both sides have a responsibility to make it work," he said, "because we both have a vested interest in the company."

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Lawmakers Pare Their 'Must Do' List

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Congress made some progress on two major pieces of legislation today as both chambers passed measures to finance the depleted bank insurance fund and lawmakers agreed on a House-Senate conference committee to handle the much-debated crime bill. 
 The House also set the stage for passing its last major domestic spending bill. But both chambers waited to see how legislation dealing with the savings and loan bailout and with transportation programs would fare before committing themselves on when they would recess and whether they would have to return in December.
 
Deadlock on Crime Bill Ends
A three-week deadlock was broken when Senate leaders today finally agreed to appoint eight members to the House-Senate conference committee that will attempt to iron out differences between the two versions of the crime bill. Senator George Mitchell, the majority leader, said the agreement was "better late than never," but he pointedly reminded members that the committee's ratio of five Democrats to three Republicans was the same the Democratic leadership proposed more than three weeks ago, when the Republicans had contended the ratio was unfair.
One crucial bit of arm-twisting that preceded the agreement was applied by President Bush in a White House meeting with Senator Steve Symms, Republican of Idaho. Mr. Symms had been refusing to consent to a conference because of his opposition to gun control elements in the bill. A Symms aide quoted the Senator as saying "The President asked me to give him a chance to get a good crime bill." He was said to have added, "Who am I to deny the President his chance?"
Though House Speaker Thomas S. Foley and Democratic Senators expressed optimism about the prospects of reaching agreement on the crime bill before the recess, senior aides said it would be extremely difficult for conferees to work out a number of differences, particularly on habeas corpus and the exclusionary rule.
The Democratic aides conceded that the Republicans would be able to block inclusion of a provision, passed by the Senate but soundly defeated by the House, that would ban the sale and manufacture of nine types of assault rifles.
Republicans hope to keep the Senate version of habeas corpus reform, which sets a six-month deadline on a single petition of habeas corpus. It would also allow a Federal judge to dismiss a habeas corpus appeal if he rules that the defendant received an adequate hearing at the state level. The House approved a far narrower reform.
On the exclusionary rule, the House version would expand the legal use of evidence seized by police without a warrant far more than the Senate was willing to do.
 
Deposit Insurance Legislation
On another crucial issue, the House and Senate today passed legislation to shore up the depleted deposit insurance fund, amid fears that Congressional inaction might cause heavy runs on banks.
But important differences separate the two banking measures and lawmakers predicted that ironing them out would be an arduous task.
The House bill was approved 344 to 84, without any of the Bush Administration proposals that would have rolled back limits on the ability of industrial firms to own banks and the banking industry's ability to enter the securities and insurance industries.
In contrast, the Senate measure, adopted in a voice vote with fewer than 12 senators on the floor, included part of the White House proposal, with provisions to allow banks greater flexibility in opening branches across state lines. The Senate measure would also tighten restrictions on the entry of banks into the insurance business.
 
Aid to the Soviet Union
The idea of taking money from the Pentagon budget and using it to aid the Soviet Union, a plan considered dead ten days ago, resurfaced in both the Senate and the House today. Senators Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee and Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, a senior Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee, and 14 other senators proposed taking about $500 million from the Department of Defense to help the Soviet Union destroy chemical and nuclear weapons.
In the House, three senior Democarts proposed legislation to spend $1 bilion on dismantling nuclear wepaons and on food aid. They were Representatives Les Aspin of Wisconsin, chairman of the Armed Services Committee; Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the majority leader, and Lee H. Hamilton of Indiana, chairman of the Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East.
The House also settled the issue of how it would proceed on the $205 billion spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education. President Bush vetoed it because it would have overturned his Administration's ban on abortion counseling in federally financed family- planning clinics, and the veto was sustained in the House on Tuesday.

Delay on Payments to Jobless
Foreign policy provided the latest issue to delay final action on the unemployment compensation benefits bill.
With Administration backing, House Republicans won a battle to include duty-free import provisions for Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru in the $5.5 billion measure to provide either 13 or 20 weeks of extended benefits for people out of work for at least half a year.
The House had included that provision when it amended a Senate version of the bill Wednesday, along with favored trading status for Czechoslovakia, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia and Lithuania. But Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Illinois Democrat who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, and Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance committee, had privately agreed to scrap the benefits for the South American nations.
But then the House voted 416 to 0 to tell its conferees to insist on benefits for the four countries, delaying the conference.

HEADLINE: Bush and Governors Agree on How to Pay for Medicaid

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
After making major concessions to avoid political embarrassment, the White House and the nation's governors reached a tentative agreement today on how to pay for health care for poor people under Medicaid.
But the compromise faces stiff opposition from state legislators and from hospitals, which are concerned about losing Medicaid revenue, and it is not clear that Congress will approve the agreement. Indeed, Congress appears likely to defer action until early next year, permitting states to continue using fund-raising devices that President Bush wants to restrict. 
 Medicaid finances health care for 27 million low-income people. It is financed jointly by the Federal Government and the states.
 
Special Tax on Hospitals
 The agreement, disclosed today by the White House, permits states to continue using special taxes on hospitals to pay the state share of Medicaid, subject to certain limits. In general, states could not use such taxes to pay more than 25 percent of the state share of Medicaid. Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the National Governors Association, confirmed that the governors had negotiated a compromise with the Bush Administration.
Federal officials have denounced such taxes as a scam because hospitals typically get back much more than they pay in, and Washington ends up paying the bill.
Historically, the Federal Government and the states have shared the cost of Medicaid. The state share rises with a state's per capita income. Affluent states like New York and California pay half of program costs for their residents.
The original restrictions on state fund-raising techniques were devised by Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, and Gail R. Wilensky, the head of the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, who supervises Medicaid. The restrictions, which are to take effect Jan. 1, provoked a storm of criticism from Republicans and Democrats who said they would devastate Medicaid in many states.
 
Withdrawal of Rules Urged
 Among those who urged President Bush to withdraw the rules were Representatives Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the Republican whip, and Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House Democratic leader, as well as Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Senate Democratic leader. Mr. Gephardt said the rules would jeopardize health care for thousands of children and pregnant women, as well as for workers who turned to Medicaid after losing jobs in the current recession.
But Federal officials said the restrictions were needed to curtail state fund-raising schemes. Under these schemes, like one exposed in Massachusetts last summer, states pay their share of Medicaid by collecting voluntary hospital donations or by imposing special taxes on hospitals, which then get back more than they paid in.
By a lopsided vote of 348 to 71, the House of Representatives voted on Tuesday to block the Administration's effort to crack down on these fund-raising schemes before Sept. 30, 1992. The Senate Finance Committee, which will meet on Friday, is expected to approve a similar freeze through March 31, 1992. Under the Senate bill, all state fund-raising techniques now in use could continue, but no new ones could be adopted.
Dr. Wilensky said that 38 states were now using such schemes and that 6 other states were planning to adopt them to help cover the exploding costs of Medicaid.
Under the compromise reached today, states could continue using such fund-raising arrangements for another year, at a cost to the Federal Government of $5.5 billion. Starting late next year, most donations would be forbidden; in other words, states would not receive Federal matching money for revenue obtained from donations by hospitals or nursing homes.
But states could impose taxes on hospitals and could use such revenue for up to 25 percent of the state share of Medicaid. States already above the 25 percent level could continue using taxes to cover whatever proportion of the state share is already financed through such taxes.
The White House abandoned its effort to limit the number of hospitals that receive extra Medicaid money because they serve "a disproportionate number of low-income patients." But the agreement says that such extra payments must not exceed 12 percent of all Medicaid spending after Oct. 1, 1992.
Brad C. Johnson, director of the New York State office in Washington, said he supported the agreement negotiated by the Bush Administration and the governors. He said it would permit New York to continue taxing hospitals and other providers of health care.
 
Protecting New Jersey Tax
 Brenda J. Bacon, the health policy coordinator for Gov. Jim Florio of New Jersey, said the compromise was "certainly preferable" to Mr. Darman's original plan, but should be amended to make sure that New Jersey's tax on payers of hospital bills was protected.
R. Michael Bird, legislative counsel at the National Conference of State Legislatures, said the proposed settlement was unacceptable. "The agreement represents a major intrusion by the Federal Government into the taxing authority of the states," Mr. Bird said.
Larry S. Gage, president of the National Association of Public Hospitals; Peters D. Willson, vice president of the National Association of Children's Hospitals, and Molly Collins, a lobbyist at the American Hospital Association, all objected to the agreement. They said that poor people could be harmed by the proposed limits on payments to hospitals serving large numbers of low-income patients.
Mr. Gage, Mr. Willson and Ms. Collins said that Congress should defer action until next year so lawmakers could study the issue further. In each of the last three years, Congress has passed laws explicitly permitting the use of voluntary hospital contributions to pay the state share of Medicaid, and last year Congress also gave permission for the use of taxes levied on hospitals. The Federal laws all expire in January 1992.

HEADLINE: House Panel Plans Inquiry On Quayle Council's Staff

BYLINE: By PHILIP J. HILTS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Democrats stepped up their attacks today on Vice President Dan Quayle's Council on Competitiveness, as Representative John Conyers Jr. announced that the House Government Operations Committee would begin an investigation of the council's staff.
Senator Al Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, also attacked the council on the floor of the Senate, demanding the resignation of Allan B. Hubbard, the panel's executive director, who is also a member of Mr. Quayle's personal staff. 
 Senator Gore accused Mr. Hubbard of a conflict of interest. Mr. Hubbard, the Senator said, has "more than $1 million in a company that is polluting the environment, but he is in charge of the regulations governing the pollution."
Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health and the Environment, announced on Wednesday that he would investigate potential conflicts of interest involving the council.
 
'Political Attacks' Seen
 Aides to Mr. Quayle called the actions "political attacks" by Democrats who are beginning to fear Mr. Quayle's effectiveness. They also said they expected more such criticism as the Presidential campaign heats up.
"The criticism has been mounting lately," David Beckwith, a spokesman for Mr. Quayle, said today. "The attacks are testimony to the council's effectiveness."
The council has come under criticism for stepping in to revise or overrule regulations after all parties to the process have had their say, and doing so out of public view. Members of the Vice President's personal staff works on the council and thus comes under the scrutiny of the House Government Operations Committee. Mr. Conyers, a Michigan Democrat, is chairman of the committee.
The White House maintains that the council is an arm of the President's executive office and as such has all the power to review and suggest regulations that the President gives it. The council has claimed executive privilege to fend off requests for information on its deliberations.
 
Letter to Bush Cited
 Mr. Quayle made public a letter sent to President Bush from the Senate's Republican leadership and about two dozen other Senators in support of Mr. Quayle and the council, which they said "provides an appropriate and much needed balance in the regulatory rule-making process."
The Senators said they would "resist partisan efforts to destroy the council's role as your overseer of regulatory processes."
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, said today, "The council is under attack by Democrats for putting some common sense into regulations such as the wetlands rules and tort reform."
He criticized requests by Democrats who asked that the council keep logs of who influences their decisions. "They wouldn't want us to apply that to Congress, get us to make lists of all the people Congressional staff meet with," Senator Nickles said. "The council shouldn't have a litany of people looking over their shoulder every time they open their mouth."
 
Conflict-of-Interest Question
 The hottest issue between the Democrats and the Vice President is the assertion that Mr. Hubbard, the council director, may have a conflict of interest in reviewing some regulations.
In a letter to Mr. Hubbard, Mr. Conyers sought answers to questions about his involvement in regulations at the same time he was making money from companies that might be affected by the regulations. The letter noted that it is a felony to become involved "personally and substantially, through decision, approval, disapproval, recommendation, the rendering of advice, investigation or otherwise" in any matter in which Mr. Hubbard had a finacial interest.
Mr. letter continued: "The finanical statement you filed on Aug. 1, 1990, indicates that you received dividend income from 12 corporations and one limited partnership. You also reported receiving interest income from the bonds of 16 corporations and from the commercial paper of two corporations."
 
A Waiver From Quayle
 Last May, in an effort to avoid conflicts between his business interests and the regulations he has reviewed, Mr. Hubbard signed a recusal saying he would not deal with any matters directly affecting the "automotive appearance" industry. He is an owner of World Wide Chemicals Inc. of Indianapolis, which makes auto wax and other products. The company also is a source of air pollution and is required to get permits for the pollution. Local officials said the permits had not been obtained.
Mr. Hubbard also received from the Vice President a general waiver of the conflict-of-interest rules so that he could consider regulatory issues in general without fear of making decisions on ones that could affect his businesses in an indirect way.
Such waivers are not uncommon among high Federal officials.
