HEADLINE: ARAB-ISRAEL TALKS MAY MOVE TO U.S.

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d discussed today where to hold the next round of direct talks between Israel and its Arab neighbors, with Washington the almost certain site.
Since the Madrid talks broke up two and half weeks ago, Israel, Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and the Palestinians have not been able to agree on when and where to meet again. Mr. Baker said that if they could not agree within two weeks, the co-sponsors, the United States and Soviet Union, would choose a compromise site and invite the parties there. 
 Administration officials say Washington is almost certainly the compromise site, because it is the least objectionable to all the parties. This is because none of the parties view Washington as perfect either.
The Palestinians want the United States to resume its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization before they come to Washington, so that P.L.O. officials will be able to sit on the sidelines for the talks. The Syrians want to be taken off the State Department list of countries supporting terrorism before they send their diplomats to Washington. The Israelis want to have the talks in the Middle East, to underscore their acceptance by the other Arab countries, but they would have a hard time vetoing Washington.
"No one is wildly enthusiastic about Washington, but no one has a better idea that everyone else might agree on," an Administration official said.
 
Baker Reports Progress
 Speaking to reporters after the two-hour meeting with Mr. Shamir, Mr. Baker said they discussed the site question and made "progress," but he did not elaborate. Asked if the site might be announced on Friday after Mr. Shamir meets with President Bush, Mr. Baker said, "Perhaps."
When Mr. Shamir was asked if Israel was now ready to come to Washington to continue the talks, he would only say, "We have discussed this question of venue together with other questions and we have not yet decided."
Israeli officials said that one thing that Mr. Shamir was trying to establish in his talks today with Mr. Baker and on Friday with President Bush is the general American approach to these negotiations. Israeli officials are saying that Mr. Shamir is serious about engaging in negotiations with the Palestinians, but before he really goes down that road he wants to make certain that the United States is ready to be a true "honest broker," and not the protector of Palestinian interests.
One of the tests for Mr. Shamir to make that determination is whether the Bush Administration is prepared to grant Israel -- unconditionally -- the $10 billion in housing loan guarantees that it is seeking. A decision on that has been postponed by Washington until late January. The Bush Administration, by contrast, is prepared to look sympathetically on the Israeli loan request -- although probably not at the level of $10 billion -- provided it feels Mr. Shamir is serious about pursuing real negotiations with the Palestinians.
 
Bush Test for Israel
 For Mr. Bush, the test of Israel's seriousness is whether Mr. Shamir is willing to accept conditions to the $10 billion that would insure that none of the money is spent on new settlements in the West Bank and Gaza Strip -- preferably by freezing building there altogether.
Since September, when the Administration persuaded Congress to postpone debate on this housing loan question, the ground has shifted on the issue. The increasing turmoil in the Soviet Union has spurred more Jewish immigration to Israel, making Mr. Shamir that much more desperate for the housing loans.
At the same time, though, the political environment in Washington has also changed. Both Democratic and Republican supporters of Israel have been quietly telling the Israelis that given the current recession, and the general reluctance of the American taxpayer to spend money abroad now that the cold war is over, they will have a very hard time justify voting $10 billion in housing loan guarantees for Israel in an election year.
"I would say that this is going to be the first year in American history when foreign aid support for Israel is going to be more dangerous than opposition to it," said Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who chairs the House subcommittee on foreign operations.
The only way that a majority of Congress can justify a vote is if it can be cast as a "vote for peace," Congressional officials say, and the only way that can happen is if it has the Administration's full backing. The only way it is going to get that is if Mr. Shamir agrees to freeze settlements.

HEADLINE: Subway Riders Balk at Planned Fare Rise

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Archie Johnson, an unemployed construction worker from Queens, says the proposed $1.40 bus and subway fare would be more than an inconvenience, it would be another obstacle to finding a job.
Because he takes a bus and then the subway from his home in South Jamaica to Manhattan, where he is seeking work, Mr. Johnson said his daily round-trip fare would jump a dollar, to $5.60. 
 "Those that don't have it, they'll get hurt the worst," the 37-year-old Mr. Johnson said, as he waited for a bus on a Bronx street corner yesterday, on his way to visit relatives. "And right now, I don't have it."
As the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday held the first in a series of public hearings preceding its Dec. 20 vote on the proposed 25-cent fare increase, New Yorkers reacted with indignation, both at the hearing at Borough Hall in Kew Gardens, Queens, and in the subways.
At the hearing, more than 150 angry commuters, many waving homemade placards, applauded one speaker after another who stepped up to a microphone and derided the proposed fare increase.
 
Many Complaints
 Like Mr. Johnson, most commuters in the subways and at the hearing said they had been hit hard by the recession. Though some said they sympathized with the M.T.A., which itself has been affected by the sluggish economy, most riders said the agency should look elsewhere for assistance. Ticking off complaints about the subways -- foul smells, delays and crowded trains were cited often -- many straphangers said the agency must make further improvements before a fare increase would be justified.
"The service we get, and the conditions of the trains -- they should not get another dime," said Darlene Porter, 43, who had just stepped off an X6 bus at the corner of River Avenue and East 161st Street in the High Bridge section of the Bronx. "They should reduce the fare."
Last week the Transit Authority recommended that the fare be increased by 25 cents on Jan. 1 unless Albany could help close the agency's estimated $263 million deficit in 1992. While some legislators and aides to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins have expressed a desire to limit the increase, neither the state nor the city has much financial aid to offer.
Most of the riders who spoke yesterday said they would blame the M.T.A., the Transit Authority or "the government" for the increase, but few cited the Mayor or the Governor by name.
Beverly Dolinsky, the executive director of the Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the M.T.A., a state-mandated oversight board, said she feared a $1.40 fare would drive New Yorkers -- and the revenue they provide -- away from the transit system and into illegal vans, which she said pull up at bus stops during rush hour and often charge riders $1. Others, she said, might take to their own cars, raising environmental concerns and causing congestion.
"Lots of companies leave the city because it's hard to get around," Ms. Dolinsky said.
But Prof. Mitchell L. Moss, the director of the New York University urban research center, said a fare increase would have little impact on the local economy.
"The cost of the subway fare doesn't determine whether people go to the theater or go shopping," Professor Moss said.
Though many New Yorkers angrily questioned the increase, there were exceptions. As she emerged from the subway station at the corner of West 72d Street and Broadway in Manhattan, Mamie Bostick, a cashier at a nearby branch of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, said the $1.40 fare was painful but necessary.
"I'm all for it if this is going to keep people in their jobs," said Ms. Bostick, 48.
Most however, sided with Toby Axelrod, a 35-year-old staff writer for Jewish Week newspaper, who said she might avoid the subways if the fare goes up.
"I've been thinking about walking to work," said Ms. Axelrod, who estimated her Greenwich Village residence was a two-mile jaunt from her office in Times Square.
As she sat in front of a microphone several feet from the M.T.A. board members last night, Marianne Loser, a retired medical researcher, urged that the fare increase be avoided.
"This increase hits hardest the segment of the population that can least afford to pay it," said Ms. Loser, the president of the community association in Briarwood, Queens. "Increases have to be earned by good performance. The M.T.A. has not earned this increase."

HEADLINE: Republicans Offer Plan To Replace Income Tax

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Top Republican legislators, who have spent the year leading a coalition of moderates and conservatives in both parties in fighting against a tax on wages, said today they were returning to their "Republican roots."
Party leaders presented a plan today to replace the state's three-month-old income tax. The plan's centerpiece was $300 million in spending cuts, including sweeping reductions in many social programs like welfare, job training and housing assistance for the poor that the lawmakers said Connecticut can no longer afford to finance with the generosity of the past. The result would be the largest one-year tax cut in state history, $429 million that lawmakers said would be left in residents' pockets, to be spent, they said, reviving the economy. 
 The Republican plan would also restore much of the tax structure that existed before the Aug. 22 law passed: The sales tax, now 6 percent, would go back up by more than a third, to 8.25 percent. Previous taxes on income from dividends, interest and capital gains would be restored. The 4.5 percent tax on wages would end on Jan. 1.
 
Sharp Departure
 The document marked a sharp departure, in both specifics and philosophy, from plans put forward this summer as the Legislature battled Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. over how to resolve the state's fiscal crisis. Those proposals were identified as coalition budgets meant to appeal to moderate Democrats in trying to build a majority in the General Assembly, where Democrats are in control.
"There has been a change from the coalition," said Representative Reginald L. Jones, a Republican from Darien and a ranking member of the Appropriations Committee.
At a news conference announcing the plan at the Capitol, Mr. Jones said: "We're cutting more government spending. And we're forcing more money into the private sector to give a surge to consumption."
Other party leaders, using far more strident language than in the past to attack the Democrats, said that if a majority does emerge around some plan to repeal the income tax, it will probably be the Democrats who will have to come around to the new Republican way of thinking, not the other way around.
"We're standing on our Republican budget," said Senator M. Adela Eads, a Republican from Kent and the minority leader in the Senate. "I'm not going to say whether they're going to join us," she said of the moderate Democrats who would be needed to make the Republican plan anything but a minority pipe dream.
 
New Tax Categories
 The Republican plan, while restoring most of the revenue system based on sales tax that existed before August, would also go beyond that old system in creating several new tax categories. Perhaps hoping to capitalize on the casino under construction by the Mashantucket Pequot Indians in Ledyard, the lawmakers said they would tax gambling income under the 7 percent capital gains tax.
The dividends and interest tax, which peaked at 14 percent under the old law, would rise to a maximum rate of 10 percent. But income from rents and royalties would be taxed for the first time, along with stock dividends and interest from savings accounts. The sales tax rate would be 8.25 percent beginning in January, but one-quarter percent of that would be eliminated on July 1, 1994.
The major spending cuts include more than $56 million in reduced programs at the Department of Income Maintenance, the state welfare agency. Lawmakers said $35 million could be saved by writing new guidelines that would govern general-assistance awards in towns where local standards now prevail.
Democrats attacked the Republican plan as an onslaught against the poor that was built with numbers that would not balance. They said that many of the spending reductions, while perhaps possible over time, could not achieve the savings needed in the six months that would be left in the fiscal year between January and July 1. Governor Weicker announced on Monday that the state already faced a gap of $175 million in its $7.6 billion budget for the fiscal year.
The Democratic Party's political director, Jonathan W. Pelto, who is also a pro-income tax state representative from Storrs, said he thought the budget marked a realization by the Republicans that the repeal effort would not succeed. Instead of a real budget document, he said it was instead more like the opening shot of the campaign for next year's legislative elections.
Lawmakers in both parties have said for weeks that a majority exists in the General Assembly willing to vote for repeal of the income tax. However, both sides have also conceded that a two-thirds majority has not been achieved. Mr. Weicker has said he would veto any repeal bill and the failure to reach two-thirds would leave the law unchanged.

HEADLINE: School Segregation Case Too Knotty, Lawyers Say

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Nov. 21

 BODY:
Lawyers for the state argued today that a lawsuit attacking the de facto segregation that divides Hartford from its suburbs raises questions of social policy far too sweeping and complex for a single judge to decide.
Assistant Attorney General John R. Whelan also said the state should not be held responsible for segregation that arises out of residential patterns, rather than from intentional government policies like the Jim Crow practices of the South before the 1960's. 
 He said the complexity of the case, and the novel legal theories that a team of civil rights lawyers is using in its effort to force the integration of suburban schools with the city's, require the case to go first to the state Supreme Court, to resolve conflicting interpretations of the law.
Otherwise, he said, a trial would be "an expensive and fruitless exercise that would be more likely to do harm than produce positive results."
 
Constitution Violated
 The lead lawyer for the plaintiffs, Wesley W. Horton, responded that the issue is not the complex social and economic conditions that result in overwhelmingly minority city schools, surrounded by overwhelmingly white suburban schools.
The issue, he said, is that Hartford's public schools are 91 percent black and Hispanic, and that the segregation violates Connecticut's constitution by denying those students equal educational opportunity with suburban children.
"If a school is 91 percent minority, that is intolerable regardless of why it occurred," Mr. Horton said.
Today was the second time that lawyers for the state have tried to block the lawsuit, known as Sheff v. O'Neill, from proceeding to trial. The case is named after Milo Sheff, a black Hartford student, and William A. O'Neill, who was governor when the suit was filed in 1989.
In 1990 the Superior Court judge in the case, Harry Hammer, rejected similar arguments as the state sought a dismissal: that the state government is not to blame for the de facto school segregation in Hartford and other cities; that there are no clear-cut solutions for a judge to adopt, and that the state, in any case, has taken some steps to help city schools and achieve racial balance.
The issues are so sweeping, Mr. Whelan said, embracing education, housing, poverty and even public health, that they are best handled by the Legislature.
"What is being suggested is a dramatic expansion of the powers of the court," he said.
Mr. Horton and other lawyers involved in the suit readily admit they seek to break new ground by overcoming a United States Supreme Court barrier, from a 1974 case involving Detroit, to integrating schools by busing students across city lines.
The Sheff case is based on the Connecticut Constitution. If a judge accepts the lawyers' arguments that the Constitution bars segregation -- de facto, as well as intentional -- and guarantees equal educational opportunity, Mr. Horton and other lawyers say the state has the authority to order any remedy necessary, including the busing of children across the Hartford city line.
The tangled nature of desegregation in Connecticut could be seen in court as Mr. Whelan acknowledged that the state has all the powers it needs to order regional school districts as a way to achieve integration.
Mr. Whelan also acknowledged that Connecticut has seen fit in the recent past to order towns and cities to balance the racial composition of all schools within any one district -- regardless of the reason for an imbalance.
Just this month, Mr. Whelan successfully argued before another Superior Court judge a case against Waterbury in which the state's authority to enforce its racial balance law was upheld in court for the first time.
Judge Hammer, at times, appeared intrigued by Mr. Whelan's dual role, arguing in one case for a court order forcing the city of Waterbury to redress the de facto segregation in its schools, and arguing here that the state should not be similarly ordered to end the de facto segregation that divides its local school districts.
"I have a brief in the Waterbury case that could have been written by Mr. Horton," Judge Hammer told the assistant attorney general.
 
A Meaningless Law?
 Connecticut is one of the few states in the nation to have adopted a racial balance law, but even this pioneering step has been attacked by the Sheff lawyers.
They say that limiting desegregation efforts to individual towns and cities makes the law meaningless in cities like Hartford, where there is no significant white enrollment, and leads to white flight -- and intensified segregation -- in other cities.
"When a white parent sees his child will go to a 90 percent minority school, and sees that neighboring suburbs aren't contributing, he'll just go to one of those towns," Mr. Horton said.
If Judge Hammer rules against the state after today's arguments, a trial is likely to be scheduled for some time in 1992.

HEADLINE: PLAN SEEKS TO CUT DELAY AT AIRPORTS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
To relieve airport congestion and reduce delays in cities where many routes intersect, like New York, the Transportation Department is proposing to let airports charge higher landing fees during rush hours, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today.
Mr. Skinner said the proposal was a natural evolution from airline deregulation; if there are problems with deregulated airways, he said, the answer is not more regulation, but less. 
 The theory is that airlines would then shift some of their flights to less busy times, saving millions of dollars that are wasted because of delays while avoiding the costs of expanding airports. These savings could then be passed on to customers who do not insist on traveling at peak hours like the early morning and evening.
But airlines are deeply skeptical, saying that their own ticket price variations already steer people away from rush-hour travel. And private airplane owners are downright hostile to the proposal, saying it would effectively ban them from airports at rush hour.
 
Blocked Similar Proposal
 The idea of "congestion pricing" at airports has been popular among economic theorists for several years. But until now, the Transportation Department has done little to encourage its adoption by airports. Indeed, two years ago it successfully blocked a similar proposal for Boston's Logan Airport.
"Economists and academics have been talking about this, but nobody has yet put together a plan for doing it that is practical," said Robert J. Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association, which represents the airlines.
Mr. Aaronson suggested that it would take huge increases in landing fees to dissuade airlines from scheduling their flights at the times of day when most passengers want to travel.
The same conclusion was reached two years ago in a study of peak-hour pricing by the Brookings Institution. The institution estimated that the average landing fee for each passenger would have to rise as much as tenfold at busy airports like New York's La Guardia before any effect on traffic would be seen. That could mean an increase in ticket prices of about $30.
 
Warding Off Smaller Planes
 Mr. Aaronson, who was previously the aviation director for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates La Guardia, Newark and Kennedy Airports, said that during his tenure "we looked at it fairly regularly and we reached the conclusion that the size of the increase would be so large that we would be embarrassed."
At present, there is a surcharge of $100 for landing at La Guardia at the busiest times of day, but this serves mainly to ward of the smallest of airplanes. Passengers on large jets would barely notice the effect on ticket prices.
After the Massachusetts Port Authority proposed in 1988 to alter its landing fees at Logan Airport in a way that would have made it prohibitively expensive for virtually all smaller planes to land there, the Transportation Department interceded and blocked the arrangement in court, saying it was discriminatory. Since then, no major airport has attempted to impose such an arrangement.

HEADLINE: In Eye of Economic Storm, the Port Authority Battens Down

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER with JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
Buffeted by the recession and humbled somewhat by the mixed results of its ambitious innovations of the last decade, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is pulling back. It is no longer planning the incinerators, industrial parks and other economic development projects that occupied it in the 80's.
The huge agency -- the largest, most varied, most powerful port authority in the country -- is returning to basics, concentrating its money, expertise and attention on renewing its prime assets: the region's airports, trans-Hudson bridges and tunnels, the port and the PATH rail line that connects Newark, Jersey City, Hoboken and Manhattan. And even with $1.7 billion in annual revenue, its ability to finance everything it would like to do is uncertain.
 
Following a Mandate

 "We're in a period, and I think it will be a sustained period, of limited resources," said Stanley Brezenoff, who became the Port Authority's executive director last year and who once served as Edward I. Koch's first deputy mayor. "Like everyone else in the region, we're experiencing the effects of the recession." 
 In the flush 1980's the authority experimented with developing everything from real-estate development to a fish market. It spent $25 million on the fish market, called Fishport, in south Brooklyn, which proved to be a dismal failure because the fishing boats and wholesalers never came. Other enterprises have proved more successful. A Japanese company assembles subway cars in an industrial park in Yonkers, and tenants are filling a legal center in downtown Newark (dubbed "tort port" by the agency's staff).
For 70 years, the bi-state agency has continually re-invented itself, largely because its mandate to help develop the local economy is broad. It was created to make order among the 14 different railroads that served the port in 1921. By the next decade, its responsibilities had broadened to include the Holland Tunnel and the George Washington Bridge.
Quasi-autonomous, the Port Authority is influenced primarily by three masters: the Governors of New York and New Jersey, and the economy. Each Governor appoints six of the agency's 12 board members, and each can veto any of the authority's initiatives. One of the prime tasks of the executive director and board chairman, who reign from offices high in the World Trade Center, is to maintain a delicate balance between the states, with each reaping equal dividends from the agency's activities.
Every new director and board chairman has reshaped the Port Authority's role, often with considerable prodding from the Governors. Mr. Brezenoff and Richard C. Leone, who took over as board chairman last year, have made clear that their mandate is to scale back the agency's costs and ambitions.
The top priority now is rebuilding the region's three major airports -- Kennedy International, La Guardia and Newark -- to make them more competitive with the country's newest and best regional airports, Mr. Brezenoff said. The renovations, he said, "are the single most important things that the Port Authority can do."
The authority is proposing one significant and large-scale innovation, to be coupled with the airport rehabilitations: a $1.6 billion light rail line connecting Kennedy and La Guardia Airports with the subway and Long Island Rail Road in Queens. A similar rail line would connect Newark Airport with mass transit in Newark and would cost an estimated $400 million to $500 million.
The rail links, long sought by planners who considered the Port Authority unfriendly to mass transit, will be financed by a new $3 tax on departing airport passengers that was approved last year by Congress.
Other bold initiatives are unlikely, Mr. Brezenoff said, because of the economic climate -- the agency's revenues are essentially flat -- and because it will cost at least $3 billion to rebuild the airports.
"I wish we were here when it looked like the sky's the limit," Mr. Leone said. "The major thing we are doing is exercising a certain amount of prudence."
 
Still a Leader, But Quite Vulnerable
 The retooling of the Port Authority comes at a particularly vulnerable time. Besides the ordinary cycles of the economy, the agency confronts broad economic and geopolitical forces that have enabled other regions to compete more effectively with the New York area than at any time this century.
Just last year, New York and New Jersey were eclipsed by Los Angeles as the nation's largest maritime port. The port, which consists primarily of huge container shipping terminals on the waterfronts of Newark and Elizabeth, N.J., has grown far more slowly over the last decade than a half-dozen other ports on the East and West Coasts. But it is still ranked second in the value of cargo that it handles.
Kennedy Airport is still the country's leading center for air cargo. But the deregulation of the airline industry and the growth of other regional airports as trans-Atlantic gateways, including those in Washington, Atlanta, Chicago and Boston, has cut into the proportion of domestic travelers who come to Kennedy to board flights to Europe and beyond. This year Kennedy accounted for 40 percent of the trans-Atlantic passengers departing from the United States, down from 50 percent in 1985, according to the Port Authority.
The difficulties of getting into and out of Kennedy, which is now 30 years old, and is somewhat run-down in appearance, do not enhance its image or that of the region, many critics say.
"It's embarrassing," said George Sternlieb, a professor emeritus at Rutgers University and former director of the university's Center for Urban Research. "You go down to Florida and you look at Tampa-St. Pete, for example, and we look like an old-age home."
Plans to rebuild Kennedy, drawn up four years ago, centered on the construction of a $1 billion central terminal that would connect passengers to individual airline terminals by a monorail. The new terminal, along with the monorail, was canceled last year because the financially pressed airlines, which would have borne most of the cost, could not afford it.
 
Facing Wider Needs With Limited Ability
 Some critics say these problems indicate that the Port Authority's difficulties are far deeper than the recession. They contend that the agency no longer has the financial wherewithal, the vision or the political muscle to represent the long-term interests of the New York region.
"It has gone from being an autonomous agency to being a collection of what used to be competence," Dr. Sternlieb said. "Still very heavy in terms of overhead, it's an old-fashioned steam engine that for the moment is just sort of lying in the scrap heap, with people occasionally ripping off the pieces.
"Conceptually, it's never been more needed than now," Dr. Sternlieb said. "It should be the spearhead to provide some regional leadership. What the region is missing is leadership, someone to sell the region."
But others maintain that the outlook is less bleak than it appears. They say that it is vitally important for the agency to focus its efforts on the airports, and that Kennedy could be made much better even without a new main terminal.
Many academics and planners who monitor the Port Authority also said the new emphasis on providing mass transit lines to the airports represented a major, and welcome, departure.
"The airports are now far more important to the region than ever," said Mitchell L. Moss, a professor of planning at New York University and director of the university's Urban Research Center. "The airports are more important to the economy today than the seaports were 100 years ago. They are the modern day equivalent of the steamships and railroads tied into one."
Stephen Berger, who ran the Port Authority between 1985 and 1990, is credited with shifting the agency's attention back to the airports.
"Steve Berger was important," Professor Moss said, "because he got the Port Authority back to basics, back to infrastructure, back to the airports and transportation." Mr. Brezenoff and Mr. Leone "are going to build on Berger," he said.
Historically, the Port Authority grew into a $1.7 billion-a-year enterprise because of the rise of the automobile and the airplane. Revenue from tolls at the George Washington Bridge, the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels and the three bridges connecting New Jersey and Staten Island -- along with money from the airports and from the World Trade Center, which is also owned by the authority -- have underwritten many other agency activities, including the Port Authority Trans-Hudson line and the economic development projects.
The Port Authority was often more sympathetic to the demands of automobile drivers than to planners' longing for more mass transit to ease the area's clogged highways, several experts said. Many people see a new receptivity to rail transit under Mr. Leone and Mr. Brezenoff.
"I sense a new openness and a willingness to consider more than the bottom line," said Richard T. Anderson, president of the Regional Plan Association, a research and advocacy group.
Several Port Authority officials said that even with the rise in international travel from other American airports, the region's airports were holding their own. While losing its proportion of international passenger traffic, Kennedy is still very much No. 1, said David Z. Plavin, the Port Authority's director of aviation.
Mr. Plavin also said Kennedy would be rebuilt, even without the central terminal, so that people could move into and around the airport more easily. For example, the airport's road system is being reconfigured, dividing access to terminals into quadrants so cars and buses no longer have to circle the entire airport, contributing to massive traffic jams, just to get to their destinations.
And earlier this month, three major airlines that have used Kennedy's International Arrivals terminal for decades -- Japan Airlines, Lufthansa and Air France -- said they wanted to build a new terminal at the site of a building abandoned last year by Eastern Airlines.
At La Guardia, the main terminal is being rebuilt, and a new terminal under construction at the airport's eastern end, next to the Trump Shuttle, should be open next spring, Mr. Plavin said.
 
Branching Out With Mixed Results
 While the Port Authority has spent significant amounts of money in the 1980's on the airports, particularly Newark, much of the agency's intellectual and political capital was expended on new economic development projects, like industrial parks and incinerators.
The agency's top executives, along with the Governors of New York and New Jersey, wanted the agency to branch out. Industrial parks were created in the South Bronx, Yonkers and Elizabeth, N.J., in response to the Governors' desire for the authority to help more with regional economic development.
The legal center in downtown Newark was built only after Thomas H. Kean, then the New Jersey Governor, said the agency should commit itself to the project if it wanted his support for a 1983 toll increase, a former Port Authority official said.
The overall results were mixed. An incinerator in Newark is performing two technological miracles: burning garbage to create electricity, and making money for the Port Authority in the process. But the agency has worked for a decade to create huge office and residential developments on the waterfronts of Hoboken, Brooklyn Heights and Hunters Point, Queens. So far, not a brick has been laid.
Peter C. Goldmark Jr., who as executive director between 1977 and 1985 presided over the Port Authority's era of expansion, said it was not surprising that the track record was uneven.
"If you try different things, some of them aren't going to work," he said. "If you're only going to play if you bat a thousand, don't even come to the ballpark."
Mr. Goldmark, who now heads the Rockefeller Foundation, said the Port Authority should pursue more of the kinds of difficult, capital-intensive, long-term projects that it does best. He said the agency should build more industrial parks, get involved in hazardous waste disposal and consider helping to repair the city's public works, particularly the East River bridges.
"I think our fundamental problem is that the political leadership doesn't know what to ask of the Port Authority," he said.
But others think that less should be asked, so the agency can concentrate on its primary responsibilities. Mr. Berger, who succeeded Mr. Goldmark, said he thought that real estate and industrial parks and incinerators could be left to other government agencies and the private sector.
"By putting a lot of intellectual energy into these areas, you really didn't do what was crucial -- putting money into the basic infrastructure," he said.

HEADLINE: Vallone Offers Own Plan For City's Fiscal Problems

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
Saying Mayor David N. Dinkins's four-year plan for closing the city's budget gaps lacks specifics, the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, yesterday offered a long-term fiscal plan of his own that calls for more job cuts and a four-year property-tax freeze.
By offering the plan, the Speaker and the Council leadership appeared to be seizing an opportunity to advance their budget priorities, taking advantage of the criticism the Mayor's plan has drawn from fiscal monitors since it was released on Sept. 6. 
 "This was not meant to be, nor is it, an attack on the Mayor," Mr. Vallone said. "All it is is the legislative branch coming forward much quicker than under ordinary circumstances to supply the missing part of what was not in the Mayor's plan."
Mayor Dinkins said: "I don't see it as an attempt to step on my toes. I see it as useful."
Mr. Vallone's plan is noteworthy because he initially supported the Mayor's plan. That was before Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, said the plan amounted to borrowing money to freeze taxes and did not shrink the government significantly. Bond rating agencies agreed.
 
Deeper Cuts Planned
 Echoing many of Mr. Rohatyn's complaints, Mr. Vallone's plan calls for deeper cuts in the work force than the Mayor proposed -- 24,300 jobs rather than 16,400 -- and calls for a property-tax freeze for four years rather than two years. Like the Mayor's plan, the Council would shrink the work force through attrition and pay for raises with labor concessions.
It also proposes several ways to prune city services. The Council would transfer the City University to the state, sell the municipal hospital system to a nonprofit corporation, and shift the property managed by the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development to community groups.
To streamline the government, the Council's plan would merge the city's three police departments, turn the recycling program over to a private company, and create an "infrastructure authority" that would administer all capital projects. It would also create an omnibus licensing agency and merge the Board of Elections with the Campaign Finance Board.
The Mayor asserted that several parts of Mr. Vallone's plan were unworkable. A merger of the police forces would end up costing more than it would save because of the different benefit packages the officers receive, he said. And selling the hospital system to a private corporation could jeopardize the hospitals' commitment to treat the poor.
A crucial difference between the two plans is how they use $1 billion in aid the M.A.C. can provide the city by stretching out payments on bonds issued by the corporation on behalf of the city. The administration initially planned to finance a two-year freeze on property taxes with the M.A.C. funds, but Mr. Rohatyn objected strenuously, forcing the Dinkins budget officials to rethink the plan.
Mr. Vallone's proposal uses $600 million of the M.A.C. money to pay for workers that will be phased out by the third year of the plan through agency consolidations. The other $400 million would be put in an emergency "rainy day" fund to cushion the city from future economic downturns.
"It seems to me at first glance that the City Council plan is more compatible to our views," Mr. Rohatyn said yesterday.

HEADLINE: In Albany, Confusion Clouds Multiyear Financial Plan

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 21

 BODY:
While Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders were boasting publicly today of making significant progress in state budget talks, their aides were conceding privately that the negotiations over a multiyear financial plan were mired in confusion.
Mr. Cuomo, speaking to reporters in Manhattan, said it represented "a lot of progress" that the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Oyster Bay, L.I., had signed on to the concept of a budget that would stretch across 15 months. The unprecedented plan, which has been championed by Mr. Cuomo and Assembly Speaker Mel Miller, both Democrats, is intended to close the gaps in both this year's state budget and next year's budget in one step. 
 But the agreement on a framework appears to mean little as long as there is no consensus on what programs would be cut and by how much. With the clock ticking, all sides said today that the talks had produced nothing resembling that kind of agreement.
 
A Nettlesome Issue
 Aides from all camps said there was serious disagreement over how much a variety of proposed cuts in social-service programs would actually save. And at the center of the statistical debate is the same nettlesome issue that forms the crux of the ideological debate -- how much the state could, and should, rein in its rapidly growing Medicaid program.
Senate negotiators have proposed a series of deep cuts for Medicaid that they maintain would save $400 million in the last quarter of this fiscal year, which ends on March 31, and would save about $1.5 billion in the next fiscal year. The state faces a gap of more than $700 million in its $30 billion budget this year and expects a gap that could approach $4 billion next year.
But aides to Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller dispute that the proposals suggested by the Senate Republicans could actually save $400 million this year. Using rough calculations, they argue that just over $1 billion will remain in the state's $4 billion Medicaid budget in the last fiscal quarter, which starts on Jan. 1. A cut of $400 million in the last quarter would eliminate about a third of all Medicaid payments, they said.
 
Lag in Reimbursement
 Furthermore, Cuomo aides said, there is often a lag of up to 90 days between the time that Medicaid services are provided by hospitals, doctors and nursing homes and the time the state reimburses those providers. That means that much of the state's Medicaid spending in the last quarter of the fiscal year will be reimbursement for services already provided.
"You can't capture the cash, and the issue between now and March 31 is cash," said one administration official.
Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Miller have both expressed a willingness to cut Medicaid, but they prefer to do it more gradually. They also believe that the Republican proposals focus too much on generating savings by limiting the services available to Medicaid recipients and by restricting eligibility levels.
The fate of the multiyear budget plan is significant not only to the state's fiscal plight but also to Mr. Cuomo's Presidential plans. The Governor said today that he could not run for President if doing so would "make it harder for us to get a budget in the state and the city."
That seemed to be a reference to Mr. Cuomo's concern that Mr. Marino, possibly acting under pressure from the White House, might impede the search for a budget solution to frustrate a Cuomo campaign.
 
Economic Growth Plan
 While Mr. Cuomo spent much of the day dealing with the state budget, he also released a national economic growth plan, a nine-page compilation of proposals that he has advanced in speeches over the last year.
He sent a copy of the plan this morning to Vice President Dan Quayle, who provoked Mr. Cuomo this week by referring to the Governor by his first name on a network television news show. Mr. Cuomo addressed his accompanying letter "Dear Mr. Vice President" and signed it "Sincerely, Mario."

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
"Four years ago, if someone asked me for a loan to buy a collection of baseball cards, I would have laughed," said Bruce Miller, founder of the Art Funding Corporation, a Manhattan-based business that lends collectors, gallery owners and independent dealers the money to purchase art. "I used to only get involved with fine art, but not any longer. In this market you have to diversify."
Mr. Miller admitted that his portfolio, which he said he values "in the mid seven figures," is tiny compared with those of the major lenders for art -- Citibank, Rosenthal & Rosenthal, Sotheby's, Chase Manhattan Bank or IBJ Schroder. But times have changed, as everyone in the business knows. With the art market struggling to find appropriate price levels and the speculators who drove up art prices in the 80's having run far away (some of them all the way into bankruptcy), for some investors art has become more of a liability than an asset. 
 "Art makes most bankers a bit queasy right now," said Edgar B. Howard, senior vice president of IBJ Schroder's program of advisory and financial services for art. "But I feel more comfortable lending money against a great diversified art collection than a Park Avenue apartment."
IBJ Schroder is one of the few banks still willing to lend at all for art. In the late 80's, many institutions saw the opportunity to cash in on the art boom, but most entered the market too late and, like the speculators, either cut way back or completely stopped their art lending. Those remaining are retrenching to meet the new demands of a changing market.
Together with the European banks that are still lending money for art purchases, Mr. Howard estimated the combined credit available to collectors and dealers in the United States and Western Europe at $1.5 billion to $2 billion. That figure, he said, is nominal when compared with the amount of credit available to an American corporation the size of, say, General Electric. "And compared to the billions of dollars of art bought and sold every year, it's not a lot of money either," he said.
He does admit, however, that even these seemingly small loans can make a big difference. "If the loan is strategically placed at an important auction, it can create a favorable tone for the market at a time when boosting may be necessary," he said. In other words, lending money has the potential to inflate the art price structure.
In today's conservative environment, this is a sensitive subject. "Make no bones about it: We're more selective now than we used to be," said Shelton Kaye, a senior vice president at Rosenthal & Rosenthal. Gideon Strauss, managing director of Rosenthal Art Equities, who started the company's art department in the late 60's, said it recognizes a new niche that needs to be filled. Knowing that money from most banks is tight right now, the company is beginning to look at the long term.
In much the same way many banks readily lent money to buy art in the late 80's, Rosenthal & Rosenthal is now offering long-term financing at interest rates that it describes as "more than a bank but less than a credit card." Now more than ever, Mr. Kaye said, "You make your profit in this business if you buy at the right price and hold on to your assets until it's the right time to sell."
Rosenthal & Rosenthal is addressing a problem common to many dealers, who want the money to buy art while prices are low and need the financial solvency to hold on to purchases until the market comes back.
Sotheby's, on the other hand, is responding to the market's need for quick cash. Recognizing that many of its customers are selling artworks because they need money fast and cannot wait three months or so for a scheduled auction, Sotheby's is capitalizing on a policy it began years ago: offering customers short-term advances for about three to six months using the consigned works of art as collateral. "While this is not something new for us, it's the most popular kind of loan we do right now," said Mitchell Zuckerman, president of Sotheby's Financial Services in New York..
As an example, Mr. Zuckerman described a recent arrangement he made with a major collector who needed money to pay his taxes. The collector approached Sotheby's with some items that he wanted to sell at an auction scheduled for in the spring. Using the works as collateral, Sotheby's extended a seven-month loan. The amount of the loan represented about half the art's appraised value.
"If for some reason the objects being auctioned do not sell, the collector still owes us the money," Mr. Zuckerman said. "We're careful about who we make these arrangements with, making sure have the means to pay us."
The auction house also offers one-year loans against a customer's art collection.
Ever since Sotheby's Financial Services was established in 1988 (as of Sept. 30, its loan portfolio amounted to about $206 million), its appropriateness has been hotly debated. To many art dealers, the company seem to be functioning more like a bank than an auction house. And when the auction house itself provides financing, the dealers say, prices are falsely inflated.
This issue became particularly heated when it was learned that Sotheby's had lent $27 million to Alan Bond, the Australian industrialist, in November 1987 to allow him to buy van Gogh's "Irises," which became what was then the most expensive painting in the world. The painting itself was the collateral for the huge loan. It is believed that the timing -- less than a month after the Wall Street crash on Oct. 19, 1987 -- helped boost sales.
"After all the criticism, in January 1990 we stopped offering loans secured by the purchase property," Mr. Zuckerman said. "Given the uncertainties of the economy, we've become much more selective in the past year and a half." Still, he says, what Sotheby's offers clients is one-stop shopping -- everything from art experts to financial services under one roof.
Citibank uses a modified version of Sotheby's all-in-one service as its selling point. Its two-pronged art program consists of an art advisory service and a banking department. Fees for the bank's lending average about 1 or 2 percentage points over the prime rate.
"In 1989, we would get in excess of 10 requests a week about art credit, and only 1 in 25 ended up being our customers," said Jennifer J. Vorbach, a vice president at Citibank's art advisory service. "Now we get maybe two requests a week, but they are from more financially solid people." Ms. Vorbach reluctantly admits that her operation has not been seamless over the last year; like all lending institutions, it has had some "glitches," as she calls them. But the advisory service has grown steadily at 8 percent a year since it started with just two people in 1979, she said, and now Citibank is by far the biggest of the lending institutions.
Bruce Miller, on the other hand, is thinking smaller and smaller. The average loan he makes is about $100,000. "Six months ago, a young Boston executive came to me needing cash to publish a photographer's portfolio," Mr. Miller recalled. "I lent him about $100,000 and took possession of four Jasper Johns prints valued at about $350,000 as collateral." The executive paid Mr. Miller back after eight months. When he did, Mr. Miller told him about another collector interested in purchasing the Johns prints. The Boston executive ended up selling them at a profit. "Often I act as a middleman," said Mr. Miller. "What do I get out of it? More clients."
Using art as collateral -- he stores artworks in warehouses because it helps him "sleep better at night," he said -- Mr. Miller is helping collectors and gallery owners buy everything from doll collections to estate jewelry. "Prices for decorative arts have held up during the recession," he said. "I've always been careful. If I'd lent money on some contemporary-art collections, as I was asked to several years ago, I'd be out of business by now."
In banking, IBJ Schroder's $50 million lending portfolio for art is also considered small. Since he started six years ago, Mr. Howard has been lending primarily to dealers. "We're selectively expanding the business, picking up customers from banks who no longer want to be involved in art," he said.
It's the knowledge that the art market is cyclical that keeps businesses such as IBJ Schroder going. Not long ago, Mr. Howard had his company brochure translated into Japanese. "Unfortunately, it will have to sit on the shelf for a few more years," he said, since Japanese investors have almost completely left the market. "That is, until the tides start to turn."

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

Lincoln Center Prognostications
Here's the scoop on Lincoln Center once Andre Bishop takes over as artistic director on Jan. 1: "Four Baboons Adoring the Sun" by John Guare will begin performances at the Vivian Beaumont Theater on Feb. 14 and Peter Hall will direct the cast of three adults and nine children. But the play, about two American archeologists, may only have a six-week run at the Beaumont before "March of the Falsettos" and "Falsettoland," the double bill of one-act musicals by William Finn and James Lapine, follows. It must open by April 29 to be eligible for Tony Awards. 
 Mr. Bishop says that either "Baboons" will have to transfer to a Broadway theater after it opens, or "Falsettos" will bypass the Beaumont and, under Lincoln Center's auspices, open at a Broadway house. Bets now are on "Baboons" moving, since "Falsettos," which received rave reviews during its recent run at the Hartford Stage Company, was directed by Graciela Daniele for a thrust stage, like the Beaumont's, which extends toward the audience. The only options on Broadway are traditional proscenium stages, meaning the production would have to be reworked.
"I believe in one thing at a time," Mr. Bishop says. "I like the Guare play and I'm thrilled that Peter Hall is directing it. The advantage of 'Falsettos' playing in a thrust space is the intimacy between the audience and the actors, but it is a powerful enough piece to be appreciated in all configurations, if it has to be."
And in the Mitzi Newhouse Theater, performances are to begin on Jan. 31 of Jon Robin Baitz's "Substance of Fire," which Mr. Bishop produced last season at Playwrights Horizons. He says he expects the original cast to return for a 12-week run, including Ron Rifkin, who played the patriarch of a family-owned publishing business.
 
Finding a Bankroll for 'Jelly'

The best wallets in the business will be gathering at 890 Broadway on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday for workshop presentations of "Jelly's Last Jam." This is the new musical about the musician Jelly Roll Morton, starring Gregory Hines and written and directed by George C. Wolfe, best known as the author of "The Colored Museum" and the director of "Spunk." How wide the wallets will open remains to be seen. A co-producer, Margo Lion, says the show will cost $5 million, and so far, only $820,000 is in the bank, though she adds that Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, has pledged $1 million. Among the other invited potential investors are: the Nederlander and Shubert Organizations, Quincy Jones, Geffen Records, Motown Records, the Bank of Tokyo, the Kennedy Center, Polygram Records, Elizabeth I. McCann, Guber-Peters, David Mirvish, Warner Brothers, M-G-M, Don Taffner and Bobby Short.
There is a lot of heat, as they say, about Mr. Wolfe right now, who, at 37 is about the only news in the musical theater this season. The scenic designer Robin Wagner, who is working on "Jelly," says, "George is the most exciting young director I've worked with since Michael Bennett," for whom he designed both "A Chorus Line" and "Dreamgirls." "He has all the same kind of instincts and gut-level excitement that Michael had, and he can get stuff out of you you never knew you had, the way Michael could. I see a lot of hope and a lot of light." Maybe they'll also see a lot of money.
 
'Peter Pan' Wins. Of Course!

The competition for recession dollars is especially fierce this holiday season, as families finally splurge on some entertainment. The big winner? "Peter Pan," the revival of the classic musical starring Cathy Rigby, which plays at the Minskoff from Tuesday through Jan. 5. Arthur Rubin, executive vice president of the Nederlander Organization, which owns the Minskoff, says the advance sale for the six weeks is already more than $1 million. On the losing side of the holiday gambles is "Moscow Circus, Cirk Valentin," which opened at the Gershwin Theater on Nov. 6 and will close on Dec. 1, because of weak sales.
Steven E. Leiber, its producer, says that he was trying something new by presenting the circus without its famous bears and other animals, in a performance similar to Cirque du Soleil. But like Samson without his hair, the Moscow Circus without its bears has no strength. "This is more like a ballet than a circus," Mr. Leiber says. "But people are staying with the things they know."
One other holiday show that might draw is "A Christmas Carol," a one-man performance of the Dickens classic that is to open on Broadway on Dec. 19. The one man is Patrick Stewart, who plays Jean-Luc Picard, captain of the Enterprise on the television show "Star Trek: The Next Generation." "A Christmas Carol" has been promoted at "Star Trek" conventions and film marathons for the last few months. Sort of gives new meaning to the Ghost of Christmas Future.
 
Holiday Bargains at the Box Office

Christmas cheer comes cheap this year, thanks to Charles Busch and his Theater in Limbo. Ten dollars buys a ticket to a revival of "Times Square Angel: A Hard-Boiled Christmas Fantasy" at Theater for the New City from Nov. 29 through Dec. 15. Mr. Busch, the playwright and drag star,plays Irish Flanagan, a tough nightclub chanteuse who is visited by an angel (an ex-vaudevillian) on Christmas Eve and given the opportunity to change her selfish ways.
New plays come even cheaper. Playwrights Horizons' New Theater Wing starts performances on Dec. 11, and tickets are $5 for each of the three new plays. The first is a collection of four short musicals, "Break/Agnes/Eulogy for Mister Hamm/ Lucky Nurse" by Michael John La Chiusa, starring Alice Playten and Joe Grifasi. The second is "Man, Woman, Dinosaur" by Regina M. Porter, about a fatherless young black man who supports his invalid mother by selling dinosaur sculptures. And the third is "Little Egypt," by Lynn Seifert, about a romance between two oddball sisters who meet two war buddies in rural Illinois.
 
Nathan Lane and Linda Hunt

Time to call in favors from your favorite member of the Century Club. On Monday night Nathan Lane and Linda Hunt will read what Mr. Lane calls "a sort of play" based on the biography by Max Wilk of the agent Audrey Wood and the letters she and her client Tennessee Williams wrote to each other. "It's not unlike 'Love Letters,' " Mr. Lane says. "It's touching and much funnier than I thought. It gives a little history of what the theater was like at that time."


GRAPHIC: On Dec. 1, John Leguizamo of "Mambo Mouth" fame will open "Moving Beyond the Madness: A Festival of New Voices," a two-week program at the Public Theater. He will perform excerpts from "Spic-o-Rama," his new one-man show about a family of six that is to open in New York next spring. The artists in the series have been chosen by the director George C. Wolfe. Tickets are $15. (David Hughes)

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
Retro-Mania: When TV Was for Families

BYLINE: By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

 BODY:
IN February, CBS struck oldies gold with retrospective specials on three of its most successful series: "The Ed Sullivan Show," "All in the Family" and "The Mary Tyler Moore Show." Well, in television, if it works once, you've got to try it again or start looking for a new job.
So now, happily, we have what is being billed as "CBS Classic Weekend II." Tomorrow at 8 P.M., there's "The Bob Newhart Show 19th-Anniversary Special," and Sunday at 9 P.M. "The Very Best of 'The Ed Sullivan Show' -- II." Actually, the time-warp trip continues into Monday night, at 9:30, with "Memories of M*A*S*H." And then for the days-gone-by insatiable, there is tomorrow's "Party for Richard Pryor," at 9 P.M., crammed with wonderful clips from decades past. 
 Why is television so fixated on the past? Some cable channels are doing quite nicely, thank you, with little more than reruns of series made decades ago, shows like "Rocky Jones" or "Mr. and Mrs. North." The Nostalgia Channel -- yes, there really is one on some cable systems -- touts a "melt-away factor," meaning that as viewers watch favorites from the past the years just melt away. Ponce de Leon, evidently, was on the wrong track.
Retro-mania is upon us, no doubt about it. On the most elevated level, there is the Museum of Television and Radio in Manhattan, preserving invaluable broadcasting and cable material in much the same way that museums around the country have been collecting old movies over the years. At the other extreme, closer to classic camp than anything else, there is the kind of project that exploits the past with an adoring wink. Top example: The current stage version of "The Brady Bunch" Off Broadway using the original television scripts.
Analysts can find endless reasons for the retro craze. For the networks, certainly, repackaging what's already in the vaults is far cheaper than producing new shows, a consideration to be taken seriously in times of lean budgets. And on a broader sociological level, viewers might understandably be eager to escape an unsettling present -- pocked with problems ranging from economic recession to AIDS -- and return to what they perceive, even if inaccurately, as less complicated and decidedly safer times.
And there's something else, something that occurred to me while watching "The Very Best of 'The Ed Sullivan Show' -- II." Back then, not all that long ago, we weren't divvied up as an audience or a people into targeted market groups. Watching Ed Sullivan meant sitting around with the entire family -- parents, children, grandparents, even neighbors -- and knowing that in the course of the hour there would be a little something for everyone. There was no palaver about appealing only to men or to women, to under-25's or over-25's. There was only the basic concept of good entertainment.
And the result could be quite grand. Consider the startling talent lineup in this Sunday's compilation: Established comics like Jack Benny mixed with such new faces as George Carlin and Albert Brooks (doing a hilarious inept-ventriloquist routine); Elvis Presley, the Beatles and the Rolling Stones, all spankingly youthful, side by side with Johnny Mathis singing his new hit "Misty" or Beverly Sills belting out an operatic aria; Richard Burton and Julie Andrews offering, in full costume, the title song from "Camelot"; Sullivan and Peter O'Toole bellowing their way through "When Irish Eyes Are Smiling"; Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev performing a pas de deux from "Swan Lake."
Yes, yes, the medium was still young in those days of the 1950's, 60's and even the 70's. The novelty hadn't worn off, and few of us were anxious about being politically correct. Henny Youngman might tell insulting jokes about his wife. ("My wife got a mud pack and for two days she looked wonderful -- and then the mud fell off.") But that would be balanced by Phyllis Diller's insulting jokes about her husband, Fang. ("His breath is so bad his dentist works on him through the ear.") Eventually, on Ed Sullivan, things had a way of balancing out, even ethnically and racially (the show was an admirable pioneer in showcasing black performers). If you had to sit through still another juggling act, you knew that you'd be rewarded with a song from Nat (King) Cole or a dance by Gwen Verdon.
Television itself, or at least the advertisers searching for specific demographics, has been at the forefront of splitting the mass audience into discrete groups, all the while subtly suggesting that one is incompatible with the other. If you want to attract younger people, goes the theory, you have to give them something that can't possibly appeal to older people. So Fox's "Beverly Hills 90210" is marketed energetically as a youth-oriented series, although it might easily prove attractive to older viewers. Age-group exclusivity becomes the calculated enticement.
Few theories have been more damaging to the very fabric of society. Now we have a former television programmer, Brandon Tartikoff, taking over a major movie studio, Paramount, and warning that "you don't want an abundance of pictures clearly tilted to viewers 25 and up." How, one wonders, did "Gone With the Wind" or "Casablanca" or "Citizen Kane" ever become such gigantic successes without such audience research?
Just about any age group, I suspect, will get a kick out of "CBS Classic Weekend II." The Bob Newhart special allows the star and his co-stars on the 1972-78 series -- Suzanne Pleshette, Peter Bonerz, Marcia Wallace, Bill Daily and Jack Riley -- to amble genially through clips from the series, augmented perfectly with the patented Newhart stammer. And "A Party for Richard Pryor," overseen with unstinting love by the show's host, Eddie Murphy ("Without you, there's no me, brother"), pays richly deserved tribute to an extraordinarily gifted and influential comedian, his career recalled and celebrated by, among others, Arsenio Hall, Lily Tomlin, Keenen Ivory Wayans, Chevy Chase, Robert Townsend and Patti LaBelle.
These excursions into the past do, perhaps, convey a message about the present. If there is an underlying sense of loss, it has less to do with innocence than with a sense of community. That is what retro-mania is probably all about.

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS: BASEBALL;
Vincent Sounds an Alarm on TV Revenue

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir

 BODY:
Baseball Commissioner Fay Vincent has told major league officials that if new television agreements were negotiated today, teams should expect at least 30 percent less than the $1.46 billion now being paid by CBS and ESPN in four-year contracts that expire at the end of 1993.
"It was part of his report to us about a variety of things," said Lou Gorman, general manager of the Boston Red Sox. "Nobody probed it a lot, but everybody understood it'll be a tough go. It wasn't a rosy forecast." 
 Clubs now receive an average of $14 million apiece per year from the TV deals, but Vincent forecast a possible cut of $4 million to $5 million per club if talks were to start now in the recessionary sports economy.
Vincent's remarks came during meetings with general managers in Florida and marketing executives in Arizona earlier this month, and he is expected to speak publicly on the subject next month during baseball's winter meetings in Miami. The comments are not surprising in light of the financial woes the baseball contracts have wrought on CBS and ESPN.
CBS announced a $282 million pre-tax write-off last year of the value of its $1.06 billion baseball contract; $322 million more, partly attributable to baseball, was written off earlier this month. ESPN has lost upward of $100 million on the first two years of its $400 million contract.
Depending on the health of the economy, Vincent may have to revise his gloomy assessment over the next year as baseball prepares to negotiate a new set of broadcast and cable deals. A prominent network executive said CBS's and ESPN's losses and write-offs and the continuing recession could result in baseball's post-1993 TV revenues being half of what they are now.
Officials who heard Vincent's report said their teams face the conflicting pressures of signing expensive free agents like Bobby Bonilla to contracts that extend beyond 1993 at a time when TV revenues will probably fall, making such deals difficult to support. Said Gorman: "If clubs recognize there will be a problem, how do you sign people down the line for five years?"
In 1989, team owners used the prospect of cascading cash from the television contracts to fuel spiraling salaries, committing to expensive player contracts before the TV money actually became available in 1990.
One general manager who asked not to be identified said: "It's disturbing. Much of what we do on the financial side of this business is relative to payroll and any reduction in revenues hurts your ability to sign players."
"The commissioner said the 30 percent drop is a scenario we have to look at seriously," said a marketing executive who insisted on remaining anonymous. "But you don't have to go further than CBS's losses to know how serious the scenario is."
Vincent's appraisal may be an accurate reflection of the current state of the economy but may also be a case of management pleading poverty at a time when players are getting record salaries and this year's top free agents have yet to sign.
The ratings orphans of "Monday Night Football" -- those who watch outside their homes in bars, restaurants, dorms and hotel rooms -- are closer to being part of the A. C. Nielsen brood.
In a study that began in September and covers the first six weeks of the Monday night season, Nielsen has found that an average of 830,000 men age 18 and over tuned in to Al Michaels, Dan Dierdorf and Frank Gifford from out-of-home sites. (An estimated 23.6 million people of all ages -- 66 percent are men -- watch "Monday Night Football.")
The boost by the male out-of-homers adds an extra point, a 6.2 percent increase, to the existing 16.1 in-home rating for men 18 and older, said Richard Montesano, vice president of market research for ABC.
If out-of-home measurements of the 11 other Monday night games buttress the early returns, ABC may, by quantifying how many previously uncounted men exist in the program's key demographic group, have the data to charge advertisers more than the average $250,000 they now pay for 30-second commercial spots.
"Most advertisers know there is an out-of-home audience," said Montesano, "but don't know how big it is."
Jack Loftus, a Nielsen spokesman, added, " 'Monday Night Football' is sold on demographics and if you have another point of men 18 and over, you can charge for it."
ABC hopes that when viewer diaries for the full-season study are accumulated, they will bear out its belief that out-of-homers are younger (age 18-34) than most of the in-home audience (25-54). A younger audience has implications for the type of advertisers buying spots on the show.

HEADLINE: In an Economic Turn, Midwest Meets Europe

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The trend for skyscrapers in Cleveland and Columbus, Ohio, Peoria, Ill., and Milwaukee, when viewed from a domestic real estate perspective, as in Louis Uchitelle's Nov. 5 Business Scene column ("The Last Vestiges of the 80's Boom"), may appear the tail end of a large growth in housing and office building space. However, in a larger context of international trade, what you're seeing is a new wave of economic growth.
Since 1983 my company has been involved with European investment in the United States and United States investment in Central Europe. Cleveland, Peoria and Milwaukee have significant manufacturing bases, which are leading the country in the weak domestic economy. Columbus, although once a farm town, has to its credit a major manufacturing and export base of Honda Motors, less than an hour's drive away. 
 It is also not surprising that two of these cities are in Ohio. Ohio exports close to $200 billion annually, which has made the Cleveland Federal Reserve Bank the strongest regional Federal Reserve Bank in the country. I have European or American clients involved in every city you discuss.
What is truly the trend is the separation of companies involved in international trade from companies traditionally involved in the United States market. The differences in the companies will become even more dramatic over the next few years. I've made more than half a dozen trips to Central and Eastern Europe since last January, and rarely have I met East Coast or West Coast Americans there. Rather, the other Americans I meet are from Ohio, Illinois and other manufacturing states.
To gain a brief historical perspective, look at the German economy of the early 1980's. Despite a weak economy in Europe, German exports to Japan, the United States and other countries provided a major motor to drive the German economy. Once the regional economy picked up, the German manufacturing base expanded even more rapidly. With the opening of Eastern Europe, German manufacturers often have lead times in excess of one year, and the German economy is Europe's driving force.
Only in the last decade have we come to realize that there is not one United States economy, but several regionalized economies. More recently there has been a growing contrast between companies that are international and those that maintain a purely domestic focus. Thus, the activity seen as the last vestiges of the 80's, and their service-orientation perspective, are really the trend of the 90's and the new age of manufacturing and exports.
The trend is not only a matter of international economics, but also one of national security. Only through manufacturing and exports can the United States regain its position as the leading world economic power. It is necessary to point out this development to those who are unaware of it. In addition to that, policy makers need to support and further its development.
 
FREDERICK M. SHEPPERD
Managing Partner, Quadral Group
Akron, Ohio, Nov. 5, 1991

HEADLINE: In an Economic Turn, Midwest Meets Europe;
Sensible Tax Relief

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I agree with "The Law That Ate the Future" (editorial, Nov. 6) on one point: there is no more pressing issue before the United States than the reworking of last year's budget agreement. The economic recession, which has thrown millions of Americans out of work, clearly makes the case for urgent change in the law. Congress needs the financial flexibility to respond to pressing domestic events, so last May I introduced legislation to amend the budget agreement. 
 But the real tragedy of last year's budget agreement is that it raised taxes and fees on low- and middle-income Americans, while trying the hands of Congress to respond adequately to the needs of those working Americans.
The agreement did this after a decade in which most Americans saw their incomes stagnate or even decline, while their tax burdens increased. The 1989 average hourly earnings -- adjusted for inflation -- were $7.64, still below their 1981 level of $7.69. Worse, working Americans have been hit hard by regressive Federal taxes (Social Security, gas, beer) and escalating Medicare fees: In short, regressive taxes and stagnating wages have made the American dream more difficult to attain. And as every American family knows, housing, health care and higher education costs have increased dramatically.
In light of this, I must take issue with your position that tax-cut proposals in Congress for working Americans are a "dangerous and cynical game." You would have the working Americans who suffered most from trickle-down economics pay for the infrastructure improvements that were neglected by that devastating policy. Certainly, Federal investments in America's infrastructure are needed to reinvigorate the American economy. And any sound tax-cut proposal should not deter the Federal Government's ability to make those investments. But the Federal Government should redistribute that burden and do it fairly.
Working Americans are tired of seeing the green grass from the other side of the fence, while too rarely seeing the green of a dollar bill. Americans need both sensible tax relief and investment, and the Federal Government ought to provide both -- sensibly.
 
TED WEISS
Member of Congress, 17th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, Nov. 15, 1991

HEADLINE: In an Economic Turn, Midwest Meets Europe;
Capital Gains

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Son of Kemp-Roth: Still Wrong" (editorial, Nov. 13) states: "The capital gains ideas now circulating would produce a windfall profit for rich families on past investment. That couldn't possibly spur future investment." What this familiar argument for taxing capital gains as income neglects is that the "windfall" profit has already been made, and the tax is a deterrent to rolling over that investment into others that we hope would spur investment. 
 The capital gains tax tends to freeze investment profits in past investments when growth has run its course. The Scandinavian countries, long known for steeply graduated taxes on current income, have already given capital gains favored treatment because it spurs future investment.
 
DANIEL C. DeMENOCAL
Rye, N.Y., Nov. 13, 1991
