HEADLINE: Your Money;
Some Advantages In Savings Bonds

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
With the interest rates paid on savings accounts, money market funds and short- term certificates of deposit only half to two-thirds their levels of less than a year ago, many savers, particularly retirees, are seeking ways to receive better yields with limited risk.
Joel S. Isaacson, a partner who is in charge of personal financial planning at Clarfeld & Company, a New York accounting firm, recommends United States Government savings bonds. He cited a number of advantages to these bonds: 
 *There is no risk of loss of principal or default.
*Interest, now 6.375 percent, is 85 percent of the six-month average yield for marketable Treasury securities with five years to maturity. There is a guaranteed rate of at least 6 percent if the bonds are held for five years.
*They are sold without commission or redemption fee at banks and savings and loan associations and by mail or over-the-counter at Federal Reserve banks or Treasury offices.
*Interest is not subject to state and local taxes.
*For middle-income people, savings bonds purchased after Jan. 1, 1990, are also free of Federal taxes when used to pay college tuition for the bondholder, the holder's children or a spouse.
*Holders have flexibility in deciding when to recognize the interest for Federal taxes: at redemption, or annually as it accrues. But a decision to take the interest annually will affect all of a person's savings bond holdings, not just certain bonds, and could apply to future purchases as well.
*An individual can convert series EE bonds to series HH bonds and receive interest twice a year, continuing to defer the accrued interest on the EE bonds until the HH bonds mature or are sold.
Series EE bonds are sold at half of their face value in eight denominations ranging from $50 to $10,000, and savers may buy up to $30,000 each year. The bonds accrue interest until they mature 12 years after they are issued.
By purchasing bonds in small denominations, Mr. Isaacson noted, savers can cash in a portion as income is needed, provided they have held them at least six months.
"This is for the person who has been rolling over C.D. money," Mr. Isaacson said. "In the environment we're in, it's not bad." C.D. rates vary with maturity and currently range from a fraction over 4 percent for one month to around 6.4 percent for five years, but the entire yield is taxable. Two years ago, three-month C.D.'s yielding more than 9 percent were available.
Some investors feeling the squeeze of these lower rates have responded to ads for Ginnie Mae funds, collateralized mortgage obligations and high-yield -- that is, junk -- bond funds, he added, without realizing that there can be significant risks to the principal in such investments. "Too many people buy strictly on yield," he said, without understanding all the nuances of the bond market. People who do not understand the market, or who cannot afford to risk the principal, do not belong in such investments.
This is for the most safe part of a portfolio, he said, but not for people who need immediate income, because money withdrawn in less than five years receives interest at a lower rate.
 
Gifts of Art
 Philanthropists have less then six weeks left to make charitable donations of valuable works of art and other tangible personal property and deduct them at fair market value without being trapped by the alternative minimum tax.
That is because Congress, responding to the pleas of museums and other institutions, created what Eli J. Warach, a tax lawyer and author of the "Maxwell Macmillan 1992 Federal Tax Handbook," calls a "one-year escape hatch" for donors in 1991. Whereas normally those liable for the alternative tax could deduct only the cost of the acquisition, all taxpayers can deduct the full appreciated value for 1991, regardless of regular or alternative-tax status.
Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Weber, Lipshie & Company, said he had been counseling affluent clients to make such gifts before the end of the year. But he cautioned that the gift must be related to the charity's purpose, like manuscripts given to a library or paintings to a museum. Even if a hospital hangs a painting or puts an antique in the president's office, he said, it would be hard to argue that those gifts qualified for the 1991 exception.
Barry Salzberg, a partner in Deloitte & Touche in New York, said one of his clients "is going to stockpile donations." Donors cannot deduct amounts equal to more than 30 percent of their income in any one year, he explained, but deductions for charitable contributions made this year can be carried forward up to five years and still qualify for the special 1991 treatment.
Charities are also counseling donors. For example, the New York Philharmonic has scheduled a gift-planning seminar for potential donors of musical instruments from 5:30 to 7:30 P.M. on Dec. 3 at Avery Fisher Hall. It is free, but reservations are required and may be made by calling David Clough at (212) 875-5696.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Settles Mostly Lower As the Mark Gets Stronger

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly lower on world currency markets yesterday as traders turned their attention to the German mark.
Gold prices rose. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.30 an ounce, up $1.10 from Thursday. The Republic National Bank said gold advanced $1.10 an ounce, to a late bid price of $368.50. 
 Analysts said dollar selling was heaviest in European trading, and activity moderated when dealings shifted to domestic markets, though the overall trend remained negative for the American currency.
The likelihood that German interest rates will remain firm if not rise, coupled with Germany's more buoyant economy, enhanced the mark's attractiveness, dealers said.
"We've seen the mark continue to strengthen," said John McCarthy, chief dealer at ABN-AMRO Bank N.V. "That's been the driving force here."
Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Chicago-based Harris Trust and Savings Bank, noted that the mark's advance was felt across all major foreign currencies throughout the week.
"Continued lack of confidence has been building over the U.S. economy, and that's reflective in the dollar," he said. The currency's only gains were scored against the Canadian dollar, which has been under its own set of pressures.
The dollar was unable to draw any support from the stock market. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial issues ended the day down about 30 points.
"The stock market was weak, and obviously we've been following that all week," Mr. McCarthy said.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to 129.65 yen, from 129.55 yen on Thursday. Later in London, it was quoted lower at 129.45 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 129.40 yen, down from 129.60 yen on Thursday..
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7975, from $1.7968 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.7945 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.7915.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5835 German marks, down from 1.5988; 1.4090 Swiss francs, down from 1.4215; 5.4135 French francs, down from 5.4610; 1,199.50 Italian lire, down from 1,208.00, and 1.1390 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1366.
Silver prices also gained ground. On New York's Comex, silver bullion settled at $4.132 an ounce, up from $4.122 on Thursday. In London, silver rose to a late bid price of $4.14 an ounce from $4.10.

HEADLINE: Discounters Closing In on New York

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
Between the stores in New York City and its nearby suburbs, shoppers can find just about everything they want, sometimes in unlikely places like Boogies Diner, a strange new hybrid in Manhattan that sells both hamburgers and hip clothes.
Only recently, though, have bargain hunters in the area been able to roam the cavernous floors of national discount stores like the refurbished K Mart and Home Depot, the hardware store on steroids. While commonplace in most other parts of the nation, these growing chains, with thousands of items at bargain prices, have only recently begun big efforts to open stores within striking distance of the city, especially on Long Island. 
 For years, the high cost of real estate, heavy competition from regional chains and difficulty finding the right locations for warehouse-sized stores largely kept the national discount chains out of range of New York City.
No more. Led by the K Mart Corporation, and with Wal-Mart Stores Inc. in close pursuit, the discounters are bringing bargain-priced merchandise to the recession-battered area. They are finding more stable real estate prices and attractive sites suddenly available because of the demise or retrenchment of some local chains, like TSS Seedmans, which owned the Times Square Stores. For Wal-Mart, the growing presence in the area is less a reflection of a regional strategy than a sign of the chain's continuing drive to populate new areas of the country with its stores.
Discount stores are one of the few bright spots in the otherwise bleak retailing scene nationwide. Most notable is Wal-Mart, which recently raced past Sears, Roebuck & Company to become the nation's largest retailer. Wal-Mart regularly reports strong sales and earnings gains in sharp contrast to most other retailers. Wal-Mart is planning to open an outlet of its Sam's Wholesale Club in Medford, L.I., real estate executives on Long Island said. A Sam's spokesman would not comment.
Regional discounters like the Caldor Corporation have had stores in the New York area since the 1950's. But most of these stores lack the size and vast range of brand-name merchandise that have made the national chains so appealing to shoppers in other parts of the country.
 
Facing Competition

Ken Wallace, a spokesman for Caldor, which has 13 stores on Long Island, said the company's business had not been hurt by the increased presence of K Mart. He believes K Mart and others were drawn to Long Island by the success of Caldor. "They ignored Long Island for some time, and now it's their gold mine," he said.
In one sharp example of the shift in shopping choices, K Mart is taking over an eastern Queens building where a Bloomingdale's is closing.
"It's a prime illustration of what's happening," said Alan Hudesman, an executive with Oxford & Simpson Realty, a brokerage in Jericho, L.I.
Long Island, with a population that rivals the nation's largest metropolitan areas and dotted end to end with affluent towns, is one of the nation's most alluring retail markets.
A study of Long Island by the real estate firm Cushman & Wakefield, titled "Pocket of Prosperity," states that 45 percent of households on Long Island have annual incomes of more than $50,000, compared with 18.6 percent of families nationally. The Long Island percentage surpasses that in two other affluent suburban areas, Bergen County in New Jersey and Westchester County in New York.
 
Ripe for Bargain Hunters
 But Long Island has not escaped the current economic malaise, and the slowdown has made local shoppers, who would once have scoffed at the notion of shopping at a K Mart, more open to the stores, real estate experts say. "The timing was not right before for a K Mart or Wal-Mart," Mr. Hudesman said. Now, he said, "The Long Island consumer has been somewhat battered by the recession and is looking to spend less money."
Long Island now has four huge K Mart stores, the first of which opened last year. K Mart officials said they would open more stores on Long Island if the right real estate became available. Long Island has also drawn several discounters that have been successful by specializing, like Ikea, the Swedish furniture retailer in Hicksville, and Home Depot, which has six Long Island stores and is planning more.
Because of the enormous space requirements of the stores, discounters are not likely to open stores in Manhattan. But the giants are inching closer to Manhattan. Wal-Mart plans to open a store next year in the Dutchess County community of Fishkill, 65 miles from New York City. It will be one of 10 Wal-Mart openings planned for New York State next year. There are now four stores in the state.
 
Some Shoppers' Views

On a recent Sunday, the 100,000-plus square feet of the K Mart store in Sayville, L.I., was filled with eager shoppers.
"Even though Long Island is affluent, people are looking for bargains; I know I am," said Theresa Stevens, a stylishly dressed 26-year-old, buying diapers for her 7-month-old daughter. "Things are getting so expensive, it's nice to get a bargain here and there."
Charles and Michele D'Onofrio of Oakdale spent more than four hours in the store, waiting to have a photographer take a portrait of their 19-month-old son. The offer of 60 prints for $14.95, along with diapers that "are $4 cheaper than anywhere else," lured the family in, said Mrs. D'Onofrio, a secretary. "We're on such a tight budget," she said.
Perhaps most important, the bleak economy and a number of business failures have provided the national chains with attractive locations.
When TSS Seedmans's Times Square Stores, a local chain, went out of business, K Mart pounced on four of their locations.
K Mart's chairman, Joseph E. Antonini, said in a recent interview, "K Mart is always willing to take advantage of all good opportunistic real estate deals."
 
K Mart's New Look

K Mart, which is in the process of refurbishing its older stores around the country, is putting its best foot forward on Long Island, with newly designed stores that are brighter and have wider aisles than earlier models. There is an older K Mart on Staten Island that does not do nearly as well as the Long Island stores.
Mr. Antonini scoffs at the notion that Long Island consumers have only suddenly become more receptive to bargains. "Long Island is no different than anywhere else in America," he said, adding that the company had long been considering Long Island, but had been waiting for the right locations.

HEADLINE: Despite Stock Fall, Bonds Don't Rally

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The slide in stock prices failed to ignite any sort of rally in the Government securities market yesterday, and prices of Treasury notes and bonds were narrowly mixed in slow trading.
Once again, prices on short-term securities remained firm while long-term bond prices fell. 
 "It's been the same trade every day this week," one Government securities trader said.
The inability of bond prices to improve during a period when stocks have been under major selling pressure and economic data have continued to be weak has been a puzzle, the trader said.
 
Worry Abut Washington

"The only explanation I have is the one that now seems to be the consensus view," the trader said. "And that is the weaker the data and the stock market get the more the market feels that Washington will panic and take some abrupt, ill-considered action."
The latest contribution to the debate over ways to stimulate the economy came from the House Republican caucus, which yesterday decided to push forward with a package that included a capital gains tax cut and other cuts to promote savings, home ownership and real estate investment.
Representative Newt Gingrich, the Georgia Republican who serves as Republican whip, said that on Tuesday the group intended to attach the package to a Resolution Trust Corporation financing bill.
Since most of these proposals have been made previously, news of the Republican initiative did not have a terribly deleterious effect in the credit markets.
 
Some Urge No Action
 However, some analysts said that at this juncture, policy makers would best serve the economy by doing nothing.
"I am not sure there is anything in particular that can be done by anybody that would have a material impact on the 1992 economy," said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon National Bank in Pittsburgh. "The Fed can't do much more by lowering short-term interest rates. And any fiscal package passed in the first half of the year would not take effect until much later. The options are very limited."
In late trading yesterday, the Treasury's 8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 100 9/ 32, down 2/32, to yield 7.97 percent, unchanged from late Thursday, but up from 7.81 percent on Nov. 15.
Among Treasury note issues, the 7.50 percent 10-year notes were offered at 100 15/32 late yesterday, down 1/4 point, to yield 7.42 percent. And the 6 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 31/32, unchanged from late Thursday, to yield 5.46 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were little changed.
Three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 4.41 percent late yesterday, down one basis point, or one one-hundredth of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates were unchanged, at a late offered rate of 4.49 percent.
 
Corporate Market
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, U.S. Leasing International offered $200 million of 10-year, noncallable notes through an underwriting group led by Lehman Brothers.
The 8.75 percent notes were priced at $99.149 to yield 8.88 percent, 1.45 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7.50 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate securities was slow, traders said. Prices of most issues dipped by 1/8 point to 1/4 point.
After a hectic week of new issues, participants in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds said that activity trailed off yesterday. Prices of most widely quoted issues were essentially unchanged, traders said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: Stocks Slip As the Dow Loses 29.96

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
Stocks were hit with another stiff wave of selling yesterday, ending a week in which the market suffered the reverberations of last Friday's 120-point plunge in the Dow Jones industrial average.
The Dow dropped 29.96 points, to 2,902.73. For the week, the Dow lost 40.47 points. Big Board volume yesterday came to 188.3 million shares, down from 196.2 million Thursday. Losing issues outpaced gainers, 1,149 to 507. 
 The weaknesses was across the board, with the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks losing 3.92, to 376.14; the Big Board composite index dropping 2.05, to 208.16; the American Stock Exchange index off 2.77, to 373.28, and the Nasdaq compsite index losing 3.87, to 526.46.
The selling began as soon as the market opened, with the Dow dropping as much as 42.94 points in early trading, fueled by several large computerized program trades.
Some traders said the selling stemmed from concern about the apparent lack of direction of economic policy in the Bush Administration and Congress.
"Today was Bush-bashing day," said Jeffrey Tabak, a principal at Miller Tabak Hirsch. "The Adminstration apparently being in total disarray is the overwhelming factor here."
Analysts said the markets lacked confidence in what Washington was proposing as ways to revive the economy, plans that include a cap on credit card interest rates and tax cuts. They said the continued sluggishness of the economy could increase the pressure on the Administration to develop new economic policies, but none appear to have been formulated. The result, traders fear, will be poorly planned policies, or none at all.
"There is increasing disillusionment with the White House and Congress over the Government's inability to address what is becoming a meaningful economic malaise," said Alan Ackerman, an executive vice president with Reich & Company.
Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer of the First Albany Corporation, said that the market failed to respond even to good news, including strong growth in the money supply figures released Thursday night.
"The confidence, whether it is in Congress or the Bush Administration, seems to be reaching a very low level," he said.
Traders also said the market closed with signs that the troubles might continue Monday. Mr. Tabak of Miller Tabak Hirsch said the Standard & Poor's 500 futures contracts, which are used in program trading, closed at a discount to the underlying stocks. "That does not portend well for Monday morning," he said.
Birinyi Associates, which tracks program trading, said that the net effect of five computerized sell orders and two buy orders yesterday pushed the market down a total of 12 points.
Among the biggest declines was ARCO, which dropped 3 3/4, to 106 5/8. Standard & Poor's said it was downgrading the company's commercial paper rating because increased debt had reduced the company's liquidity.
Another oil company, Chevron Inc., was also among the day's net losers, dropping 2, to 67 1/2, after Dillon, Read & Company reduced its earnings estimate.
The Newell Company dropped 2, to 39 3/8. The industrial products maker announced it was buying the Sanford Corporation in a stock deal that will result in the issuance of 15 million new shares.
The day's biggest gainer was McDonnell Douglas, which rose 1 7/8, to 72 3/4. A Paine Webber analyst, Jack Modzelewski, upgraded his opinion of the company, saying the company's plan to sell 40 percent of its commercial airline business to the Taiwan Aerospace Corporation would be successful.
Consolidated Freightways rose 1 1/2, to 14 1/4, on news that a subsidiary had reached an agreement to provide transportation services to a division of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

HEADLINE: Court Ruling Gives Lift to Lenders

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 22

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court has bolstered the rights of lenders in bankruptcy cases by preventing delinquent borrowers from adopting the increasingly common tactic of keeping control of indebted properties by investing new money into them.
Lawyers said the ruling by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit was likely to reduce the potential losses that banks, insurance companies and other big lenders might suffer from thousands of real estate bankruptcy cases now in litigation. 
 "Bankers have told me that over a five-year period, this ruling could reduce the cost of borrowed money," said Hugh Ray, a bankruptcy lawyer in Houston who has represented several banks in bankruptcy cases. He said that rising loan losses were one factor that had prevented banks' interest rates on loans from falling further than they have.
The ruling by the appellate panel in New Orleans, issued on Tuesday, was the first Federal court review of the practice among debtors in bankruptcy proceedings of winning court approval to retain a troubled property by agreeing to invest more capital in it.
Lawyers for Greystone III Joint Venture, the developer of an office building in Austin, Tex., said they would appeal the ruling to the full 15-judge appellate court in New Orleans.
In an opinion written by Judge Edith H. Jones, the panel rejected a reorganization plan approved by lower courts for Greystone.
Greystone had borrowed $8.8 million from the Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford to buy the building. Greystone sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1989 to prevent foreclosure by Phoenix Mutual. Greystone's debts to Phoenix amounted to $9.3 million, including the original loan plus other fees.
 
Creditors Were Split
 Greystone also owed $10,000 to various trade creditors and to tenants that had provided security deposits. It won approval for a bankruptcy reorganization plan by splitting the creditors into two groups.
The firm promised to invest $500,000 in the project and make full payment to the trade creditors. But Phoenix Mutual, which wanted to take control of the project, would have had a paper loss of approximately $4 million.
The smaller class of creditors approved the plan, a requirement for Greystone to execute a "cram-down" reorganization. Some courts have ruled since Congress passed the 1978 Bankruptcy Act that debtors could have a reorganization approved if one class of creditors backed the plan.
The appeals panel said the Greystone plan ignored the law by classifying the creditor claims differently "to gerrymander an affirmative vote in a reorganization." The opinion also emphasized that the 1978 law gave senior creditors more power than junior creditors in determining a debtor's rights to property.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Aetna Life's President Gets Chairman's Post

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
The Aetna Life and Casualty Company announced yesterday that Ronald E. Compton would succeed James T. Lynn as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Lynn retires on March 1 at age 65.
Mr. Compton, who is 58 years old, will keep his title as president of Aetna Life, the nation's largest publicly traded insurance and financial services company, which reports assets of $91 billion. 
 Mr. Compton said he was not worried about taking over at a time when the recession has created problems in Aetna's real estate portfolio. The company told the Securities and Exchange Commission last week that it expected $1.27 billion of its real estate portfolio, or about 5 percent, to run into problems next year.
Although "prices are soft" in several of Aetna's businesses, Mr. Compton said, "You can't be successful only when the sun shines."
Mr. Compton recalled that he was a senior executive with Aetna's American Re-Insurance unit "at the depth of the casualty insurance cycle" in the early 1980's, but that he was still there, as president, to enjoy the rebound. "Maybe the economy will come banging back by next March," he said yesterday.
Mr. Compton, whose grandfather was a coal miner in Higbee, Mo., helped pay his college expenses at Northwestern University by living at home in Evanston, Ill., and taking wedding photographs. After graduating, he joined Aetna as a property casualty underwriter in 1954. According to Aetna's 1991 proxy statement, Mr. Compton's cash compensation as president was $737,885 last year; Mr. Lynn received $1,066,539 as chairman.
Mr. Compton became a senior vice president with Aetna in 1987, serving as an executive assistant and then executive vice president in the office of the chairman. He was appointed president and a director in 1988.
As chief executive, Mr. Compton said he planned to continue moves he started with Mr. Lynn to "turn Aetna into a multi-niche business." He said that Aetna would try to build up profitable units, like the Ailac mutual funds company, but that it had stopped selling personal automobile insurance where it considers business conditions unacceptable, in 28 states and the District of Columbia.
Aetna expects to stay in automobile insurance in New York and Connecticut, he said, but it will pull out of some other states. Analysts said New Jersey, where a number of insurers have said they are losing money, might be one such state.
Mr. Compton said his agenda also included plans "to continue flattening the management structure" as well as to develop employees' skills in Aetna's management-training program.
A photography buff, Mr. Compton develops his own black-and-white prints and will have a one-man show of his pictures of ballet dancers opening on Jan. 9 at the Bushnell, the Hartford performance center.
Mr. Compton, who lives in Connecticut, is also a Wagnerian opera fan and is on the boards of Carnegie Hall and the Connecticut Opera, and is chairman of Bushnell's capital fund drive. He and his wife, Nancy, like to relax on their 41-foot sailboat. They have three grown children: Erika, Barbara and Craig.

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

ANATOMY OF A RECESSION
Businesses in the New York region that are waiting for a national recovery to lift them out of their doldrums are looking in the wrong direction, several economists say. The downturn, they say, has less to do with the nationwide slump than with the wrenching changes being forced on many of the industries for which the city is a center. Banks, broadcasters, firms that specialize in accounting, law, public relations and advertising -- although these industries have already shed thousands of jobs, they may have still further to go. Page 1.
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
ABORTION DOCTOR WENT UNPUNISHED
State health officials said that they were aware of misconduct accusations against Dr. Abu Hayat for more than two years -- including a report that he botched an abortion, leading to a young woman's death -- but took no action against him because they did not believe they could prove he posed an "imminent danger" to public health. Page 27.
 
STATE PROBLEMS, CITY PROBLEMS
New York State's growing budget gaps will deepen New York City's fiscal problems, forcing it to cut spending even more, the Dinkins administration warned. The warning came as the administration ordered all city agencies to draft four-year targets for cutting the work force and improving productivity. The city Budget Director said the budget gap for the next fiscal year would be even greater than the $1.2 billion forecast just two weeks ago. Page 27.
 
NEW RULES FOR ROAD CONTRACTS
Acknowledging that New York City's oversight of its vast program for street reconstruction is flawed, transportation officials say they have begun making changes to insure that contractors do what they are being paid for. The changes come amid revelations that the city's Transportation Department failed to act after being told that contractors used faulty concrete and violated safety rules on three major projects. Page 27.
 
REGION
 
A FAILED SUIT, A $60,000 BILL
Saying that the Constitution had been debased and the court system had been ridiculed by their lawsuit, a Federal judge ordered a Westchester County couple to pay the $60,000 legal fees of the school system they sued because their son was not admitted to the honor society. Page 28.
 
THE C.I.A. IN THE GROVES OF ACADEME
After months of disclosures about a hidden relationship with the Central Intelligence Agency, the Rochester Institute of Technology is trying to decide whether there is room for secret intelligence research on a college campus. The debate, which began when the school's president acknowledged he had secretly worked for the C.I.A., will be taken up by the trustees today. What they decide may influence how other universities respond to the criticism that research for clandestine groups is inconsistent with academic values of open expression. Page 28.
 
TOP FLORIO AIDE TO RESIGN
After weeks of denying that it would happen, Governor Florio announced that Douglas C. Berman, his former campaign manager and a leading architect of his $2.8 billion tax increase, would resign as state treasurer. Page 28.
The Cuomo-Wachtler legal battle is back in state court. Page 28.

HEADLINE: Park Service Backs Demolition on Ellis Island

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY

 BODY:
After fighting for years to save all 32 historic buildings on Ellis Island, the National Park Service has endorsed a plan to demolish 12 small, crumbling structures to provide room for a $140 million conference center with 325 hotel rooms, a restaurant and shops.
Federal officials say the buildings, abandoned and decaying since 1954, have less historic and architectural significance than any others on the island and that demolition is the only financially viable way to build the new conference center and hotel and to guarantee the rehabilitation and preservation of other derelict buildings on the southern half of the 25-acre island. 
 Others, however, including historic preservation officers in New York and New Jersey, take a dim view of the demolition plans.
Michael Adlerstein, regional chief of urban projects for the National Park Service, said: "Either we get nine-tenths of the pie or we get no pie at all. We feel we have arrived at a reasonable plan that preserves as many of the buildings as is economically possible."
 
Buildings in National Registry
 The 12 buildings, all listed on the National Registry of Historic Places, are tucked in the island's southwestern corner, which is overgrown with brush. They include an immigrant-processing building and a recreation hall built during the Depression, after immigration had slowed to a trickle. Other buildings include a furnace room, laundry, morgue, crematory and five contagious-disease wards, where ailing immigrants were quarantined.
Only a small percentage of the 12 million immigrants who passed through Ellis Island from 1892 to 1924 used these particular buildings. Nonetheless, historic preservation officers in New York and New Jersey have considerable doubts about the demolition program. Both states are entitled to comment on the proposal under the National Historic Preservation Act.
New York's preservation officer, Orin Lehman, called the project an "inappropriate use" of Ellis and refused to endorse it in a letter to the Park Service.
"This demolition, the commercialization of the island and the restriction of large areas for exclusive private use are not consistent with the national significance of this resource, and, indeed, its very reason for recognition as a national monument," Mr. Lehman said.
New Jersey's Office of Historic Preservation has appealed to the Park Service to fully explore what it called a "no-build option" and concentrate on stabilizing and rehabilitating all 30 of the buildings that are still empty and decaying. Two structures have previously been rehabilitated.
New Jersey based its appeal on the "remarkable public interest" in Ellis Island since the Museum of Immigration opened in September 1990 after a $156 million restoration. About 3 million people have visited the museum since then.
 
New Jersey Reaction
 James F. Hall, New Jersey's deputy historic preservation officer, urged the Park Service "to insure that the amount of demolition is held to an absolute minimum."
The Park Service has scheduled a public hearing on the plan on Dec. 17 on Ellis Island.
Mr. Adlerstein, of the Park Service, argued that the plan retains the facades of the buildings that were seen and used by the great bulk of immigrants when they arrived. "The Ellis Island immigration story has already been preserved in the new museum," he said.
The Park Service's willingness to accept demolition of the 12 buildings reflects a compromise between the service and a New York developer, William Hubbard, director of the Center for Housing Partnerships, which specializes in rehabilitating older housing. The service selected Mr. Hubbarb in 1984 to lease the southern half of the island and create a conference center.
Until recently, the Park Service had insisted that all the island's abandoned buildings be rehabilitated to house the center and the hotel rooms. But for eight years Mr. Hubbard has been unable to obtain financing for the project.
In the last six months, Mr. Adlerstein said, Mr. Hubbard obtained a partner, International Conferencing Resorts of America, which was willing to finance the center if the Park Service relented in its demand to save all the buildings.
"This is the best of the options," Mr. Adlerstein said, explaining that rehabilitating old buildings generally costs about $450 a square foot, compared with $150 a square foot for new construction.
The structures earmarked for demolition make up about 10 percent of the 698,000 square feet of building space on the island, he said. Under the current plan, buildings containing 383,000 square feet would be rehabilitated.
The building for the new center would total 375,000 square feet, and be no taller than existing buildings. It would have the same French Renaissance design and limestone and brick exterior as the main museum and other structures.
The center would house conference suites, 250 hotel rooms, an auditorium, a banquet hall and ballroom, a pool and a restaurant open to the public. An additional 75 hotel rooms and conference suites are to be built in rehabilitated turn-of-the-century hospital buildings. Shops and a youth hostel would be built in what was once an immigrant dormitory.
The Park Service's share of gross revenues will depend on the size of the center approved after public hearings.

HEADLINE: Sanctions Said to Fuel Haitian Exodus by Sea

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Local and international relief workers here say that the international embargo imposed on Haiti has increased the pain of poverty in ways that are likely to lead thousands more people to set out for the United States regardless of the perils of the sea journey or the chance that they will be picked up and sent home.
In recent days, international relief organizations said that in parts of the countryside, peasants have been forced to forage for wild plants because regular food supplies have virtually disappeared. 
 "People are not starving yet, but they are starting to eat roots and things that animals usually eat," said Virginia Ubik, the local director of Project Care.
 
Using Stockpiled Supplies
 Ms. Ubik said that in the northern city of Gonaives, a region that has produced many of the boat people in the past, her organization was feeding as many 8,000 people a day from supplies that were stockpiled here before the coup that overthrew Haiti's elected President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, on Sept. 30.
With diplomats estimating that as much as a third of the capital's population of 1.2 million had fled to the countryside, Ms. Ubik said that many rural homes now housed 15 or more people living on the same amount of food that four or five ate before the crisis.
At the Bon Repos repatriation camp several miles to the north of the capital, one of the country's only refugee centers, relief workers said they were still overwhelmed from a previous flood of Haitians who were expelled earlier this year from the Dominican Republic.
"There is no possible way for us to handle more people here," said Sister Maureen Fuelkell, director of the center. Since the coup, she said, her camp had only managed to feed and care for the 1,548 people it currently houses through the donations of a handful of international charities.
More than 17,000 Haitians expelled from the Dominican Republic have passed through the camp since June, Sister Fuelkell said.
In a statement broadcast over the Voice of America today, Father Aristide urged Haitians contemplating an attempt to reach Florida to "stay at home rather than ending up in the jaws of sharks."
But like others, Sister Fuelkell said she expected the tide of Haitian refugees to increase dramatically in the coming weeks unless the political situation was stabilized and relief operations could be set up in the countryside, where most of the people fleeing the country have come from.
The international embargo has stopped the sale of gasoline, which in turn has virtually stopped public transport here and blocked deliveries of goods. Moreover, businesses continue to lay off office workers, swelling the already large numbers of poor people.
 
'Afraid to Stay'
 "You could have a million people trying to leave Haiti unless something is done soon," said Sister Fuelkell. "Most of the people in the countryside are trying to get out for economic reasons of course. But there has been a lot of repression too. Many have gone because they were too afraid to stay."
In the normally congested capital, Port-au-Prince, the streets are now empty most of the day, except for brief bursts of activity in the morning and late afternoon.
Since gas stations shut down for lack of fuel last week, there have been no buses, and those with private cars husband their gasoline for emergencies. Electrical generation in the capital has also become more erratic, and diplomats say that a lack of oil might force a total blackout and interruption of telephone service within two weeks.
At the downtown offices of the Haitian Red Cross, which has been the agency charged with receiving returning Haitians since a repatriation agreement was signed with the United States 10 years ago, officials said they did not have the wherewithal to do anything more than simply distribute $10 apiece to the 510 boat people dropped off here earlier this week by the Coast Guard.
"I have no gasoline for my own car," said the director, Dr. William Fougere. "We have no food to give them. We don't even have fuel for our generators to operate our blood banks."
Asked if he had been able to assess whether the returned Haitians had faced any persecution by soldiers or the police, Dr. Fougere said: "I have no idea. We cannot even reach the suburbs."
Despite the markedly increased hardships it has brought, here in the capital, support for the embargo, which was imposed to help return Father Aristide to power, remains strong among many Haitians.
Sitting under the tin awning of a barren shop in one of this city's poorest neighborhoods, a clutch of young Haitian men urged foreign nations to maintain the embargo as a means of punishing the army, even as some of them contemplated fleeing the country, in part because of the difficulties it has brought.
"Here in Cite Soleil, there are arrests every day by the army, there are shootings and there are disappearances," said Joel, a 26-year-old unemployed man. "An embargo is the only weapon we have."
Although Joel pledged to stay in the country and "resist until the final victory" over the army and provisional Government that replaced Father Aristide, several of his friends said they were awaiting the first opportunity to get out of the country.
"We are all interested in leaving," said Harold, a 19-year-old. "There is so much misery here. We are all prisoners."
 
 
 
246 FLEEING HAITI ARE RESCUED
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Coast Guard picked up 246 Haitian refugees packed into a 30-foot sailboat in the Windward Passage between Haiti and Cuba today. It was the largest single group of fleeing Haitians to be intercepted since the Sept. 30 military coup that overthrew the Government of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
"I just can't imagine how they got that many people on that boat," a Coast Guard official said in Miami.
The Coast Guard said the rescue brought the total number of Haitians intercepted at sea in the last few weeks to 3,138.
As news of the rescue reached Miami, there were also reports of a rising confirmed death toll in a shipwreck of Haitian refugees on Tuesday in stormy weather off Cuba. Cuban radio reported today that 59 more bodies had been found.
On Wednesday and Thursday, 16 bodies washed ashore near Cape Maisi, Cuba's easternmost point. An additional 60 people are missing and presumed dead, which would bring the overall count to 135.
Since a Federal court in Miami ruled Tuesday that no more Haitians should be forcibly returned to the island pending a hearing on Nov. 27, the refugees are being held at the United States Navy base at Guantanamo, Cuba, on Coast Guard cutters at sea or in temporary centers in Honduras and Venezuela.Today 100 more Haitians were flown to Venezuela, bringing the total in the two countries to about 450.
An American official said today that about 100 Haitians had been given the right to apply for asylum in the United States, and would be allowed to come to Miami.

HEADLINE: Congressional Roundup;
Two Financing Bills Stall Lawmakers

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Congress moved toward clearing a few of its pre-adjournment problems today, but made no visible progress on two of the toughest: financing for the savings and loan bailout and for the nearly insolvent bank insurance fund.
House and Senate conferees on the transportation bill believed they had settled their biggest dispute, how to allocate money among the states, and there was steady progress on appropriations bills. But conferees on crime legislation held only informal meetings, and no progress was made on settling disputes over trade provisions or the extended unemployment benefits measure. 
 No floor action is expected before next week on financing the Resolution Trust Corporation, which handles the savings and loans bailout. Banking legislation, passed by both houses in very different forms, appears too complicated a problem even to be sent to a conference committee until Congressional leaders and the Administration devise a plan they think can be passed in the House, which killed two earlier versions of the bill.
 
Transportation
 Early today, House and Senate conferees on the transportation bill reached a tentative agreement on the fundamental issue that has divided them: how to share $151 billion among the states over six years.
Lawmakers from both chambers appeared confident today, for the first time, that they would work out a bill before their planned adjournment for Thanksgiving.
The apportionment formula, designed to satisfy the conflicting demands of crucial state delegations in each house, is so complex that members and aides said they could not fully explain it today. Aides were meeting tonight to refine the formula and calculate how much money it would allot to each state. The lawmakers will meet Saturday morning to see if the results satisfy them.
Once they agree, Congressional aides said, it should be easy to adopt the Senate's overall structure for the bill. That would give great discretion to state and local governments in choosing how to spend the money.
 
Medicaid
 The Senate moved toward joining the House in an effort to upset Administration efforts to restrict the ability of states to help finance Medicaid, the health program for 27 million low-income Americans, with money collected from hospitals. The Senate Finance Committee approved legislation that would delay enforcement of the Administration rules until April 1.
Earlier this week the White House and the National Governors Association negotiated a tentative agreement on the issue, but Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, and other Senators said today that the agreement needed further refinement.
The House has voted, 348 to 71, to block the rules until next Sept. 30.
Representative Henry A. Waxman, the California Democrat who is chairman of the Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Health, objects to the agreement negotiated between the White House and the governors because it would impose numerical limits on the proportion of Medicaid that could be paid for by state taxes on hospitals and nursing homes.
 
Spending
 The House passed, by a vote of 364 to 58, and sent to the Senate a $205 billion spending bill for labor, health and education programs. The legislation provides money for everything from cancer research to Federal aid to poor school districts.
The measure was almost identical to the bill vetoed by President Bush earlier this week. But the exception was crucial. This version does not prohibit the Administration from enforcing regulations that bar federally financed family planning clinics from discussing abortion with pregnant patients. Mr. Bush cited that provision as the reason for his veto, which opponents failed to override on Tuesday.
The Senate approved a $9.5 billion emergency spending bill that includes money for the remaining costs of the Persian Gulf war, for the Federal Emergency Management Agency and for children's aid programs. The largest amount, more than $3.8 billion, is for expenses related to the war.
The measure, which passed by a vote of 75 to 17, is similar to a bill that passed the House last month. The Senate defied a White House veto threat by adding an amendment allowing women in the military to have abortions on overseas bases.
 
Pentagon Programs
 The Senate completed Congressional action on a $291 billion Pentagon program bill. The measure would all but eliminate future construction of B-2 Stealth bombers but would continue spending for an anti-missile defense system.
Opposition to the anti-missile system produced most of the 15 votes against the bill. Seventy-nine Senators voted for the bill, and it was sent to the President for his signature.

 
INQUIRY ON HOSTAGE DEAL
 WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Senate Republicans tonight blocked money for an inquiry into allegations that the 1980 Reagan-Bush campaign made a deal with Iran to delay release of American hostages until after the election.
On a largely party line vote of 51 to 43, Democrats failed to get the 60 votes needed to shut off a Republican filibuster against the measure, which would have set aside $600,000 for the inquiry. As a result, the investigation will be sharply curtailed if not killed. A separate House inquiry is proceeding.
Since the 1980 election, rumors have persisted that the Republicans conspired with Iran head off an "October Surprise" that would free the 52 American hostages and salvage Jimmy Carter's re-election chances.

HEADLINE: Boston War Zone Becomes Public Housing Dream

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Only five years ago, Ruby Jaundoo lived in one of the country's most dilapidated and dangerous public housing projects. Likened by city residents to a war zone, the Columbia Point apartments sat secluded on a peninsula jutting into Boston Harbor; even ambulance crews and firefighters would not come to the neighborhood without a police escort.
"Nobody wanted to come out here," Ms. Jaundoo said. "The police wouldn't patrol. The gangs were infesting our housing. I was fearful and I'd had enough." 
 Ms. Jaundoo and the other women who dominated Columbia Point's tenants' board began negotiating in the late 1970's with developers who coveted the project's 51 acres, a strip of waterfront property that shares views of the harbor with the nearby John F. Kennedy Library.
 
Fears of Being Driven Out
 "We knew this land was becoming prime property and we were an eyesore," said Ms. Jaundoo. "We were afraid that we would be driven out."
Today the site, renamed Harbor Point to shed bad memories, is a sprawl of manicured lawns surrounding tennis courts, town houses and mid-rise apartment buildings where residents, including Ms. Jaundoo and most of her original neighbors, represent a broad range of races, ethnic backgrounds and incomes.
While mixed-income developments have been successful on a smaller scale, Harbor Point is the nation's first effort to transform a large Federal project by recruiting middle- and higher-income residents, government officials say. State and local authorities are hoping Harbor Point will be a model for economic and racial integration of public housing elsewhere.
But the transition has not been painless. Fractious tenant disputes are only now easing, and a surprise investment from the Chevron Oil Company in August rescued Harbor Point from the brink of bankruptcy.
When Catherine D'Vileskis moved into Harbor Point three years ago, the first white person on her block, she was greeted by a young Hispanic boy who pointed at her and said, "It's a whitey!" Now "that family has been my neighbors for years," she said, adding, "The shock is gone."
But feelings of mistrust still linger among tenants. Harbor Point had been home to black and Hispanic low-income Bostonians since it first opened in 1954. The imposing yellow brick buildings, 30 seven-story structures built to house 1,504 impoverished families families, were a source of great pride in Boston. Yet by the 1970's, the buildings had fallen victim to neglect and blight, and were abandoned by all but 356 families.
Conceding failure, the Boston Housing Authority turned over the site to private developers in 1986 with the ambitious goal of renovating the neighborhood without driving out low-income residents. The 99-year lease names two owners: the tenants' elected board and a partnership of developers led by the firm of Corcoran, Mullins, Jennison of Braintree, Mass.
The development now has 1,283 units, some refurbished and others built new. The lease requires that 400 of them be set aside for residents who receive rent subsidies, while the rest command market rates. A two-bedroom apartment now goes for $825 a month.
To attract wealthier tenants, the developers advertised the site's proximity to downtown Boston and amenities in the development, including a fitness club, two swimming pools and a child-care center. The developers also hired a 24-hour security force to help ease fears about crime.
Nearly all the low-income units are now occupied, but 26 families who lived in Columbia Point before the arrival of the private developers have since left, many evicted for drug dealing, nonpayment of rent or vandalism.
"There was a bad element and there still is," said Joe Corcoran, who heads the development firm. "We have rooted out 25 families that were really bad, but there are five more to go."
Fears that the developers are trying to rid the site of all low-income residents have emerged among tenants who complain of harassment by the 25-member security force. Many longtime residents have chafed at strict rules enacted by the tenant board. Residents are asked to move along if they loiter on streets at night. Young children must be inside by 7:30 P.M. in the school year, and teen-agers by 10:30. No pets are allowed and the management checks apartments to enforce housekeeping rules.
Ms. Jaundoo acknowledged that some security guards had been dismissed for mistreating residents, but said: "People have to pay their rent on time, take care of their children and respect other people's rights. Those rules are true at any housing project, but we enforce them."
Many residents describe the 12-member tenants' board, a mix of low-income and wealthier residents who hold quarterly open meetings to air disputes, as the glue that holds the community together. "The security force is only acting on what the tenants themselves have enacted," said Onjada Haggard, a resident.
To help blur the color line between low- and higher-income residents, an aggressive marketing effort has attracted black, Asian and Hispanic professionals and a small number of white low-income renters. Many of the market-rate renters are young professionals who work nearby in Boston's financial district.
Maureen Coleman, a manager at Scudder, Stevens & Clark, a mutual fund company in Boston, moved to Harbor Point in 1988. "I like it here," she said. "It's clean and it feels safe. But if you grew up in a neighborhood where everyone looks just like you, this isn't the place for you."
Despite improvements in tenant relations, Harbor Point was still struggling until recently to stay afloat financially. Boston's rental real estate market began to plummet soon after Harbor Point opened in 1988. Trying to attract affluent renters as the recession deepened, the developers slashed rents by 35 percent. Deficits and costly loans finally pushed Harbor Point close to bankruptcy this summer.
Help arrived in August, when Chevron announced it would invest $34 million over seven years to take advantage of $38 million in low-income housing tax credits and depreciation. The credits were established by Congress in 1986 to encourage private investment in low-income housing.
 
Rescue of Harbor Point
 The deal saved Harbor Point from defaulting on some of its $175 million in state and Federal loans. Mr. Corcoran said he believed the cash infusion would cover any future deficits.
At Chevron, company officials are quick to reassure shareholders that they are not operating out of pure altruism. "Our primary objective is to generate income for the company," said Nancy Carroll, a spokeswoman. "But the fact that it's a social investment doesn't hurt."
